mechanisms: Action Point Allowance SystemArea MovementDice RollingModular BoardPick-up and Deliver
description:
In Search for Poseidon's Gold, up to four players engage in an ocean battle to see which player can collect the most gold and win the competition!  A reconfigurable board gives this game high replay value.  Control your submarine fleet and divers to collect the treasure while using torpedoes to thwart enemy submarines.  Kraken and Sea Serpents patrol the depths in an effort to ruin your plans for victory.  Win by being the last Captain standing or by collecting the most treasure.  Ages 10 and up, takes about an hour.

Publisher's Website
(edit- Website no longer active)

title: Takeover: The Stock Market Game
mechanisms: Auction/BiddingBetting/WageringHand ManagementRoll / Spin and MoveSet CollectionStock Holding
description:
Takeover is a stock game with simulations of standard market mechanics and an additional twist of hostile takeovers. Players must build up their financial portfolio by risking money on long or short selling, playing the variations in the market, using margins and generally speculating. Players roll and move around a Monopoly-type board, with landing spaces and card draws giving various options. The board features an outer track where stocks can generally be purchased, and an inner criss-cross track where gambles and takeovers predominate. Purchasing of stock is unlike standard Monopoly exclusivity: when landing on a square, the active player may purchase up to 40% of available stock, and then all other players may also purchase stock. Disclosure rules generally limit ownership levels except for takeover situations. Typical brokerage mechanisms such as longs, shorts, margin calls, warrants, Futures, dividends, etc. are incorporated into the game.

The game comes with three difficulty levels, with the goal of the full-difficulty-version involving acquisition of shares in every company in one of the four market groups and absolute majority of one of the companies in that group.

This game was endorsed by the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Racing Challenge
description: A collectable card game (CCG) of NASCAR Auto Racing.  Players assume the role of a driver and race around a track made up of track cards using a Car, Equipment/Skill cards, and Gas.

title: Warhammer Quest: Lair of the Orc Lord
types: Adventure Expansion for Base-game Exploration Fantasy Fighting Miniatures
description:
From the back of the box:

The Black Fang Orcs of Mount Gunbad are ruled over by the tyrannical Warboss Gorgut.  Surrounded by his brutal Big'uns, entertained by Gubbinz the goblin jester, Gorgut holds court, counting the skulls of the warriors who have dared enter his bleak domain.

This Adventure Pack can be used to add an extra Orcy flavor to your games of Warhammer Quest.  The rulebook contains background; six new adventures to complement the new Gorgut's Lair Objective room; new treasure, magic items and Monster Tables; and a Warhammer Quest Roleplay adventure for Warriors of battle-level 2-3.

Contents:

1 Rulebook

3 Floorplans

     1 Shaman's Den
     1 Gorgut's Lair
     1 Collapsed Passage




36 Playing Cards

     3 Dungeon cards
     21 Event cards
     8 Treasure cards
     4 Special cards




6 Counters

     1 Fallen Block counter
     3 Netted counters
     2 Pit of Despair counters




Citadel miniatures

     1 Gorgut the Orc Warboss
     1 Skabnoze the Orc Shaman
     3 Orc Big'Uns
     1 Gubbinz the Goblin Jester
     1 Bogoff the Snotling
     1 Growler the Squig Hound
     2 Plastic Doorways




Expands:

     Warhammer Quest




Microbadges

 Warhammer Quest - Kill Krazy Total Brew

title: Minion Nation
types: Adventure Expansion for Base-game Horror Science Fiction
description:
This is the expansion kit for the Minion Hunter game by GDW.  The following text is from the expansion kit itself.

If you've played Minion Hunter, this kit will provide you with options and background to make your play more satisfying than ever.

If you've never played Minion Hunter...you're missing out on a good time.

Included in this package are:

- New rules options, for grimmer, yet more cooperative games.
- Expanded encounter tables, for further variety in play - including a table of random Plot Card results!
- 16 new Equipment Cards, including Empathy-enhancing items, a second Wildey Wolf (for two-fisted shooting!), and even minion equipment you can capture at Dark Encounters!
- Designer Notes, with topic-by-topic, space-by-space, encounter-by-encounter comments to further flesh out your understanding of Minion Hunter and its treatment of the Dark Conspiracy horror RPG world.

A new Dark Age has come. Never has the world been so grim...nor the battle so heroic!

Expands:

    Minion Hunter

title: Chainstore
description:
The Highstreet Battle of Takeovers and Mergers

One of the Monopoly-inspired family of games. Players purchase chains of high street shops and London department stores, furnish them with stock and charge their opponents as customers.

Later in the game, players may pair up and pool their assets to become mergers. Players drop out as they become bankrupt until only one player or merger remains.

title: Warhammer Quest: Catacombs of Terror
types: Adventure Expansion for Base-game Exploration Fantasy Fighting Miniatures
mechanisms: Dice RollingModular BoardRole PlayingVariable Player Powers
description:
From the back of the box:

In the sun scorched wastes of the Land of the Dead, the Dread King waits within the darkness of his pyramid tomb.  Gunther Laranscheld, evil Necromancer, seeks to restore the Dread King to power, and only the heroic Warriors can stop him.  If they succeed, they will return with the treasures of this long dead realm.  If they fail, they will surely die...

This Warhammer Quest Adventure Pack contains six new adventures for use with the floor plans in this pack; lots of new tables for Undead Monsters, hazards, events and treasure; plus an exciting pre-written adventure for Warriors of battle-level 5-7.

Contents:

1 Rulebook

4 Floorplans

     1 Dread King's Throne Room
     1 Hall of Death
     1 Chasm of Despair
     1 Flames of Khazia




36 Playing Cards

     4 Dungeon cards
     18 Event cards
     11 Treasure cards
     3 Special cards




(note that the official rulebook is incorrect as it states there are 12 Treasure cards and 17 Event cards)

6 Catacombs counters

Citadel Miniatures

     1 Dread King on his throne
     1 Gunther Laranscheld
     1 Luthor the Hunchback
     3 Tomb Guardians
     1 The Grimoire Necris
     2 plastic Doorways




Expands:

     Warhammer Quest




Microbadges

 Warhammer Quest: Catacombs of Terror

title: War of Masters
description:
Simple Chess-style game played on a 9x9 board and using a single die. Each side has nine short cylinders, eight large cylinders and one master large cylinder.

The object of the game is to capture your opponents MASTER.(That is a wooden token). You do this by rolling the dice and move your counters the given numbers of squares according to the movement rules.  Players take turns to roll the die and move one piece the number of squares shown, or a six may be used to move two pieces a total of six squares.  The small counters move and capture in only one direction - straight ahead. Whenever a small counter reaches its opponent's back row, it is exchanged for a large one. The large counters, including the MASTER, move and capture in any direction.

title: ITC
mechanisms: Action Point Allowance SystemHand ManagementPick-up and DeliverStock HoldingTrading
description:
In ITC, the players attempt to gain profit by various activities. On the one hand they transport different goods into the markets of the six continents, and on the other hand they sell those goods in the continents. Gray imports also rake in additional Euros.

Players choose the types of action they take by selecting 2 of the three dice. One of the dice rolled will be used and this indicates the number of action points allowed in the area that the dice allows.

Players transport various goods to different markets using cards and wooden markers. They earn money for the transportation process and later for selling in the different markets.

The object is to accumulate 200,000 Euros.

title: Wheel of Intoxication
description: This is a drinking game which involves stunts and dares. A game for the adventurous. It will get very loud playing this game.  Six well known drinking games are built into the game including Fuzzy Duck, A**hole, Thumbmaster, and Suck and Blow.

title: Factories
description:
In Factories the object is to collect at least one of each of the ten resources. This is done by creating factories with the cards drawn. A factory consists of one output card, and any number of equation cards. By paying the costs in the equation cards, in order, you produce whatever the output card indicates.

This alone would be a little like solitaire, so enter the challenge you can make once per turn. Challenge anyone for up to three resources, and then each bid a secret amount more. Whoever has more wins everything, unless they overbid by more than three in which case the lower bid wins! This allows for player interaction, although not a high degree of such.

title: Fimbulvetr: Winter of Winters
types: Abstract Strategy Fantasy Fighting Medieval Print & Play Wargame
description: A chess-like abstract strategy game with a Norse theme wherein pieces attack each other diagonally by matching symbols on their corners. The two included armies differ slightly in their abilities, and suggestions are included for creating your own armies using the black backs of the pieces.

title: What's Up, Doc?
description: You're suffering from some strange sickness and rush to the hospital to see the doc; only to find other patients also trying to get to him, too. You make your way through the hospital (roll and move, with some path choices) heading for the doc's office on the top floor. On your way, try to guess the other players' sickness (deduction) and send them back to the entrance. Be the first to get to the doc and you win. - The strategy consists of keeping track of what other players already know about you, so that you can choose the best path thru the hospital corridors. Kids love the humorous disease names such as Glumps, Running Nose, Kung-Flu, and Stinkfoot. Instead of paper and pencil bookeeping like 'Clue', 'What's Up Doc? uses doctor charts with erasable crayons.

title: Last Starfighter: Tunnel Chase
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description: Fight the tunnel chase battle of the movie The Last Starfighter.  May also be played by more players where the last player alive wins.

title: Last Starfighter: Duel In Space
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Based on the eponymous film, The Last Starfighter: Duel in Space puts its players in the roles of opposing starfighter pilots engaged in a battle.

The game is played out in a repeating sequence of play.  Players first secretly plot the heading and reveal them simultaneously.  They then use the Navigation Wheels, a custom 3-layer disc, to resolve the effects of their movement.  By rotating the layers of the wheel in accordance with their crafts' headings, the players learn which of their weapons can fire at their opponents.  They then roll dice and consult a table to determine the effects of their weapon fire, recording damage on their cards.

The game ends when a player has inflicted 10 points of damage on their opponent's starfighter.  A solo game variant is available, dictating the opponent's actions by dice rolls.

title: Mock My Words
description:
...it's not what you say... ... it's what you hear! (TM)

This game is the precursor to Mad Gab. The basic premise is that you are given a string of words that are meaningless, but sound like another phrase or title. Ache Leans Late = A Clean Slate.

In this version, 2 to 4 teams compete to collect cards while advancing toward the center of a board. On a team's turn, one player gives clues for the words in a puzzle (e.g. What you do when you're sore -- ache). That player's partners guess the words, and then try to figure out the puzzle. If the timer runs out before they've solved it, then the other team(s) can steal the card. Each card is worth from 3 to 7 points.

When one team is in the middle, they can play for double points on their turn; however, if they lose the card, they're sent back a few squares, and the team that gets the puzzle gets the double points.

The game ends when all teams are in the middle. Whoever has scored the most points wins.

title: Lightning Strike
Slag!: Combat on the High Frontier
description:
From the back cover:
Slag! is the space combat game you don't need to be a rocket scientist to play, or a defense budget to afford. Fast enough to play over lunch, with custom ship design and handicapping rules for different Tech Levels to provide endless variation and challenge. Let Slag! take you to where the wars of the future will be fought. You'll be glad you're not actually there.

title: Struggle For The Throne
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
mechanisms: Modular BoardPlayer EliminationSecret Unit DeploymentTake That
description: The Klingon Emperor is dying, and the Struggle For The Throne has already begun between the powerful Thought Admirals. Each Admiral uses bribery, assassination, spying, accusation, threats, battle, and even making deals to gain power while the Emperor lives. The diplomacy is intense, for when the Emperor dies, there will be a battle to the death.

title: Glebdo
description:
This hard-to-find German game with simple mechanics uses a very unusual board inspired by the drawings of M.C. Escher and hand painted (!) clay figurines. Two teams of either 1 or 2 players compete, the vampires try to hunt down the brigands who try to escape the castle Glebdo with a valuable codex. Although no dice are rolled for movement going anywhere at all is actually extremely hard on this board, as the hallways twist and turn in a nausea inducing manner...

Still available directly from the designer (April 2007).

title: Rule the Hand
description: Trick-taking card game for 3 or 4 players where votes are cast after the deal and for what conditions apply for that hand, such as which suit is trump (if any) or passing your entire hand to the right. Players cast their votes by placing some (or all) of their chips onto a specific rule card. Once you've used your allotment of chips, you can no longer vote in later hands. Players get 10 points for each trick won, unless modified by a rule that was voted for that hand. High score after 4 hands wins.

title: Gender Bender
description: At least two each of men and women must play.  Questions are asked, If you were a man/woman ... with multiple choice.  You get points by matching the majority vote of those of the opposite gender.

title: Le Chat Noir
description:
Consists of only 24 cards with happy situations on one side (true love, buying a new home, vacationing, etc.) and the Black Cat ruining the situation on the other side (heartbreak, getting locked out, getting lost, etc.). The loser of the game is the one with the most catastrophes at the end (everyone else wins).

Re-implements: Who is going to do the dishes?

title: Stop Secret
mechanisms: Pick-up and DeliverRoll / Spin and Move
description: Pachisi variant where the goal is to get at least one of each of the other color of tokens (secrets) into your home embassy.  Secrets can be taken from other spies or foreign embassies.

title: The Dark Crystal Card Game
types: Card Game Fantasy Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
Each player selects a color (publically announced) and then the entire deck is shuffled and each player is dealt four cards from the deck (they may get cards of their own color, they may get cards of their opponent's colors).  On your turn, you draw a card from the pile and then place a card onto the board.  The card placed on the board must match the card/illustration of the card it is placed onto (cards feature illustrations of characters, creatures and objects from The Dark Crystal).  The cards all have values of 1, 2, 3 and 5 on them.  When a Sun card is played (on a player's turn), all visible cards are scored per suit/color (the Sun card may also be countered by a Stop Sun card).

The game continues until the last card from the deck is drawn and then there is a final scoring round.

title: Richard Scarry's Busytown Poles & Ladders Game
description: This rendition of Snakes and Ladders has Richard Scarry characters and art and a stand-up board that actually allows the poles (and hoses) to slide the pawns back down to the earlier space.

title: Roundhouse
description: Roundhouse is an interesting game from Winsome where players use a limited set of action points to move locomotives into repair stalls and get them repaired.  The name comes from the fact that a turntable (in concept)is used to take trains from three input points and move them to five different repair bays.  Players deploy workers at the bays, and when the locomotive is repaired and released everyone who contributed to the repair gets paid.

title: Contiquences
description: Contiquences is the new board game that combines trivia with world power.  In your quest to control the world you must show that you have the knowledge to do so.  Move around the world take control of an area, but be careful your opponents may take control away from you.  Can you handle the Contiquences

title: Tron: Assault on MCP Game
types: Action / Dexterity Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction
description: A path-race game based on the movie, TRON.  Various spaces and situations in the game pit players against one another, Sark, or the Master Control Program by the players' pawns firing light discs.

title: How to Host a Murder: Roman Ruins
description:
Having mentioned your name in his Roman epic, the renowned poet, Flabbius Corpus, invites you to a banquet for the premier recitation of his historical work. When you arrive, you discover there's been a murder in the garden and a priceless statue is missing. You assume the role of one of these great Roman characters and solve the mystery. Like a history lesson come to life, the schemes of less-than-noble characters are laid bare.

CHARACTERS
Licentius Caesar, Rotunda Immaculata, Maximus Testosterus, Cleptopatra, Bogus Fortunatus, Flotilla Submergia, Harangus Adnauseum, Mercedes Accelleratti 
Description taken from deciphers website

title: The Dark Crystal Game
description: A path-race game based on the movie, The Dark Crystal.  This game uses a physical manifestation of time, so not only are the players racing against one another, they are also racing against time to attempt to restore the crystal.

title: Monster Maker
description:
In this game, similar in some ways to Mille Bornes, players attempt to play corridor cards to progress down into a dungeon. Monster cards are played to stop a players progress, while character cards can be played to combat them. By reaching the 100 distance mark and returning, treasures and prizes are collected, which can give victory points and also aid in exploring further dungeons. When prizes run out, whoever has the most valuable collection wins.

Expanded by:

    Monster Maker: The Queen of Darkness (This is an unlicensed expansion)

title: Monster Maker 2: Dragonbuster
description:
[This is after what I understood from the English rules here at BGG]

Monster Maker 2 is an entirely different game from the first in the series. In this game, players compete to slay a dragon. The dragon being a powerful creature, players must first hire a strong enough party. But fighters don't come for free and treasure must first be gathered by slaying various monsters.

The game feels a lot like old-school console RPGs from the 80's.

title: Magic Master
description:
In the style of Monster Maker, this card game looks more complex (twice as many pages of rules!)

The decks consist of spells, characters, monsters and some event-type cards, each with a series of statistics on them.

title: Gangsters: The Game of Disorganized Crime
description:
A Tom Wham game showing up in Gameplay Magazine, January 1984.  Although  the game superficially resembles Monopoly, instead of becoming the richest player by bankrupting everyone else, the goal is to be the first player to raise enough money to fly south, i.e. somewhere in Latin or South America.
This is accomplished by carrying out the usual Mafia activities during the Prohibition Era: bootlegging, racketeering, narcotics smuggling, robbery, bookmaking and Al Capone's favorite.. income tax evasion. Obstacles to achieving your goals include gun battles with other mobsters (players), police chases when robberies go wrong, and stints in the hospital recovering from gunshot wounds, or being sent up the river to the Big House.
To aid you in your quest, you hire cronies to carry out your bidding, and gain influence through power tokens. 
These can be used to bribe city officials when you end up in court. You can also run for Mayor, which increases your influence even more.
While all of this sounds very serious, the game is actually quite humorous, with everything being done in Tom Wham's inimitable cartoon art style. For 2-6 gangsters.

title: Magus
mechanisms: Action Point Allowance SystemRoll / Spin and Move
description:
A game of light-hearted acquisition and conquest for 2-6 players. Each player represents a powerful wizard -- a Magus -- and attempts to acquire various Power Zones represented on the game board. By skillful use of his acquisitions and cards, each player then attempts to gain control of the Towers of all other players, or else gain all Power Zones on the game board.

Published in Dragon Magazine #147.  Artwork by Tom Wham.

title: Beyond Competition
description:
A book containing the following six cooperative games: Space Explorer, Resources, Rescue, Peace Conference, Search, and Round 'n' Round.

Part of a series of five paper-and-pencil game books by Sid Sackson, including Beyond Competition, Beyond Solitaire, Games of Art, Beyond Words, and Calculate!.

title: Spark
description:
Each player has eleven pieces on a 7X7 grid. There are two types of pieces (Sparks and Orbs), only one of which (Sparks) can capture or be captured. The game is won by capturing all of your opponents' Sparks or preventing your opponent from moving.

The power or value of a Spark is determined by the number of Orbs it is aligned with; a Spark can only capture another with equal or lesser power.

Similarly, the mobility of an Orb is determined by the number of Sparks it is aligned with; An Orb can move as many spaces as the number of Sparks it is aligned with.

title: The Sorcerer's Cave Extension
types: Card Game Expansion for Base-game Exploration Fantasy
description:
This expansion was designed by Terence Donnelly, and adds 30 new dungeon tiles and 30 new encounter cards. The players are also given five new types of characters to select from in building their parties.

Expands:

    The Sorcerer's Cave

title: Indiana Jones from Raiders of the Lost Ark
description: Another game centered around the 'Raiders of the Lost Ark' movie.  Spin the spinner, move your piece, and do what the board says.  To win, collect the four cards of the same color.  The board looks good, but the mechanics are weak.

title: The Art of Siege
description:
From the publisher:

Four great siege battles:

    Acre - Richard the Lionhearted's arrival signals the end of the two year defense by Saracens in the Third Crusade. 
    Tyre - Alexander the Great undertakes the first large-scale amphibious assault in history. 
    Lille - the greatest star fortress in France is taken by the Anglo-Dutch-German Confederation. 
    Sevastopol - Ingenious Russian fortifications in the Crimean War require one year of continuous bombardment before the city is taken. 




Each battle in The Art of Siege is simulated on its own comprehensively illustrated map portraying the actual siege areas and fortifications. Colorful cardboard playing pieces move, position, and engage according to the nuances of each game's system of movement. Simple probability charts reveal each combat's outcome.


The Strategy  Tactics magazine game The Siege of Constantinople is considered by some to be the fifth quad game of this set.

title: Games of Art
description:
Beyond Tic Tac Toe  (1975) is the original form of this book, and contains the following seven games meant to be played with coloured pencils or markers.  The games are named after the artists whose works they most resemble graphically: Vasarely, Miro, Mondrian, Arp, Delaunay, Klee, and Springer.

It is part of a series of five paper-and-pencil game books by Sid Sackson, including Beyond Competition, Beyond Solitaire, Beyond Tic Tac Toe, Beyond Words, and Calculate!.

 Games of Art  (2014) is the new edition of Beyond Tic Tac Toe that was published on Kickstarter by Eagle/Gryphon Games in the form of a reusable book with laminated pages and dry erase markers.

title: Beyond Words
description:
Contains six competitive paper-and-pencil word games by Sid Sackson, each named after an author suggested by the style of the game: Tolstoy, Joyce, Dickens, Poe, Carroll, and O. Henry.

Part of a series of five paper-and-pencil game books by Sid Sackson, including Beyond Competition, Beyond Solitaire, Games of Art, Beyond Words, and Calculate!.

title: Calculate!
description:
Contains six paper-and-pencil games with various themes, meant to be played while assisted by eight-digit, four-banger calculators (still a relative novelty when the book was published). The games include  Run for President, Target Number, Invasion, Away Across, Travels, and High Finance.

Sometimes the calculator serves as a dice-alternative for producing random numbers (selected digits are read from the display), other times it just handles manipulating large numbers

The bulk of the book consists of perforated pages to tear out and use to record gameplay progress.

Part of a series of five paper-and-pencil game books by Sid Sackson, including Beyond Competition, Beyond Solitaire, Games of Art, Beyond Words, and Calculate!.

title: Beyond Solitaire
description:
Contains six paper-and-pencil games meant to be played by a single player, including Four Color, Pinball, Profit  Loss, Mountains  Valleys, No Way, and Buried Treasure (which is not to be confused with the later Sackson game of the same title that is a re-theming of Das Super-Blatt).

Part of a series of five paper-and-pencil game books by Sid Sackson, including Beyond Competition, Beyond Solitaire, Games of Art, Beyond Words, and Calculate!.

title: Hard Vacuum: Science Gone Mad
types: Expansion for Base-game Fighting Science Fiction Wargame World War II
description:
The Battle for Orbit continues!  Technology runs amok as this expansion for Hard Vacuum finds the space war moving into 1945!  Fiendish shadow fighters, immense space battlecruisers, bizarre magnetic raiders, nimble parasite ships and even the war-torn British all show up in the seventh year of World War II.

Expands

    Hard Vacuum

title: Munchkin 2: Unnatural Axe
types: Card Game Expansion for Base-game Fantasy Fighting Humor
mechanisms: Card DraftingDice RollingHand ManagementTake ThatVariable Player Powers
description:
Publisher's Description

You demanded it, and here it is. Created by Steve Jackson and illustrated by John Kovalic... 112 more cards for the game of killing monsters and taking their stuff. Play a new race: Orcs! Face foes like the Hydrant and the Tentacle Demons. Equip yourself with dread armor like the Spiked Codpiece. Recruit allies like the Shoulder Dragon. Wield mighty weapons like Druid Fluid, the Catapult and, of course, the dread Unnatural Axe... and show them who's the greatest munchkin of all.

Munchkin 2 - Unnatural Axe is a supplement to Munchkin; you will need the original game to play. Or you could add it to a game of Munchkin, Munchkin Fu, or Munchkin Bites! instead, or mix them all together for a Munchkin-fest of truly mind-bending proportions!

				
					Other

Part of the Munchkin series.

title: Jolly Roger
description:
From the Italian company International Team comes this fairly simple game of piracy on the high seas.

On a map that can only be considered a fantasy world you sail your galleon around the outer islands picking up treasure chests in the hope of delivering the treasures to his island in the middle of the board.

Movement is handled by way of a wind disk. Every 3 turns this disk turns and the wind will be coming from a new direction. A ship always moves in a straight line that can be at a diagonal. If it is sailing in the direction of the wind it must move 4 spaces. If in a diagonal with the wind it must move 5 spaces. If perpendicular to the wind movement is 3 spaces. If diagonal against the wind movement is 2 spaces and if against the wind 1 space. The wind rotates in a rigid sequence so you can always plan what your ship will be doing. If a ship runs onto land it is sunk. A ship can stop short of its full movement if it is in a harbor square of which each island has one. On the outer islands this is where a galleon picks up treasures and each may carry up to 3. The board wraps around on itself so if a ship sails off an edge it reappears on the opposite side of the board.

There are 6 dark areas on the seas that can become storms. The start player rolls 2 die at the beginning of his turn and puts a marker on the corresponding areas. Ships cannot enter these and ships that are in these areas cannot move.

Each player also has a frigate. Frigates attempt to pass over another ship, regardless of the type, which will sink it. A sunken ship will always reappear at that players island at the start of his next turn. Frigates may not dock at harbors so they cannot end their movement short when passing over one. Ships sunk have their treasures returned to the bank.

You play until a player has collected an agreed to amount of treasures. The rules suggest 8 to 20.

The rules take up 3 small pages of which half the page is rules in another language. There are also 4 illustrations in the rules so you end up with about 1 page of rules. Some things are very vague though. How the Disk of Winds is used is not very clear. Here logic can get you through. The islands in the center are not marked as belonging to anyone so I have always had each player put a treasure on one to claim it. We have also played that the islands belong to no one player and you just need to get you treasures to an island. This makes it a lot easier to dock and drop off treasures.

title: Octrix
description:
Notes from Box: 
OCTRIX is an intriguing game of eights. Each player receives eight cards. Each round consists of eight tricks. And the first player to score eighty-eight points wins!

Each hand is posted on an OCTRIX board so everyone knows exactly what cards are held by each player. Skillful evaluation of all hands is essential as each player plots his strategy-attempting to score more points by taking tricks in sequence. For 2 to 4 players.

Belongs to the 3M Gamette Series.

title: Assembly Line
description: A game where the object is to build 4 cars on your assembly line. You start out with just the Chassis and must move along the assembly line to acquire the Engine Block, Steering Posts, and Body to complete each vehicle. The first person to complete all 4 car assemblies is the winner. The car companies represented in the game are Plymouth, Studebaker, Chevy, and Ford.

title: Four-Letter Frenzy
types: Action / Dexterity Card Game Word Game
description: An amalgam of Scattergories and Spoons.  Players are given four cards, and must pass one and draw one until someone has a four-letter word that fits the category drawn at the beginning of the round.  When someone grabs a beanbag signaling he or she has a word, everyone grabs for one.    When someone is caught six times without a bag, the game ends, and whomever has the most points wins the game.

title: Bioscopy
description:
The object of Bioscopy is to be the first player or team to score 20 points in each of the 4 categories of trivia (Who, What, When, and Where).

Each player or team puts their playing marker at the center of the board, and their 4 scoring markers on the 0 at the start of each of the 4 scoring scrolls. Players take turns rolling a six-sided die to determine how far you may move on the board, moving in any direction they choose (but they may not visit the same space twice in a turn). The spaces on the board are color coded to each of the 4 categories of questions, and are marked with a number (10, 7, 4, and 1) that corresponds to the difficulty of the clue. Each card has 4 clues on it, descending in value (10, 7, 4, and 1). Players may hear the clues in descending value until they reach the minimum value indicated on their space on the board -- if they can successfully answer at a higher point clue value, they will receive the higher points.

An alternate form of scoring is based on stealing points from the opponents by landing on a space on the board without a number. When this happens, the player competes head-to-head with the person that has scored the most points on that category's scoring scroll.

title: Tochtli
description:
Tochtli is a strategy game in which you out-maneuver your opponent by moving, jumping, splitting, or stacking your game pieces to control one of six triangles.

Components:

     One game board consisting of 12 spaces forming 6 outer points (triangles).
     Six pieces of each color (12 total)

title: Prospecting
description:
The gameboard is a 7x9 grid. The players draw from a bag containing seventy-eight tiles called nuggets. Each nugget represents one of six metals. Each player, in turn, places one, two or three nuggets on the gameboard. The nuggets placed must match each other, however. After placement of the nuggets, the player may purchase up to two shares of stock of the mines represented by the nuggets on the gameboard. The player then ends the turn by replacing the nuggets played with nuggets from the bag. Every subsequent turn has each player beginning the turn by collecting profit based on the number of shares owned and the size of each mine and rarity of the metal therein.

The game ends when the gameboard is filled. All players cash out the value of their stocks and the player with the most money is declared the victor.

title: Sum-Up
description:
Players are dealt a hand of card and attempt to form the highest scoring equation in each of the four rounds -- addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. For example, a player holding the cards 0, 0, 4, 4, 6, 6, 6, 8, 8, 9 could form this equation during the addition round and score 864:

800 + 64 = 864

Using every card is not mandatory. During a round, players pass their hands, so each player plays every hand once, eliminating the luck of the draw.

Challenging Game of Creative Equations

Belongs to the 3M Gamette Series.

title: Tryce
description:
The game consists of two standard card decks including the jokers from each deck. In addition to the standard numbers and suits the cards also contain a letter of the alphabet.

The players are attempting to create runs, groups and words. A Run is four or more cards in the same suit in sequence. A Group is three or more of a kind. A Word is formed using the letters on the cards and can be any non-proper word found in a standard dictionary. A game consists of seven rounds, and in each round a player must form a specific number of Runs, Groups and Words.

Each player is dealt a number of cards, the exact number of which varies depending on the round in play. Each turn the player draws the top card from the deck or from the discard pile then plays as many cards as possible (either by forming new Runs, Groups or Words or by adding them onto cards which have already been played, either by themselves or by other players). Finally, they discard one of their remaining cards. The round ends when one player manages to empty their hand.

Players gain points by forming the number of Groups, Runs and Words specified for the round and for the cards in the melds they created. They lose points for cards left in their hand when the round ends. The player with the highest total after all seven rounds is the winner.

An interesting variation of Rummy, Tryce adds an element of strategy to that game.

Belongs to the 3M Gamette Series.  It was also released in a butterbox or butterdish version.

title: Crypt: The Pharaoh's Curse
types: Ancient Collectible Components Exploration Fantasy Fighting Horror
description:
Crypt: The Pharaoh's Curse is characterized as a Trading Board Game, available in Starter Box Sets of 5 hexes (hexagonal tiles), 3 six-sided dice, 3 character cards, 34 action pieces (cards), and 20 life/creature tokens. Booster sets are also available.

Each player selects a character card secretly before the beginning of the game, which will affect which action pieces that the player will be most effective with, determines the minimum and maximum number of action pieces that the player must play with, and describes any special abilities of the character. Next, each player chooses which action pieces they will play with from their collection, subject to the limits of the character card. Finally, each player contributes an agreed-upon number of hexes (rooms) to the game in their own stack.

Gameplay consists of drawing/discarding action pieces,  playing any number of free action pieces, taking one action (such as moving, exploring by adding a new hex to the board and resolving the occurrence on the hex, playing an action piece, attacking another player/creature, or exiting the crypt).

The goal is to be the first player to find your key in the action piece deck, find and place your exit tile, and successfully exit the crypt complex.

Online Play


     CCG Workshop (no longer available)

title: Demonwand
description:
Demonwand represents a struggle between powerful wizards for control of a magical land. The only human characters in the game are the Wizards themselves and the greatest warriors; ordinary mortals stay out of the way when dragons battle with demons and giants. The Wizards attempt to rally neutral beings to their cause, and to hamper their opponent's efforts by moving the very terrain itself. The landscape is enchanted, and its mountains and forests are subject to powerful spells. With these spells, the magic portals called Gates, and his own forces, each Wizard hopes to give his rivals their death blows. The winner is the last Wizard left in the land.

Published in Fantasy Gamer #5.

title: Lost Worlds Adventure Set I: In the Ruins of the Ancients
description:
This is the first boardgame based on the Lost Worlds series of fighting gamebooks. Players would take miniatures into a 3-D plastic molded dungeon room, and maneuver on the board until they came into melee range, at which point they switched to the Lost Worlds books to resolve combat.

Rules were provided for movement, ranged combat and furniture. Several scenarios came with the game.

Part of the Lost Worlds series.

title: RuneSword
description:
A thematic series in the Lost Worlds series (these books are even compatible with the others). Players each take a character represented with a game book and a stat sheet. By giving the book to the opposite player, the pages give a first person view to the combatants. As various moves direct the players to turn to this page or that, combat damage, restrictions, and other special events are relayed to the players via the pages of the book.

Part of the Lost Worlds series of books.

title: Karl May-Spiel
description: Karl May Spiel is a game rather intended for the children. The principle is classic. The players are in confrontation in a running where it is necessary to be the first one in the arrival, having found two identical objects and having crossed different obstacles. The originality of the game lives in the die. In fact, there is no die, because the players determine their advance by a shot to the elastic representing archery. It is thus the fitness and not the fate that leads the game, but for some players, it is about the same thing!

title: Cassa Grande
description: Cassa Grande is a Roland Siegers's small and fun game. The idea is very simple, rules are read in two minutes and a game need 10 minutes. The players have the same set of cards at the beginning of the play. Each at his turn plays a card back to front on the table in a virtual tray of 6x6. When all the cards are put, you turn the whole and each books its points. Cards form numbers which are differently read as we are in the North, the South, the East or the West.

title: Die Drei
description:
Die Drei, means the three games. The box indeed contains the material and the German rules to play three Alex Randolph's games: Hepta, Pegs, Tetrods. It also contains the rules of T. for two, a game created by Franz-Josef Schulte with the pieces of Tetrods.

Hepta is also known as Hepta (Ravensburger Spieleverlag GmbH) or Magic 7 (Ideal).
Pegs was published as Peggino (Ravensburger Spieleverlag GmbH).
Tetrods was never published before.
T. for two was never published before.

title: Sabotage
description:
Sabotage puts a thematic pipe-building spin on Leopard, from Abbott's New Card Games.

Each player has a hand of cards and a playing grid of 3x3 cells. In turn, each player draws and places a card on one of the grids. Most cards can only be placed on a designated cell. For example, 'E'/'5' (Sabotage/Leopard) can only be played into a center cell. A few cards (10-K in Leopard) have special abilities (e.g., wild, cover opponent).

Each row, column, and/or diagonal of three like-colored/-suited cards scores points. Players interact by playing cards of the wrong suit on their opponents' layouts, while trying to play good suits on their own.

Re-implemented by: 

    Sabotage Pur

title: The VANITPL8 Game
types: Humor Party Game Puzzle Word Game
description:
The VANITPL8 Game takes the English language and pushes the phrasecreative license to the limit. Up to 3 clues will help you unscramble these challenging vanity license plates.

Players race against each other and a hour glass to unscramble phonetically written phrases.  For example, 8ATVILNP unscrambled is VANITPL8, which says vanity plate.

Very fun and challenging for the whole family.  Available at http://www.vanityplategame.com/

title: The Fall of Castle Bondi
description:
This expansion for Castle of Magic contains a reprint of the first expansion and additional material in the form of three new scenarios.
   Material from the first expansion has been generalized to use with all scenarios.
   The expansion consists of a single perfect-bound book. Almost all the pages must be torn out and copied. In some instances this means copying it onto cardstock and creating decks of cards.

Expands:

    Castle of Magic

title: Blackmail
mechanisms: Auction/BiddingCo-operative PlayRoll / Spin and MoveTile PlacementTrading
description: Set up surveillance cameras to blackmail opponents, send them blackmail letters, receive wage increments or reductions, hire thugs and private investigators or even let the FBI on someone's blackmail scam.

title: W.A.C.K.O.
description:
W.A.C.K.O. stands for Wild and Crazy Kids Only.

These series of action/dexterity games included the following:
BMX Racer
Gobblers
Shoot the Rapids
Escape from Devil's Castle
Baseball
Alligator Alley
Hoops
Jungle Safari

Some were just races, with each person taking a turn and the best (fastest, most completions) would win, while others actually had a head to head component like Hoops (basketball) or Gobbler (like hungry-hungry hippos).

title: Round Four
description: Round Four is a variant of Connect Four. 2-4 players can play at the same time. The object is still to match four of your color chips in a straight line. The board is four circles inside of each other. the three outer most circles have 16 holes for pieces while the inner circle only has eight. Also some of the holes can fit two pieces inside of it, one on top the other. An added depth to this game is that each circle can be rotated clockwise. During your turn, you can either place a piece, or rotate one of the rings clockwise, causing all of the pieces to shift on that circle. The winner has four of his color pieces in a straight line starting from the inner circle and moving out.

title: Renegades:  Eldar and Chaos Armies for Space Marine
types: Expansion for Base-game Miniatures Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Renegades:  Eldar and Chaos Armies for Space Marine, does not come with any extra figures for playing Space Marine, but comes with rules and background information for Eldar and Chaos armies.  It also contains a set of Eldar and Chaos epic army cards for both the Eldar and Chaos army to add to the basic Space Marine game.

Expands:


    Space Marine

title: Dark Lore
types: Horror Movies / TV / Radio theme Mythology Science Fiction Trivia
description:
Dark Lore: An Epic Fantasy Adventure Game for Your Mind, is a Sci-Fi and Horror Movie, Supernatural, Monsters, Magic, Superstition, Mixed Macabre, Comedy Horror trivia game. In it you role a die, move your piece a certain number of Spaces and answer a trivia question. The subject is based on the number on the die you role. There are spaces that send you back some on the board. Also there are some spaces that you receive cards that can move you ahead, behind or move another player forwards are backwards. There are over a thousand questions. Some sample questions that appear on the back of the box are:

What is Agent Mulder's nickname on the X-Files?
What color cat is bad luck if it crosses your path?
Who is the father of Hercules?
What must a weapon be made from to kill a werewolf?
What must you do to a vampire after you drive a stake through its heart?
Where does a Jedi Knight get his mystical power?

Play if You Dare

title: Gundam M.S.War Trading Card Game
types: Collectible Components Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction
description:
Gundam M.S.War Trading Card Game is based on the popular Japanese anime series based on giant robots.  Gundam first started in 1979 and continues to this day with various series, movies, models, and toys and now a collectible card game.  The particular gundam series it is based on is Gundam Wing, although they were going to release other expansions to add more series to the game.

To play the game, you need two opposed decks. In this case you need the Wing Gundam starter Set and the Oz Corps Starter Decks.  You play cards depicting giant robots and can equip them with character cards to increase the attack strength.  The  cards are played by playing their cost points.  The cost if discarding a certain number of cards.  Then the robots battle and the loser loses a certain number of cards from his draw pile, when the draw pile is empty, the game is over.

title: P.O.W. Rescue
description: This is a pretty esoteric game. The object of the game is to rescue POW's from Viet Nam's infamous Hanoi Hilton. The first player to rescue and escape with a POW from the camp cell and reach the end of the rescue/escape route wins the game. The designer believed that POW's were still being held in North Viet Nam and apparently created this game to keep people aware of that fact. He comments  POW Rescue is an action game of rescue dedicated to those still held as POW with the hope that Americans will never forget those we left behind. The rules for this very simplistic game are 3 very short pages in length.

title: Bodyguard Overlord
description: Bodyguard Overlord is a simulation of intelligence, deception and preparations preceding the Allied Invasion of Normandy in June 1944 and their effect on the subsequent course of military operations. The emphasis of this simulation is on the often overlooked fog-of-war, the tendency for information to get mixed up in the heat of a campaign.

title: A Bold Stroke
description:
A Bold Stroke: The Soviet Liberation of Kiev, 1943, is a simulation of the battles between the Soviet Union and the German forces for the control of Kiev and the right bank of the Dnepr River in November and December of 1943. Early November Soviets attacks blew holes in the thin German defenses, resulting in the liberation of Kiev and the pursuit to Korosten and Zhitomir.  A massive German riposte led by the XLVIII Panzerkorps stuck the Soviet flank and rolled back some of the initial Soviet Gains.  In December, additional German efforts pushed in the Soviet forces around Korosten.  Heavy Soviet reinforcements (undetected by the Germans) enabled the Soviet to return to the offensive on Christmas Eve and drive the Germans back from Kiev once and for all.

Game Scale:
Turn: 2 days
Hex: 5 miles / 8 kilometers
Units: Battalion to Corps

Game Inventory:
One 22 x 34 full-color mapsheet
One dual-side printed countersheet (280 1/2 counters)
One 46-page A Bold Stroke rules booklet
Two single-sided Set-up Charts
Two Player Aid cards
One 10-sided die

Players: 1 or more
Playing Time: 2-20 hours
Complexity: Medium
Solitaire Suitability: Moderate

title: Pentagon Games
description:
A book containing three games:


Pentagon

Pentagon is not a simulation in the formal sense of the word. The events in the game are intended to be illustrative and the decisions fictitious, woven from the progress of play. But by giving the players incentives both to compete and to cooperate, the game does simulate bureaucratic politics. And the content of bureaucratic politics is similar in tone and substance to real debates over military budgets. Pentagon shows how political factors influence the shape of budgets before the bureaucracy even gets down to decisions on weapons procurement and their merits.


The RD Game: Congressional Chutes and Ladders

The RD Game is designed as a solitaire game. It is based on a decision-tree mechanism that leads the player through a set of alternative developments. This type of approach is sometimes called a scripted role model because the main emphasis is on broad decision choices rather than narrow selection of tactics. Given the broad choice, the decision tree itself generates much of the action, unlike a two-player or multi-player game in which action flows from the decisions of each of the players.


The Last Days of Saigon

An introductory level wargame.  The goal of each player is to destroy the other player's forces, so the game does not follow the historical values.  The map is pretty basic, moderately large scale, 3-color with just basic terrain. Units are mostly Brigade-level units with a few regimental and batallion units thrown in. There is a mostly abstract representation of air, and naval units. [Note: This game was also published as 'Last Days At Saigon' in 'Bridge' magazine, Volume 4 #1 (11/75) bound-in, with bw components, as part of a 'Vietnam in Retrospect' issue.]

title: Ronin: Duels
description:
Ronin is a customizable miniatures game of gigantic mechanized battle. In Ronin you design your own unique battle armor and equip it with heavy turbo rocket launchers, jump packs and assault cannons of your choice. Make tactical decisions on what energy-fluids to use and how to process them through your system in order to cool weapon systems or boost your movement circuits.

Design your Ronin from the 102 different parts of weaponry and equipment, and numerous different Ronin designs. All parts are interchangeable.

- 60 mm scale vouch for high detail and great presence on the tabletop.

- Fast and intense combat including missile weapons and close combat covering hit locations and critical hits.

- Features the unique MAG-HIT magnet indication system.

Expanded by:

    Ronin: War

title: Udder Madness
description:
A lighthearted cow-tipping game in which aliens are trying to tip cows for bragging rights.



In the first part of the game, players place their cows. 
On an 8x8 grid (3 players) or 9x9 grid (2 or 4 players), players take turns placing 12 cow chits of their color, 1 at a time and 1 per cell, inside the fence, which is a 1-cell perimeter. When placing cows, players try to achieve Cow Lock, which is two identically-colored orthogonally adjacent cows. Four cows in a square is called a Bovine Doom Block. Next, each player places their alien chit on the center square of their edge of the board (on the grid, but outside the fence). They take turns moving the alien up to 3 spaces, and then they may choose to tip cows. Tipping starts from the alien and stops at a Cow Lock -- the alien cannot tip a cow directly into a cow of the same color. The player then collects all tipped cows.

To determine individual scores, each player tallies their cows, subtracting the number of cows of their color from the remaining cows. High score wins.

In the 2-player game, each player uses a single alien marker as normal, but chooses and places cows of 2 colors. Cow Lock and Bovine Doom Block can still only be achieved with cows of the same color.


From the packaging:
In Udder Madness you are an alien engaged in a contest with your alien pals to see who can tip the most cows of your opponents while tipping as few of your own as possible.

Why an alien, you ask? Well there are a couple of reasons.

One reason is that by now, any alien visitors we may have must surely have grown bored with abducting people and examining their nether-regions. So with nether-regions out, and crop circles quickly becoming pass, they're going to need some new mystifying activity... Why not this?

The second reason is that we at Placebo Press could not possibly believe that an actual human being, no matter how depraved or intoxicated, would participate in such an activity outside of the confines of a harmless board game? Hence it must be aliens. I don't think that our logic is flawed here.

title: Breacan
description:
[for more information on this game and to play online, visit www.allumbra.com]

Lost in the ancient Celtic migration across Europe, this game was played between the clan chieftains to resolve disputes peacefully rather than resort to a costly and bloody war. It was played on a swatch of ornamental cloth familiar to this day as a plaid. Instead of stones used in the traditional game, this variation presented here uses as the playing pieces.

To win at Breacan - and thus resolve the dispute in your favor, you must be the first to weave a path from one side of the Breacan to the opposite side.

Placing the dice
On your turn, place two of your four rolled dice. After your turn has ended, two more dice will be automatically rolled to replace the two you rolled.

Dice can be placed in two ways:
1. They can be placed on a square of your own color (e.g. red on red) when that square has no vertical or horizontal neighbors.
2. They can be placed on any square as long as each adjacent (horizontally or vertically) neighboring die of your color is either one higher or one lower than the die being placed. Note: 6 can be placed next to a 1 and 1 next to a 6.

Winning
The first player to complete a path from top to bottom or from side to side is the winner.

title: Take Five
types: Bluffing Humor Party Game Trivia Word Game
description: Players write there 5 best answers to questions on cards... i.e. 'Name 5 fictional characters you would like to invite to dinner.' Players then compare answers and tally matches and non-matches. There are 15 questions per game. The player with the lowest difference in matches and non-matches though the fun of the game is mostly found in the interesting conversations and debates that always follow each question.

title: Metis
description:
[For more information and to play online visit www.allumbra.com]

Metis is a pure strategy game in which you guide your Priests in exchanging power with each other to ultimately wrest control of your opponents Temple of Metis.

Your Priests all have varying degrees of power. Those with greater power can make sweeping movements greatly altering the course of the struggle. Lesser Priests, while more limited in might, are able to move more freely.

Movement

A piece can move horizontally, vertically or diagonally exactly the number of spaces as the value currently on the die. After, you move, transfer power with the pieces you jumped (see below).

Landing on Pieces: You may land on a piece (yours or your opponents) only if your piece has a higher value than the one it is landing on. The piece that you land on is destroyed. The capturing piece gains +1 power.

Power Transfer

As pieces move over one another, they exchange power. You give (1) power from your moving piece to each of your own pieces that you jump. Your piece takes (1) power from each enemy piece it passes over.

Underpowered and Overpowered Pieces: During movement, if a piece falls below (1) power, it is has become underpowered and is removed from the board. Likewise, if a piece gains more than (6) power, it has become overpowered and is removed from the board.

Winning

There are two possible ways to win Metis.

1. Occupy seats in your opponents Temple of Metis. There are two areas in each players temple: The inner chamber (darker) and the outer chamber (lighter). Occupying a seat in the inner chamber is worth 2 occupation points. occupying a seat in the outer chamber is worth 1 occupation point. You must hold 8 occupation points to win the game.

2. Destroy opponents pieces until she has three or less (making the above goal impossible for your opponent).

title: Battlewagon Salvo
description:
Similar to Battleship, but with more complicated rules.

Each player deploys ships in secret on their copy of the mapsheet. Then they try to find all of the enemy ships and destroy them.

The basic rules allow for simple movement and firing. The advanced rules cover submerging of submarines, reload time, torpedoes, and depth charges.

Ship movement is always announced in terms of direction but not location.

Two different mapsheets are included.  One for basic play and another for advanced.

title: Rosetta
description:
Rosetta is a tile laying game where players are trying to match the designs on the tiles to form a complete picture.
The two main game types are co-op in that players are all working together to complete the design. It can be thought of as a puzzle, with square pieces, that has multiple solutions.

On one side of the tiles, the Rosetta, 1-3 players work together to make a 6x6 square picture. When complete, the picture shows different coloured flowers, each made up of two corresponding square pieces. You may choose to use the 4 joker tiles as wild cards.

On the other side, Puncola, you are creating a 6x6 square picture by matching the edges of the tiles with a similar pattern on an adjacent tile. At the corners of certain tiles is a 1/4 circle that is paired with 3 other tiles to form a complete circle.

Domino-Puncola is an alternate version of the game that adds competition. Each player picks 5 tiles at random and, in turn, tries to match an edge of the Puncola side to a tile on the table. If that person cannot place his/her tile, he/she draws a new one. The first person to place all of his/her tiles is the winner.

title: The California Raisins Board Game
types: Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
Welcome to the land of sunshine, palm trees and yep, you guessed it, those oh so cool California Raisins.  Raisins are coming to Hollywood from all over California to be singing and dancing stars.  In fact 'conga' lines of raisins can be seen all over the city.  But which raisins will hit the 'big time'?  It's all timing in Hollywood.  Be the first player to get your quartet on center stage and your four raisins will be the 'stars' of the show.

according the the Making of The California Raisins Board Game, three artists spent more than three months to design, create and perfect the three-dimensional sculpted clay model that was photographed to make the game board.

title: Dweebs Geeks & Weirdos
types: Action / Dexterity Children's Game Humor Party Game
description:
Dweebs Geeks  Weirdos: The Totally Awesome Game of Zany Stunts is a game in which players advance on the score board from an Absolute Zero to a Totally Bad Dude.  To play, players toss their plastic Dip Chip onto the game board in an attempt to get closest to the illustration of the gold tooth. The winner draws a Stunt Card, performs the action required by the card, and advances their playing piece a number of spaces on the score board. The first player to reach the status of Totally Bad Dude wins.

Examples of card text are:

Flex your muscles like a bodybuilder.  
Blow a bubble using only your spit.
Choose one player to race against, then do the crab walk across the room.
Plus many more...

title: Garfield Kids' Card Game
types: Card Game Children's Game Comic Book / Strip Movies / TV / Radio theme
description: Everyone knows Garfield loves to eat lasagna, play with Pooky, sharpen his claws on Jon's favorite chair, and tease Odie. Be the first to collect 4 cards of any one of his favorite things, and Garfield says you're the winner!

title: World 7
description:
WORLD 7 the Help! Where's the Rest of the World?! game plays with the fun and ease of the old-fashioned rummy-type card games--but, there is much more than rummy in this fast Trip of Cards across the 7 continents of the world.  Players race to be the first to connect all their cards in a continuous chain of connecting countries.  But, WATCH OUT!  There are many kickers along the way!
Can be played as singles or partners.
Parents' Choice Foundation Award Winning Game!
By the makers of USA Trip 50.

title: Bulls, Bears and Billionaires
mechanisms: Co-operative PlayPaper-and-PencilRoll / Spin and MoveStock HoldingTrading
description:
Bulls, Bears and Billionaires is a board game that makes winner a Millionaire on a short game or a Billionaire for a long game.  It takes making money and turns it into even more fun because you are buying and selling stocks as the prices go up and down.  And to help you relieve your stress, you get to yell out your stock orders and when you sell your stock you must throw the trading tickets on the floor.  The Bulls, Bears and Billionaires game allows you have fun while learn more about the real stock market.

Players roll dice and that causes the stock prices to change, sometimes just one stock price changes; other rolls cause all stocks prices to go up or down.  Its a game that test wit against daring.  Should you sell out now or wait for a higher price.  Or, if your stock price is down, double up the price by using the Rumor Mill but bewarestock prices can go down just as fast as they go up.  The game uses Good News and Bad News to change stock prices just like the real stock market.  There is even an Insider Trading Violation penalty to keep all things equal.

All stock prices go up with a Bull Market and watch out for the Bear Markets when they all go down.  Rolling doubles takes on a whole new meaning in this game.   One double reduces your stock shares while another doubles your holdings.  The game is a fast pace of buying and selling stocks.  It creates an atmosphere of constant participation because every move affects any and all players.  It doesnt take long to learn strategies to help you win.  Build an alliance with other traders to try and control the market or force the prices down on stocks you do not own.  It is a great game for the family or those more serious players looking for a real challenge.

title: Lemmings in Space
description: Hex-and-miniature game in which players fly spaceships filled with lemmings around the game area hoping to intentionally kill off their entire crew as quickly as possible.  The trick is, upgrading your ship and exploration (which may lead to successes rather than failures) are the best ways to approach your doom faster.  As your ship grows more powerful, you make a better target, but you'll do more damage to other players' ships.  The objective is to lose all 28 members of your crew.

title: Index Pro Football 2002
description: Index Pro Football 2002 is the new, solitaire NFL Statistical Simulation Game designed for NFL Fans who loves to keep stats of their favorite NFL Players while replaying NFL Games of the previous 2001 NFL Season.......The play-by-play recording onto the Game Logs and the huge dose of statistical accuracy brings gameplay excitement.......This game is a statistician's dream !  http://www.indexprofootball.com

title: The Anyville Horror
description: An asymmetrical board game in which one player plays a nasty monster while the other player(s) take on the roles of family members defending their home from the evil intruder.  If the monster can kill the whole family, he wins.  If the family gets the monster first, they win.  The monster has certain advantages, special abilities, and is unidentified until he is seen by a family member, but family members can utilize items around the house (like moose-heads, ties, and remote-control cars) to attack the much stronger monster.  The game uses scalable rules ranging from basic (Go Cower Under Your Blankie While Crying For Your Mommy), Intermediate (fearfully challenging) which adds in monster powers and more complex combat rules, and Advanced (Hero Worship) which adds in even more combat rules, monster abilities, and allows one or all family members to be significantly stronger than the rest.

title: 1776: The Birth Of A Nation
types: Age of Reason American Indian Wars American Revolutionary War Political Wargame
description:
The object of this game is to assume the identity of a famous American Colonist and collect bounty, money and signatures for the Declaration of Independence. This is done through a series of reenactments of historical events from the landing of the Pilgrims through the American Revolution

User review: Players start the game with an Identity Card. This tells the player who that person is during the game and what victory conditions must be met in order to win: the number of Signature Cards, bounty units and amount of money. Players also start with $5000 and a pawn on Independence Hall. In turn, players will roll the dice and follow the instructions on whatever space the pawn lands. A player who lands on another players space sends the latter player to stock where that player must lose one turn. Players are free to barter Signature Cards, bounty units, and money amongst themselves. Every time a player passes Independence Hall that player gets $1000. A player who reaches Independence Hall with the assigned requirements is the winner.

title: Tiles
description: Game equipment consists of 72 letter tiles (color-coded to indicate vowel, common consonant, or less-common consonant) and two frames. Each frame holds 19 letter tiles in an array of four interlocking words, of 4, 5, 6 and 7 letters; the frames can be rotated and flipped to form 16 different patterns.  A player draws 19 to 25 tiles (depending on desired level of difficulty), balancing the colors to get a good mix of letters, and tries to form words in the frame.  Can be played solitaire or competitively.

title: Three Eyed Jack
description: Fluxx meets Wyatt Earp.  Win by being the first to get three chips which match the three face-up Wanted posters.  But the cards played can not only let other players take your chips, they can require you to turn your chips over (displaying a different outlaw on the reverse) or can replace one Wanted poster with a new one.

title: Crime Busters
description: Players are shown a picture of a crime scene and try to answer questions about it.  Since only twelve pictures come with the game, repeated playability is limited.

title: Pre-Fix
description: A card displaying two or three letters is drawn, and players list as many words beginning with those letters as they can within the time limit.  Points are awarded for number of words, number of words not found by other players, and length of words.

title: Railroad Dynasty
description: Rummy-like game in which players try to get rid of their cards by laying down systems consisting of U.S. cities and the (historic) railroads connecting them.

title: Double Talk
description: Players advance around a track by guessing words with double meanings (A vagabond/To walk with heavy feet = tramp) or homonyms (Metal rooftop rooster/Mirror watcher = vane/vain).

title: ¡Knock-on-Word!
description:
Players give crossword-style clues for words that can be placed on the board.  A four-player partnership game, with two- and three-player variants.

Knock-on-Word! is sort of a redesign of Joli Kansil's own Montage.

title: Malarky Card Game
description: Players take turn reading trivia questions from cards (example: Why do we tie shoes to the back of newlyweds' cars?), then either give the correct answer shown on the card or make up an answer.  Other players must guess which.

title: König Laurin
description: Deep inside his crystal castle the mysterious King Laurin prevails since legendary times. His subjects are dwarves, who dig treasures from rock, in order to fill his vaults. In the wonderful garden of the king the dwarves show their lord the most precious treasures to rise in his favor. But only few will succeed in acquiring liberty ....

title: Wild: Rummy Edition
description: Rummy game with a 75-card deck, consisting of: the 52 standard cards; 13 quadrate cards bearing a rank and all four suits, with the effective suit determined by the roll of a special die; and ten wild cards.

title: Regency
description:
Game for 2 to 4 players which combines strategy with a setting of medieval war and intrigue among the Scottish clans.

You are a Clan Chief trying for the regency of Scotland. You can attack other peoples pieces,  depending on whose territory you attack them in they could be injured, captured or killed. Along with attempting to gain the crown, and sabotaging your rivals attempts, you must also try not to get cursed by the witch, for then your lineage would end with your current Heir.

title: Hi-Spot
description:
A game for 2-4, where players place tiles of clear plastic with dots on them on a playing board with nine positions. Each turn the player can place a tile in a clear position, or over the stacked tiles in an filled position provided that the dots on the tile do not overlap those on the tiles already played. Once all 9 possible dots are placed in each position the stacked tiles are removed for reuse and the position is cleared for new tile placements. Points are awarded to the player after each turn based on the number of dots in the position that the tile was placed. The first player to score 200 points wins the game.

Identical in materials but different in rules is Topminos.

title: Slip Disc
types: Action / Dexterity Children's Game Electronic Puzzle
description: A motorized Disc-Dealer releases 40 shaped discs two at a time which players attempt to match up to the 9 shapes in their board quadrant.  The first player to match all 9 shapes wins.

title: Starfarers of Catan: 5-6 Player Expansion
types: Civilization Expansion for Base-game Exploration Negotiation Science Fiction
description:
This expansion contains everything you need to include two additional players in Starfarers of Catan, the exciting, fast moving, science fiction game.  Here you'll find 2 mother ships, 2 sets of playing pieces, additional cards, 2 reusable gameboard overlays, and a new alien race ripe for encounter.

Now you can play one of five or six Starfarers commissioned to explore the galaxy, build new colonies, and expand commercial ties with the various races of the Galactic Council.  Accept the challenge!  Careful diplomacy, clever trade, a firm stance against pirates, and the bold colonization of distant planetary systems will win you the support of humanity and the other races of the galaxy and make you the Council's Galactic Ambassador!

Expands:

     Starfarers of Catan




Belongs to the Catan Series.

title: Catan: Cities & Knights – 5-6 Player Extension
description:
Now up to six players can muster their knights against the scourge threatening Catan!  The 5-6 Player Expansion for The Cities and Knights of Catan allows you to expand and inject more excitement into your games without sacrificing ease of play.  Designed for five or six players, it adds even more drama to the award-winning game of culture, politics, and warfare.

Belongs to the Catan Series.

Expands (all are required):

    Catan
    Catan: 5-6 Player Extension
    Catan: Cities & Knights




Microbadges

  Buy One

title: Catan: Seafarers – 5-6 Player Extension
types: Civilization Expansion for Base-game Exploration Nautical Negotiation
description:
Now five to six players can sail into the uncharted and explore and settle the mysterious islands near Catan!  The 5-6 Player Expansion for The Seafarers of Catan allows you to add 1-2 more opponents without sacrificing ease of play.  Try one of ten new exciting scenarios! Designed for 5-6 players, it adds even more drama to the award-winning game of seafaring, exploration, and trade.

Belongs to the Catan Series.
This game requires The Settlers of Catan, The Settlers of Catan 5/6 player extension,and the Seafarers 3-4 expansion (http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgameexpansion/325/catan-seafarers) to play.  Ideally, using the same publisher and edition of the game.

title: Sssnake
description: Players each try to be the first to build a complete snake, connecting the head and tail of the snake printed on their large start tiles.  On a player's turn he rolls a special die and plays one or more small tiles showing snake body parts to either his own snake or to his left-hand neighbor's snake.  How many tiles he plays and to which snake he plays the tiles depends on the roll of the special die.  The body tiles can contain turns, crossovers, and twists which can extend the distance your neighbor needs to cover to complete his snake.  But if the tile you select to play on your neighbor can't fit, it comes back to you!

title: Big Bucks Baseball
description:
Not a stats based game and not a replay game. Teams are fictional and can be built based on fixed points or amount of money the team has. Players are of three average, good, exceptional and cost different amounts of money to hire. 
Money can either be a fixed amount in pick up games, or using the advanced economy rules, can be obtained from running concessions and selling broadcasting rights.

The dual-fold, multi-color game board folds for easy storage. Each comes with three teams of ten sculptured ABS figurines, each with individually stenciled numbers. A designated hitter is included on each team. Since the whole family can play BIG BUCKS BASEBALL, one set of figurines is female.

The game also includes 3 special challenging dice, 32 player upgrade snap rings, 12 ball/strike markers, 10 concession/broadcast replicas, 2 miniature game baseballs, 90 pieces of currency, 32 special event cards, 2 reproducible score sheets, and a complete instruction booklet and quick start guide. All of this is packaged in a compact 10-inch by 10-inch durable game box.

The game uses a unique system of roulette type spinner based on batter and pitcher's experience (3 levels) to determine the outcome of each pitch. Once a pitch is hit the defensive team can still field the ball using a system of color coded dice. Careful through, failing the fielding roll will increase the effectiveness of the hit (error). Also there are event cards such as injuries and automatic player upgrades (having a good night) which influence the game randomly.

title: Ipswich
description:
The play consists of forming interlocking words, crossword fashion on a board, using letter tiles. In each of five rounds players compete for high score by forming words on a crossword puzzle pattern on individual game boards, taking advantage of letter usage points and bonus words.

In rounds after the first, the board is passed to other players, so that each one is building on the partial crosswords of another player's previous rounds.

title: Gamblers Golf
description: The game consists of a playing board layout of a typical 18-hole championship golf course. A tee marker is moved along the course to indicate the number of strokes (rolls of the dice) a player has taken to hole out. Twenty-five chips are given to each player at the start of the game, and these are given up as a player fails to keep their ball on track, eventually being won by whoever has the low score for the game. Also included are 3 dice and a pad of golf scorecards. The score is kept for each player as in golf.

title: Capitol Rummy
description:
53 Cards represent the 50 States, Washington DC and the states of Confusion and Ecstasy.

The object is to go out by laying down sets of 3 cards, where all the cards are adjacent states. The first person to rid their hand of all cards ends the round and points are scored. Play is to 500.

title: Snapshot
description: Players / Teams try to identify what is shown in the black and white pictures that are revealed one section at a time.

title: Supremacy: Field Marshall's Handbook
types: Expansion for Base-game Modern Warfare Wargame
description:
84-page handbook for Supremacy players.  Five sections:

1) Questions and Answers - FAQ for rules clarifications / errata
2) Rule Variants - Adds rules for convoys  escorts, multi-theater attacks, rocket technology, etc.
3) Strategy and Tactics
4) Rules for a Two-Player Game
5) Tournament Rules

Expands:

    Supremacy

title: Word Checkers
description: Players play a game of checkers with letter cubes.  Every time a move is made, the player can score points by forming words using the cube that was moved, and he can change the letter of that cube to help facilitate this.  The object of the game is to score the most points, and this occurs in two ways: forming words and winning the checkers match.

title: Across the Continent
description:
Each player draws a list of cities that they must visit, in sequence, which starts and ends at a particular city.  Players roll the dice and move along their chosen routes to reach their target cities.  Every time they throw doubles they must draw a card.  Most cards have a question about a state capitol that rewards the player for answering correctly, or punishes them for answering incorrectly.  Occasionally the cards have no question but just advance the player's car to the next destination.  The first player to reach all of their cities and return home is the winner.

Originally published 1890 (patent no. 469089), re-released by Parker 1901, 1910, 1922, 1952.

This game may well have been the inspiration for the later games Pirate and Traveler, Boxcars and Rail Baron.

title: In The Dark
description: Connect Four with a twist: the balls are kept hidden from both players, so they must try to remember which colored balls are where.  When a player thinks they have four in a row, they pull the lever that drops the balls into sight.  If they are right, they score a point.  If they are wrong, their opponent scores a point.  The first player to eight points wins.

title: Man O' War: Plague Fleet
types: Expansion for Base-game Fantasy Miniatures Nautical Wargame
description:
The first of two expansion sets for Man O' War, Plague Fleet brings the chaos fleets into play: Nurgle, Tzeentch and the rest.

Expands:

    Man O' War




[From the game manual]
