For Gloriana to win, she must reach the Holy City or totally rout Aemulatio's minions; for Aemulatio to win, her forces need only capture Gloriana (even if Aemulatio and her Necromancers are all dead, which would be a very odd outcome).

A six-sided die (not included) is required to resolve combat, and also to allow the Necromancers to cast one spell with random effects once per turn, and the Guardians to cast one spell each of Mind and Magic per turn.

The lurid cover art by R. P. Dick Winther, seems intent on evoking both Silver Age comics and 1940s pulp magazine covers, but falls far short of Excalibre's self-proclaimed Beautiful graphics and detail. A gargoyle is seizing a terrified Gloriana by the thigh, and appears to be wrestling her atop a rock... but closer inspection of the lower left corner of the cover reveals a second, smaller gargoyle in flight, and the space between it and Gloriana is filled with ant-sized fighting men. Presumably the main figures are meant to be aloft, though you'd never know it to look at them, making this cover one of the worst examples of the classically bad game art of the 1970s.

title: Yugioh! Hexors Collectible Battle Tile Game
description:
Hexors are a new collectible battle-tile game that features 75 pieces to collect and battle. The starter set includes 10 Hexors, a Game Mat, Instruction Booklet, 6 Glass Beads, Chains and Dice. Collect an army of monsters to clash in the Arena! Collide with enemy Hexors to battle and corner your opponent as you unleash monsters and magic to win!
Uses a very basic gameplay mechanism utilizing elementary math.  Involves elements of strategy and luck.

title: Citadel
mechanisms: Grid MovementModular BoardSecret Unit DeploymentVariable Player Powers
description:
Two-player adventure game set in a six-level citadel represented by six square-grid maps. One player takes the side of the forces of evil and places doors, monsters, pitfalls, sinkholes, and a talisman in the citadel. The other player takes the side of the forces of good and begins sending heroes into the citadel. The evil player must kill all the heroes to win; for the good player to win, a hero must capture the talisman and escape from the citadel.

Counters are provided for all citadel components and heroes, but miniatures can be used instead. Playing time is a guess.

title: Warlocks & Warriors
description:
Introductory fantasy board game in which players choose to be either a warlock or a warrior, start off on the board's movement track, cast spells at each other (which consist only of move an opponent a certain number of spaces), and try to be the first to conduct the princess to her castle at the end of the track despite the numerous perils along the way. (The fairy tales don't talk about would-be rescuers having bloody fights over who gets to take the princess back to her castle, but oh well.)

Playing time is a guess.

For 2 to 6 players Ages 8 and up.

title: Empire 1
description: Heavy-duty strategic SF wargame; doesn't have a lot of components (it can fit inside a large Ziploc style bag), but is still extremely involved. Four empires -- Antares, Crate Armada, Chroma Raphael, and Star Concord -- engage in a major interstellar war. Game rules cover space and ground combat, exploration of new systems, economic development, ship and planetary-shield construction, troop recruiting, the whole nine yards. Four different winning conditions are suggested: (1) the last surviving player; (2) the first player to control more than 50% of the star systems on the map; (3) the strongest player after a set number of turns; or (4) the strongest player after a set time limit (they recommend five hours).

title: Worlds of Heroes & Tyrants: Hell Card Expansion #3 – The Maze
description:
Yet another 40 cards for WHAT.  The WHAT: Hell expansion board is also required.

Expands:

    Worlds of Heroes & Tyrants

title: Worlds of Heroes & Tyrants Card Expansion #2: Secrets of The Cataclysm
types: Adventure Expansion for Base-game Fantasy Fighting
description:
Second card-pack expansion for the World of Heroes and Tyrants board game. Consists of a new character (Liz, starts in Flint, IN 5 FT 7 ST 4 DX 11 HP 50 SB 19, advantage is to start the game with one item), ten Spell cards, ten Item cards, and fifteen Quest cards.

This expansion's designer is uncredited but is presumably Bruce P. Dowrie, designer of the main game.

Expands:

    Worlds of Heroes & Tyrants

title: Worlds of Heroes & Tyrants: Hell
description:
An 11x17 add-on board for Worlds of Heroes  Tyrants (WHAT).  It adds 14 new areas, 4 new characters, plus new quests, encounter cards and more

Expands:

    Worlds of Heroes & Tyrants

title: Worlds of Heroes & Tyrants: Hell Card Expansion #2 – Anger Management
description:
Yet another 40 cards for WHAT.  The WHAT: Hell expansion board is also required.

Expands:

    Worlds of Heroes & Tyrants

title: Worlds of Heroes & Tyrants: Hell Card Expansion #1 – Alone
description:
Forty additional cards for WHAT (the WHAT: Hell expansion board is required as well).

Expands:

    Worlds of Heroes & Tyrants

title: snip
description: Players attempt to flick their logs across the board. Logs that don't find their way into the grooves are removed from the board. If you get all your pieces on the board and one or more of your logs across to the other end you win the game.

title: Die Flößerei
description: You move around the board to cut down trees, then use the river to transport the logs to the cities and sell them.

title: Prisma
description: In one of Knizia's earliest published works, players try to form the best Poker hands in a square, one player tallying from top to bottom, the other from side to side.

title: Schachjagd
description: A kind of Pachisi with 3 pawns for each color (4 Players)and a die with all chess symbols on it. Throw the Die - move one your pawns around the parcour. One obstacle can be moved to attempt to block your opponents.

title: Burgenland
description: This is the wooden version of Terra Turrium or the oldest forerunner of Torres (game of the year 2000). It was published 1986 by ABRA in a very beautiful wooden version.

title: Pirate Inc.
description:
Hunt for the treasure of Treasure Island by R.L. Stevenson - two players try to evaluate the exact coordinates of this treasure.
There are 2 treasure charts - 1 player knows the latitude, the other the longitude of the buried chests on Treasure Island. They both land at the same time and spy on each other in order to try and find out the other's secret.

title: This Hallowed Ground
description:
This Hallowed Ground is game with area movement like Risk. The map is covering the whole territory where the most battles have taken place

There are three levels of troop quality among infantry: recruit, veteran, elite. You can upgrade your troops by winning the battle. Four Turns are one year. Each turn you roll for command points to determine how much you can do.

There are a variety of naval units in the game: riverboats, troop transports, raiders, frigates, ironclads, and cruisers.

The beauty of the game are the many plastic pieces.

Its a very light Civil war game ( a kind of mixture of A HOUSE DIVIDED and AXIS and Allies)

title: Tic Tac Dice
description: Players roll two dice, and may keep none, one, or both of them.  After two rolls, the number must be entered on the scoresheet in one of sixteen cells.  A 7 is entered as an X and prohibits scoring in that row or column.  A 2 OR 12 is a wild roll, and any number may be entered.  After all the cells are filled, points are scored according to the combination of numbers in each roll, column, and diagonal.  The player with the most points wins the game.

title: Am Rande des Gletschers
description:
Ice age glaciers push their way over the land and bury most food. Try to make your clan survive. Send out your hunters and  herb gatherers. When the time comes for the Great Meeting of Clans, you may become the best of all clan chiefs.

Components:

110 cards:
-4 Cave cards
-20 Clan cards 
-60 Hunt cards 
-24 Fate cards
-2 chip cards

title: Sambesi
description:
It is hot at the Sambesi river.
The elephant Diboo goes to the river to satisfy his thirst, but when he bends down to drink is he frightened seeing another elephant in the water.
The other animals quickly calm him down by asking him if he doesn't recognize his own image.

Can you find the correct mirror images of all the animals?

title: Navigation
description: Navigation is a race game, for 2 players,  using tiles to successfully complete a missile attack on an enemy base. Using tiles with lines on them, one must create a connected path form start to finish.  First player to the finish line wins.

title: Plus One
types: Abstract Strategy Electronic Maze Memory Puzzle
description: Plus One, the 4-sided electronic computer, remembers every flip, every flop. You and your opponent alternately tumble Plus One down an invisible path on the gameboard by adding one move every turn. The course... of course... gets longer and more difficult with every turn! Listen to Plus One's guiding tones and watch its color caps for clues. But stray from the path and Plus One gives you the razz... you've lost! Plus One is the 4-sided electronic computer with the one-track mind. Give it a tumble for unforgettable fun! It's very much like a board game version of Simon in which you move a pyramid shaped electronic device around a triangular board.

title: When Darkness Comes: The Horror Within
mechanisms: Co-operative PlayModular BoardRole PlayingRoll / Spin and MoveTile Placement
description: This is the first expansion for When Darkness Comes.  It focuses on the world of shape shifters and lycanthrope and features additional rules and scenarios, four additional map tiles and two additional miniatures. It also contains part two of the GM campaign.

title: When Darkness Comes: Hell Unleashed
mechanisms: Co-operative PlayModular BoardRole PlayingRoll / Spin and MoveTile Placement
description: This is the second expansion for When Darkness Comes.  It features additional rules and scenarios, more encounter disks and two additional miniatures. Also contains part three of the GM campaign.

title: The Great Invasion: The Gettysburg Campaign June 24 – July 3, 1863
description:
THE GREAT INVASION is a two player, division/corps level strategic game covering Lee's second invasion of the North in June/July 1863.

The game has alternate player moves, representing both the strategic moves and the tactical allocation of units during combat. As units take their losses their combat strength declines and they will become ineffective. 
The game is ten turns in length. Victory is determined by the Victory Option chosen by the CS player and victory points obtained by each player during the play of the game.

The game map depicts the theater of operations from Harper's Ferry to Harrisburg. The map is divided into into forty six areas to regulate movement. 
Combat also takes place within these areas. The map also depicts the terrain in the theater of operations including mountains, mountain passes, rivers and defensible terrain all of which affect movement and combat.

Playing pieces represent Confederate infantry divisions, Union Infantry Corps and the Cavalry Brigades  of both sides. Artillery strengths are built into the infantry units.

title: Chauvinist Pigs
types: Bluffing Deduction Humor Memory Party Game Trivia
description:
The game that finally resolves the Battle of the Sexes.

Hey Guys!  Do you know all the stuff that guys are supposed to know about cars, sports and the stock market?  Hey girls!  Do you know your way around a sewing machine?  Are you a queen of the culinary arts?  You'll find out in Chauvinist Pigs, the game that lets you slice and dice the opposite sex with your all-around knowledge of the male and female lore.

OBJECT
Be the team with the most chips in their piggy banks after each player in the game has selected and read two questions for his or her team.

title: FS Chess Football: A Thinking Fan's Game
description: Game pieces of different speeds, power, and abilities are strategically positioned and moved to play a chess like football game.  The plays occur in stages.  A small and soft ball is tossed and kicked with the fingers.  The game is played within the box that it comes in, and the sides of the box keep the ball from easily leaving the playing area.  Sand timers are included if the participants want to speed up play.

title: WildWords
description:
Played somewhat like the classic Scrabble, but every word in English can be played (no matter how long).

There are many more possibilities than in the classic, so you are never left with little to think about. Also, your play becomes a puzzle for your opponent and bluffing is part of the game.

An Windows Internet Version to play against a friend is available.

title: Dice Deck
description:
This game consists of four dice and a deck of special cards.  They come in three suits (blue, green, red) and range from 2 to 12 in value.  The frequencies vary (one each of 2, 3, 11, and 12; two each of 4, 5, 9, 10 and three each of 6, 7, and 8).

There are rules for ten games.  Two family games: Cancellation and Dice Deck Rummy, two children's games: Give And Take and Crazy Dice, two casino games (you will have to supply the betting chips): Three Card Down and Make My Point, two strategy games: Pathfinder and Admiral, and two solitary games: Dice Deck Bingo and Stack 'Em Up.

To give but one example, in Dice Deck Rummy you are dealt 8 cards.  On your turn, you draw a card from the stock or the top discard.  You then roll two dice.  You can play any sets of the number rolled (two or more cards of that value), or any runs (three or more same color cards that follow each other in sequence) that end or begin with the number rolled (counting the dice as an extra card).  Finally you discard.  You can also freely increase played sets and runs on your turn.  First player to go out scores the total value remaining in the other players' hands.

Dice Deck is similar to the Deck of Dice

title: Trial of the Century
description:
A humorous spoof of the legal system, the media, and law  order. Players (as lawyers for the prosecution or defence) attempt to win their case while hindering the case of the other players. The humour comes from the illustrations, and the game mechanics.

[ed: doesn't say this on the box] Based on the O.J. Simpson-trial.

title: Winchester
description:
Winchester is a race game where the players score points by getting their pawns around a rectangular track the fastest. Each player gets 3 to 5 pawns (based on the number of players) which are placed on a 4 by 4 starting grid.  The track is four squares wide. During the setup, the players randomly cover some of these squares with wooden blocks to provide obstacles that prevent movement. The location of the blocks is determined by several die rolls.  This random setup provides for a different track each race.

Movement of the players' pawns is controlled by a special six sided chess die. The die contains the six basic chess pieces: King, Queen, Rook, Bishop, Knight and Pawn. Each turn a player will roll the chess die to determine everyone's move for that turn.  Once all players have moved, the next player on the left rolls the die for the next round. When moving, the player must move one of his pieces based on the indicated chess piece.  Like chess, the player may not move off the edge of the board or over one of the obstacles, except for the knight move.  If the player captures one of the piece of another player, the two pieces exchange positions.

The first piece to cross the finish line scores 15 points with each successive piece scoring one less (14, 13, 12, etc).  There are small bonuses for certain finishing conditions (first to have all pieces finish, three positions in a row, etc).

The game comes with a rolled up, laminated board, 25 pawns, 24 wooden blocks for obstacles, one normal die and one chess die.

title: The Buntu Circus
description:
The Buntu Circus was independently published by a group of UK gamers calling themselves The Buntu Circus. It is an abstract strategy game for 2 to 4 players. The board is divided into a 14 x 14 grid. Each square has a combination of one of eight colours and one of twelve symbols, arranged in a symmetrical pattern on the board.

A deck of cards has one card per square on the board, matching colour and symbol. Each player gets a hand of eight cards and a set of counters and rubber hoops in their own colour. These are metallic colours, distinct from the board colours.

In turn each player draws and then plays a card from their hand, placing or removing a counter on one of the appropriate squares on the board - each colour and symbol combination appears in two places on the board, and has two cards which can match.

The idea is to get a number of linked rows of five counters in your colour, orthogonally and/or diagonally. The target number of rows depends on the number of players - five in a two player game and less if there are more players. Once a row has been formed, it is designated by placing hoops over each of the counters in the row.

There are couple of further wrinkles. Most importantly are the power colours. At the start, each player has power in a single board colour, determined randomly. This allows the player to use a card of that colour to move an counter on the board (their own or another player's) either to an adjacent square of that colour or from a square of that colour to an adjacent square. Creating a row of five gains the player power over the colour of the middle square of the row - this is marked by removing the central counter from its hoop and placing it on one of the power colour markers to the side of the board. In this way players gain power over new colours. If another player already has power in that colour, their power is removed - but the player who gained power merely displaces them - they do not gain power in the colour. Gaining power over a colour in which you already have power reinforces power in the colour. The player hoops the power counter and this prevents any other player from gaining a row that would give them power in that colour. In effect they have a lock on that colour. A final wrinkle comes with the discard piles. Played cards can be discard to one of four face-up piles. Once one of the four draw decks is exhausted, the adjacent discard pile is turned over - but not shuffled. This allows long-term strategies of stacking the deck with particular colours or symbols.

The quality of the components is superb. The board is big and colourful, the symbols clear and distinct. The player's counters are chunky plastic discs which come in little cannisters like pill-boxes. The hoops are rubber-like rings which come in individual cloth bags. Very satisfying to hoop your rows with.

title: Maremba
description:
A tactical game of skill and strategy

The board is 10x10 (1 inch squares), with the inner 4x4 squares replaced by a 10x10 grid of smaller squares.  The whole thing is in the middle of an octagon, with the edges used for storage of the 80 colored pegs.

Each player starts with ten pegs of a color.  Each player places a peg in turn in the inner grid.  You are eliminated if: a) you have two pegs (of your color) in the same row, column or diagonal; b) you take more than a minute to place a peg; or c) you seek help from a non-player!  Once the inner grid is complete, play continues/repeats with the outer grid (you remove a peg from the inner grid and place it in the outer).

Optionally, the last player can try to finish placing all 80 pegs whilst respecting the exclusion rule.

Note that the outer grid is actually harder to solve because of the 4x4 hole in its middle.

title: Silk Road
description:
Japanese language game of trade on the Silk Road from Asia to Italy. Players buy goods at one location and sell them at a different location.

Out of print.

title: Fill 'er Up!
description:
The object of the game is to get the cars back on the road.

Fix flat tires, help lost travelers, tow stuck cars! Draw a help-me card from the deck and match it to the all-fixed card at the friendly service station. Each time a problem is solved, one player advances her service station dial, and the other player puts the matched pair back on the road. The game ends when all the problems are solved, all the cars are back on the road, and all the players have happy cars showing on their service station dials.

title: Horse Sense
description: Be the first player to collect ten horses of one breed and you win. You can collect Thoroughbreds, Arabians, Clydesdales, Tennessee Walkers, and Quarter Horses. You can buy horses from the band when it is your turn, and can make trades with other players. Players also will have different horse-related careers throughout the game, allowing you to collect horses and receive income.

title: Monster Mash I
description:
Players choose a character and travel on a random board made of individual tiles. They face monsters which re-spawn until monster generators are destroyed. Monster generation and combat are resolved by rolling dice.

Goals vary with the type of game selected. In a cooperative games and solo play, players must get rid of all monsters. In death match, players must kill each other and are only eliminated when killed by another player.

(This is the new name for the Ultra Vilelence Box Set. There are some rule improvements)

Each expansion comes with two unique player characters, monsters and their generators, items, traps and encounters. All components include (8) 6.25 x 6.25 tiles laid out on a 1 inch to 5 foot scale and (150+) die cut pieces; all in full-color.

Integrates with:

    Cthulhu Mash for a 5-8 player game.

title: Eskimemo
description:
Memory game with plastic igloos, cardboard Inuit, and a die.

The first player to hide all of their Inuit in the igloos wins.

Each player rolls a die and then puts as many igloos on his or her Inuit as the number on the die.  Because the igloos are so small, you can only fit one Inuk in every igloo.  And, of course, there are never enough igloos to go around.  Luckily, you can steal already occupied igloos from the other players once your igloos are full.

If a player rolls a special symbol on the die, they can switch two igloos around -- just to confuse everybody.

title: Banana Republic
mechanisms: Roll / Spin and MoveVariable Player PowersVoting
description:
Banana Republic. A small nation. Somewhere. Nestling between the mountains and the sea. Consisting of six provinces, each with a unique topography, character and culture. And each with its own REBEL LEADER, consumed and driven by ambition. A country struggling for unity after a long and peacefully ignominious colonial past, but, more often than not, torn apart by ethnic differences and personal ambition. Not to mention its neighbors, sometimes meddling in its affairs, and sometimes being manipulated and bullied by the Republics leaders. 
At the start of the game each player is the REBEL LEADER of one of the provinces.

THE POLITICS: Invariably chaotic. Each province has its own REBEL LEADER, jockeying for power. The Prize: The Presidency!

At the center is THE PRESIDENT in his palace, attempting to hang on to power! His aim, and therefore the ultimate aim of each of the REBEL LEADERS: to become PRESIDENT FOR LIFE!

THE MEANS: Recruit soldiers, and arm them for those inevitable ARMED CHALLENGES.

Perform public works programs such as building roads, schools, hospitals etc. with the sole aim of buying sorry gathering tax-paying voters for those crucial ELECTIONS.

Manage political scenarios by means of multiple choice Monkey Puzzle cards.

And out of left field come Natural Disasters, sometimes with devastating consequences.

The game is a humorous simulation of the political dynamics of a small country. Not a deep strategy game, but certainly a fun game with lots of player interaction.

title: Weed Wars: On Higher Ground
mechanisms: Commodity SpeculationRole PlayingRoll / Spin and Move
description: The object of the game is for the first person to make a million dollars by growing, harvesting and trafficking different strains of marijuana.  It is a highly interactive game, giving players the opportunity to hinder another opponent's financial progress.  This game does not endorse the use, sale or cultivation of marijuana, however is a fantasy of a different life, lived by some and to others only ever read about in the papers and seen on TV.  This is the first of a series of patented games brought to the world by Nyte Tyme Enterprises Inc., with the idea of representing alternative lifestyles in play, and offering an opportunity to be someone that you either never wanted to be, or never had the opportunity to become.  Weed Wars - On Higher Ground is a factual representation of the trials and tribulations of characters involved in all aspects of the marijuana industry and culture.

title: Lindy, the New Flying Game
description:
Created to commemorate the famous 1927 first solo flight over the Atlantic. Similar to Touring, there were 99 cards, 51 of them mileage and 48 of the move and event type.

Headwinds kept you from playing the 500 mile cards. Beside obvious disasters like running out of fuel, you had to deal with ripped fabric and broken propellers. There were no equivalents to things like puncture proof tires and extra gas.

Box cover shows a plane flying across the ocean.

A similar game called The Lindy Flying Game by Nucraft Toys came out in the same year and was apparently the subject of a lawsuit by Nucraft against Parker Bros which the latter won. This caused the Nucraft game to have a far more limited production  the company ended in 1928 after having changed the game to CRASH, THE NEW AIRPLANE GAME  and thus their game is far more valuable to collectors today.

title: The Lindy Flying Game
description:
Card game similar to Touring was published in a form fitting box with 75 cards:  39 mileage, 10 take off, 10 weather, 15 hazards and 1 Lucky Lindy.  Based on the historic flight of the same year, hazards include forced landing, storm,  fog, engine trouble, etc.

Inventor was a flier in the US Navy and also made gliders and models.

Came out in the same year as the similar game Lindy, the New Flying Game by Parker Bros., apparently the subject of a lawsuit by Nucraft against Parker Bros which the latter won. This caused the Nucraft game to have a far more limited production and thus their game is far more valuable to collectors today. 

     Not so sure about this interpretation. A note on the rules for
     Nucraft's game Crash game indicate that Parker Brothers bought
     the rights to the Lindy game from Nucraft. So it would seem
     that Parker bought out Nucraft and shelved their version of
     the game.



After the lawsuit Nucraft issued a different game called Crash, The New Airplane Game. It seems to be a Parcheesi type game played with three planes per color and a four color spinner.

Nucraft Toys ended in 1933 when the company started operating under the name of its founder Paul K. Guillow.  The company Paul K. Guillow did not produce any games.

title: Warchon
description:
From the game's description:

This new concept in gaming can be played anywhere and uses two main components. A book that replaces hex maps and game boards (and includes the rules and scenarios to boot). And play marks (i.e. book markers) for two armies to do battle as they move through the pages of the book. 
Nothing else is needed, not dice, not even a playing surface!

In this Playmark Book Game (PBG) players become Warchons - battlelords fighting for domination of the continent of Sygillis.

You'll build and control the forces of the holy warriors of the Celestine Order or the foul creatures of the Azuthkan Horde. Cast spells, combat in various terrain and survive random events, all while vying for the title of Grand Warchon!

title: Früchtchen
description: A odd filler-type game with lots of little colored dice.  Each player tries to harvest fruit, and the interesting mechanism is that some of the dice you roll are given to others other players, and this can help you. Of all the Fanfor games, this is one of the more approachable ones.

title: Hand Drauf!
description: A simple card-based memory game. 21 cards showing two hand images in various colors are spread out on the table. On his turn, a player rolls a die and covers a hand image of the matching color. If he covers the last uncovered image on a card, he must announce the color of the other, previously covered, image. If he's correct, he gets the card as a point. If not, his turn ends and the next player takes his turn. Play continues until only 5 cards are left. Most cards won wins the game.

title: Boundary
description: Abstract war/strategy game. Each player has one row of pieces deployed at one side of an 8x9 grid. An elastic band divides the board. Pieces move vertically and horizontally with the objective of placing one piece in the opponents back row. The gimmick is pieces can be eliminated by stretching the elastic band (the boundary) around an opponents piece(s) which eliminates that piece and causes the boundary to change (as that piece is removed from play).

title: Run Hippy! Run! The Boardgame
types: Card Game Dice Economic Environmental Humor Political
mechanisms: Hand ManagementRoll / Spin and MoveSet CollectionTrading
description:
Run Hippy! Run!The Boardgame is the game of capitalism let loose on the globe. As a Captain of Industry, you will exploit the people and resources of the world to advance your corporation, all the while plotting to crush any dissent.

Gameplay consists of moving around a board and collecting profitable Corporate Misconduct Cards and costly (but useful) Tactic Cards. Use your Tactic Cards to catch and crush that spirit of dissent, the Hippy.

The entire game is available FREE in 4 PDFs through the Puzzling Evidence website (see link below).

title: Tour Mala!s
description: A meticulously hand-produced bike racing game with great but delicate components.  Beyond that, can't say much because I don't have a rules translation though I'm working on it.

title: K-Tel Superstar Game: The Original Rock 'n Roll Music Game
description: Players are rock stars and collect gold records to win.  Roll dice to spiral in the player counters from the start to end square on the board.  Squares have events for players to collect or lose money or release an album, which may turn out to be a hit, a dud, or break-even.  Game comes with a 45 RPM which must be played when any album is released.  A random track determines the success of the album.

title: Loser
description: LOSER is a party game where players move around the board based on their responses to questions about bad behavior, bad judgment, and just plain bad luck.  The colors on the board and the roll of the dice add an element of Loser's Luck to the game.  A social game with lots of embarrassing storytelling.  Because we've all done things we're not proud of.

title: Waldesfrust
description: One of the Fanfor Big Box games (along with Brauerei, Geweihte Steine, Neues Land, and ITC), this one dealing with environmental issues. Each player has two roles to play - one must protect the environment while the other must fell the trees for profit.  This general idea was used later (and a bit better) in Visjes by Cwali (also called Ocean). Multiple scoring options and generally good ideas but marginal game play.

title: Articulation
description:
Articulation is a word game that can be played either individually or in teams.

The five categories in the game are slang, jargon, word origins, spelling, and vocabulary. The cards, except spelling, are multiple-choice.

In Articulation, the player with the best vocabulary will not always win The game has been designed to provide a level playing field. Duel squares, stop squares, and free roll squares are but some of the equalizing factors in Articulation.

title: Coolympics
description:
The north pole animals hold their own athletic contests.

Intended for children Ages 5 and up.

title: Notable Quotables
description: A trivia game where gameplay is extremely similar to 'Trivial Pursuit'. Main difference is all questions deal with quotes made by famous people. All questions are multiple choice, and players must 'fill in the blank' from a quote read from the question card.

title: Election Day
mechanisms: Hand ManagementLine DrawingPartnershipsSecret Unit DeploymentVariable Player Powers
description:
Election Day is a card game where you, the candidate, are attempting to collect the votes of as many special interest groups as possible.  Cards are played face-up during your turn in an area called your caucus.  Here all candidates can see your vote tallies.  It is possible to split votes or use special cards to effect the number of votes in your opponents caucus.

The endgame begins when a candidate plays the Polls Open card.  Now the game will end when ANY player plays the Polls Closed.

It should be noted that Election Day is a parody game.  And the humor concerning the special interest groups can be very sharp.  Jabs are taken at Big Business and the Tobacco Industry.  The recount card comes with a tourism logo for the state of Florida.

Election Day was designed by Ed Evans for Alien Menace Games for 2-4 players Ages 13 and up.

title: Life is Money
description:
From the rules...

Idea of the game:  
Oh, if only I were richer. Oh, if only I could find the right one for me. Oh, what destiny do the stars hold for me. Which path should I take? This one or that? Or, is an even balance the path to eternal happiness?  
In Life is Money, each player has the option of playing points in different areas of life. However, as in real life, most decisions are influenced by the actions of others.  
  
Goal of the game:  
To gain as many points as possible (varies according to the number of players) in the different areas of life. Whoever has the most points at the end of the game wins.

Players try to earn and spend money to gain victory points in various areas of life (Work, Education, Relationships, Spiritual Well-being, Status Symbols). You need to balance your investments in order to maximize your score.

title: Mein Lieber Biber
types: Action / Dexterity Animals Children's Game Racing
description: In this game, the players try to earn wooden sticks by advancing colored beavers on spaces of matching color. The board is set on balance on a wooden piece. When moving a beaver, you have to carefully choose the right one, so as to not let the board fall.

title: Dice Kwon Do
types: Action / Dexterity Adventure Children's Game Dice Fighting Sports
description: A fast-paced martial arts game for 2 players. Takes 10 minutes to learn  play for hours of enjoyment. In each game you can win, lose or draw. A match is won when one of the players wins 2 games.

title: Rays of Light
description:
In Rays of Light, each player sets up colored chips and chips representing mirrors on their grid, which is hidden from their opponent, much like in Battleship.  The object is to guess what your opponent's grid looks like, by shooting imaginary light rays into the grid.  Your opponent will tell you where on the grid the light exited, and what color it was.  Using this information, you try to recreate your opponent's grid before he does the same.

Rays of Light could be described as a combination of Battleship and Black Box.

title: The White Flame
description: The White Flame is a scenario pack for the Star Trek Starship Combat Game which details the exploits of the Emperor's own 123rd Assault Flotilla. This Klingon Battle Group patrols the uneasy border of Klingon, Federation, and Romulan space. Included are unit history, organization, personalities, and combat readiness, as well as fifteen scenarios, pitting the White Flame against Orion, Romulan, and Federation opponents in a series of deadly encounters.

title: Gamer Tycoon
description:
Take the reins of your very own game company and prove you have what it takes to make it big in this easy to learn and fast to play card game.

This is an ultra simple non-collectible card game where you play cards out of your hand that represent games you want to publish in several categories.  You pay money to publish the games, and then collect money as long as you can keep them on the market.  Random event cards and such are thrown in for added fun.

All of the cards are humorous parodies, such as Galaxy Rules Battles (Who needs miniatures when we're just going to argue?), Custer's Greatest Triumphs, Eighth Reich, and Goths: The Wandering.

title: Golden Goal
description:
Golden Goal simulates a Soccer World ChampionShip in which each player is a country. A player is going to play twice against every opponent. A single match consists of a few throws of special dice (with 5 black sides and 1 ball side). In addition, one can play special cards (penalty, goalie, etc...) to modify the number of goals.
This game is very convivial and is best played with 6 players.

title: The Voyage of the Mayflower
description:
From the back of the box description:

Sail with the Pilgrims in 1620 across the storm-tossed Atlantic as they seek their new home in America. Make another journey next year with ships bearing new settlers and supplies for the hard-pressed colony. Storms, ice, fog, pirates and uncertainty will make for an exciting voyage as you race to land your life-saving supplies.

Designed for 1-4 players Ages 10 and up, The Voyage of the Mayflower also has a unique solo version. The 8-page Game Book includes the rules of play, the story of the voyage, life aboard ship, a list of supplies and provisions, and educational notes. Also included is a decorative frameable print of the Mayflower passenger list.

title: el Juego de las Diez Pistas
types: Card Game Deduction Dice Party Game Trivia Word Game
description: There are 360 cards divided into 4 categories: Places, People, Nature and Objects with 10 clues each and a word that corresponds to the clues. Each category has their own color. And there are a dice with colors instead of numbers and pawns. First player rolls the dice and get a color. The player on the right takes a card from that color and reads the first 3 clues so other player tries to guess the word if so player advances 3 tiles on the gameboard, if not player reads next 3 clues and tries again, this time if player guesses the word he advances 2 tiles, if not player reads the final 3 and the other player tries to find the hidden word, if so player advances 1 tile if not the other player reads the last clue, if player answers correctly does not advance with his pawn but keeps playing with another card rolling the dice, if not the turn passes to the next player and so on.

title: Personality Game
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Party Game
description:
Based on the NBC TV show.

Players secretly write an answer to a loaded question in their Secret Answer Cover. The Master of Ceremonies then reads these answers aloud.

The object is to score points by guessing correctly who wrote each answer.

title: Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom
description: Be the first player to move Indiana Jones, Short Round, and Willie Scot past the many dangers and hazards and finally  across the rope bridge to safety.

title: Crusade: Lawrence Welk's All-Star ACS Kit
Upper Hand
description:
This is a simple but challenging game. It is very simple to learn but the strategy can be very deep. The board consists of a 5x5 grid of dimples in which marbles are placed. The game is played somewhat differently than Pylos or Pyraos which form a pyramid on a 4x4 grid.

The wild third colored marble is placed first in the center of the 5x5 grid. This overcomes the problem that the pyramid on a 5x5 base requires an odd number of marbles to build.

In Pyramids the goal is to get rid of all of your playing pieces first. If placing a marble completes a square and at least three of the marbles in that square are the players color, then the player gets to place an additional marble on top of the square. If the additional marble completes another square, then using the same rule as before the player gets to place a third marble on so on.

Since the two players may have overall played a different number of marbles towards the end of the game, the game might be over before the pyramid is finished. The game obviously cant last longer than 27 moves since there is no rule to remove marbles in Pyramids.

title: Cradle of Civilization
description:
Cradle of Civilization is a 2-7 player game which blends Diplomatic, Military, and Economic mechanisms to produce an exciting game system for both the casual gamer and the experienced hobbyist. Players control the destinies of the world's major cultures from 800 B.C. onwards. Each turn lasts 100 years, with players controlling  the Armies and Economies of their respective Civilizations.

By utilizing skillful diplomacy and military strategy a player can achieve world-wide pre-eminence for his Civilization.

title: The Cities Game
description:
The Cities Game
Urban Tension  Negotiation.
A psychology today game.

You make secret deals. Apply economic muscle. Buy votes. Break promises. Explore the psychology of power and politics. Develop your skills as a persuader, an agitator, and a negotiator. But above all, you get the mental sharpening of dealing in the complexities of city strife.

Set your own rules. This game has no dice, no complicated instructions, no restrictions. Like it or not, you must form coalitions with other players. Or risk riots, unnecessary police action and unpredictable change.

You play the role of Government or Agitator or Business or Slum Dweller.

Discuss and negotiate issues such as riots, teacher strikes and business boycotts. Your vote could sweep you into either The Future City or back into the chaos where you started.

Explore the sources of urban tension, corruption and the undercurrents of city politics. The Cities Game -- designed with a purpose. To simulate the realities of city life. Your life.

title: Dinosaur Hunters!
description:
Using a spinner to randomly select which action you must take this turn, each player attempts to assemble their jigsaw puzzle depicting a fossilized dinosaur.

Actions direct the player to buy, trade or draw a bone (puzzle piece) or take a card of a random event deck.

title: Timestream: The Remnant
types: Card Game Collectible Components Science Fiction
description:
Timestream: The Remnant is a new collectible card game which features high-quality components and packaging. The game takes place in the year 3026, where religion has been outlawed and a small band of underground patriots called The Remnant discover the secrets of time travel. Players must play cards to travel back in time to the Age of Apostles, visit a Biblical city, record an event on a data cell, and return to the future.

You play Advance and Event Chain cards on a colorful game board which details your progress. Your opponent tries to stop you by playing Obstacle cards. Both players have access to power cells and other enhancement cards which of course have a variety of special abilities that change the course of the game. The first one to complete your three Event Chains and play the TIMESTREAM card wins the game!

title: Quick Cross
description:
Billed on the box simply A Game of Strategy

Players alternate placing disks onto a 4x4 grid, orienting the pieces either vertically or horizontally.  On his turn a player may enter a piece in either direction, or the player may change the orientation of a piece already on the board.

You win by getting 4 disks in a row with the same orientation.

All the disks are identical, and the players draw from the pool of disks which starts at 16.

title: Zorro
description: The board shows a town from the Wild West. In it are foundations for six buildings, a jail and central plaza. Pawns represent Zorro and five other players (bandits). There is also a mask to obscure the vision of the Zorro player. Despite being dressed in black, Zorro is a good guy and must capture the bandits. Each bandit gets 3 cards. Buildings are placed on the foundation spots and the bandits attempt to rob them. Zorro dons his mask and the others take turns silently placing their pawns in the buildings of their choice. Then Zorro chooses his location. Using cards the players are able to move and engage in their activities.  Whoever has the most success wins.

title: Ginny-O
description:
The crisscross Rummy game -- a fast action rummy board game where players compete on as many as nine hands at once.

Plays similarly to Scrabble on a 15x15 board.  Each person has seven tiles representing cards in a standard deck and must score as many points as possible by playing the tiles to the board to form gin rummy melds.

title: Fast 111's
description:
Be the first to cross the FINISH line in this car-racing board game.

Easy to learn and set-up, this fast-paced game features a unique play element.  Movement around the track is determined by cards.  But you draw two cards per turn - one to move your own car and the other to move an opponent's car.  Force an opponent off the track and move your own car way ahead.

Replicas of license plates from the 10 Canadian provinces and 2 territories are colorfully illustrated on the cards.

title: Carrera de Mente
description:
Consist of a board and 6 books with different colors with questions about different themes.
Player or teams rolls the dice 3 times on each turn obtaining 3 numbers for example 316.
Then on the correspondent book other player finds question number 316 and reads the riddles. Player/team  must give the correct answer so keeps gaming, if not, turn passes on next player/team and so on.
Every time a player/team answers correctly and the pawn is on a tile with a star, the player/team receives a plastic star with color of the associated book and continues playing.
The first player/team that collects all 6 stars wins!.

title: Gorilla
description:
The game includes a cardboard with 12 areas, 30 counters
that figure gorillas, sheets for orders and a dice.
Each player secretly chooses one gorilla, and his goal will be to climb to the highest hierarchy level in his group
of gorillas.
During the game, each player secretly writes orders for specific gorilla(s), which will be resolved simultaneously.
These orders relate to natural activities of gorillas; the dice are used to determine the results of some activities,
as conflicts.

title: Blue & Gray
description:
Blue  Gray  4 civil war battles where players maneuver colorful card board counters on three color maps of the actual battle sites.

A hexagonal grid superimposed upon each map regulates the deployment, movement, and battle engagement of each unit.  The colorful counters represent the infantry, cavalry, and artillery units that actually fought at each battle. A roll of the dies on simple probability charts determines each combats outcome.  
The updated and revised rules booklet clearly and concisely presents the player with playing rules, a short history of each battle, and other information needed to recreate Americas epic struggle of brother against brother.

Includes scenarios for:

    Shiloh  the forerunner of costly Civil War tactics
    Antietam  a setback for Lee after a string of Victories
    Chickamauga  the Confederates seek to avenge the Unions capture of Chattanooga
    Cemetery Hill (Gettysburg) overlooking Gettysburg, determined Confederates couldnt capture it in three days




Decision Games edition replaced Antietam with 1st and 2nd Bull Run.

Components:

    Rules of Play - 16 pages
    Player Reference - 20 pages 
    1  2 sided Map sheet
    400 counters




Extras:    1 Errata sheet in the form of a printed out E-mail
    1 storage box

title: The Old Pacific
description:
Part of the American Adventure series.

1903 automobile race from San Francisco to New York.

Players move a space and then spin to see what happens to them.

Intended for Ages 8 and up.

title: Solar Space Maze
description:
The object of the game is to be the first to explore all nine planets in order before plunging into the mystery zone of a black hole.

On each turn your die roll can be used to move your spaceship, or it can be used to advance planets in their orbital path.

title: Megachess
description:
Chess for three players. Also includes Megacheckers on the flip side of the board.

When the other two players have resigned or their king has been checkmated, the third player wins.

title: E$tabli$hment
description: This game is designed to be similar to real life, yet remain fun as a game. The idea is that you have just completed high school and you now face decisions as what to do with the rest of your life. The game consists of 60 years (revolutions around the board) and the player with the highest net worth at the end wins.

title: Saqqara
description:
A Game of Tactics

Players take turns moving pawns from the bottom of a pyramid to the top. Strategy comes in the form of being able to jump pawns to move further, and in some cases being able to send a pawn back a row by jumping.

Winner is the first player to move all of their pawns off the pyramid via exiting them once they have reached the single space at the top.

title: Dealing with Murder: Fatal Error
description:
In Dealing with Murder - Fatal Error , 2-6 players get together to try and solve a murder mystery. Each player is dealt a hand of 3 cards that comes from a deck of cards where each card is unique, and has either has some information pertaining to the mystery, or has actions that a player can take. Each turn a player plays a card (reveals evidence) to the discard pile where everyone can read the information. The cards a player keeps in his hand are considered 'withheld evidence'. A player may also play a subpoena card to look at all the cards in a given players hand or to increase their own hand size. Play continues like this until a player thinks they can solve the mystery. They announce their solution (Who, Motive, How) and then reads (silently) the solution. If correct, they win, if not, they are out of the game and play continues.

Game is (very slightly) compared to the 'How to Host Your Own Murder' series, in that once the game is played, it cannot be played again by the same players, as there is only one solution.

The box even references said product, by stating that to play 'Dealing with Murder', you don't need to cook a dinner or show up wearing a costume to play.

title: The Hollywood Squares
description:
This game is very much like the TV show it is based on.

Players attempt to answer true/false trivia questions to place their X or O on a tic-tac-toe grid. Incorrect answers award the space to the opponent.

Play is best of 3 games of tic-tac-toe.

title: Corporate Pursuit
description:
From the rules:

Welcome to Corporate Pursuit and the world of high finance.  You are now an investor building a financial empire by buying, selling, and trading corporate stocks.  Million dollar deals are a piece of cake because all the calculations you'll need are listed right on the stock certificates.  The only figuring you have to do is adding up your fortune at the end of the game.

The game uses many real companies as the companies in which the players buy stock.

title: The Game of Ancient Kingdoms
description:
The components for this game consist of 18 plastic hex tiles in each of 5 colors - each player gets 16 blank tiles, one King, and one Warrior.  In the initial phase of the game, players place these tiles on the table (there is no board) in one connected group, but are not allowed to connect more than 5 of their color together.  Once all tiles are placed, a turn generally consists of exchanging the positions of any two tiles.  The object is to unify all of one's own tiles into the same country (connected group).  The King protects the tiles in its group (another player can only remove one by swapping it with his or her own King), but can only be moved once for free - after that a penalty must be paid.  The Warrior offers additional movement abilities.

The game was originally published in 1975 under the name Kingdoms.  The version shown, titled The Game of Ancient Kingdoms, was published in 1976.  The rules are nearly identical, with the later version adding the penalty rule for moving the King and a rule for scoring draw games.

title: James Bond 007 Le Jeu
types: Adventure Dice Fighting Movies / TV / Radio theme Novel-based Spies/Secret Agents
description:
In this James Bond game, each player is a special agent with 3 skills (charm, strength and dexterity) with different values. The aim of the game is to defeat the most enemies by beating them in one of the skills (resolved with dice).
The box depicts Timothy Dalton in License to Kill.

title: Bärenspiel
description:
In Brenspiel, players try to rescue a little bear lost in the great forest. Rolling special dice, players must first construct a map of the forest, find the bear, then help it out of the woods, working together to overcome one obstacle or another. Once the bear is located, players are allowed seven rolls of the dice to get it clear of the forest. If they fail to do so, they lose the game and the bear eats them.

The 2011 AMIGO edition is part of its kologisch + Kooperativ (Ecological  Cooperative) line of games.

title: Money! Money! Money!
description:
Players attempt to collect money, memberships and material goods to win.

As each player collects more wealth, they move to new areas of the board, which give more lucrative opportunities.

title: The Love Boat World Cruise Game
mechanisms: Roll / Spin and MoveVariable Player Powers
description:
By moving their Love Boat pawn back and forth on the movement track according to a die rolled, you attempt to collect cards that suit the star personality you drew at the game's start.

Port and Cruise cards are worth different amounts to different stars, and a picture on the front of the card gives a hint to this (The Star Athlete would like to collect the cards with sporting event pictures, for example).

When a ship reaches San Francisco, the player doing so collects 500 extra points, all points are totaled, and the winner declared.

title: Duo-Bridge
description:
Two-handed contract Bridge.

Rules for playing Bridge against an automated pair of opponents.  Primarily designed for one pair of players to practice their bidding and trick-taking skills.

title: Campaign Politiks
description:
The goal of each of the players is to be the first to mark off all the symbols in his game triangle.

The players will find that he must use some political strategy at times by advancing the cause of other players in order to make some small gains himself, or still at other times he may conspire with the majority to stop an opponent who has presidential fever, or who is on a steam roller.

This game is basically a card game with a board for scoring.

title: Guet-Apens
description: Guet-Apens is a medieval wargame. It contains quite heavy simulation rules for knights, soldiers, bowmen, etc... and a book of 12 scenarios.

title: Fortune Seeker
mechanisms: Auction/BiddingBetting/WageringCommodity SpeculationRoll / Spin and MoveStock Holding
description: The board has 4 quadrants where players can seek their fortune in the Casino, Race Track, Real Estate, and Stock Market. In the Casino, you are playing blackjack while in the Race Track, you are horse racing. In Real Estate, you are buying and selling property, while in the Stock Market you are buying and selling stock. Each quadrant includes playing squares from the other three to keep the entire game active at all times e.g. there are Casino, Real Estate, and Stock Market playing squares in the Race Track quadrant. When you unfold the board it measures 38 by 24. There are two methods of winning Fortune Seeker. The most common is to be the first player to arrive at or pass through the boards center logo with at least $10,000,000 cash and no debt. The second is to be the owner of an oil field in Real Estate that has an oil gusher.

title: Ein Nilpferd kommt selten allein
description:
Party-game where players have to answer questions, mime or draw objects with a limp pen...

In this party game, players move one of two hippo pawns over an 8-shaped track.The fields they land on determine the task they have to fulfill (for this, they also draw a card) - in most cases, the other players try to guess the word/phrase that was intended: 
- Draw an item with a wobbly pen
- Take a sip of water and gargle the word
- Group acting (together with one or more players they chose)
Other tasks include
- Reading out a text - now everyone in turn has to say a word connecting to the text within three seconds. Players who fail to do that are out of this task round; the last player standing receiving points. 
- Rolling a poker die. A saxophone means a five point chip and the chance to roll again. When a lemon is rolled, all chips of this round are lost. The player can stop rolling any time.

Each kind of field has its own scoring rules. The first player to score 100 points is the winner.

title: Word Maze
description:
Players draw letter tiles and create words on board to race from their start to their goal.

By making crosswords and removing whatever tiles remain unused in the previous word, each player's colored tiles crawl across the board towards their own goal.

title: Juggler's Jam
mechanisms: Action Point Allowance SystemCo-operative PlayHand ManagementPattern Building
description:
In Juggler's Jam each player is a juggler attempting to perform the best tricks. All actions are based on confidence points. You need confidence to play tricks and place new items into your juggling pattern and you gain confidence at the start of each turn by adding the values of tricks and objects you have in your pattern.

Other jugglers are trying to disrupt your pattern and force to drop your items and start over. Just like in real juggling you have a choice of a few patterns you can juggle your objects in and when an object is in your hand you can invoke any special powers the object commands.

Juggler's Jam is a humorous game for 2-4 players Ages 13 and up designed by Jay Turley.

title: MM-peli
description:
The official game of the World Championships in Athletics!

In this game you compete in five different sports: long-jumping, 110m hurdles, javelin-throwing, pole-vaulting, and 1500m.

In each sport your results are measured in meters or seconds, just like in real life, so you have a chance of setting new world record! In addition, you get result points in each sport. The better your results, the more points you get. The result points are added up, and the player having the most points after all five sports is the winner! The super score - very hard to achieve - is 1000 points or more.

One special feature of the game is that you yourself can influence your results; the outcome is not decided by the dice alone.

So if you're planning to win this official game of the world championships in athletics, it is going to take both skill and luck - just like in real life!

title: Tzuris
description: Tzuris is an avoidance game with bidding, an elaborate trump suit and a gimmick. The gimmick being that when you play a card, you don't play it in front of yourself but in front of one of your fellow players. This is done in such a way that by the end of each trick, each player will have a card face down in front of them. These cards are then turned face up and the winner of the trick is determined. So the idea is to use your own good cards to force opponents to take tricks which will, you hope, contain cards which will count as penalties against them. Stuart Dagger, Counter, November 1999

title: Haithabu
description:
Who is the cleverest Viking of all?
The life of the Vikings was rough and tough, but even they were not able to survive without exchanging goods.
Haithabu-the Venice of the Vikings with its stilts- was founded as a center of trade during the 8th century. Whatever trade flourished, there were jealous people, highway robbers and gangs of robbers. For protection, protective walls, traps and bridge systems were constructed that were supposed to make life difficult for all undesired intruders.
Every year, the inhabitants of Haithabu hold a contest in their town, in honor of Odin, to find out who is the cleverest of all in overcoming the traps.

title: Go Surf
types: Card Game Humor Memory Party Game Sports
description:
Go Surf is a colorfully illustrated deck of  45 surf theme cards. With cards like Tube Ride , Cutback, 
and Overhead Monster; play the games Go Surf, Watch the lineup, Wipe Out and more...
The surf deck is designed with 11 books of 4 color suits and 1 wipe out card. The games
involve interactive play between players using some strategy, memory and chance, to build
pairs and or books of matching cards. Cards can be numbered and /or dice added to create
additional variety of games.

title: Electronic Arcade Mania
description:
From the box:
Arcade Mania is a skill and strategy game that features a mini arcade machine that's simple to operate, a challenge to play, and totally portable, so you can play a real honest-to-goodness arcade game away from an arcade!
To challenge THE MACHINE, you must react with lightning-fast fingers. Either to battle alien raiders, to track down a slithering serpent, to blast away at threatening missiles, or to run away from a very hungry monster.
It take skill to score points on THE MACHINE but it takes strategy to win the game. For Arcade Mania challenges you to collect chips during a match... and chips are accumulated either by winning on THE MACHINE yourself or by betting successfully on other players tackling THE MACHINE. You'll discover that WHO to bet on and HOW MUCH to bet takes clever planning and plotting.

The four arcade games are very simple and are played at three different skill levels, as decided by a throw of a die. The game features a colorful board (19 1/2 x 24 inches) and THE MACHINE, which requires six AA batteries.

title: Millennium
description:
The game is played on two maps, the tactical map and the strategical map, on which the fleets of space ships belonging to the Empire and the invading Aliens move.
The Zoom effect of having two maps makes it possible to carry out each conflict between fleets as a little space battles each of which is a game in itself.
Parts of the game:
-Rigid, plastic cardboard box printed in 5 colors, giving the indications of the number and age of players, the duration of the game, the level of difficulty and the historical setting.
-Pieces representing the various fleets and space ships in matte finish cardboard cut and printed on both sides.
-1 deck of identifying cards for the various solar systems.
-1 rule booklet in 4 languages with examples.
-1 tactical map in rigid thick cardboard.
-1 strategic map in rigid thick cardboard.
-3 tables to indicate the points earned during the game.
-Transparent plastic storage tray and dice.

title: Thistle
description:
Game set in Scotland, the theme is unimportant.  There are 10 suits with 9 identical cards in each suit.  In addition there is a Coat of arms for each suit and four Castle cards for additional points.

Each round you draw a face-up card that you must play immediately, then you can play from your hand.  The goal is to form sets of 6 cards with your partner.  Bonus points are awarded for having the coat of arms or a castle in your set.

Add a few capture rules, and that is the game.

title: Ice Cube
description: Pop your men out of the supplied ice tray and move around the waterproof board. You encounter hazards such as the warm bath, Hot Head (a hot metal washer placed on your ice-head, and a shower of salt. Last player to melt wins. Messy game (the salt residue is particularly messy when it dries). The high mess factor ensured that many Moms threw this one out, thereby allowing the rare remaining copies to command high prices on ebay.

title: A Racing Game!
description:
Be the first to cross the finish line in this fast-paced game of luck and strategy.

Roll the dice as many as three times and save the best combination that moves your racer as far down the track as possible.  If you roll a flat tire on your third roll, you lose your turn.  If you cut off another player, that player loses a turn.

A Racing Game! helps children learn basic strategy skills and develop social skills by following rules and taking turns.

title: Fire on the Suns: Tactical Command (2nd Edition)
mechanisms: Hex-and-CounterModular BoardPaper-and-PencilSimultaneous Action SelectionVariable Player Powers
description:
Fire on the Suns: Tactical Command 2nd (TCOM2) is a tactical starship combat and war game construction kit.  The product is a CD-ROM and the game can either be printed out for head-to-head play or it can be played via hot-seat/play-by-email with software such as V_MAP (Windows version included for free.)

TCOM2 has been retired.  The author, Todd Zircher, is currently developing a third edition of the Tactical Command series that will focus on a harder sci-fi setting with additions to the game mechanics such as vector movement.

title: Die Monstermacher
description:
The players must try to stitch together a monster and revive it. You collect body parts from graves, the gallows and from other players warehouses.

There is a nice rule controlling when you can steal from other players. You have a die that moves up or down one number when you perform certain actions. Others can steal from you when the amount of body parts in your warehouse exceeds or is equal to your die number. This balances things out and keeps the players stitching their monster together (using their cards) to keep their warehouses (card supply) from being raided.

Art may be too gruesome for the youngest players.

title: Stop
description:
Stop is a variation of Uno, with players trying to empty their hand of cards by playing onto a discard pile by matching the color or number of the card on top of the pile. Stop also includes a few special cards and rules to tweak the gameplay and differentiate it:


     6s and 9s are considered to be identical, so a 6 can be played on a 9 regardless of the color and vice versa.
     If a player has a number card identical in color to the top card, she may play it out of turn onto the discard stack.
     An exchange card allows the player playing it to have everyone give their cards to their left- or right-hand neighbor.
     The +X card forces the next player to draw the top card of the deck and add it to her hand. If it's a number card, she must also draw that many cards.
     The +2 card forces the next player to draw two cards and skip her turn  unless she also plays a +2 in which case the next player must draw four cards, etc.
     A skip card skips the next player.
     A stop card, which is numbered 0, can prevent the action of an exchange, +X, +2 or skip card played by the previous player.


When a player runs out of cards, the other players score points based on the cards they still have in hand. After multiple rounds, the game ends if a player has 500 or more points; the player with the fewest points wins!

title: Warhammer Warriors Battle Books
description:
A Warhammer version of Lost Worlds based on Games Workshop's 40,000 setting. Each player uses a battle book and chooses a page number for a maneuver for their turn. These are revealed simultaneously and cross-referenced. A chart then shows you which page to turn to see  the results of the maneuvers. Players usually end up wounded or in a better position to strike a killing blow.

Warhammer Warriors is slightly more stream-lined than Lost Worlds and plays faster. Warhammer Warriors does not have behind you maneuvers and there is a lot more shooting/ranged combat. All characters have a Deathblow maneuver which speed up games if you're in a good position.
Great art by Karl Kopinski, Kev Walker, and Wayne Reynolds.

title: 1 on 1 Adventure Gamebooks: Castle Arcania
mechanisms: Role PlayingSimultaneous Action SelectionVariable Player Powers
description:
You Are Eric Sunsword, Legendary Knight of the Northern Marches (book one title)
You Are Neves, An Ancient and Powerful Wizard (book two title)

From the Back of the Box:
Inside are two books for two players. One of you becomes the Knight, Eric Sunsword. The other becomes his bitter enemy  Neves, the wizard. The two of you meet in magical Castle Arcania. Will you find each other and meet in final combat? Will you fall into one of your opponents traps? Be ambushed by his henchman? Or will one of the strange creatures in the Castle get you first!

Castle Arcania is the first One-on-One Adventure Gamebook, and involves a fight between a knight and a wizard over the Princess Mara. There are two books in the box set, one for the player of the knight Eric Sunsword and one for the player of the wizard Neves. Players move their characters from location to location, collect items, set traps, use their allies, and come into conflict when the two sides are in the same place at the same time. Conflicts are resolved by using a Combat Table. The players choose numbers simultaneously, and then look up the result on the chart.

Imagine reading a Fighting Fantasy book with another player as the Dungeon Master.

title: Spellcast
description:
From the Northern Games website:

Spellcast is a mystical card gaming experience designed for two to six players that lets you jump into the realm of spells and spirits. Its bold, colorful, and filled with excitement. Come and explore the magic that is inside and all around us.
The players gather ingredients to cast spells, fly to different realms, battle against their opponents with power cards, and play hands-on with crystals. So, has it captured your attention?
Spellcast also features a game within a game. A starter pack of 45 Coven's Circle battle cards is included in every game. Coven's Circle is designed to be integrated into play of Spellcast however, this highly exciting card game can be played totally on its own.
Play Spellcast and jump into the realm of spells and spirits... if you dare!

title: Dragon Epic
description:
Dragon Epic is a strategy game of army maneuver and battle, with the added flavor of magic. Heroes go on quests to discover powerful artifacts. Dragons can fly across territories to raze and pillage. Mighty leaders send hordes of mercenaries and strange creatures into mortal combat.

Troop types range from basic infantry, knights, mystic creatures, and heroes. Each troop card is placed in a battle line and casualties are removed from the front of the line unless they can be targeted with a special ability. So generally you want to place your toughest units in the front lines.

Each card lists its strengths and weaknesses. The number of stars across the top represent the amount of damage it can take, followed by number of dice it  rolls in combat, offensive strength, and defensive strength. This seems simple, but the addition of creatures, special abilities, artifacts, and spells add to the strategy.

title: Cleric's Revenge
description: Board game using 2 armies of about 30 heroes  baddies each, numbered 1-10 on one sided character cards mounted on plastic bases. Armies are set up on a hex board detailing a battlefield with terrain  buildings (printed, not 3D). Pieces move on a turn-by-turn basis and victory is achieved by finding the opposing army's chest of gold character card. Mechanics include variable movement based on the piece's battle power, dice rolls to determine casualties, and characters with special abilities.

title: Drug Attack
description:
Drug Attack
Springboard to Family Communications
An informative game on drug abuse

Something unseen is happening in your community now! Are you aware of the drug culture? How does drug abuse affect your community, your family? What can be done about the problem? Solutions are necessary here and now!

The answer to these problems await you when you play Drug Attack. Learn how to identify and help drug abusers. Learn how to cope with criminal drug pushers.

Drug Attack involves you as a Mayor, Health Officer, or Agent striving to save their community from a drug disaster. Together, they must detect the attack, meet it, and treat its victims.

Drug Attack is being played in schools throughout the United States. It is an ideal game for establishing family communication on the subject of drugs. It is a game of urgency -- a game of today!

title: Egomania
mechanisms: Roll / Spin and MoveVariable Player PowersVoting
description:
From the back of the box:

Be an Egomaniac! Let unbridled self-interest be your guide. Unleash those long repressed diabolical yearnings to triumph over others as you maneuver for power, control, and total victory.

The object of the game is for you to become the Supreme Ego by amassing the required amount of Powers and Properties. Owning Powers gives you potential control over other Egos' freedom of movement, security, access to information, and the amount of their money. Owning Properties gives you the potential to control and block other Egos' board movement strategies. The inevitable conflicts that arise are resolved by direct negotiations between players, resulting in bargains that are as devilishly clever as human invention permits.

title: The Classified Encyclopedia of Chess Variants
description:
A book containing about 1400 Chess Variants and Chess-related games. Rules of non-proprietary games are described in detail.

From the book cover: The Encyclopedia of Chess Variants is a compilation of board and table game related to, derived from or inspired by chess. The games ranges through the ages and across continents and from the brilliant to the bizarre. Most can be played with an ordinary chess set. Established variants are treated in depth. The main aim of The Encyclopedia of Chess Variants is to entertain, but it also offers some remarkable yet little-known variants for the keen games player and is a source of reference for the student. An essential book for every games library.

Expands

    Chess

title: ConTrack: Switzerland & Austria
types: Economic Expansion for Base-game Trains Transportation
description:
Expansion for both TrainSport: Austria and Trainsport: Switzerland. Comes with cards for both sets as well as some gold chips to use as $100 markers. Note that the expansion does not combine the two games together into one game.

Expands:

    TrainSport: Austria
    Trainsport: Switzerland

title: You Said It
types: Bluffing Educational Humor Party Game Trivia Word Game
description:
An exciting word game that's fun and educational. Perfect for two players or twenty... ages 12 to adult. Each person or team is in competition to bluff the other into believing the real meanings of extraordinary words, that really exist! Who's telling the truth... who's fibbing? It's a humorous race to gain winning points for you or your team while you increase your vocabulary in the bargain.

Learn to judge personalities as the game intensifies. You'll notice your opposition becomes shifty eyed, with an uncontrolled smile or a silly grin... their foot is busy tapping or they look away. They're bluffing and you know it! If you're right, you've won a point, if you're wrong, you've been bamboozled... and you're ready for another round of You said it!

title: Challenge Bridge
description:
Part of the 3M Bookshelf Series.

Using a special deck of cards and a punch card overlay, this games allows 4 people to play what amounts to tournament Bridge. There are 100 predetermined deals taken from American Contact Bridge League tournaments. Each partnership does not score raw points as in rubber bridge, but rather points in comparison to how other partnerships did playing those same hands in tournaments.

The game also contains a book that has analysis of each of the 100 hands by noted bridge expert Oswald Jacoby.

An additional set of 100 hands was released for this game.

title: Fields of Honor: The American War for Independence
types: Age of Reason American Revolutionary War Miniatures Wargame
description:
An introductory level wargame, using a simplified version of the Fields of Honor miniatures rules for playing the American War of Independence on a regimental scale.

Several individual battle scenarios are included (Bunker Hill, Brandywine, Monmouth, Freeman's Farm, Bemis Heights (Saratoga) and Guilford Court House), plus a campaign game covering the entire conflict. Maps and counters are provided for playing all six scenarios, but the game can also be played with miniatures.

title: Harry Potter Dicers Game
types: Children's Game Collectible Components Dice Fantasy Movies / TV / Radio theme Novel-based
description:
From the Warner Bros. website:
Dicers is a collectible dice game with two levels of play. Knock your opponents dice out of play in the basic game, or develop unique combinations to expel dicers to the dungeon in the advanced game. For ages 5 years and over.

The dicers game is played with collectible dice. These have 5 clear sides, with a figure representing the character inside of the dice. The sixth side is solid, and shows the name of the die, its casting number, its special ability, and its affiliations. The clear sides are numbered from 1 to 5, while the solid face is the '6'. Each die represents a character or item from the Harry Potter stories.

The starter set includes 6 dice; Harry Potter, Hermione Granger, Draco Malfoy, Severus Snape, Hagrid, and the Sorting Hat. It also includes a sheet of rules.
The rules actually have 3 levels of play described in them. The basic game only uses the casting numbers on the dice. The Intermediate game adds in the abilities of the dice, and different areas of play, and the advanced game adds in the affiliations of the dice, and reserve abilities.

In the basic game, players set out the six dice and each take turns picking one to determine which dice they will use. Players then roll to see who goes first (the Challenger).
The challenger picks one die, and then the defender picks on of their dice.
The challenger may roll the die a number of times up to its Casting number, looking for as high a roll as possible. Only the last roll made counts, even if it is lower than a previous roll.
The defender does the same with his or her die.
The lower roll is expelled (removed from play) and the winner becomes the new challenger. This is repeated until only one player has dice left.

In the Intermediate game, there are three areas of play. All dice begin in the Field. A losing die is placed in the dungeon, where it cannot be used. A winning die is placed in the Keep. Dice in the keep cannot be used until a player has no dice left in the field, at which point all of the dice in that player's Keep are moved into the Field. The winning die can choose to either expel the losing die to the dungeon, or to just place it in the Keep and activate the special ability of the winning die. One side of the rules lists the different special abilities. A few examples include:
Capture, which lets you take the enemy die and use its special powers as well as your own.
Summon, which lets you retrieve a die that has been placed in the dungeon.
Swap, which lets you trade the locations of two of a player's dice.
The game ends when one player's dice are all in the dungeon or captured.
