description: The battle of Salamanca is a Napoleonic operational game  that simulates the historical confrontation between a French Army (known as the Army of Portugal) commanded by Marshal Marmont and an Allied Army, commanded by Viscount Wellington of Talavera, and composed of British, Portuguese and Spanish Troops. The Battleground lay a few miles south east of the ancient city of Salamanca, The battle was fought on the 22nd of July, 1812.

title: Smurf Card Game
types: Children's Game Comic Book / Strip Movies / TV / Radio theme Travel
description:
The Smurf Card Game is similar to the classic War game but with a few changes.

Instead of suits, the cards have specific characters that win over other characters. Smurf takes Smurfette, Smurfette takes Papa, Papa takes Smurf and Gargamel takes anything.

During the game, all cards are dealt out for 2 to 4 players. During each turn, players turn over the top card of hid/her face down pile. The person with the winning card collects all of the cards and places them on the bottom of their pile. If there is a tie, cards are turned over until one player turns over a card that matches the original.

In a 3 or 4 player game, players play the player adjacent to them, taking turns, in a clockwise direction.

The game is won by the player who collects all of the cards.

title: Fangface
types: Dice Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction
description:
Fangface is a roll and move game, with simple interactive elements, based on the cartoon series of the same name.

Players spin a spinner in order to move around the board. Some squares are safe while others cause you to move back. The most common square on the board is throw fingers where two players randomly put out a number of fingers. If the total is odd, the active player moves back while if it is even, he/she stays on the square. There is also an element where you must guess in which hand a player is holding a token. During the game, a special moon card can be used on a player to move them back on the board to a specific square.

The first player to make it to the End space is the winner.

title: Big Picture Game
description:
In The Big Picture Game, players separate into groups and try to communicate to their partners through drawings.

The groups take turns to play, each sending a representative to take a puzzle and draw it on the provided board.  Each drawer is supposed to convey three words and a phrase through sketches; the only textual clue to everyone is a word that conveys the central theme of the sketched items.  Points are awarded to the drawer's group for their correct answers.

After a number of rounds have been played, the scores are tallied and the group with the highest score is declared the winner.

title: Chicken Run: The Chicken Pot Pie Game
types: Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
Chicken Run: The Chicken Pot Pie Game is a relatively simple children's game, where you make your chickens out of Play-Dough then use them for a roll and move game. However, when your pieces die they are squashed into a pie. Additionally, you sometimes fling pieces with a catapult and try to hit a target.

Rescue your chickens before they all become pies!

title: Bulls and Bears
description: Acquire $200,000 by buying and selling stocks, mutual funds, fixed-income securities, foreign currency, gold, and real estate.

title: Richie Rich
types: Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
Richie Rich is based on the comics of the same name.  In this board game, players assume the roles of the titular character and his friends.  Their objective is to deposit jewels at the bank and return home.  Standing in their way are thieves and the pranks of Richie's cousin, Reggie.

Players move their pieces along the track by rolling a die.  They may move forwards or backwards.  When they land on a space, they must follow the instructions on it: for example, Reggie makes players lose a turn, while short-cut spaces let players move their pieces further ahead.  Thief spaces, however, stop a moving piece in its tracks and hold it there.  Players must draw an Invention card each turn to obtain one with a number that matches the thief's to escape the criminal's space and continue moving.

The first player to land exactly on the Finish spot wins and ends the game.

title: Inspector Gadget Game
types: Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
In the Inspector Gadget game (based on the cartoon of the same name), players take on the role of the titular bungling cyborg detective in a quest to capture villains from the MAD (Mean And Dirty) organization.

Players move on the board along a circular track by using the results of a spinner.  Along the track are spaces that move a player piece, stop it, or make the player lose a turn.  There are also villain tokens placed on the board that move around.  Players capture these villains by landing their Inspector Gadget exactly onto the tokens.  Players can also steal a villain token from each other by landing on their opponents.  Lastly, villains can liberate their fellow criminals by moving onto the players' pieces.

The first player to reach the Jail, while holding three or more villains captive, wins the game.

title: Columbo Detective Game
types: Deduction Memory Movies / TV / Radio theme
description: A 1970's copy of the MB game Why. Features nearly identical gameplay, but with a theme following the popular TV show.

title: Wicket The Ewok
types: Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme
description: Basic move and collect game based on the characters from The Return of the Jedi film. It is part of the  Star Wars games.

title: The M.U.S.C.L.E. Mega-Match Game
description:
Have your M.U.S.C.L.E. characters battle against each other.
M.U.S.C.L.E Stands for Millions of Unusually Small Creatures Lurking Everywhere.

A battle arena for your Muscles, with ten muscles!
Objective: Knock out all your opponent's muscles.

Playing the Game
1. Each player spins to see who goes first. The player who spins the higher number goes first.
2. Players take turns spinning the spinner and moving their M.U.S.C.L.E. creatures.
3. On each turn, a player spins the spinner, and them moves 1 or more of his creatures the same total number of spaces as the number just spun. A player can divide up his total move among as many creatures as he likes.
4. A player can move his creatures forward, backward, sideways, or diagonally in any combination.
5. A player can have up to 2 creatures on the same space at one time. You can move through a space with 2 of your creatures on it, but you can't stop there.

COMBAT
1. When you move one (or two) of you creatures onto a space occupied by one (or two) of your opponent's creatures, you begin a Combat.
2. During Combat, each player in turn spins the spinner once for each creature he/she has in battle. 
3. After both players have spun, the one with the most M's wins the Combat and gets to knock over 1 or 2 of the opposing creatures.
4. Once knocked over, the defeated creatures are out of the game. Players leave defeated creatures lying on the arena, but those creatures are not counted as occupying space, and may be moved around as necessary to make room for more Combat.
5. If both players spin the same number of M's, the battle is a tie and will continue after the player takes his/her turn moving.
6. Once each player has had one chance to do battle on every space where his/her creatures are in Combat, it becomes the next player's turn to move. This player takes his/her turn moving even if there was a tie in the battle or if both players still have creatures standing on the same space after the battle.
7. Play continues for the rest of the game with one player taking a turn moving, then a Combat round (if there are any Combat situations on the board), then the other player takes his/her turn moving, and so on.
8. You can be involved in any number of Combats at one time.
9. The last player with one or more M.U.S.C.L.E. creatures left standing wins the game!

There are stickers! You get a whole sheet of stickers with which  you can decorate your arena as well as your muscles.

title: Pronto
description: Five lettered dice are rolled. The players play simultaneously. They have one minute to use the letters rolled to fill their scorepads. Words started may be finished on subsequent turns. There are spaces on the scorepad for four three-letter words and one each of a four, five, six and seven letter words. There is also a Junk Pile for unused letters. The game ends after eight rounds and players score for complete words. Highest score wins.

title: Ms. PAC-MAN Game
description:
In the Ms. Pac-Man Game, one player takes control of the titular character and the others play as ghosts, taking turns to move in a maze.  Ms Pac-Man's goal is to eat the pellets on the board and the ghosts try to capture her.

Moving according to the results of flicking a spinner, Ms Pac-Man gobbles (removes) pellets by moving over them.  The ghosts move according to the result of a die roll.  They start in their strong state and capture Ms Pac-Man by moving onto her.  When a ghost captures Ms Pac-Man, the ghost's player takes control of the titular character and removes his or her ghost from play; the former Ms Pac-Man player puts the ghost of his or her color into play.  Ghosts turn weak if an F2 is rolled on their die, or if Ms Pac-Man gobbles a Power Pellet (located at the four corners of the maze).  Ms Pac-Man can capture weak ghosts and gain an extra turn by doing so.

The first player to have his or her quadrant clear of pellets wins the game.

title: Wacky Wizard Game
mechanisms: Role PlayingRoll / Spin and MoveSet Collection
description:
Wacky Wizard is a game in which players assume the roles of unfortunate victims of a looney wizard.  Changed into one of six types of animals (bats, spiders, snakes, etc), the players must gather the ingredients necessary to break the spell over them.

Taking turns to play, players move their pieces on the board based on the flicking of a spinner.  Ingredient discs are placed at the edges of the board and a player's piece must land exactly on the spaces to collect the items.  To break the spell over them, the creatures need to collect two different ingredients with their own symbols (e.g. a Turtle would require an Eye of Newt and a Fingernail of Newt).  If the spinner lands on the Wacky Wizard symbol, the player draws a Wizard Spell Card, which will turn his or her playing piece into another creature (and thereby changing his or her winning conditions).

The first player to break the enchantment over his or her piece wins and ends the game.

title: Beatlemania Trivia
description: Beatlemania Trivia was released in 1984 and features questions of varying degrees of difficulty. Players move along a track and, by correctly answering trivia questions, accumulate points.

title: NogginNosh
description:
Finally, a game that recognizes that people think differently. NogginNosh is the exciting, fun new game that provides your brain with a little food for thought. Included in this game are 410 game cards with 1,025 questions that allow players to strut their stuff in a wide variety of categories, including logic puzzles, vocabulary, trivia, and picture games. The numerous puzzle styles will allow everyone a chance to shine, whether right-brain or left-brain thinkers.  You'll use your common sense and creativity, not just your memory.

Contents: 
410 game cards 
30-second timer 
50 score sheets 
Two pencils

title: Clay To Win
description:
The only game you'll ever knead. Challenging! Creative! 3-D game of charades. Enjoy the laughter as players discover their hidden creative skills. Join the fun by trying to sculpt clues that communicate a word or phrase to your teammate(s)

Includes: 2 vinyl mats, 2 six ounce containers of clay, 250 boxed cards featuring 1,250 subjects, 2 plastic molding knives, 1 die, and instructions

title: Big Business
description: Every player is a Big Businessman in this popular game and has a chance to develop large business ventures across the U.S. Players compete for state patent rights to develop industry in different states, such as lumber in Washington or dairy products in Wisconsin.

title: Billboard Top 40 Trivia
description: A music trivia game featuring different styles and eras. Players answer questions and advance their token to the end of the track to win.

title: Survivor Trading Card Game
types: Card Game Collectible Components Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
Strategy game based on the original Survivor TV Series

The Upper Deck's Survivor Trading Card Game is a game for two players.There is a 60 cards deck from which players choose their castaways and then they pit them in direct competition. Only one can capture the Immunity Idol and stay on the island during each test. 
Players compete in immunity Challenge mini-games and have to manage and appoint their Food and Alliance cards. 
You have to Outwit, outplay and outlast your opponent in order to manage to survive and win.

During each of the immunity chalenge mini games, players have the opportunity to vote off an opponent's Castaway. Nothing is certain though since Fortune and Item cards come into play and the fate of any survivor is uncertain until each game round is over. 
Strength, wits, endurance, speed, accuracy, balance, swimming, and politics are all elements the Castaways must use in their quest to become the reigning survivor.

title: Moovit
types: Action / Dexterity Card Game Electronic Real-time
description: A fast-paced sound and card game.  Try to match the animal or color AND make the animal's sound from cards in your hand.  The point is to discard while matching cards fast and try and get out of cards before the time is up.  If the timer says Moovit before you are out of cards, you draw 4 cards and the next player goes.  You must make the sound of the animal on the card each time you put down a card.  If you don't, you're penalized by drawing 2 cards.  Things get a bit more complicated as you are not supposed to make the animal sound when you play a red card.  There are other special cards that reverse direction and other effects kind of like Uno.  Easy to learn and play.

title: Formula Dé Circuits 19 & 20: Suzuka & Melbourne
description:
Expansion tracks for Formula Dé:


    19 - Suzuka, Japan
    20 - Melbourne, Australia

title: Formula Dé Circuits 17 & 18: Buenos-Aires & Barcelona
description:
Expansion tracks for Formula Dé:


    17 - Buenos-Aires, Argentina
    18 - Barcelona, Spain

title: Formula Dé Circuits 13 & 14: Montreal & Long Beach
Formula Dé Circuits 11 & 12: Watkins Glen & Silverstone
description:
Expansion tracks for Formula Dé:


    11 - Watkins Glen, New York USA
    12 - Silverstone, England UK

title: Formula Dé Circuits 9 & 10: Estoril & Interlagos
description:
Expansion tracks for Formula Dé:


    9 - Estoril, Portugal
    10 - Interlagos, Brazil

title: Formula Dé Circuits 5 & 6: Kyalami & Ferrari Autodromo
description:
Expansion tracks for Formula Dé:


    5 - Kyalami Circuit, South Africa
    6 - Autodromo Enzo  Dino Ferrari, San Marino


Expands:

    Formula Dé

title: Formula Dé Circuits 3 & 4: Zandvoort 2 & SPA-Francorchamps
description:
Expansion tracks for Formula Dé by the new publisher Descartes Editeur:


    3 - Zandvoort 2, Netherlands
    4 - SPA-Francorchamps, Belgium


Zandvoort 2 can be combined with the Zandvoort track that comes in the base game to make a very large track.

title: Formula Dé Circuits 31 & 32: Zhuhai & Sepang
description:
Expansion tracks for Formula Dé:


    31 - Zhuhai China
    32 - Sepang Malaysia

title: Formula Dé Circuits 27 - 30: USA Track Pack #2
description:
Expansion tracks for Formula Dé:


    27 - Detroit, Michigan USA
    28 - Lexington, Ohio USA
    29 - Atlanta, Georgia USA
    30 - Daytona Beach, Florida USA

title: Formula Dé Circuits 23 - 26: USA Track Pack #1
description:
Expansion tracks for Formula Dé:


    23 - Monterey, California USA
    24 - Portland, Oregon USA
    25 - Elkhart-Lake, Wisconsin USA
    26 - Indianapolis, Indiana USA

title: Formula Dé Circuit 33: 10th Anniversary
description: Fantasy track released for the 10th Anniversary of Formula Dé. Players race around a designer's desk top covered with paints, pencils, etc.

title: Play It By Ear: Volume 2
description:
Play It By Ear 2 is the second volume in the Play it by Ear series of audio trivia games.

As in the first, players select a trivia categories from which they must answer a question. Each question is complemented by an audio clip on the cd. The board is the same as the first version where players can select their category in beginning positions, but opponents select the category near the end. Players answering questions correctly will move around the circular board, working their way towards the winner's circle.

In this edition, the sounds bites are updated from the previous version and 3 new categories were added: Earobics, Grab Bag and At the Races. Some categories were also removed.

The first the winner's circle is the victor.

title: PAC-MAN Card Game
types: Card Game Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme Video Game Theme
description:
A card game derived from the popular video game.

Players form 3-card sets of cards with picture cards of the Pac-Man or Ghost characters or number cards with dots, simulating the dots which Pac-Man gobbles up in the video game.

Players utilize individual game boards and place cards in open spaces as defined on each board. Picture cards are placed between two number cards. If the picture card is a Pac-Man card, the two number cards which bracket it are added together.

If the card is a Ghost card, the number card on the right is subtracted from the card on the left. So opponents are allowed to place ghost cards and number cards on opponents game boards in an attempt to hinder point scoring.

There is also a Pac-Man eating a Ghost card which acts as a multiplier between the two numbers.

Players play one card per turn, and the person who reaches 100 points if the winner.

An advanced version would subtract points from the players running total if the three card combination included a ghost and the subtraction resulted in a negative total.

title: Formula Dé Circuits 7 & 8: Magny-Cours & Monza
description:
Expansion tracks for Formula Dé:


    7 - Magny-Cours, France
    8 - Autodromo Nazionale Di Monza, Italy


Re-implements

    Formule Dé Circuit № 2: FRANCE – Circuit de Nevers Magny-Cours
    Formule Dé Circuit № 3: GRAN PREMO D'ITALIA – Autodromo Nazionale Monza

title: Formula Dé Circuits 21 & 22: Budapest & Nürburgring
description:
Expansion tracks for Formula Dé:


    21 - Budapest, Hungary
    22 - Nrburgring, Germany

title: Formula Dé Circuits 15 & 16: Hockenheim & Zeltweg
description:
Expansion tracks for Formula Dé:

    15 - Hockenheim, Germany
    16 - Zeltweg, Austria

title: Timberland
description:
Timberland is a German family game about woodland management in the old days. 
Play is card driven according to the four seasons; fruit falls from the trees in the Autumn; in Winter, wild boar eat the fruit and run through the woods depositing seeds as they go; in the Spring and Summer the seeds grow into trees; and thereafter the trees are cut down by the axe-wielding woodcutter. Players select cards and maneuver the boar and the woodcutter in order to get the largest stand of contiguous trees.

Ages 8 and up.

title: Enemy Agent
mechanisms: MemoryRoll / Spin and MoveSecret Unit Deployment
description: Players divide their 6 travelers into 3 secret agents and 3 tourists and select matching passports that will be used throughout the game. With throws of the dice, the travelers are moved from the hotel or railroad station toward the wall. After passing through the checkpoint, which can cause delays, travelers are moved toward the opponents buildings to locate his Master Plan. When found, the Master Plan is rushed back through a checkpoint or Over the Wall.In addition, each player has two inspectors, which are used to hunt opposing enemy agents.

title: Frag PvP
types: Comic Book / Strip Expansion for Base-game Fighting Miniatures Science Fiction Video Game Theme
description:
Scott Kurtz' hit comic PvP is now a game. And it's not just any game . . . it's Frag!

Join Francis, Cole, Jade, Brent, and Skull as they blow each other away with flamethrowers, rocket launchers, and anything else they can get their hands on. This set features metal miniatures of the five main characters, sculpted by Richard Kerr, and 56 Frag cards illustrated by Scott Kurtz!

Extra special bonus: three original comic strips . . .

This is not a stand-alone game; it's a supplement for Frag, SJ Games' best-selling game of first-person shooter computer game mayhem, and you'll need that game to play.

title: Jamie Swise Mystery Games: Murder by Proxy
description:
Early (predecessor?) parlor/play-acting game of hosting a murder/mystery.  There were at least six games in the Jamie Swise line, some of which were incorporated into the Milton Bradley Life of the Party line of mystery games.  This one...

Why did a nice lady like Mary Wrightwood suddenly stop publishing her weekly gossip rag and begin building a virtual empire, producing closet pornography?  We think it is a question which needs answering.  And if that burning question doesn't compel you, you might like to figure out who murdered her.

The case of characters is indeed curious: a right-wing megalomaniac, the cold-blooded co-publisher, a pompous author, a flower child, the degenerate son, an immensely virile handy man, the town's mayor and only plumber, and Mary's bible thumping ex-best friend.

The time is March, 1968.  Feelin' groovy?

title: Lost Gold
description: Each player secretly hides 3 gold bags under the platform. The board is reversed and play begins. Neither player knows where the other has hidden his gold. The board is divided into a grid and a treasure detector is used to search for the buried treasure. The gold bags are magnetic and the treasure finder has a window that turns red when it has passed over treasure. A die is used to determine how many squares can be searched in a turn. The detector has a window that must be closed prior to searching for treasure. After moving the detector over a number of squares, the window is opened and if it has turned red, the detector has passed over a piece of your opponents treasure. By strategically searching the grid, a player is able to determine where the buried gold is hidden. A treasure map is provided to aid in remembering possible locations. The winner is the player that can locate all three treasure locations before his opponent. If you are not correct in all three locations, the opponent automatically wins.

title: Pay Cards!
description:
Based on the obscure 1968-69 game show, an MC is chosen and shuffles a deck of twenty cards. The cards are inserted face-down into a numbered vinyl sheet. Players choose three numbers from the vinyl sheet and the cards are revealed. If a pair shows, the player must take all three cards. If not, the player may refuse the cards and they are turned face down and placed back onto the numbered sheet. After all cards are drawn, the hands are evaluated and the players given cash for pairs, three of a kind, four of a kind, and for highest hand in the round. The player with the most money after three rounds plays the Jackpot Game and can earn additional money. The player with the most money after the Jackpot Game wins.

Three versions were apparently released: the original (Version I) has no Wild Cards and a red Jackpot spinner; the box has black copyright lettering, and the adult male wears a brown shirt. Some early copies of the release with Wild Cards (Version II) feature the same red Jackpot spinner and box design as Version I, but include the updated rules for using the Wild Card decks. Later Wild Card editions (Version III) have the updated rules and a black Jackpot spinner, plus the box has pink copyright lettering and the adult male wears a red shirt.

The game was given away as a consolation prize on the show. On the one circulating episode, late in the show's run (#209 of 260, taped 4/22/69), host Art James holds up the box with the brown-shirt male. This strongly suggests that Versions II and III each had a short print run.

title: Elementary Watson
description:
The perfect crime! This boxed game allows players to plan and try to solve it. No dice or other elements of chance.

One player (a referee) plots and writes the basics of a crime set in Victorian London. The other players (detectives) have little to work with at the start other than a description of what occurred, plus some information on the main characters. From that point on, it becomes a race against the clock since each crime must be solved within a set number of turns known only to the referee.

The mechanics are simple: detectives submit questions in writing to the referee. After collecting all of them, the referee answers them verbally. This means that the answers usually are understood only by the asking players. Questions must be very specific: for example, a player can check bank records only if he or she has spent part of a turn going to the bank. A mixed group of players will always have one or two ahead of the pack and one or two behind. Players also may pool information, but some always will hold back.

Elementary Watson is simple to play, difficult to master because it requires role-playing thinking. Players can choose areas of expertise, which might help them gain additional clues. A game board of London with neighborhoods and landmarks is included, but Elementary Watson can be played with paper and pencil.

title: Meet the Presidents
description: Game features collectible metal coins of all the presidents from Washington through Lyndon Johnson. By answering questions on American presidential history, players move their presidents around a track and on to the White House. First player to put 8 presidents in the White House wins.

title: Equality
description:
Almost identical to Scrabble, but with numbers forming equations rather than letters forming words.

The game is played with tiles numbered 0 to 12 and tiles showing mathematical signs and parentheses. Each tile has a score (except the equality sign and parentheses). The most valuable numeral is 7 (because it has the least options for making an equation that equals 12 or less) and the most valuable signs are division and multiplication (again because there are less equations involving these operations that equal 12 or less). Like scrabble, squares on the board can increase your score, whether an individual tile or for the entire equation.
Source:   http://www.dicemaestro.com/vintage-games/retroactive.asp

title: Scandinavia
description:
1997 BC, the Old World is at dawn of known Antic times... in those backwards times, in mythical Scandinavia, six great kingdoms coexist, inhabited by heroic fantasy creatures. You are the overlord of one of them.

Your aim: increase as best as possible the prosperity of your realm and extend your powers of domination. To achieve your target, you must cleverly manage your kingdom, timely tax your villagers, negociate alliances with other lords and enter trade to enrich your vast estates.

You can also try to conquer new areas to enlarge your territory, while protecting your villages and your lands by raising armies. Castles, windmilla, camps, fortifications, drakkars, merchant guilds, trade goods, ports; you might wish to build so your reign is better appreciated.

Honoring the gods and obtaining magic powers is also important in those mythical time: build temples and sanctuaries in your marvelous land...

You may be a Viking Lord, an Elfic Prince, Grand Priest of Chaos or Princess Sandra... then you might become the legitimate successor of Helric, anew mythical king, beloved of the Gods and worthy of legends to come...

title: Earth Satellite Game
description: Using a three stage rocket, players attempt to avoid launch mishaps, meteors and other space debris as they attempt to move from the earth to the moon.

title: The Sting Game
description:
You have just landed on Teaser's Lucky Casino; its token is valued at 20 million. You quickly take a deal card and give it a sly glance. Is the deal card worth millions or is it a worthless Sting Card? Nobody knows except you! The tension mounts as you place both the token and the card on the gameboard. As the Sting Man, you open the bidding with 10 million... the other players are confused... are you bluffing, or does the deal have a real value? They all pass. You make your final bid... 120 million. The next player sense a Sting Card... he challenges; the following player thinks you bid too high... he challenges; the last player pauses... 121 million... he wants the deal.

A grin crosses your face as you are handed 121 million in cash. Slowly the deal card is turned over... it's a Sting!

You have to be a shrewd Sting Man to make the wildest deals and get away with it... or be sharp enough to uncover a Sting to receive the big payoff. If you work your deals with skill and finesse, you'll build the largest fortune and win the game.

title: Consequential
description:
Teams compete to reach the winning square first.  On a turn, a team is given a card with five words on it.  They roll dice to determine their sequence of letters (e.g. B-J).  Then the timer starts.

The team's active clue-giver must use single word clues, in sequence, to get his or her teammates to guess the key words.  An example from the box bottom:

Block... Cold... Dry... ICE!
Electric... Fluorescent... Glows... Halogen... LAMP!
Pass I (Yes, you can pass, but be careful)
Jump... Bronco... Cowboy... pass D... Event... RODEO!

That's about it.

title: Dollars & Sense
description: Dollars  Sense is a fun and educational game that enables players to make real world decisions. Players must decide if they will own or rent a home, buy auto and health insurance, and whether or not to buy things on credit. Players can make career decisions as well. The game is played for a pre-determined amount of time and the player with the most net worth at that time, is declared the winner. A good educational game that parents can use to show youngsters how to make wise choices.

title: Quest for the Ideal Mate
description:
From the back of the box...

It's here!... the revolutionary new game that replaces dating bureaus, singles bars, sex therapy and marriage counseling.  CAUTION.  It is not for monks, nuns or hermits.  Quest for the Ideal Mate is a game for the liberated male and female.  You will discover who you are, who others are--and what you can be together!  Playing with 3 to 12 friends, strangers, lovers, marital partners (or any combination of these).  It could result in a single person discovering their Ideal Mate within the group.  You'll laugh your head off at the responses of the other players while awaiting what's in store for you.

Shirl Solomon, internationally known handwriting analyst, author and lecturer on personality and compatibility has created Quest for the Ideal Mate to provide an entertaining diversion for people to get to know each other.  One game will tell you more about someone's hidden character than a dozen dates and bare feelings on countless subjects that would not surface in a normal relationship until too late.
End of box quotes.  There are also ideal mate trait cards to be filled out and at the end of the game, you find out how compatible you are with others in the group.  Box says it plays best with an equal number of each sex.

title: Desperado
description: Sort of the Clue of the old west. At the start of the game, one player secretly becomes the Desperado. He must make his way to the city where his money is stashed and head across the Mexican border to safety. The other players use deduction to determine who the Desperado is and try to land on his location and capture him before he crosses the border. A good game that involves bluffing and deception.

title: Jet World
types: Adventure Aviation / Flight Economic Transportation Travel
mechanisms: Commodity SpeculationRoll / Spin and MoveSet CollectionTrading
description: Players travel around the Jet World gameboard, going from city to city, to buy various World Traded Articles, some of which are worthless. The others have a value that can go up or down, according to the number showing on the World Price Board. When a player has two or three matching articles of value, the money paid by the bank, when they are sold or used as a bonus, increases tremendously. The object is to have the most money, at the end, when the value of each player's article cards and cash are added together. Game features exotic locations like London and Berlin, and commodities like diamonds, sports cars, and gold

title: Tuf-abet
description:
Players compete against time and one another to be the first to use all (or most) of their 20 letter-cubes.  Each player has the same combination of cubes, but the letters are randomized by rolling prior to each turn.  The 3-minute timer is then started.

The first player to complete their grid (to their satisfaction) calls Tuf and receives an 8 point bonus at which time a second timer is started (2 minutes).  If anyone else should top that player's number of used letters (must beat, not match), they may call Tuffer and start the 1-minute timer.  At this time, the Tuf player may re-enter the competition by reorganizing his cubes (but the Tuffer player is hands-off).  Should someone top the Tuffer player's tally during this one-minute span, he or she shouts Tuffest and the turn is over.  Otherwise, players simply finish their grids before the minute is over and then everyone totals their score.

Bonus points are given for capitalized words, longer words (6+ letters), and intersecting letters in the grid.  Also, the Tuf and Tuffest players receive 8 point bonuses (this often being the same player who uses all 20 cubes during the first 3-minute segment).

title: Build the American Dream
description:
Object of the game is to become the player with the greatest net worth through accumulating money, buying a house and improving the house with extra features or Hot Buttons.

There are three phases.  The outer ring is for collecting money for a down payment.  The middle ring is the bank, requiring house inspections, title searches, closing, etc.  The inner ring is the neighborhood where you gain power and prestige within the block and add on to the house (and experience financial ups and downs).

Subtitle is an adult strategy game for today's home buyer

title: Hauberk
description:
Hauberk: The Ultimate Game of Intellectual Cunning, is how this game is billed.  The side of the box reads A game of ruses and rescue.  And according to the rule book, the objective is:

To rescue the Princess by entering the castle where she is located after you have become a Player Knight.  Though you are courageous as a Squire, and possess the ability to locate the Princess, you lack the power to save her.  Only as a Player Knight may you accomplish your task.

It appears that a player can accumulate artifacts and cards to progress towards being a player knight.  Then if he or she can enter the castle (where the princess is), that person wins.

Seems much like a 1970s fantasy video game combined with The Mystic Wood.

Was once on the Games Magazine Top 100 games list.

title: Real People
description:
The object is to be the player (or team) who earns the most points by correctly matching photos of people with what they wrote about themselves when asked 10 questions.

The more quickly the person is identified, the greater the score for the person or team.

After a series of rounds, the player(s) with the highest score wins.

title: An Evening of Murder: The Final Act
Fence
description:
Fence is popular with both children and adult game and card enthusiasts, and combines game board strategy fencing squares of high value and skill in booking words and forming sentences.

Players own that territory which he fences, and plays with posts of the same color. Each player should try to complete the fencing of a square in order to book a word for scoring with the cards he has drawn from the deck, face down on the table.

Each play on the board is made in the same territory as the color of card drawn. Players try to build a natural fence in opponent's territory, as a bit of zest, as a word being formed by opponents is broken up.

title: Truth or Consequences
types: Bluffing Humor Movies / TV / Radio theme Party Game Trivia
description:
Editions vary in execution but one player asks a trivia question or riddle of the one or more of the other players. A player scores by answering correctly and the turn passes to the next player. If the player fails to give the correct answer then the player must complete a physical stunt to score. Players takes turns being quizzed and quizzer.

The game ends after a predetemined number of rounds or after someone reaches the goal score. Highest score wins.

This a faithful translation of the television (and radio) game show with the same name.

title: Flight of the Boodles
description: This is a simple wargame from The Dragon magazine.  One player commands the Boodles and tries to get them across the gameboard safely.  The other player commands the Grumjugs and attempts to destroy the Boodles before they make it across.

title: Arrakhar's Wand
description:
Published in ''The Dragon'' magazine, Issue #69.

From the introduction:

Arrakhar's Wand is a fantasy boardgame of tactics and strategy for two players. One player (the sorcerer player) hides the wand in his realm and defends it with a group of evil sorcerers who can summon the aid of demons, orcs, and ghouls. The other player (the wizard player) invades with a force of good wizards, barbarians, dwarves, and elves, seeking to locate the wand and escape with it.

Before the play of the game begins, both players secretly design their forces. The board portrays the valley of the evil sorcerers, and on it the sorcerer player places the counters representing haunts (temples, ruins, and crypts), secretly recording one of them as the haunt in which the wand is hidden. The counters representing the sorcerers and their minions are then placed on the board, and on the sorcerer player's first turn they can begin summoning other evil units. The wizard player brings in the wizard units and their allies through one or more hexes along the valley border, and the struggle begins.

Each side can attack with spells and by physical combat. The wizard player should usually try to strike quickly, before the sorcerer player can organize an effective resistance. Only the sorcerer player gets a steady stream of reinforcements, in the form of wandering-orc counters, but the wizard player has the advantage of special attacking bonuses. To win, the wizard player must locate the wand and remove it from the sorcerers' valley through an entry/exit hex.

title: Marston Moor
types: Civil War Pike and Shot Wargame
description:
Marston Moor is a simulation of the largest battle oh the English Civil War. Fought in the county of Yorkshire, this battle decided the fate of the North and influenced the ultimate course of the war.

Published in Issue 7 of The Wargamer Magazine.

260 counters = Simulation Games 1978 Edition

title: Heroes of the Maze
description:
Players move fantasy pieces through a large, circular, ever-changing, plastic maze to reach the center and battle an ogre for magic rings.

On your turn, roll 1d6 and then rotate the walls of the maze to clear a path for yourself, with the aim of reaching the center of the maze, moving as far as you want/can before moving the walls again.

The first player to defeat the ogre at the center of the maze takes his place and can then use the ogre to rampage through the maze, attacking other adventurers.

Each time you win a fight you gain a treasure ring.  The winner is the first person to gain three rings.

title: Caesar's Game
description:
An original game of pure strategy.

Roman coins (representing wealth) move diagonally, whilst metal columns (representing empire) jump over coins, of either color, in order to form a square formation on four adjacent circles to be victorious.

Rules are very simple; a double-sided A4 sheet provides ample explanation, but the strategy is deep, and developing the ability to assess the state of play at any given time requires considerable application in order to play the game well.  A winning situation may be engineered very quickly from a seemingly hopeless one.

title: Der Fuhrer
description:
Quirky little ziplock bag (remember them?) game in which players representing different political parties vie for control of pre-Nazi Germany.

Players select campaign platforms and move from one province to another trying to elect enough Reichstag deputies to win. Components aren't much, but play includes issues such as fiscal austerity, Versailles treaty, law and order. Nazi and Communist party players have street mobs options.

No incentive is provided for cooperation among players, giving the Nazi Party player a slight edge. If no one accumulates enough deputy points after three elections to win, players may assume that President Hindenburg restores the monarchy, or continue playing until winner is declared.

The game is comprised of a 28-page softcover digest, with a map and markers sheet.

title: Don't Feed the Gators
description:
It's a race!  Be the first player to get your monkey across the gator-infested swamp to Great Banana Island, and you win.  But whatever you do, Don't Feed The Gators!

The path to the Island goes across the backs of the four gators; when a player lands on a gator's snout, his monkey is put in the gator's gaping jaws, and the naughty red monkey is then placed on the gator's neck.  This sometimes makes the gator's jaws snap shut --and you must start all over with a fresh monkey.

The monkey spaces on the board allow you to swap your place with another player's, so you're always in the race, even when far behind.  The gator spaces allow you to designate a monkey to advance to the next gator jaws in front of him --sometimes you'll get rid of the competitor, sometimes you'll help him get closer to the finish!

It's all done with magnets.   ;-)

title: Torpedo Run Card Game Deluxe Edition
description:
Additional details from the instruction booklet:

OBJECT: To score points by launching a ship that cruises to a required number of ports which completes a cruise. Four may play as 2 partnerships, adding to the same cruises. Otherwise, they play as individual players.

Contents:

    2 decks of cards




Pencil and paper are also required to play but are not provided.

Card breakdown is as follows:


    Captain (16 cards)
    Sailor (16 cards)
    Port (16 cards)
    Ship (16 cards)
    Torpedo Run (4 cards)
    Torpedo (4 cards)
    Port Blockade (4 cards)

title: No Respect: Rodney Dangerfield's Game
description:
From the box:

Here's just the game for you Dangerfield fans--a combination of strategy, suspense and total frustration to challenge even the most self-respecting player!

Stay alive by playing number tiles on your own columns--or on your opponents', to stop them.  If you're the first to reach the top, or the last to play a number, you win, and everybody else is a loser!

The odds can quickly stack up against you in this fast-paced game of ups and downs.  You could be one number away from a win, lose a column, and suddenly find yourself behind!  So plan each move carefully, keep a sharp eye on your opponents--and don't count on winning 'til you've won!

title: Land Race Card Game
types: Card Game Children's Game Racing Transportation Travel
description: Collect all 3 REGION cards in numerical sequence to win the race (a cross between UNO and Mille Bornes).  For ages 4-9.

title: Incognito: The Game of Charades
types: Action / Dexterity Humor Party Game Word Game
description:
The game of charades with three new twists

Players act out the provided charades and then try to stump your opponents with Bonus Tidbit questions.

title: Operation Condor: The Liberation of Spain 1942/1943
description:
Condor is a hypothetical simulation of the circumstances in which Spain might heve been forced into active participation in World War II.

Scenario A involves a German invasion of Spain in 1942 while Scenario B is concerned with an Allied invasion of the peninsula in 1943.

Published in The Wargamer Magazine issue 6 as well as in a boxed edition

Counters = 260 (includes 52 blank white counters and 15 blank blue counters)

title: The Wine Game
description: The Wine Game is a trip through the famous wine producing countries of the world - France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Portugal, and the U.s.  With a role of the dice and some entrepreneurial skill, you can own vineyards in California, a wine estate in Italy or most of the great wines in France.  The Wine Game has the thrills, excitement and speculation of the real wine world.  It involves buying and selling great vineyards, bidding in rare wine auctions and risking your fortune on a chance to become the wine baron of the world.  The Wine Game is fun to play.  But it isn't just a game - it's an education!

title: Tunisia 43
description: Tunisia 43 uses a streamlined version of the same system found in Moments in History's Piercing the Reich and Triumphant Fox. This system is very interactive with players activating each of their formations at various times during the turn.

title: Body Boggle
description:
From the back of the box:

Two players from each team use their hands and feet to spell out words on the letter mat.  The first word's not too hard to stretch and spell, but just try rearranging hands and feet to spell the next word. And the next. And the next...It's the word game that's truly body boggling!

To win, your team must spell 20 words or more.

title: The Great War 1914-1918
description:
A strategic level, area movement game based on WWI. The map covers all major European and West-Asian countries ranging from Britain and France in the west to Persia and Russia in the east. Players maneuver armies, corps, and naval squadrons while engaging in mobilization, combat, and diplomacy.

There are seven historical and one hypothetical scenario, plus a campaign game that links all of them into one massive 72 turn game. (One turn equals one month.)

Each player begins with a set amount of resources and must manage them properly to gain victory. Run out of money (National Resource Credits) before the others and you're probably out of the game. Similarly, players have fixed mobilization pools from which to draw on to create new units. You can end up with having enough money to outfit a new infantry division but without any more young men to wear those uniforms! There are no endless supplies in this game to keep building unit after unit after unit. Makes for a very challenging and interesting gaming situation.

Contents: 

    1 32 x 22 map 
    200 double-sided die-cut counters 
    Rules Booklet 




Also available: 1 errata sheet, 1 advanced tournament optionals sheet.

title: D.A.K.
mechanisms: Action Point Allowance SystemSecret Unit Deployment
description:
Strategic level game covering the battle for North Africa during WWII. The key feature of this game is its operation points which represent supply. These points are expended when units move or fight and also just to maintain a unit's existence. They're moved from the ports to the forward battle area and require record keeping.

This game's supply system portrays the situation that existed. Even if you're just digging in and awaiting an attack, you still need supplies flowing to your troops to feed (and water) them. Also, because all units must be able to trace supply to exist, players are rewarded well when successfully able to cut off enemy units from their rear areas. You can even capture enemy supply depots that are located too close to the front.

It can be linked with the game La Regia Marina, also published by Simulations Canada. When playing this way, the available number of operations points is based on how well you manage your fleets and convoys in La Regia Marina rather than the fixed supply schedule that comes with D.A.K.

One full map is divided into Eastern map and Western map.  The whole map covers from Damascus to Casabranca.  This is one of the widest map of this theatre, I think.

title: JUMP: Genesis Savage Manakins vs. Micro Titans
description:
JUMP: Genesis Savage Manakins vs. Micro Titans is a strategic level conquest game that can be played solo or with up to 4 players if a second set is used.

The object of the game is to conquer the Home World(s) of the other player by using space and ground forces, and fortifications as defense. Although most of the pieces are hex tiles, special measuring sticks are included which are used in the basic game, and even more sticks for the miniatures game.

The components are actually usable in three ways. (1) As a stand alone game for 1-2 (3-4 with additional sets) player, (2) as an expansion for JUMP: Into the Unknown game, or (3) as a tactical miniature game.

title: JUMP: Genesis Die-Cast Messiahs vs. Cannibal Korp
description:
JUMP: Genesis Die-Cast Messiahs vs. Cannibal Korp is a strategic level conquest game that can be played solo or with up to 4 players if a second set is used.

The object of the game is to conquer the Home World(s) of the other player by using space and ground forces, and fortifications as defense. Although most of the pieces are hex tiles, special measuring sticks are included which are used in the basic game, and even more sticks for the miniatures game.

The components are actually usable in three ways. (1) As a stand alone game for 1-2 (3-4 with additional sets) player, (2) as an expansion for JUMP: Into the Unknown, or (3) as a tactical miniature game.

title: Grand Empire
description: Build and maintain a strong empire by strategically placing, reversing, and moving game pieces to destroy your opponent's empire. Grand Empire is not for the weak of mind as it challenges one's strategic skills and decision making ability. With a combination of skill and lady luck on your side, your empire will never fall.

title: 5 in a Row Challenge
description: 5 in a Row Challenge is not just a game of connecting 5 game pieces in a row. With the ability to capture your opponent's pieces and move pieces after all 25 pieces have been placed on the board, connecting 5 in a row becomes a fun, exciting, and satisfying challenge.

title: Flinke Finger
description:
Flinke Finger is a collection of 3 different games:

REFLEX is a fast, exciting card laying game.  
Goal of the game: Each player tries to get rid of his cards as quickly as possible and, by doing so, to score points.

TRAF is more tactical, but, still easy to understand.  
Goal of the game:  Each player tries to get as many points as possible by skillfully combining his cards.

PUKO is a poker variant with interesting special rules.  
Goal of the game: Each player tries to score as many points as possible with his card combinations.

title: Europa Universalis Extension No 1
types: Economic Expansion for Base-game Renaissance Wargame
description:
This expansion to Europa Universalis adds a complete countersheet and rules to AWE's game of early modern Europe (1492-1792).

Countersheet Europa Universalis #7 contains 260 square counters and 13 round counters.

New types of counters include:

    Forts (like fortresses, but you can build them on the Rest-of-the-World map)
    Missionaries and missions, which give bonuses on some colonial actions.  Some are marked Jesuit, Franciscan, Torquemada
    Colonial governors
    Sepoys (colonial land detachments -- they're the ones marked Cipaye) can be raised by the French, British and Dutch for use in Asia
    Native allies -- American Indian detachments that can be raised by the French in North America
    New industry counters for Prussia, Sweden and some major powers




New rules include:

    A simplified Fast Resolution System for land combat
    New minor states - Corsica, Napoli, Granada, Sicily, Catalonia, Ireland, Ukraine
    Rules for games with fewer than 6 players.  You treat the non-player powers as Minor Countries.
    A list of historical monarchs, with their Admin, Diplomatic and Military values.
    Additional/Replacement leaders for several scenarios in the original game, using new counters from the expansion set.
    Provisions for existing forts, missions, etc. in the campaign scenarios of the original game.




New scenarios:

    7 Years War in Europe and the world
    War of the Austrian Succession in Europe and the world
    Felicissima Armada (1588)
    Culloden
    Turco-Persian War of 1630-1639
    War in Livonia 1560-1582

title: Victory Circle
description:
Victory Circle is a variant on the old Trap the Cap game.

The object of the game is to be the player with the most capped and/or captured pieces at the end of the game.  You can only cap one piece at a time; it is best to drag the capped piece back to your Victory Circle --where it'll remain until the end of the game.  When you cap a piece that is itself capping another, you get to keep either one capped, setting the other free (sending it back to its own Victory Circle).  The green spaces are safe.

The game ends when all of a player's pieces are capped or captured.  If keeping score, captured pieces are worth 3, capped pieces 1.

title: Supremacy
description: This game is very similar to Monopoly. Players go around the board and buy cities, with infantry, subs, generals etc (rather than money). Once they have a set of any 2 cities in a county they can then build forts, which enables the fort owner to receive military units from other players who land on that city.

title: Planet of the Apes
types: Exploration Fantasy Maze Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction
mechanisms: Modular BoardRoll / Spin and MoveSet CollectionTile Placement
description:
Designed to cash in on the popular remake of the classic sci-fi movie Planet of the Apes, the object of this game is to collect a set of items which will allow you to be the first to escape the planet through a time portal.  The playing surface comprises 20 modular board units which are shuffled prior to play and therefore create a randomized labyrinth planet to be explored.  120 push-out cardboard tiles  represent hidden bonuses and hazards and three special dice decide the combat and range of movement. Exploration elements work well and ensure no two games are the same. Dressing the board with the rather fiddly little tiles each time a new part of the maze is uncovered can become tedious. The cumulative effect of collected weapons can render a lucky player almost invincible very quickly, with the chimp warriors soon becoming superfluous and little more than an irritation.

A reasonable strategic exploration game for the younger player.

title: End of the Line
description:
You can win in either of two ways.  Be the first to score five points (with the small token) before moving the large token onto the End Of The Line space or outlast the opponents so they all end up at the End Of The Line before you do, even if you score less.

The players simultaneously choose one of their 13 cards to play.  Ties are discarded; of the remaining cards, the highest scores a point.  Except for the discards, all players move their large tokens toward the End Of The Line by the amount played.

title: Push
description:
The object of the game is to Push your Prince from its home position to one of the crowned squares on the opposite side of the board (the edge rows).  This is achieved with the help of your eight Escort pieces.

On your turn, you move either your Prince (1, 2 or 3 steps) or an Escort (by its exact value: 3, 4, 5 or 6).  Each step is horizontal, diagonal or vertical --but the board is odd.  It is 33x33 with 64 3x3 tiles punched out, some with a connected square remaining in the middle.

Jumps aren't allowed.  A Push occurs when an Escort arrives short of another piece (Princes can't Push); what happens is that the Escort's remaining steps are transferred to the pushed piece --which may be an opposing piece or your own Prince.  The pushed piece's move must be in a straight line, in the direction dictated by the collision.  When the straight line isn't possible, deflection occurs as indicated in the rules.  Compound pushes can occur, when a pushed piece in turn collides with another.

title: Rrib-Bit
description:
Battle of the Frogs

On a 7x9 chessboard, the central 3x3 area is marked off as the Arena.  Each player sits at a long edge and starts with his nine frogs (hollow plastic figurines, 7 cm along their largest dimension) filling that row.  All frogs move like Chess knights.  Light moves first.  Capture is by landing on an opposing frog and is not mandatory.  The object of the game is to line up three frogs horizontally, vertically or diagonally in the Arena in such a way that the opponent cannot break it up (by capture) on his next move.  A draw occurs when both players are down to two frogs.

In advanced play, a frog that captures gets to move again, sort of like in Checkers.  Other variations allowed include different starting dispositions (any can be used as long as they are player-symmetrical).  Finally, the alternate win rule states that you can also win by reducing the opponent to two frogs.

title: Tac-Tic-Turn
description: A simple variant of Tic-Tac-Toe.  The board measures 6x6 and is subdivided into nine 2x2 boardlets which can individually be turned.  On your turn, you either place a marker *or* turn a boardlet ninety degrees.  First player to line up four or more markers horizontally, vertically or diagonally wins.

title: Entertainment Tonight: The Trivia Game
description:
From the box:

Entertainment Tonight: The Trivia Game is the family-fun board game that challenges everyone's trivia IQ.  The game contains 3600 questions in 6 categories, including the fields of History and Geography, Entertainment, and Sports.  Questions are graded on each card in levels of difficulty from 1 thru 6.  You choose the level of difficulty to win faster or win safely.  Strategy counts!

title: Berzerk
types: Abstract Strategy Children's Game Fighting Science Fiction Video Game Theme
description:
From the box:

Go Berzerk and play the exciting shoot-em-up game that's just as much fun as the arcade game of the same name!  You and your opponent take turns controlling either the Humanoid Warrior or the indestructible Evil Otto and his robot army.  Make the wrong move and your Humanoid will get zapped.  You score points for every enemy robot your Humanoid zaps and a bonus if you get all six.  You opponent gets a chance to be the Humanoid player and zap robots to score points later in the game.  Score more points than your opponent and you'll win the game!

title: Lucan
description:
From the box:

In this game adapted from the TV series, follow Lucan, the boy raised by wolves, in his daring search for his parents.  Travel with him on his danger-filled adventures, rescuing people and animals from perilous situations.

title: JED
description: JED = Just Employed Dimwit.  Card game of climbing the corporate ladder.  Cards are business card-sized of fictional companies.  Players take on different roles, and income denotes which role you play.  Your income can change based on how well you do each round, so you can be CEO one turn and eventually fall to JED if you're not careful.

title: It's Only Money The Game
description:
From the box:

Shoppers enter the It's Only Money Mall via the spinner and begin shopping, with the aim or acquiring 5 spaces on the It's Only Money Shopping Money Card, while denying opponents' ability to do the same.  Perilous pitfalls and profitable bonus spaces all contribute to playing excitement.  The first player to acquire the five spacess, as well as the $50,000 in game money, is the winner.  It's a fast paced game of shopping strategy, savvy and spending.  Do you have what it takes to win it all?

title: The Mother Goose Game
description: Great introductory game similar to Candy Land.  Spin the spinner and move you pawn to the first space with matching colors.  If you land on a rhyme picture, you try to match it with the nursery rhyme on the board.  If you do so, you move to that rhyme!  The winner is the first person to make it to the Humpty Dumpty rhyme square.

title: Jack and the Beanstalk Memory Game
description:
From the box:

An ideal family game: challenging for all ages, yet a game that children frequently (usually!) can win against adults.  Requires concentration, memory, and a bit of luck!

Note - it's a simple race game with a mechanism like Chicken Cha Cha Cha - you move forward if you can turn over a tile matching the space in front of your pawn.  You continue to move until you cannot make a match.

title: Sweet Pickles
description:
From the box:

Here are the famous funny Sweet Pickles and here is the town they live in.  Welcome!

Although the game is basically a simple collection game for the young child, it is made even more entertaining by the dialogue (suitable for early readers) from each of the animal characters.  Reading is not required, only optional.  The game is based on the characters created by Ruth Lerner Perle and Jacquelyn Reinach and illustrated by Richard Hefter.

title: The Goldilocks and the Three Bears Game
description: Another simple children's game in the same vein as Candy Land.  It's a race around the board.  Spin the spinner and move your pawn to the next matching symbol on the trail.  If you land on someone else, they have to move back to the previous space with the same symbol.  Continue until someone wins.

title: Sly
description:
Sly isn't a single game but six different ones, sharing board and pieces.  The board is 12x12, divided in 16 fields of 3x3, with field centres specially marked.  The pieces come in four colours and each set consists of a cylinder, four triangles and six squares.

All games but Line up use the whole 12x12 grid as a playing area. Line Up only uses the center positions of the 16 3x3 fields to effectively yield a 4x4 grid of playing positions.

Solitaire Sly is for 1 player and is a variation on the old puzzle of removing pieces by selected jumps. The game starts in 6x6 grid of pieces, but pieces can jump outside the 6x6 area using the whole 12x12 board if desired.

Sniggle is a racing game for 2-4 players.

Line Up is an alignment two-player game played on a 4x4 grid with each player having two squares, two triangles and one cyclinder of his color.

Empire is an abstract two-four player wargame of sorts.

Blockade (two players) is a distant relative of Hnefatafl; each player tries to have his king escape whilst blocking the other's with his guards.

Gateway, finally, is a 2-4 player game where each tries to enter all his pieces by forming alignments with opposing pieces.

title: Condomoneyum
description:
In this heavily sponsored game, the players are advertising executives who try to land accounts with clients and earn money (through the accounts, speculation on the stocks of the companies whose accounts they hold, lotteries and random events) so as to buy their condo, room by room.  First one to complete his condo wins.

Movement is controlled by a distance die (1-3) and a direction die (east, west, uptown, downtown, choice).

Very random, as the players have no influence on the values of the stocks of the accounts they hold, for example.

title: Feeding Frenzy
description:
The object of the game is to score the most points by competing against other great white sharks for a limited supply of prey.

There are two levels of play.  In the introductory game, the sharks circle around the outer board, attacking each other when they catch up or from the Circle or Attack spaces.  After each fight, the winner takes 5 prey tokens from the loser.  Starve and you lose a turn.  Other spaces make you lose or gain prey tokens, and the Feeding Frenzy space causes a fight royale.

In the full game, the inner part of the board represents the prey population; when your movement allows, you can dip into and out of this part of the board to eat prey.  Prey reproduces periodically, replenishing the inner board.  Whoever fed the most after 10 to 20 rounds (depending on the number of players) wins.  But if you're too greedy and you wipe out all prey, all sharks starve and everyone loses!

title: Sherlock Holmes Game
description: A distant relative of Clue, where each player tries to deduce the Suspect, Motive, Crime Location and Weapon cards that were put in the Cemetary at the game's outset.  Suspicion cards change hands, some are revealed to all, and so on.  You win by correctly deducing the four hidden cards.  Deduce incorrectly and you've lost, however.

title: Iron Horse
description:
Each player draws cards from the Rolling Stock Deck and uses them to construct a passenger or freight train. Players then draw cards from the Operations Deck. Operations cards will be passenger cards, freight cards, special cards, or destination cards. Passenger cards may only be loaded on cars for passengers. Freight cards may only be loaded on freight cars. The destination cards govern the movement of the trains from place to place. Special cards are either disasters or opportunities.

(Note that this game is unrelated to Metro, which was coincidentally originally released with the title Iron Horse.)

title: Expedition
description: The players are competing archaeologists on digs throughout Egypt.  Each wants to publish more valuable discoveries than his competitors.  Status points replace money.  Discovery cards need to be collected (in sets of four) to form complete discoveries.

title: Incredible Hulk Smash-Up Action Game
types: Action / Dexterity Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
From the rules:

While doing research, Dr. Banner became the victim of radiation gone wild.  Now, in times of stress, he becomes transformed into the rampaging Incredible Hulk.  He must build a lab to cure his terrible problem.  Each player tries to build one for him.  But watch out - the players must sometimes rev up and unlease The Hulk who could, in his rage, smash up the Labs that are being built!  Players must rebuild and survive the Hulk's attacks to win.  POW!

title: Doctor, Doctor!
description:
From the box:

Doctor! Doctor! Come Quick! It's poor Mr Illbert!  He's sick in bed again.  Does he have Burning Ears, or is it an outbreak of the dangerous Stiff Upper Lip?  Maybe it's Love Sickness... Or is he Just Fakin'?  If your diagnosis is correct, it'll speed you up the ladder from Medical Student to Chief Doctor! (and Mr. Illbert will be eternally grateful to you too).

title: Yogi Bear Game
types: Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
From the box:

Yogi and Boo Boo were at home in their cave.  It was a nice day and the door was open.  The aroma of fresh baked cakes and doughnuts drifted thru the open door.  Yogi knew it came from Ranger Smith's Headquarters and he was determined to get a taste of the goodies.  Boo Boo told Yogi he could get in real trouble if he tried to get them.  Yogi said he would go alone but Boo Boo knew he would help his friend if he could.  In this game, each player moves both Yogi and Boo Boo thru many adventures to be the first to get to the Ranger Station and all the sweets there.

title: Null Bock!
description: Null Bock is the game of deer mating rituals.  Cards include Bucks and Does which are played to a central arena or to peripheral areas by each player.  Those in the center must constantly better the previous buck or doe, while there are separate rules for the periphery.  Points are scored by collecting doe cards.  The null bock (zero buck) is too cool to fight and has special abilities to overcome the strongest buck.

title: Duckling Dancin'
types: Children's Game Expansion for Base-game Memory
description:
This is a two-fold expansion for Chicken Cha Cha Cha.

1) You get two more birds so you can play Chicken Cha Cha Cha with up to six players now!  The newer figures look more like ducks than chickens.

2) You also get chicken poo in matching colors to the chickens.  These act as extra obstacles that other chickens have to avoid.  If you fall in someone else's poo, you have to give that player one of your feathers!

This game is part of The Chicken Family of Zoch.

Expands:

    Chicken Cha Cha Cha

title: The Disneyland Game
types: Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme
description: This game was produced for the 35th Anniversary of Disneyland. Be the player who scores the most points by visiting Disneyland attractions, seeing Disney characters, and taking photos on your trip through the Magic Kingdom.

title: Thunder
description:
From the box:

Thunder is a unique card game based on the seasons of the year. The object of the game is to win tricks with cards played from your hand and be the first to reach a game winning score.

title: CrossWord: The New York Times Sunday Puzzle Game
description:
From the box:

Analyze the Sunday crossword clues, try to decide which ones their opponents don't know, then challenge them to fill in those answers.  Go on the offensive with clue selections for your opponent to solve, then be part of the action as the grid fills up, points accumulate, and defensive play takes over.  It's non-stop excitement until the last few open squares, when anyone can come from behind to win CrossWord!

title: Back to the Farm
description:
From the rules:

The object of the game is to be the first player to collect and fill up his or her Farm Card with 19 Farm Items to win the game.  The lucky farmer gets to wear the ORGANIC FARMER OF THE YEAR button - at least until the next game!  During the game, farmers will discover various strategies they can employ - fair and square.

(Note - this is a Monopoly-styled game with plenty of education features and a booklet about organic farming).

title: Mansions & Money
description:
From the box

Create your own ideal home with breathtaking house plans designed by one of the country's leading architectural firms, fabulous top-of-the-line building products and magnificent furniture from America's leading manufacturers of building products and home furnishings.  Develop your strategy to move into your ideal home before your opponents do - using the very best products on the market today.  All photos feature real building products, furniture and accessories that are actually available for sale in galleries and home centers!

title: Fat Chance
description:
From the box:

Fat Chance is a rollicking game for children that nutrition-conscious parents will love.  Players move Fat Man pawns around the colorful game board trying to collect as FEW junk food pounds as possible.  But the temptations are many and it's hard to resist pie a la mound, mozzarella mess, sunday driver and the tube steak special (sic).  What a combination - Ugh!  Just imagine what you'll feel like after stuffing yourself with all that junk! (yuk!) If you are lucky, though, you'll be able to sweat off some of those pounds in the steam bath.  Then if you challenge another Fat Man to a Weigh-In, he'll be the one to flip down the scale not you.  What a relief because the fewer pounds you gain the better your chances are of winning the game of Fat Chance.

title: Intuition
types: Deduction Educational Memory Party Game Word Game
description:
Unusual party game from the mid-trivia binge.  Players are to collect five experience tokens and one skill chip from each of the seven intuitive areas.  The game includes hundreds of props for the different intuitive skills, which are as follows:

Pattern Perception: name a word which is printed in a very blurred fashion.

Psycho-Osmosis: Determine the meaning of a selected Hieroglyph.

Analysis: Select the two points of a large maze which are connected.

Imagination: Draw an abstract image card and name four things it could be (may require a vote from fellow players).

Connection: Draw two abstract image cards and state how they could be connected.

Recall: Look at an image and recall five or more of the eight items depicted.

Recognition: Look at an image card, then turn it over and point out the three images which weren't on the face.

The trick here is that all these actions have a 12-second time limit.  No analysis paralysis.  Players pretty much have to shoot from the hip or, that is to say, use their intuition.

A second edition was published and the meta-game of this edition was to intuitively figure out the exact date and time of that release.  First 100 correct guessers were to receive a limited 2nd edition.

title: People Weekly
description: This is a party game loosely based on the popular weekly magazine of the same name.  Players roll dice to determine the category and method to use for the round.  In attempting to get one's teammates to guess the celebrity within the particular category, they must use one of four methods: impersonations, charades, word associations, or drawing - before the time runs out.  You can also wager some of your points to increase the payoff.

title: Kreskin's ESP
description:
From the box:

Extra Sensory Perception is the ability to send or receive thoughts, using only your mind to do so.  Do you have this supernatural power?  Kreskin, the worlds foremost authority on ESP, thinks you do. You need only to develop it. This fascinating ESP game shows how!

Imagine the fun! Alone, or with a friend, or with a whole party of people, players can reveal their innermost thoughts on love, politics, or any other subject. Kreskins ESP game will give you the opportunity to reveal your ESP powers and explore the outer frontiers of the human mind in two scientifically proven ways.

Similar to an Ouija board, this game includes several tricks and a magic pendulum which can be used to determine answers to yes/no questions and even spell out words.

From correspondence with Kreskin, December 2010:

Regarding your inquiry about the Kreskin ESP game, yours truly designed the game.  As far as the artwork for the box, the Milton Bradley people had their staff do that.  At one point, the amount of sales was over a million and it approached two million.
 Thank you for your interest about the game.  It became a very popular showcase, as I played it with many people on television, including Johnny Carson, Mike Douglas, and Merv Griffin, as the pendulum proved to be a fascinating phenomena.
 With all my best thoughts,
Kreskin

title: GIPF Project Set 2
description:
This includes two expansions for GIPF and one for ZÈRTZ.

Contents:


     6 DVONN-potentials for each player
     6 ZRTZ-potentials for each player
     12 ZRTZ rings


See the project GIPF wiki page for more details on the potentials' powers.

This expansion can integrate DVONN and ZÈRTZ with the original GIPF game. Additionally, it contains ring pieces to extend the ZÈRTZ board into new configurations.

The ZRTZ-potential has the power to jump other pieces. The DVONN-potential has the power to land on top of other pieces, changing their color.

This is part of project GIPF.

title: Deduction
description:
From the box

Deduction - the game that makes thinking fun!  Deduction is the great new game for the entire family... a challenge of wits and deductive reasoning.  Both players secretly set up one of thousands of possible color patterns.  The excitement builds as you race to duplicate your opponents pattern... move by move... before he duplicates yours.

title: Keyword
description:
Each player plays his letter blocks to the cross-word layout on the board, trying to spell the Keyword or other words or plays his letters on the squares that give him the highest score.  Players should try to play out all their letters before his opponents do, for letters left in a player's hand at the end of play are counted against them.

The highest score wins the game.

title: Magnetic Takeoff
description: This is an interesting older dexterity game that uses magnets that are placed at the end of long bamboo sticks.  The magnets move around quite a deal on the end of the sticks, so they are hard to control.  Different colored washers are placed in bins, and you try to pick up specific washers with your unwieldy instrument.  Can also be played solitaire.

title: Cube-It
description: This is boxed version of the tradition pencil-and-paper game Cube-It that you used to play in grade school.  This version has some updates include random scoring sheets that give each player different point values for specific squares on the grid as well as some cards which offer special plays.

title: Rolomatic Bridge
description: Great way to learn how to bid and play complex Bridge hands.  Endorsed by Charles Goren himself.  The Rolomatic Bridge machine has a roll of paper inside it with 100 Bridge hands printed on it.  You see the initial deal, then a quick turn of the wheel shows what cards the opponents play as well as what is recommended that you play.  Great learning tool for the moderately skilled Bridge player.

title: Go Gin
description: Basically a variant of Gin Rummy where the cards have letters on them instead of the traditional numbers and suits.  You collect sets of cards in order to spell words and then either knock with the fewest exposed points or Go Gin!

title: The Beatles Flip Your Wig Game
description:
A marketing tie-in for The Beatles, the game consists of rolling a die to move your Beatle (John, Paul, George, or Ringo) to a new space which may instruct the player to draw one of two different types of cards, steal a card from one or more other players, or lose a card.

Play continues until one player wins the game by collecting the four cards corresponding to the Beatle that they are playing.  i.e. John needs to collect a John picture card, a John signature card, a John's Guitar card, and a hit record card.

title: Love it or Hate it
description:
Party game where a category is chosen (random spin on any one of four disks).  Then all players write down something associated with that category and whether they love or hate it.  All slips of paper are put together with the authors unknown.  Then the reader goes through the slips of paper and everyone votes (with color cards and either their love it or hate it card) on who they think wrote the particular slip of paper.

Each person who correctly guesses the writer and the love/hate notation receives a chip.

Copyright goes to Daryl Hannah and Hilary Shepard the actresses.

title: Phenomenon: the Extra Sensory Party
description:
A party game which is to be planned ahead of time, somewhat like a murder mystery party.  Only this time, players are exploring their psychic powers.  Players are to bring a personal object concealed in a plain paper bag for psycho-transmissions or something like that.

When the game begins (after a warm-up period), players simply move along a board and partake in activities written on cards.  These usually involve some pseudo-science along the lines of the doctors from Ghostbusters.

Game even includes a quartz crystal.

title: Frazzle
description:
Players alternate being the judge (complete with gavel, which really is a plastic hammer).  When the judge, the player chooses a category (many suggestions are printed on the board, but there is also a choose your own option).
