Then, the judge takes five cards from the deck of letter cards (each contains a single letter--no duplicates).

At that point, the judge turns over the first letter for all to see.  When someone thinks of an item within the chosen category which starts with the appropriate letter, they blurt it out.  As soon as the judge hears an answer to their liking (know thy judge), he slams the hammer down and awards the card to the person who shouted the answer.  That player moves forward on the movement track.  After five letters are completed, someone else is the judge.

title: The Decathlon Games
description: This game is a card game which features the 10 Decathlon events and past champions.  Each player is dealt a number of athlete cards which have actual medal winners on them with their results from various events.  An event card is flipped up and then each player plays an athlete card containing a result for that event.  Scores are compared and points are awarded.

title: International Soccer The Game
description:
From the box:

True to life Action-Packed soccer where you command the country of your choice to victory!  Challenge your opponent... Strategize your shots... And be the coach!

Game includes 10 countries, 13 players per team with different skill level per player and soccer cards for injuries, penalties, corner kicks, throw ins and more!

title: Red Capture Green Capture
description:
The game consists of 144 cards.  Each card has a symbol (shape) that is either red or green.  There are 12 shapes, 6 red and six green of each.  To win the game is to collect 7 unique shapes.

Play is simple, play a card, draw a card. Green cards can only be played in front of the current player.  Red cards can only be played in front of other players.  Whenever a players play a card on top of a like colored and shaped card, they get to keep the trick and draw an extra card keeping a hand of 5.

title: En Garde!
description:
En Garde! is a superbly implemented 3-player version of Chess and Checkers.

The tri-colour hex board has a 9 hex wide starting rank, to allow for a third bishop (for the third colour). Otherwise, rules are identical to orthodox chess.

The well-defined wooden playing pieces are black, white and red, although in my set, the black (really dark brown) and red (sort-of mid brown) are a little too similar for comfort.

Children who have recently learnt to play Chess will absolutely love this development and experienced adult players will relish the challenge.

Three colour draughts pieces are also provided, but this feels more messy and forced, than the Chess varient.

title: Det store norske spillet
description:
Norwegian game similar to Trivial Pursuit, based on facts found in the biggest Norwegian encyclopedia - Store norske leksikon.

This game is related to NE-spelet.

title: Ad-Lib
description:
Unlike Spill and Spell, this game is extremely similar to Scrabble, differing in only one small regard.

The game concept is that the point values are on the board instead of the letter tiles. This supposedly permits a more liberal use of the letters and helps develop full word power and effective strategy.

Besides that major departure from Scrabble, there are a number of minor differences, such as the number of tiles held on the rack, and the bonus for using all tiles.

title: Bedlam
description:
Pit with a board.

In this game, the objective is to move along your pawn's lane from one end of the board and back before anyone else does.  Along that path are 8 different pictures, repeated over and over, and each person's path is slightly different (at least the sequence of the images varies, but the same images are used).

Each player also holds a hand of cards and their goal is to collect cards with the same images as the one their pawn is resting on.  That part of the game is pretty much the same as the classic game, Pit.  Players trade cards unseen, in any combinations (unlike Pit) and all that must happen is that an equal number of cards must be given and taken.

When the timer runs out, move your pawn forward the number of spaces equal to the number of matching cards in your hand.  At that point, most of the time, you will be sitting on a different image, so another round of trading is necessary to redistribute your hand.

title: The Incredible Crash Dummies Crash Test Game
description: Those lovable crash test dummies (Spin, Slick, Darla and Spare Tire) are in a race to get safely home.  On the way, they may lose and get back parts (heads, limbs, torsos), sometimes as a result of a crash.  First one to make it to the finish line with a complete set of parts (not necessarily his own) wins.

title: Fascination Checkers
description:
The board measures 10x10, with four 4x4 areas in the corners marked in a black and white checkerboard pattern (the remaining cross-shaped area is neutral).  The black and white squares start off loaded with the black and white pieces.  Black goes first.

Jumps are horizontal or vertical, over the opponent's pieces only.  Multiple jumps are possible.  Each jump captures the jumped piece.  When a player cannot move, the other player keeps going until that player can move again.  The game ends when no moves are possible by either player.

Whoever has the most pieces left wins.

title: Franchise
description:
The goal of Franchise is to accumulate the most money in 30 days, by opening your selected franchise in as many locations as possible.  On Mondays, Thursdays and Saturdays, each may purchase a franchise in a new location or draw a Fluke card (random events benefiting all or penalizing the other players).  On Wednesdays, each player purchases inventory.  Tuesdays and Fridays are pay days (you collect your profits).  Sunday, you negotiate.

There are 21 cities.  In each, there can only be one franchise of any kind!  Opening the franchise costs money, of course, but you must also maintain a certain level of inventory for the franchise to operate.  Revenues fluctuate by die roll, one die per player --applied to all of his franchises.

At the end of the month, you total cash on hand plus the ground breaking value of your franchises.  Most money wins.

title: Punto y Raya
description:
Punto y Raya translates as Point and Line.  The lines are the walls, presumably.

The players alternate placing walls on the 8x8 board (optionally, the walls must be contiguous).  Whenever an area is closed off, the player claims it with one of his markers.  Whoever captures most of the board squares wins.

Similar to:

    Honeycomb (which uses a hex board)
    Squares (which uses a cross-shaped board)
    Box-It (the walls can pivot to enclose areas)

title: 3 Up
description:
The players alternate placing their six discs onto the 3x3 playing area.  The object is to form a stack of three of your own colour.  During play, no stack may grow taller than three in height.

Once all placements are done, on your turn you move a piece from atop its stack to any other stack --covered pieces cannot move.  You pass if all your pieces are covered.

When two players play, each uses two colors.  (There is no three-player game)

title: Dino-Checkers
description: Played as the classic Checkers except there are only 7 pieces per player (dinosaurs).  There are two variations on game rules depending on age of the players allowing movement forward and backwards with or without kinging first.  The winner is the first to capture all the opponents pieces or force the opponent in a situation where they cannot move a piece.  The pawns are cute stegosaurus and apatosaurus, the kings tyrannosaurs.  The board has been drawn to look like stone pillars in a sea of lava, and there even are colorful volcano piece-holders.

title: Obsession
description:
This is essentially 3D Nine Men's Morris with dice.

The board consists of three stacked surfaces, each looking like a progressively smaller Morris board.  They are numbered from top to bottom.

The first play phase is placement.  The dice dictate where you can appear.  For example, a throw of one and two allows either one piece on board two, or two pieces on board one.  Placements are mandatory.  You may be forced to pass if no placement is possible.

Once all of your pieces are placed, you use the dice to move them (the transition turn may feature a placement and a move).  Here too the dice dictate the moves: a throw of one and two allows either one piece to move on board two, or two pieces on board one, or one piece from board two to board one (or vice-versa).  Moves are mandatory.

As in Morris, every time a three-piece alignment is formed (including vertical ones), this is a Mill and one opposing piece of the miller's choice is removed.  Pieces in mills are protected.  Multiple mills may be formed by a single move.  You win by grinding the opponent down to two pieces.

The four-player game is a partnership game.

title: San Francisco Scene
description:
This text is from a promotional flyer included in the game, which was part of the [gamedesigner=4] collection auctioned off on November 16, 2002:

The excitement of a cable car ride, a shopping spree around Union Square, elegant dining in a famous restaurant, and a tour of the Bay Area's famous landmarks -- all these are a part of the San Francisco Scene.

Have you ever wanted to own Grant Avenue, the Oakland Raiders, Sausalito or Walnut Creek? Now is your chance by playing the San Francisco Scene!

You will by and sell your favorite local properties; become either a labor leader, an attorney, a politician, or a membership chairman of an exclusive club; and bargain with the other players to receive a Connection Card which will permit you to develop your properties and thereby collect increased rent.

title: Code Breaker
description:
A fairly simple and quick deduction game.  Cards come in three types; Artists, Thinkers and Leaders, each with a picture and short biography of an appropriate historical character, and in two colors, red if born before 1700 and yellow if afterwards.   The Code Master chooses a pattern for cards to be laid down in incorporating color, type or both, either from the Code cards supplied or by inventing his own.  Players, including the Code Master, then take it in turns to play cards from their hands and are told whether the cards are correct or not.  If a player deduces the pattern before running out of cards he scores; otherwise the Code Master scores.

Based, according to the rule leaflet, on a game by the same author called Eleusis published in 1963.

title: Queen's Guard
description: Queen's Guard, a.k.a. Agon, is played on a hexagonal board, comprised of 91 smaller hexagons, six to each side of the board. The central hex is known as the throne; most Agon boards feature alternating colors of hexes in rings, starting from the six hexes surrounding the throne. Each player has one queen piece and six guard pieces. These all have alternating starting positions on the board's outer ring. Players take turns moving their pieces forward (or laterally) towards the center of the board; pieces may be captured by an opponent, if they are surrounded on two sides in a straight line. The captured player must then relocate his piece to the outer ring of the board. To win the game, a player must have his queen on the throne and surrounded by all six of his guards.

title: Quest for the Dragon
description:
This Sorcerer's Cave type adventure boardgame sees each player starting from a different corner of the board. Tiles are placed on the board as it is explored; initially each player is looking for the rooms containing their equipment (Key, allowing teleportation between various points, Weapon and Armour). On the way they encounter Monsters to defeat. Once they have found their equipment players make their way to the center of the board to challenge the Dragon; defeating him wins the game. Players can have combat with each other if they land on the same space and can barter items with each other.

Success is dependent on your rooms turning up somewhere near you early on in the game. There is a limited amount of decision making re the routes and which is the best way to put tiles.

The components are quite attractive and sturdy.

The game comes with a Story Booklet and a leaflet explaining how the Invalay board system will be used in subsequent games; unfortunately this game, the company and the system all appear to have sunk without trace!

title: Tri-Umph
description:
This game is distantly related to the Mill game or Nine Men's Morris, in that the object is to make alignments of three pieces: each such alignment created removes one opposing piece (miller's choice).  You win when you've reduced the opponent to two pieces or put him in such a bind that he cannot move.  If both players become immobilized, a draw occurs.

The 56 board is set up by both players by plunking down each of their 12 pieces alternately.  Strategy is crucial during this phase.  The only restriction is that alignments of three cannot be formed during this phase.  Once all pieces are set up, on your turn you move one of your pieces one space horizontally or vertically (diagonals aren't allowed or considered).

Strategies are alluded to but not explained in the short rules.  Shan Ruwa (to drown) consists of setting up so as to force the opponent to place in positions that will aid the starting player and drown the opponent.  Conversely, Turi (to push) prevents the starting player from forming alignments and makes his opening move bad for him.

A mill is called here Doki (galloping horse).  It is a combination of five pieces such that you form an alignment on each leg of the back-and-forth motion of the fifth piece.  The game terms are all taken from Hausa, a West-African language (presumably the first author's maternal tongue).

title: Lingua
description:
Very good variant of Scrabble. Scoring is easier and allows for tactics in trying to outscore your opponent. The game can be forced to an end by reaching the bonus end-fields.

Lingua was also published in the Ravensburger Casino Series.

title: Sea Hawks
description: Sea Hawks is played on a board that is an authentic map of the Carribean in the 18th century. Ten chests are buried in the islands, but only one contains treasure. Each player is a pirate captain searching for that chest; navigating dangerous waters, picking up clues, battling with rival ships in the quest for the hidden treasure.

title: Murder to Go
description:
David Landau staged live large-scale murder parties for a couple of years before designing a home, boxed version of some of his scenarios.  That's according to the box copy.

This box includes three separate murder parties: Murder's the Game, Centerfold for the Coroner, and Circumstantial Evidence.  Much like traditional murder party kits, except that this one includes more props and requires (for at least some of the scenarios) a little more up-front preparation of the crime scene for visual clues.  Includes more props than other murder party lines.

title: Murder à la carte: What the Butler Saw
description:
This is a later episode from the Murder a la Carte line by bePuzzled, and those later titles were probably published in England.  At this point, it appears that bePuzzled was no longer the title holder to this large line of murder mystery party games.

Like most in the a la Carte line, this game is written for 6 players with two additional characters available who are not real suspects and whose testimony really has no impact on the game play.  Comes with menu planner.

From the box:

It is 1912, and a small party has gathered in London to celebrate the engagement of Bunny Mandelson and Agatha Eton-Hogg.  But then the body of Mellors, the butler, is discovered, with a revolver in his hand, a bullet in his head and suicide note that says: 'I have seen too much, and can take no more.'

What did the butler see?  Did he really kill himself?  Or did one of your guests murder him?
Those present at the dinner-party are:

    Bunny Mandelson, a gentleman of very little brain.
    Agatha Eton-Hogg, his fiancee, and inquisitive and intelligent young woman.
    Sir Douglas Eton-Hogg, Agatha's uncle and a highly respected Member of Parliament.
    Oscar Hemmingway III, an American big-game hunter and ivory merchant.
    Sister Morticia Lewinskaya, a Russian-born nun now resident in Chicago.
    Mary Lippe-Anstoldt, one of the leading stars of the Edwardian Music Hall and a friend of Agatha.
    Herr Schnapps, a successful German industrialist and business-partner of Sir Douglas.
    Georgette Michel, a young Frenchwoman who is only just recovering from her ordeal of going downon the Titanic.

title: Alfred Hitchcock: The Unexplained
types: Deduction Movies / TV / Radio theme Murder/Mystery Party Game
description:
This murder/mystery party is a bit different from others.  It includes a full 14-page script (a copy for each player) which will be performed during the evening.

From the box:

Good evening ladies and gentlemen.  Allow me to introduce myself: Alfred Hitchcock, master of suspense and ... MURDER.

You hold in your hand a spellbinding evening of The UNEXPLAINED.  This is my first adult party game, in a series of thrillers that I believe will leave you screaming for more!

Your host will send you postcards confirming your role in my new movie.  You are the star, you'll be giving the performance of your life, as your very life may depend upon it.  As the evening unfolds the tension builds.  This chilling tale of murder is brought to climax in an unforgettable ending.

According to John Hansen Co, no more episodes were released in this series.

title: Murder Mystery Evening: Death in the Ring
description:
Similar to How to Host a Murder type games except much more scripted.  Each player receives a packet of cards containing some information about their deep dark past, but mostly containing dialogue which is to be revealed at specific intervals.  Between segments (there are several), a tape is played.  At the end, everyone attempts to figure out whodunit, even the killer, as he or she is not informed of their crime.

From the box:

The Place: 
Bodger's World--Renowned Variety Circus

The Victim: 
Slippery Sid, the fearless escapologist.

The Scene: 
Padlocked  bound, Slippery Sid was attempting to escape whilst suspended upside down in a tank of water.

The Crime: 
Something went terribly wrong during Sid's stage act; the police have formed the opinion that foul play was involved!

The Suspects:
Roger the Ringmaster, Anna Conda, Raisa Legovo, Sven Garlic, Wanda Lust, Buster Gutt.

title: Partyzone: The Inheritance
description:
You are about to enter a world of romance and intrigue, of high society and scandal. Many surprises lie ahead...and the party you are about to throw will be remembered and talked about for months to come!

Each Partyzone Game is a complete mystery party in a box. It is a party game for you and your guests. It provides a theme for your party. It is an icebreaker to help get your party started. You don't sit down and play; instead, you and your guests move around and socialize with each other. Just what you would want at any good party!

In The Inheritance Scenario, your guests are given roles as members of the Caldwell family, who have gathered at the family mansion for the reading of the will of the patriarch, the late Jonathan Jerome Caldwell. During this evening of mystery and expos, your guests will determine who among them is entitled to compete for the inheritance Each guest has a mysterious past and some secrets to protect, and each has one or more missions that involve the other guests at the party. Many of these missions conflict with one another.

This Partyzone game of intrigue and deception for adults includes instructions and party planning booklet, 12 invitations and envelopes, 20 identification badges, decorations, and much more

title: Murder Mystery Party: Party to a Murder
description:
The Murder Mystery Party line of murder party games is the most extensive.  They were originally published by University Games in California, but are now produced in England, though they still carry a note that the rights belong to University Games (who, when you call them, have no knowledge of the recent episodes).

These games play just like other main-stream murder party games like How to Host a Murder, Evening of Murder, Mysteries by Vincent, or Milton Bradley's Life of the Party.

From the box:

Whose birthday party ended in murder?

The time is the present, the place is The Crystal Club and Sir Montague Funtingdon-Smythe is celebrating his birthday.  His friends have been invited to join in the celebrations but before the party gets into full swing, Sir Monty is found dead in the study.  Who is responsible for giving him the full monty?

The suspects include:

    Gaston Flambee -- French Restaurant owner
    India Ganges -- Romantic Novelist
    Givva Goodtime -- American Society Hostess
    Rich Pickins -- Antique Dealer
    Juke Box -- Manager to the Pop Stars
    Satina Silk -- Accountant to the rich and famous
    Jim Nastics -- Personal Fitness Trainer
    Taka Hike -- (most people wish she would) Gossip Columnist

title: Crime Solver Party: The Black Hole Mystery
description:
The Crime Solver series games play like standard parlor murder/mystery parties.  Each game is playable by 4, 6, or 8 people.

From the box:

Who murdered Lt. Gail Johns?

Space station geologist Lt. Gail Johns jettisoned from the station on a data gathering jet pack ride in orbit.  Someone sabatoged her pack!  The crew members all look pale.  It had to be one of them that sent the lieutenant on a space ride into the sun!

The suspects:

    Captain Kirk Hagen: Space station captain and war hero flying ace.
    Dr. Rick Moriarity: The station's doctor and number one womanizer.
    Natasha Turensky: Czech ballerina and dance film star.
    Lt. Dorothy Borman: Navigator for the station, she guided the ship safely around Earth.
    Buck Barraza: Spicy South American ace pilot with a yearning for his co-pilot.
    Lt. Yvonne Escobar: Sexy co-pilot responsible for keeping buck's attention from the skies.
    Sabrina Ashley: American film star and TV soap commercial queen.  A guest abort the station because of Presidential pull and a good complexion.
    Faheem Abdul Kamal:  Arab oilman and multi-billionaire.  Aboard the station as a gesture of peace and hopefully cheaper oil imports.

title: Guilty Party: Murder on the Casting Couch
description:
First in Steve Jackson (I)series of adult murder/mystery party games.  Not sure if any others followed.  Standard issue, very much like How to Host a Murder or Murder Mystery Party line, only no audio tape.  However, each invitation includes a mini-newspaper with background information about the murder.

The story line:

Who Killed the Studio Chief?

The date is 1927.  The place is Hollywood.  The crime is murder. Arthur McCutcheon made a lot of movies.  He made a lot of enemies, too.  When he was found dead in his luxurious office, it was easy to find suspects.  Too many suspects!

Was it...

    Matt Montgomery, dashing star of the silent screen?
    Kathleen O'Shea, Superior Studios' leading lady?
    Olaf Hedrikssen, the brilliant Danish director?
    Betty Sue Wilson, Iowa farm girl turned starlet?
    Wilbur Andrews, the famous inventor?
    Irma Meyers, hair stylist and girl Friday?
    Alice Chatterly, the gossip columnist?
    Clyde Willoughby, insurance adjuster and movie buff?

title: Noah's Ark
description: It's a wild world in this perfect pair of memory games. The beaver is by the bear. The antelope is eating with the elephant. The lion is lying all alone. You must re-pair the animals before the ark sails. The box itself is a three dimensional ark - which can create difficulties for storing with your other games.

title: GIPF Project Set 1
description:
This is an expansion for GIPF.

Contents:


     6 TAMSK-potentials for each player


See the project GIPF wiki page for more details on the potentials' powers.

The TAMSK-potential is the first additional piece of project GIPF. It is named after the game TAMSK and offers new ways to play GIPF.  The TAMSK-potential can grant its owner an extra move during a turn.

A clarifying note from designer Kris Burm about the GIPF Project expansion Set #1 and the TAMSK potentials included with the TAMSK game:

As you maybe know, enclosed in the TAMSK box are 3 white and 3 black TAMSK-potentials. These are samples. You need a minimum of 3 potentials of each color to get a feeling of how they change a game of GIPF. The GIPF Project Expansion Set #1 contains 12 TAMSK-potentials; 6 potentials per color is the standard number to play with. The kit is meant to give players who like playing with the potentials the possibility to get more potentials without needing to buy a second game of TAMSK. That aside, it is also meant to serve those who want to find out what potentials are all about without needing to purchase TAMSK.

This is part of project GIPF.

Expands:

    GIPF

title: Scarab
description:
Egypt 2100 BC: In the temple of Thot, god of science and inventor of the game, the priests met annually to choose the highest priest of the temple. They did so by playing the game. Therefore they gathered around a board studded with Scarabs. The goal of the game was to collect as many pieces as possible. Because the one who had the most valuable collection at the end of the game was chosen to be the highest priest of Thot for the following year.

Players move around a grid trying to collect the highest numbered tiles and force their opponents to take low or negative numbered tiles. Can be played in partnership with 4.

title: Mutual Mania
mechanisms: Commodity SpeculationDice RollingRoll / Spin and MoveStock Holding
description: A competitive and educational board game for ages thirteen and up that provides a realistic simulation of the win/lose world of Mutual Fund investing.  The object of the game is to maximize wealth through the shrewd buying and selling of the nine mutual funds offered.  Fund values fluctuate based on a variety of 'market and world events' while 'personal events' created from real life situations have positive or negative effects on the player's personal finances.

title: Australian Menagerie
description:
A competitive game of chance and strategy which highlights the diverse range of Australia's wildlife and habitats. The aim is to collect as many animal cards as you can for each habitat of your nature reserve You score points for each animal card you have in your nature reserve at the end of each hand.

The first player, or team to gain 100 points wins the game.

There is the second level of difficulty, where players can cast threats on other player's habitants, e.g. fire, pollution, feral animals.. And can protect their habitants from threats.

title: Space Master: Star Strike
description:
From the box:

Starcraft Combat in the Far Future

Iron Crown Enterprises presents Space Master: Star Strike, a fast-paced boardgame of starcraft combat in the far future. Simulate deep-space battles involving any number of vessels. Dogfight with small but lethal SMAC fighters or deploy Line Cuisers to slug it out with a death dealing Dreadnought.

Expanded by:

    Star Strike Vessel Compendium #1: Adventurer Class
    Star Strike Vessel Compendium #2: Pursuit Class
    Star Strike Vessel Compendium #3: Imperial Ships

title: Das Revolutionsspiel von 1791
description:
Das Revolutionsspiel von 1791 is a thematic implementation of the 16th century Game of Goose.  The game board is illustrated with scenes of the French Revolution in the late 18th century: the pictures from the starting point to the end point follow the course of the event.

Players take turns to roll the dice and move their tokens according to the total of the dice.  Landing on certain spaces could mean advancing the token further up the path, losing turns, or going back to the starting point.  If a token lands on a chicken space, it gets to double its move (and double it again if it still lands on a chicken space).

The game ends when a player's token lands exactly on the end point, making him or her the winner.  If the movement would overshoot the end point, the token has to backtrack the excess amount.

title: Sozoikum
description: Players represent Stone Age people looking for partners and wanting to build their own homes.  Players must bluff and negotiate help to get enough stones to build their home.

title: Quantum
description:
Quantum is an abstract strategy game, played on a simple squared board, with three different types of pieces. A quick game may be played on the central 60 squares of the board, or the full game on the entire 96 squares.

Initially, all pieces move just one square. A square piece moves horizontally and vertically, a circle moves diagonally and a cross combines the two moves.  Opposing pieces are captured by landing on top of them to form towers. A tower may move as many squares as pieces it contains. Power squares in each corner allow unrestricted movement. Once a tower reaches the height of six pieces, it can no longer move or be captured.  The game is won when black or white owns three towers of 6 pieces.

Both offensive and defensive strategies are possible and players should remember that a tower of 6 cannot move or be captured, but it can still block!

title: Champs de Bataille II: La bataille de Kadesh
description: Champs de Bataille is designed to simulate the fighting between armies of widely differing types over a long period of history. In this Battle for Kadesh in 1300 before Christ, is the first battle of the history of the humanity, and it sees the victory of ambitious conqueror Egyptian Ramss II.

title: Nibar's Keep
description:
Nibar's Keep is a short game of tactical combat for two players.  Each player assumes the role of a warrior in Nibar's arena.  Each warrior is aided by a force of diverse creatures, some of which are magically summoned after the game has started.  To win the game, a player must accomplish either of the following two objectives:
1) Move one's own warrior onto one of the two rune hexes guarded by the opponent; or,
2) Inflict two wounds on the opponent's warrior

Published in Dragon magazine, Issue #118.

title: Die Siedler von Catan: Das Turnier-Set zum Kartenspiel
description:
The first expansion for the Settlers of Catan Card Game. It contains 57 cards, most of them new (and a few duplicates of cards from the base game). It was later split into the smaller expansions Wissenschaft & Fortschritt (Science  Progress) and Ritter und Händler (Knights  Merchants).

For the tournament game, both players need a copy of the base game and of this tournament expansion. Before the game, each player builds his own deck from the available cards: a starting hand of 3 cards, and another 30 cards that form 4 draw stacks. The event deck is constructed by five fix cards, and another 4 cards choosen by each player.
Gameplay is unchanged from the base game, except that each player only draws from his own supply stacks.

As a variant, rules for an expanded base game without deck building are included, for which only one copy of base game and expansion is needed.

Belongs to the Catan Series.

Expands:

    Catan Card Game

title: Dragon Kings
description:
The Dragon Kings game depicts war between four clans of dragons.  It is a game for two players, but it can also be played by three or four.  One player commands the Black Dragons and their allies, the Red Dragons (who appear as reinforcements).  The other player commands the Green Dragons and their allies, the Blue Dragons (who appear as reinforcements).  The object of the game is to defeat both of the enemy clans by eliminating all of their dragons or by occupying their home caverns.

Published in Dragon Magazine #170

title: Dino Wars
description:
Dino Wars is a miniatures game with lots of grade B movie humor.  Players use stuffed dinosaurs and plastic army men for pieces.

Published in Dragon Magazine #166.

title: Yin Yang
description:
From the rules:

Yin Yang is a game of pawns where the rules of combat and development are set by the players themselves.  Dominoes are used to secretly define the laws of evolution and are then played like cards.

Contents

    1 board of 16 boxes
    16 two-tone pawns
    8 dominoes
    65 cards (including 30 white, 30 black and 5 reds). 




To win, it is necessary to reach the corner of the opponents corner (with the yin and yang symbol) with a pawn, or to prevent the opponent from playing at all.

title: Championship Rodeo Circuit
description:
The object of the game is to become the World Champion Cowboy/Cowgirl (ie, the richest player).  This is achieved by traveling along the board and entering rodeos as they are reached.  Various mishaps can occur, such as hospital stays, and there are the expected expenses along the way.  Once you've garnered two trophies, you can enter the National Finals, at the end of the game track.  Once there, you enter events repeatedly, until the entire Finals purse is gone.  You must therefore decide whether to stop at every rodeo on the way to the Finals (which will garner money and trophies but leaves the Finals purse vulnerable to faster players) or charge there as quickly as possible (assuming the prerequisites have been achieved).

The copyright indicates the game was revised in 1981 and 1987.

title: BASH!
types: Abstract Strategy Children's Game Humor Party Game
description:
Contents:

    The base
    6 each of red and yellow pieces (round and square)
    Hammer
    Oh Fooey card.




Opponents strike colored pieces from the stack, without toppling the stack. The winner is the owner of the last remaining piece(s).

Similar to:

    Daruma Otoshi
    Toc Toc Woodman

title: Derivation
types: Bluffing Humor Party Game Word Game
description:
A board game released late in 2002 and is a multi-game in one with an emphasis on creative wordplay, phrase guessing and a whole lot of fabrication.

Half of the game features the theme which is where the players hear a common word of phrase used on popular culture such as cut to the chase or spam and then fabricate the origins of those phrases to fool the other players into guessing their false derivation.  The other half is split into three different mini games all built around the same key phrases.  Two involve trying to guess the popular word or phrase by either charades/drawing or talking about the phrase but not using any of the words in the actual question.

The last part involves pure chance where a random event migh help or hinder the current player slightly.  Winning the round in these various activities will earn cards with an individual letter which eventually spells out D-E-R-I-V-A-T-I-O-N.

The first player to do this wins the game.

title: Metasquares
description:
Made by Metacreations in the summer of 1996, this game was very good for its time. Two players take turns placing pieces on the board. These pieces can't move once placed. The object of the game is to make squares with these pieces. The larger the square, the more points it's worth. Squares may be tipped at any angle(Ex: a diamond is a valid square). You win when you get over 150 points with at least a 15 point lead over your opponent.

The game exists only in on-line format, but you can easily play-it with a standard chessboard and some 2 color counter (GO stones i.e).

Online Play


     http://www.metasquares.com

title: Baseball 3010
description:
Excerpt from Official web-site:

Baseball 3010 (TM) is a game of chance and strategy based on rules and skills of baseball.  3010 signifies the year and setting for the game which features a pantheon of superhuman baseball players dubbed Xenotrons.  Each Xenotron has a special power that enhances its ability to execute certain baseball skills.  Play calls characters to hit and field while enduring changing futuristic weather environments and dangerous base traps to earn runs and claim victory.

The game is distributed in starter sets and booster packs. Starter sets  comes with 24 playing cards, 2 game cubes, and 1 reference card and foldout game instructions packaged in a pocket-sized custom designed foldout case. The case doubles as a game board and is made of a high-tech tear resistant paper for increased durability. There are over 150 Xenotrons cards and other limited edition cards that can be collected through booster packs.

title: Reverse Curse
types: Card Game Children's Game Fantasy Humor
description:
From the box:

Come play Reverse Curse and see if you can cast spells on your opponent before they cast one on you. The wizard with the least curses against them wins. Each wizard collects cards until a spell is completed. Then they cast the spell on an opponent. Beware of magic wands, as they allow you to reverse a curse that was cast on you!

title: Excursions
description:
Excursions is an action-packed Travel/Vacation game which combines the elements of fun, fantasy, social interaction, strategy and risk. Based on an exciting new concept, it is sophisticated enough to challenge the adult imagination, yet simple enough to provide a fun-filled family evening.

The game features beautiful pictures of exotic world destinations and is played on a quality board of unique design.

title: Rommel & Tunisia
description:
Rommel  Tunisia is an operational game of the campaign in Tunisia. Units are at battalion to brigade size and the map covers from the Libya-Tunisia border to west of Tebessa Algeria.

600 counters

title: Jigsol
description:
From the designer:

The firsts are born in bursts, and the best of the rest are obsessed. This is how I defined that illusive state, the 'open' or 'perfect' game, in 1976. Since perfection is all but impossible to achieve, I decided to design all-inclusive or 'peri-' games, Jigsol' is the first of the series.

Designed to play with more versatility and challenge than any other word game, Jigsol' is ideal for any player who can spell 24 words or more. For those who are curious, a Jigsol is a 'jigsaw solution'. Jigsol is a legal word when playing this game.
-E.M.W.

Each player starts with 25 letters printed on hexagons, the timer is started and each player tries to form an interlocking word puzzle. When the time is up each player calculates his points. When all 25 letters are used a player receives a delta mark on the score sheet (small triangle) and 25 points. The game ends when someone gets 5 or more deltas, or at 200, 500 or more points.

title: Hex-Meister
description:
The board shows a series of concentric hex-gridded spaces, of varying colors. The two white rings (lanes) allow movement limited only by the presence of other pieces. The three blue rings (moats) cannot be crossed in one go; you must stop on them. The lone exceptions are the four blue hexes on your side of the board --you may cross them freely, but your opponent cannot. The thirteen red hexes (gates), finally, are the game goals; you win by occupying five of these in a straight line. To enter a gate, you must start adjacent to it (except for the two gates adjacent to your base). Entering a gate (other than the two base ones) gives you a bonus move. Occupied gates are the only occupied spaces that can be jumped.

A hex is secured (the opponent cannot enter it) if surrounded by three or more of your pieces. Securing a hex captures any piece that happens to lie there (it is removed from the game and you get a bonus move). Finally, the fifth gate of any triangular set is secured if you occupy the first four. This is called triangulation.

The rulebook also supplies handicapping suggestions, optional rules for a more challenging game, and explains how to support team play.

title: Scorpion
description:
Scorpion is an elegant variation on the Pachisi/Ludo style of race game.

The board comprises a raised S-shaped track with baize-coated recesses for throwing the dice. The poker-chip sized pieces, embossed with scorpions, also stack neatly onto the impressively designed and attractive playing surface.

The race starts with players entering their pieces onto the yellow track. After 18 spaces, when the end of the initial S has been reached, players double-back on themselves, taking the black track to return home. The twist lies in 
that a scorpion may sting another, not just by landing on the same space, but also by landing on an adjacent space on the other coloured track. This enables a player to hinder opponents or to boost his own position by switching scorpions onto the other track.

Unfortunately, the rather minimalist rules supplied do not cover every gameplay eventuality. In particular, the knock-on effect that occurs frequently on a congested board, where a stung scorpion may inadvertently sting another is not explained in a satisfactory manner.

title: Campaign
description:
This 1966 publication is a fairly simple roll and move contest to collect electoral votes. The center of the board has an outline map of the United States with the Electoral College votes of each state marked. The map divides the states into six color-coded regions.

Players move around the edge of the board on a 64-square track. Most of these are individual states, and landing on one allows a player to take the state if uncommitted or to contest it if held by another player. To contest, he rolls 2D6, and on a 2-6 wins the state, while on 7-12 the challenged party gets to take a state in the same region from a challenger.

There is a deck of Political Fortune cards which are collected on eight of the spaces. These can be positive or negative: losing a state or a turn or even all states in a region; or winning states and becoming a favorite son in a state, which confers unchallengeable ownership of that state for the rest of the game.

When a player collects the majority of the states in one of the six regions, he takes over all the electoral college votes for the region and all of those states are locked (can no longer be challenged). First player to 270 Electoral College votes wins.

title: Take A Letter
description:
Collect, Swipe and Trade Until A Word Is Made!

As you move around the edge of the board, you collect letters, usually two per turn. 
Your 3 'Word Play' goal cards specify the conditions of the word(s) you need to put together. For instance: a word of greater than 7 letters or a word starting with 'TH' or a word that uses the same vowel twice. Scores range from 10 points to 75 points with harder goals resulting in higher scores. One word may fulfill the conditions on 1, 2 or all 3 of your cards. You then place the word on the gameboard in a crossword grid similar to Scrabble. By covering certain spaces on the board you earn bonus points or take a letter from another player. First player to get 400 points wins.

title: Maestria
description:
A strange word game, where each player draws from a bag 39 tiles with geometric segments on them.  Simultaneously, both players try to arrange their tiles to make a word of four or more letters (most letters are 2x3 tiles, the I is 1x3, M, T, Wand Y are 3x3).  First player to shout Stop! wins the round and scores.  The word may be contested.

Note that a word with an I in it will score less, and conversely with M, T, W or Y.

The players swap boards and shuffle the tiles of each board around, then play repeats.  On the second round, swap again but draw 6 more tiles.  Words must now be 5+ letters.  Repeat for a third round (six-letter words), drawing six tiles again, so there are six words scored total in a game.  The boards show bonuses that can be scored by making really long words.

The rules show the exact patterns that make up each letter.  An incorrectly drawn letter will lose a challenge.

title: The Powerpuff Girls: Flying Action Game
description:
Features the PowerPuff flying pole. Attached to the pole by a string is a plastic model of all three PowerPuff Girls flying together. When you reach certain areas on the board, you place the pole there, holding it with one hand and the plastic PowerPuff model with the other. The goal is to make the model fly around the pole by swinging it, to knock down surrounding villains and score points.

Swedish version of a game called PowerPuff Girls: Flying Action Game from Drumond Park Ltd..

title: Raise the Titanic
description:
The object of the game is to earn fame and fortune by exploring (plundering?) the sunken Titanic, raising it and recovering the ship's log.  You need to gather expeditions of crews, supplies and equipment and face many pitfalls.

The game plays in two phases, before and after the ship is raised (more on this later).  In the first phase, you circle the outer board gathering your expeditions, and occasionally enter the two inner paths that actually lead to the ship.  This is where you plun...er, recover artifacts from the Titanic.  After the ship is raised, the game now becomes a race to the Home Port with the ship's log.  All players get an advance from the publisher and the race proceeds.  The player with the log rolls only one die to the others' two, and the log changes hands each time the player with the log is caught up with.

Winner is the player with the most money from artifacts recovered, fame points garnered and the ship's log bonus.

The board is centered on a plastic column with a spring inside; a large model of the Titanic rests on the spring, loaded down by the weighted artifacts.  As the latter are recovered, the model naturally climbs up towards the top of the column.  Simple, clever and visually quite effective.

title: Penta Go
description:
The game is played by two players or two teams of two players and is a curious amalgam of Go and Monopoly.  The object is to eliminate the opponent's stones.  There is an outer circuit with roughly every other square being a castle property, the others bearing various instructions (Monopoly-style).  The inner board consists of 10x10 lines enclosing 81 squares, twenty of which are castles in five colored groups of four.

You start with your Knight (pawn piece) on the Start space and a box of fifty stones (men).  The third box is the King's Treasury (bank).  On your turn you roll, advance the Knight accordingly, and then add a stone to the central board.  Stones are placed on intersections, as in Go, and mark possession of the territory surrounding the intersection.  Taxes and commands on the outer board are ignored until the Knight has completed two circuits.

The outer board has spaces with named castles; when you land there, you pay the castle's owner a land use tax of two to seven stones, depending on the castle (the central one is worth more, for example).  You own a castle by encircling it (as closely as possible).  You control territory by encircling it.  You can also trace a line across the board, which then gives you control of the smaller of the two parts thus created.  Capture is as in Go: an encircled set of stones dies if it does not have any eyes --empty spaces inside it and the encircling enemy.

Stones can be exchanged freely, so you could, for example, sell captured opponent stones back to him in exchange for treasury stones in order to pay a fine.  If you absolutely run out of stones, you can take some off the board.

title: Sports Spectacular
description:
This set contains simple games for six sports. They appear to all be modified versions of the six games in RGI's Play the Pros series, published a few years earlier. The games are:


    Baseball, presumably based on Major League Baseball Game by Yogi Berra (no BGG entry)



    Football, presumably based on Pro Football Game by Paul Warfield (no BGG entry)



    Hockey, presumably based on Pro Hockey Game by Rod Gilbert (no BGG entry - this is not the same as Rod Gilbert's Violent World of Pro Hockey)



    Basketball, presumably based on Pro Basketball Game by Oscar Robertson (no BGG entry - this is not the same as Oscar Robertson's Pro Basketball Strategy)



    Auto Racing, based on Grand Prix Auto Race Game by Jackie Stewart. This version removes the apex lines, changes the car construction system in several ways, adds pit stops, etc. 



    Tennis, based on Pro Tennis Game by Rod Laver. This version adds shot cards and makes other changes.

title: Beyond Valor: ASL Module 1
types: Expansion for Base-game Wargame World War II
description:
(from MMP's website and user's description:)

Beyond Valor is the first, and most important, of the Advanced Squad Leader modules. BV contains the German and Russian orders of battle from 1939-1945 as well as three different squad-types of Finnish troops. Additionally, the module contains the necessary markers and fortifications required by the ASL Series.[...]

Paired with the ASL Rulebook, Beyond Valor is quite a lot of ASL in a single box. DYO possibilities are endless, and additional scenarios using only the components in BV can be found on our website in the downloads section.

Contents:


    Boards 1-5  8 [3rd edition only], 20-23 [all editions]
    12 counter sheets [1st edition] / 15 Counter sheets [2nd edition] / 14 Counter sheets [3rd edition]
    ASL Scenarios 1-10 [all editions], 123-136 [3rd edition only]
    4 six-sided dice


[Note: in 1st edition, Finnish counters are in the same blue as German counters]
[Note: 2nd edition only, includes also complete Red Barricades: ASL Historical Module 1 material]

Scenario List:

[all editions]:
1 Fighting Withdrawal, Terijoki Finland 1941
2 Mila 18, Warsaw Poland 1943
3 The Czerniakow Bridgehead, Warsaw Poland 1944
4 The Commissar's House, Stalingrad Russia 1942
5 In Sight of the Volga, Stalingrad Russia 1942
6 Red Packets, Zhabinki Russia 1942
7 Dash for the Bridge, Warsaw Poland 1944
8 The Fugitives, Berlin Germany 1945
9 To The Square, Warsaw Poland 1945
10 The Citadel, Brest-Litovsk Russia, 1941

[3rd edition only]:
123 The Borders are Burning, Kuhmo Finland 1939
124 On The Borderline, Artahuhta Finland 1939
125 First Crisis at Army Group North, Raseiniai Lithuania 1941
126 Commando Schenke, Liepaja Latvia 1941
127 Land Leviathans, Lipki Russia 1941
128 The Defense of Luga, Leningrad Russia 1941
129 Slamming of the Door, Panikovo Forest Russia, 1941
130 Debacle at Korosten, Korosten Russia 1941
131 The Penetration of Rostov, Rostov Russia 1942
132 Hill 253.5, Ponyri, Russia 1943
133 Block Busting in Bokruisk, Bokruisk, Russia 1944
134 Counterattack on the Vistula, Wola Chodkowska Poland 1944
135 Acts of Defiance, Breslau Germany 1945
136 The Agony of Doom, Muncheberg Germany 1945

title: Paratrooper: ASL Module 2
types: Expansion for Base-game Wargame World War II
description:
(from the back of the box and user's description:)

PARATROOPER is the second module in the ASL series, which means it is not a complete game unto itself. Players will need boards 1-4 of SQUAD LEADER and the ASL rules to play all eight scenarios included herein. However, all other components necessary to play the game are enclosed-absolutely no other purchase is necessary.

PARATROOPER has been specially designed as an Introductory Module for those SQUAD LEADER players contemplating a switch to ASL to provide an inexpensive medium for them to sample the rich delights of the ASL game system without requiring the purchase of the full Russian/German OB found only in the first ASL Module: BEYOND VALOR. Yet, the countermix in PARATROOPER serves as a supplement to the BEYOND VALOR components, rather than an unneeded duplication of those counters should the player decide to expand his ASL collection.

Included are board 24, featuring a village in a valley, and two countersheets.

Due to the special nature of the fighting that comprised the airborne invasion of Normandy, the eight scenarios emphasize infantry encounters with little in the way of vehicles, ordnance, OBA, or the more detailed rules which constitute the entire spectrum of ASL.

This goes hand-in-hand with the introductory nature of PARATROOPER.
PARATROOPER is not a complete game; ownership of ASL and boards 1-4 is required.

Scenario list:
11 Defiance on Hill 30
12 Confusion Reigns
13 Le Manoir
14 Silence that Gun
15 Trapped!
16 No Better Spot to Die
17 Lost Opportunities
18 The Roadblock


The second module for Advanced Squad Leader. This one is an introductory module, geared towards those gamers who are experienced with Squad Leader.

The first edition, published by Avalon Hill, included mapboard 24 and ASL 1st edition rules Chapter K Training Manual. The first four boards from Squad Leader are needed to play the scenarios included.

The second edition, printed by Multiman Publishing, adds mapboards 2  4 (from the original Squad Leader) but deletes the Chapter K Training Manual as it is now included in the ASL 2nd edition rulebook.

Avalon Hill Complexity Rating: 10

title: Yanks: ASL Module 3
types: Expansion for Base-game Wargame World War II
description:
(from MMP website and user's description:)

This is YANKS ... the American extension to the ASL game system.

YANKS is not a complete game. Ownership of the Advanced Squad Leader Game System is required for play.


[1st edition]

An extensive U.S. Army countermix is presented so that you can command every major vehicle, weapon and troop type that saw action in the European Theater.[...]

NOTE:  Chapter E, the optional rules including Night, Interrogation, Weather, Ski Troops, Boats, Swimming, Air Support, Gliders, Paratroop Landings, Ammo Vehicles, Convoys and Artillery Barrage rules, is now included with the  ASL RULEBOOK SECOND EDITION.  The Chapter E pages included with YANKS first edition are ASL RULEBOOK first edition versions.

Scenario List:
ASL Scenario 19    Backs to the Sea
ASL Scenario 20    Taking the Left Tit
ASL Scenario 21    Among the Ruins
ASL Scenario 22    Kurhaus Clash
ASL Scenario 23    Under the Noel Trees
ASL Scenario 24    The Mad Minute
ASL Scenario 25    Gavin's Gamble
ASL Scenario 26    Tanks in the Street

Contents:

    Four 8 x 22 mounted mapboards (#16-19)
    519 1/2 counters + 528 5/8 counters (5 countersheets)
    rule chapter E (pages E1-E26) [first edition rule]
    chapter E divider with play aids
    U.S. vehicle and ordnance notes (chapter H, pages H31-H48)
    U.S. OB detail (chapter N, pages N7-N10)
    8 scenarios (#19-#26)





[2nd editon]

YANKS contains the entire United States Army order of battle for ASL, including five different squad types, their half squads, leaders, and all the varied vehicle, ordnance, and support weapon and crew counters, thus enabling you to command every type of combat unit used by the American Army in every theater throughout the war.

YANKS now includes the essential elements of PARATROOPER and 24 additional scenarios.

Chapter H contains over 20 pages of detailed notes on the guns and vehicles, complete with some minor updates to the original. Also included are eight mapboards: 16-19, 24, 40-41, and 46, which will help you play many of the 40 scenarios inside YANKS: the 16 original scenarios from YANKS and PARATROOPER (all re-balanced) as well as 24 more out-of-print scenarios, re-numbered and re-balanced, all with existing errata incorporated. (New errata have been issued for the old scenarios to reflect the balancing changes made in these updates.)

Scenarios [...]:

        Backs To The Sea

    Gavin Take
    Strayer's Strays

    Not Out Of The Woods Yet

    The Attempt To Relieve Peiper

    Ace In The Hole

Contents:

    eight mapboards (16-19, 24, 40-41, and 46)
    six countersheets (1/2 and 5/8)
    American Chapter H (U.S. vehicle and ordnance notes)
    40 scenarios

title: Hedgerow Hell: ASL Deluxe Module 2
types: Expansion for Base-game Miniatures Wargame World War II
description:
This is the second Deluxe Advanced Squad Leader module, with larger map hexes to allow for miniature play, or just to spread out the counters more. This module contains scenarios set in the summer of 1944 in France, after D-Day.

Expands:

    Advanced Squad Leader




Requires:

    Advanced Squad Leader
    Beyond Valor: ASL Module 1
    Yanks: ASL Module 3
    Streets of Fire: ASL Deluxe Module 1 (for two scenarios)




Contents:
4 11x26 mounted mapboards: e, f, g, h
1 countersheet of status counters
8 scenarios: Deluxe ASL Scenarios 11-18
24 AFV cards

The 40 vehicles described in the 24 AFV cards are: M3(MMG) ht, M3 (HMG) ht, M3 GMC ht, M3A1 ht, M4 MC  M4A1 MC ht, M21 MC, LVT2, LVT(A)2, LVT4, LVT(A)1, LVT(A)4, M2A4, M3 (Stuart), M3A1, M3 (Lee), M4, M4(105)  M4A3(105), M4 DD, M4A1, M4A1(76)W, M4A2, M4A2 (L), M4A3, M4A3(75)W, M4A3(76)W, M4A3E2  M4A3E2 (L), M5A1, POA-CWS-H1, M26, M8, M8 HMC, M10 GMC, M36 GMC, M36B1 GMC, M18 GMC, M20, M24, M7 HMC, T19 HMC, and T30 HMC.

Scenarios:
D11: Ripe Pickings
D12: Repulsed
D13: Bogged Down
D14: Buying the Farm
D15: Barkmann's Corner
D16: Clay Pigeons
D17: They're Coming!
D18: King of the Hill

title: Streets of Fire: ASL Deluxe Module 1
types: Expansion for Base-game Miniatures Wargame World War II
description:
This is the first module of Deluxe Advanced Squad Leader. Not a new game, the major difference between ASL and DASL is the hex size on the maps. The hexes are 2.2 across, big enough to use 1/285th scale miniatures or to spread counters out in a more convenient manner. This module contains scenarios depicting street fighting on the Eastern Front.

The scenarios can be downloaded from the Multi-Man Publishing site

Requires:

    Advanced Squad Leader
    Beyond Valor: ASL Module 1




Expands:

    Advanced Squad Leader

title: G.I. Anvil of Victory
types: Expansion for Base-game Wargame World War II
description:
It is December, 1941; Europe lays stricken beneath the Nazi boot. Only Britain, sheltered by her fleet and the English channel, stands fast before the swaslika. To the East, German panzers stand stalled by winter at the very gates of Moscow. However, the Third Reich is nearing its high water mark for the tide is about to turn. The Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor will usher the United States into World War II and seal the doom of the Thou sand Year Reich. American industry will supply the Allied armies with vast quantities of war material, and a fresh, new breed of fighting man will enter the fray against Hitler's tested Wehrmacht. The G.I. will become the anvil on which the victory over a bled white Wehrmacht is forged.

G.I.; ANVIL OF VICTORY allows you to command the full gamut of American fighting men as they drive the Germans from Africa, Sicily, Italy, Normandy, and back across the Rhine and into Germany itself. G.I. adds the complete American arsenal of rrgmlng men ana machines to your SQUAD LEADER repertoire, while expanding and enriching the most acclaimed historical gaming system yet devised. Can the greater numbers and superior-gunnery control systems of the American Shermans compensate for the more lethal guns of the feared German Panther? G.I. provides a gripping and graphic answer unmatched by any book.

But G.I. offers far more than just American tanks. It contains more components than any of the preceding games in the series. The entire game system has been streamlined while enhancing realism even further. German, British, and even French infantry counters have been revised to enhance unit identification, add inherent smoke values, and more clearly distinguish the differences between squads, crews, and half-squads.

In each game you get: 

    1040 two-sided 1/2 die-cut counters representing the infantry combatants of the European Theatre from 1942-45 .
    528 two-sided 5/8 die-cut counters representing the complete vehicular and ordnance Order of Battle for the U.S. in World War II 
    Illustrated scenario cards for situations 33-46 
    Five additional 8 x 22 geomorphic mapboard sections increasing the possible terrain configurations many told and introducing several new terrain types [mapboard 8, 12, 13, 14, 15]
    Comprehensive, illustrated 36-page Programmed lnstruction Rulebook 
    Two expanded Quick Reference Data Cards 
    Terrain Overlays to further vary existing mapboards




(source: the back of the box and user's description)

title: Dilemmas
description: Dilemmas includes a book of 150 situations that the players have to craft solutions for. There are solutions provided, which will score points if matched in the party game, but the main puropose seems to be to stimulate conversation of the Why would you do that? variety.

title: APBA Major League Baseball: All Star Edition
description: An introductory version of the APBA baseball game. All star teams of 25 players from each league are provided. Play is based on hitting only- pitching skills play no part in this version of the game, in a similar way as Ethan Nathan Allen's classic All-Star Baseball.

title: 1876 Centennial Baseball
description:
A unique game based on the early (c. 1860-1890) days of baseball. Games can be played with generic players or with the ratings for the 1876 National League.

Game play is simple, with each player rolling a die, applying individual player modifiers for the pitcher and batter, and then consulting a chart to arrive at an outcome of the at bat. If a hit ball results, then another die roll comparison is made between the batter/runner and the fielder the ball is hit to.

In some cases, a play will be resolved after consulting a card that also describes an event in 19th century baseball.

The components are of high quality.

title: SPI Baseball
description: Richard H. Berg's and SPI's foray into the world of statistically based baseball games. Included are ratings for the 1979 National league plus the American League playoff teams from that year, Baltimore and California.

title: Face-Off Pro Hockey Game
description:
A stat-based hockey game, with cards representing individual NHL players.

From the rules:

Face-Off is a complete simulation of the game of professional ice hockey. It does not cut corners with detail, and includes every facet of the fastest team sport in the world.

Face-Off revolves around the use of four dice, the Game Chart and the player cards. A roll of the dice on either the Game Chart or a player card will lead to an instruction or code, with that action to be taken immediately.

title: Among Nations
description: An easy-to-play card game of international wheeling and double-dealing.  Each player represents the executive leadership of one country.  During each round, players determine their country's agenda and try to promote it while helping or hindering the agendas of other nations through fast-paced card trades and diplomacy.  Originally sold with GameFix issue number 9.

title: First Galaxy G1
mechanisms: Roll / Spin and MoveSimultaneous Action Selection
description:
The object is to fly a Rocket around the board to collect all 4 parts of a Battle Station, which is assembled at the base.
 The Rocket must then race back to it's home base and dock with the Battle Station to win.
The game involves attacking other players with lasers, fuel management, a black hole, and an original designed board of a galaxy with 10 arms and round supply cards. If you are swallowed by the black hole you re-enter by rolling two dice, the 1st number selects the arm , the 2nd tells you how many spaces you move.

Contents:

    1 Galaxy gameboard
    5 Rockets
    5 Space stations
    56 Supply cards
    60 Fuel cell pieces
    1 Standard die
    1 Deca dice
     Rules

title: The VCR Hockey Game
description:
This game is played until one team scores a number of goals agreed to before the game.

Play is controlled through cards, moving the puck and allowing shots, which are resolved through dice rolls. However, when a VCR card is drawn from the deck, a videotape is consulted which can result in an opportunity to try for a goal by flicking it from a spot on the board into a net.

title: Fighting Ships
description: One of the Helen of Toy games that had lots of low quality miniatures and were advertised in comic books in the 60s and 70s. The game is a Stratego variant with more open information.

title: Speedway
description: Speedway is fairly simple auto racing game that lasts three laps. The main mechanism is roll and move for speed. There is, however, a little strategy as you must declare intentions to change lanes or pass before you roll and you can get caught. Also, there is an Ave Caesar like pit stop requirement forcing drivers to decide whether to make a pit stop on the first or second lap (pit stops on the third lap require an extra lap to finish the race.) Once the decision is made, it then becomes a matter of planning to get to pit row.

title: Kaiju: Giant Monster Boardgame
types: Fantasy Modern Warfare Movies / TV / Radio theme Mythology Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Kaiju: the Giant Monster Boardgame  is one of the games in the Empires of History, a series of Axis  Allies variant board games by Guild of Blades. It is the second game in the Alternate History game series.

In Kaiju players assume control of one of four different factions: 

    Play Japan and try to defend your nation from giant Kaiju stomping through your cities, from the alien invaders trying to conquer your lands, and from the mythical Atlantean invaders. 
    Play the Kaiju from Monster Island and rampage through Japan's cities and battle against mechanized war machines and mecha kaiju, alien flying sourcers and other kaiju. 
    Play the alien invaders from Planet Z and try to conquer Japan while using your technology against the rampaging Kaiju and mysterious Atlanteans. 
    Play the Atlanteans from the underworld and come forth in the world to conquer Japan and battle Kaiju and aliens alike. 




In Kaiju each faction must compete for dominion using cut throat diplomacy and tactics to achieve victory.

Contents:

    17 x 22 4 piece, full color, hard mounted game board
    4 separate 8 1/2 x 11 hard mounted zone maps
    126 large plastic playing tokens
    216 small plastic playing tokens
    Rule book
    D10
    Misc mounted chit counters

title: Rummy 21
description:
The object of the game is to lay down sets by combining cards and tiles.  First player or team to reach 1000 points wins.

Contents:

    54 playing cards
    60 plastic tiles
    Mouse pad style board to organize play
    Score pad
    Rules

title: World Cup Soccer USA 94
description: This is a fairly simple Soccer game where shots are allowed only from certain positions on the board.  There are cards for goals, fouls, and even trivia and rules if you want to add those for learning experience.

title: Writersports
description:
Writersports was created to encourage, promote and inspire the art of literacy.

The modern decathlon of the mind

title: Impromptu
description:
'Impromptu: The ultimate challenge of getting your message across.  

The object of the game is to concoct a story in one minute that will convey a given word without specifically mentioning the word.  You'll be amazed and amused at some of the outrageous stories you and your friends will create.

You don't need a public speaking background and you don't need to be a novelist.  With a few friends and a lot of laughs you'll be the expert at getting your message across.

title: Raconteur
description:
From the box:

'Raconteur is entertainment, a game of shared stories, fun and laughter. Friends and family will enjoy this game again and again. Each story is different and there are over 10,000 combinations. You will live your stories as they unfold . . .

Be a Magician. Be an Explorer. Be Yourself. Be Extended. Be Amused!

title: Wordmania
description: From the box: Wordmania - you have just joined the frenzy of Wordmania, the thrilling new crossword puzzle game.  You race against time trying to place words on the crossword play board.  Letters are facing in all directions as the seconds run out.  You challenge another player to guess the word you have hidden.  But beware - your challenge could turn against you!

title: Slot Shot
description:
From the box:
Take to the ice as any of the 26 teams in the NHL. 

Play against the team of your opponent's choice. When the game begins it becomes two fierce rivals battling for goals. Move in on your opponent's net. Position your goalie to defend your net. See who has the moves to score! You'll need both strategy and luck to outscore your competition. Be careful where you skate, cross a referee or hit an opposing player and you'll spend some time in the penalty box.

No hockey experience or understanding of the game is required!

title: The Sheffield Wednesday Soccer Supremo
description: A football (Soccer) board game.  Players use a die to move either a player, players, or the ball.  Simple game that does deal with items such as tackling, offsides and shootouts.  Goals depend on where the shot is taken from and results from a card.  The board looks very similar to StreetSoccer but predates it by 10 years.  This is also a 5 on 5 game and comes in various boxes depending on where you bought it.  There's a Manchester United version and a few others as well.

title: All-Pro Hockey
description: Touted as the Official National Hockey League Game and played with strategy and skill, not luck or chance.  The offensive coach plans and carries out moves for his entire team while the defensive coach plans and carries out defensive moves.  Play by play the strategy unfolds simulation a real hockey match.  An interesting game of move an counter move to get into that scoring position. Penalties simply occur from forgetting to uncheck a body checked player.  .

title: Soccer-Football
description: A dice-driven simulation of football (which Americans call soccer).  The odd player gets to be the referee; when playing with 4 or 5, each team is split between offensive and defensive team players.

title: Inns & Taverns
description:
2 players (or 4 players playing as partners) each start out with 6 bidding chips, numbered 1 to 6. You and the player to your left simultaneously reveal their chips.  The player whose turn it is then gets to move his pawn a number of spaces, either forward or backward (his choice) equal to the difference between the two bids.  If it's a tie,  the player can't move.

The board is a 25-space track of famous English Inns  Taverns.  The game starts with each space having a corresponding coaster with the Inn name on it. If you move onto a space with a coaster still on it, you take the coaster.  Then the next player goes, bidding against the player to his left.  As the bidding goes round and round, eventually each player has used all 6 of his bid-chips.  They then take them all back into their hand, and start fresh.  First player to get to space 25 then gets to take all the remaining coasters still on the board.

The player (or partnership) with the most coasters wins the game.

title: Route 66
description:
Race from Chicago to Los Angeles along one of the most famous roads in the World; then see as much of America as possible on the way back.

Players have to play a valid State Card before moving on the first leg (the race to LA), and also play a Speed Card to either alter their own or another player's speed.  On the return journey, State Cards are collected; players travelling as slowly as possible to see the most sights.  The player who arrives back at Chicago with the most State Cards wins.

title: Ocean
description:
In Ocean, players pilot fishing boats through a world reminiscent of the old Wa-Tor population dynamics simulation from A. K. Dewdney's Computer Recreations column in Scientific American.  There are three different kinds of breeding fish (represented by shells) that the players are trying to catch.  There are also sharks, a wave, and viruses that move around the board according to fixed rules in order to wreak havoc with your plans.

The game was originally published as Visjes in 1998.  Ocean is the 1999 re-release.

Re-implemented by:

    SeaSim

title: American Derby
description:
American Derby has up to 6 horses race to the finish line at various lengths from 4 furlongs to 1 miles distances using the deck of 54 cards.

All cards are shuffled and distributed equally to each player. On each turn every player is allowed to play one card which allows their horse to move from 1-5 spaces or apply a penalty to another horse.

Plays very similar to the more recent game of Win, Place & Show by 3M. Comes with 6 painted metal horses.

title: Chercles
description:
The game of Circular checkers (hence the name).

The board is laid out as a series of intersecting circular paths. The playing pieces are silly-looking ogres called Cherks. Players alternate moving a Cherk one space forward along the one-way arrows printed on the paths. Pieces are captured in direct chess-fashion rather than by checker-style jumping. If a capture is possible, it must be performed, sometimes resulting in two or more captures in one turn if capturing one piece places the Cherk next to another piece. There is no last-rank promotion.

The player who succeeds in capturing all of his opponents Cherks wins.

Note: Parker Brothers published a companion game called Smess: The Ninny's Chess. The Cherk Pieces of this game were also used in Smess as Pawn-variants called Ninnies.

title: Mug Shots
description:
If you witnessed a crime ... could you identify the criminal?  Would you be able to remember his face?

The Mug Shot file contains many different eyes, noses, mouths, etc. printed on transparent film.  The idea is to reconstruct the criminals face, testing your memory and your ability to observe facial details.  Included are 30 different Mug Shots along with 54 assorted styles of facial features that you mix and match to try and recreate the Mug Shot you saw.

Can either be played with two people or in a party atmosphere by splitting into two teams.

title: 3 Men on a Horse
description:
Milton Bradley game #4367. Each player begins on START with their horse and 3 men in front of them.  Object is to race around the track and cross the FINISH with 3 men on your horse or if you cross the FINISH without the 3 men you sprint around the track at twice the normal speed to try and complete the second lap before any other person completes their first lap with 3 men on their horse.

Based on the 1936 Warner Bros. comedy movie of the same name.

title: Nitty Gritty
description:
Do you know what your friend, girlfriend or brother would answer to these questions??


    If you could assassinate someone, who would it be? 
    Have you ever fantasized about a workmate? 
    What is your favorite alcoholic drink? 
    If you had to take 3 people into a bomb shelter, who would they be? 
    What Simpsons character are you most like? 
    If you could keep only 1 of your 5 senses, which would it be? 


With questions like these, Nitty Gritty will test how well you know your best friend, lover, sister, husband or best friend's lover's sister's husband!

To play is simple - land on a category, ask your teammate a question and let them write down their answer. If you guess the answer, then you get another go. If not, pass the die to the next team!

All it takes to be a champion at Nitty Gritty is to have listened to your teammates boring childhood stories, put up with their opinions, know their tastes, and heard their secrets!

title: Khe Sanh, 1968
description:
(from ATO web site:)

The turning point of the American war in Vietnam occurred during the first months of 1968, a period framed by the Tet Offensive as well as the campaign featured here, the fighting for Khe Sanh. The region just below North Vietnam, Quang Tri province, was especially vulnerable to threats from the North Vietnamese Army (NVA) in the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) and across the Laotian border. For almost a year the US Marines had been fighting to stabilize the DMZ region.

Khe Sanh was the outpost intended to block and seal off the NVA's access to Quang Tri from the west, from Laos where many of their base areas were located. Other fortifications barred the DMZ. In early 1968 the NVA countered by assembling large forces around Khe Sanh, threatening a battle for the place. The American command focused its attention upon Quang Tri, and even more, Khe Sanh. The ensuing campaign pitted South Vietnamese and American forces, at the peak of their combat efficiency, against a tough NVA enemy. At stake was victory in the Vietnam War.

Khe Sanh, 1968 game

    Full color 22x34 map
    200 full color die cut counters
    Rulebook length - 16 pages




Complexity - Medium
Solitaire Suitability - Low

title: Hegemon
description:
(from ATO web site:)

Hegemon is an operational simulation for two players which recreates the efforts of Athens and Thebes to withstand the Makedonian pursuit of Hellenic hegemony in the crucial years of 339-338 BC. One player commands the forces of Athens, Thebes, and their allies (the Hellenes), while the other controls the Makedonian army and its allies (the Makedonians).

The uneasy and uncertain partnership between Athens and Thebes is based upon the tenuous agreement that Athens will be dominant at sea and Thebes will be dominant on land. Knowing that Makedon can offer only limited challenges to the Athenians at sea, Philip II of Makedon chooses to wage a land war, ostensibly to enforce a ruling of the Delphic Amphiktyony against the Lokrian city of Amphissa.

Contents:

    Full color 22x34 map
    360 full color die cut counters
    Rulebook length - 20 pages
    Charts and tables - 12 pages




Complexity - Medium
Solitaire suitability - Medium
Playing time - 10 hours

title: Quatero
description:
Quatero is the ideal mind game for two players and one that will surely mentally stimulate with shapes, colors, and marks.

Two basic rules govern Quatero during each turn, they are 1) a pattern of all four different solids in at least one row must be made and 2) an alternating end color pattern must be maintained. You have to push out one of 4 cards in the center and replace it with a card from your 3 card hand that will allow all 4 figures to appear atleast once in the 3 rows of each card in the center. Then you accumulate points labelled on the pushed out cards when 2-4 but not 1 [when 1 is on the card from your side, your opponent loses that card as well as the last card taken in the second color, either blue or red. When the deck is exhausted, add up your blue and red points accumulated and see who has won.

Contents:

    48 playing cards 
    1 rule book 
    All packaged in a black velvet bag 




Players: 2
Game running time: about 25 minutes
Ages: 11 and up

title: BattleBots: Build' Em Bash 'Em
types: Action / Dexterity Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
Based on the TV series with the fighting robots, this is a two-stage game. You start with a chassis that also includes a basic weapon.

In the first part of the game, you bid on robot bodies, armor, and upgraded weapons. Each player has a hand of cards that are numbered from 0 to 3, plus a Battle card. To get a body, you play a war-like card game, blindly drawing one of your cards. The player with the highest card gets to choose from the four bodies available. The loser chooses from what is remaining. Next, the players bid for accessories, the armor and weapons. The loser of the body choice gets to choose the first accessory up for bid. Each robot has a specific set of armor that will fit it. If you lose the bid on it, you are at a severe disadvantage. However, your opponent will have had to use up bid cards and thus will have less for later auctions. You also can prevent your opponent from completing his robot by playing your Battle card in an auction.
