Players take the roles of up to four terrible 'Plant People', each with a different special power.  Players alternate placing their vines on the board.  When a square is surrounded on three sides it forms a pod (worth 3 points in combat).  Players have either 8 or 12 pods depending on their special power.

When opponent's vines touch, there is combat... loser must remove all of the vines being attacked.

The object of the game is to completely choke out all other player's vines and pods, forcing them off the board.

title: Escape from the Brotherhood
description:
A solitaire game, based on the Agent 13 comic, published in 13: Assassin magazine #2.

All you have to do is get from Start' to the Agent 13 Cell by avoiding loss of life points and trying to evade as many random encounters as possible.  There are more encounter tokens than game spaces, so every game is different.

title: Race for the Crystal
description:
A two-player boardgame based on the Agent 13 comic published in 13:Assassin magazine #3.

One player takes the role of Agent 13, the other is Agent 13's nemesis, China White, and her minions.  Players alternate moving (resolving any random encounters) and then resolve any combat.

The first player to capture the power crystal and escape, or eliminate all of his opponent's characters, is the winner.

title: Aura Battler Dunbine: Wing Caliver
types: Expansion for Base-game Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity rating 5 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

Comes in a full-size box. Includes 3 new maps, counters, with additional and expanded rules.

Expands:

    Aura Battler Dunbine

title: Aura Battler Dunbine: Byston Well
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity rating 5 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

Not an expansion to any other Aura Battler game, this game is completely stand-alone.

2 player ground based tactical wargame. 3-fold out mounted maps combine to make one big map.

title: Witches and Wizards
description:
From the box:

The Evil Lords of the Dark Castle have stolen the gold from the Village of Hope. The townspeople need Witches and Wizards to return their chest of gold using your magical power. Will you win the race for the gold and be the first to safely return from the Enchanted Forest to the Village of Hope?

Contents:

    Gameboard
    Illustrated Story Book and Game Rules
    8 Witches and Wizards Game Pieces
    Spell-Caster Cards
    Spell-Buster Cards
    Gold Chest
    1 Die

title: The Battle For Smithville II: An R.I.P. Cardgame
description:
The Battle for Smithville II is a two player card game. It was published in R.I.P. magazine #6.

Included in the game are rules and sheets of cut-apart cards.

Part rummy, part concentration, players play, then flip cards to match adversaries. If the adversaries battle, the player gains points. The one with the most points after all of the cards have been played, wins.

title: Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Gate of Zedan
types: Expansion for Base-game Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
The Kit of Expansible in the Z Gundam Games

Yes, that's the official wording on the box.

Expansion set for either of the main Mobile Suit Z Gundam games (Titan being one of them).  Includes a sheet of counters, and 36 data cards for easy reference for lots of different mechs (and a rulebook as well of course).

This is based off the Mobile Suit Gundam anime series and is part of the Mobile Suit Gundam familly of games.

Expands:

    Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Green Noa 1
    Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Titans

title: Mobile Suit Gundam: Close Fight
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity level 6 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Mobilesuits Combat in Gundam

One of many wargames based off Mobile Suit Gundam anime series from the early 1980s. This one has 7 different ground-based scenarios to fight. Includes many counters, a pad of record sheets, and 4 double-sided maps.

This is based off the Mobile Suit Gundam anime series and is part of the Mobile Suit Gundam familly of games.

title: Mobile Suit Gundam: White Base
types: Expansion for Base-game Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity level 6 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Space Fleet Battle in the Gundam

Expansion set for Mobile Suit Gundam: New Type has additional units and rules aimed at making the game more dynamic. There were two versions of White Base released, with a different cover (other changes are uncertain).

Includes counters and 3 single sided mounted maps. 10 more scenarios are described in the rulebook.

Expands:

    Mobile Suit Gundam: New Type

title: Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Green Noa 1
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity level 1 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Space Fortress Combat in Z Gundam

Based off the Mobile Suit Z Gundam (Zeta Gundam) anime. This one has 4 different space-based scenarios to fight covering episodes 2 through 11 of the anime, overlapping the episodes that the Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Titans game covers.

Includes many counters and 3 single sided mounted maps.
Not as complex as some of the others in the series, the rulebook is just a few pages long.

This is based off the Mobile Suit Z Gundam anime series and is part of the Mobile Suit Gundam familly of games.

Expanded by:

    Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Gate of Zedan

title: Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Titans
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity level 5 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Space Fortress Combat in Z Gundam

1st wargame based off the Mobile Suit Gundam Z (Zeta Gundam) anime. This one has 4 different space-based scenarios to fight based off the first 11 episodes of the anime. Includes many counters and 6 single sided maps.

This is based off the Mobile Suit Z Gundam anime series and is part of the Mobile Suit Gundam familly of games.

Expanded by:

    Mobile Suit Z Gundam: Gate of Zedan

title: Mobile Suit Gundam: New Type
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity level 6 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Space Combat in Gundam

3rd of many wargames based off Mobile Suit Gundam from the early 1980s. This one has 12 different space-based scenarios to fight. Includes many counters and 4 single sided mounted maps.

Expanded by:

    Mobile Suit Gundam: White Base

title: Mobile Suit Gundam: Fortress
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity level 3 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Space Fortress Combat in Gundam

2nd of many wargames based off Mobile Suit Gundam anime series from the early 1980s. This one has 7 different space-based scenarios to fight. Includes many counters and 4 single sided mounted maps.

This is based off the Mobile Suit Gundam anime series and is part of the Mobile Suit Gundam familly of games.

title: Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity level 6 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

Only released in Japan, this is a hex-based wargame based on the 2nd Star Trek movie of the same name.

It claims 2-4 players, but like many of Tsukada's games, you have to split into 2 'teams' and share counters for more than 2 players; it's really just a 2 player game.

Includes 8 different scenarios to fight.

title: Star Wars: Endor
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity level 3 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

Only released in Japan, this is a Star Wars themed hex-based wargame based not on the entire Return of the Jedi movie, but just on Endor. This game has no relation to West End Games Star Wars: Battle for Endor game (other than being based off the same movie).

title: Star Wars: Hoth
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity level 3 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

Only released in Japan, this is a Star Wars themed hex-based wargame based not on the entire Empire Strikes Back movie, but just on the attack on Hoth. This game has no relation to West End Games' Assault on Hoth (other than being based off the same movie).

title: Star Wars: Death Star
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity level 3 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

Only released in Japan, this is a Star Wars themed hex-based wargame is based on the rebels attacking the Death Star.

While the box says 2-8 players, like many of Tsukada's games, over two players means get on one of the two teams and share the counters; it's really a 2 player game.

Tsukada could've paid more attention to their box.. Two things of note on the box:

1) On the front, it has the Empire Strikes Back logo on it, even though the game is based off the Death Star attack from the first movie. Most likely it's just because it came out after Empire Strikes Back, but..

2) On the back of the box, in says in English May the forth be with you!

title: Jacob's Ladder
mechanisms: Dice RollingRoll / Spin and MoveSet Collection
description: The goal of this game is to construct a Frankenstein's Monster, or, in the games terms, a Surgically Composite Monster. Players do this by traipsing about the land mustering an army, battling neutral armies, and eventually collecting enough pieces to bring their monster to life. The battle is done in a mini-map fashion, titan style. Plenty of spells and items are sprinkled throughout.

title: Place Your Bets!
description:
Based on the 1974-75 game show Dealer's Choice, with a stake of $100 each player participates in five games of chance. Each game has been assigned rounds in which it may be played. The player designated as the dealer for each round chooses the game from a group of 12, all used on the show. The rules for each game are written on its board.

The final round is played with the Bonus Dice. The Bonus Dice have money amounts from $50 to $200 written on eleven of the twelve faces; the twelfth face contains a spade. Each player makes a secret guess how much money the Bonus Dice will accumulate before the spade is rolled. Those who come closest without going over get their holdings doubled. The player with the most money wins.

title: The 6 Pack of Paper & Pencil Games
Deadlands: Lost Colony – Showdown
types: Card Game Collectible Components Science Fiction
description:
A collectible card game based on the Deadlands Lost Colony Roleplaying system.

Sold in starter sets of 65 cards and booster packs of 30 cards each.

title: King of the Anthill
description:
King of the Anthill was published in Intruder magazine #6. Can Eric, the Intruder, rescue the other humans before the they are trapped forever in this alternate dimension?

One player controls the interdimensional creatures trying to capture the humans and drag them deep into the 'Anthill'. The other player takes the role of the humans and attempts to escape from the top of the hill, battling native creatures along the way.

To win, the Human player must get all three humans to the top of the hill. The Native player wins if he can prevent this from happening.

title: Orguss: Orguroid
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity level 2 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Battles in the Orguss

Based off the mecha anime Orguss, this game takes place on the ground, over mountainous terrian. Includes counters and 3 single sided mounted maps.

title: Orguss: Factory
types: Economic Exploration Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction
description:
Complexity level 4 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

The Diplomatic Game in Orguss

A break from Tsukada's usual 2 player science fiction hex-wargame fare. It's still science fiction, but this time it's a true 2-5 player game, more in the style of the old Avalon Hill's Diplomacy and Civilization games.

title: Raid on the Bunker
description:
This solitaire game was published in Warhawks magazine #1.

The Zetans have placed a bomb on the Time Platform... your squad of mercenaries must avoid or eliminate  14 Zetan guards in the research facility, without causing any casualties to the scientists, and get to the 'Time Platform' in seven game turns to win... easier said than done.

title: L-Gaim Mark II
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Alternate but not official title: Heavy Metal L-Gaim Mark II

Complexity level 5 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

Based off the mecha anime Heavy Metal L-Gaim, this takes L-Gaim to space, with 6 single-sided space maps and 300 new counters. This is a seperate and complete game from the original, ownership of the original is not required. However, both games use the same expansion kit.

Expanded by:

    Heavy Metal L-Gaim Expansion kit

title: Heavy Metal L-Gaim
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity level 5 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

Based off the mecha anime Heavy Metal L-Gaim, this is a ground-based 2 player hexcounter wargame.

Includes 4 single-sided mounted maps and counters. There are rules for 3 different scenarios to fight.

Expanded by:

    Heavy Metal L-Gaim Expansion kit

title: Raid on Bananama: The Bad Boys Game
description:
A two-player game based on the Bad Boys comic series published in Warhawks magazine #2.

After the invasion of Bananama, the forces of the U.S. have taken El Presidente into custody... or have they?  You play either the forces of the 'Bad Boys: American Special Forces', or 'The Cartel', the elite drug runners of the Third World.  Each side wants El Presidente... the U.S., because he's been helping run drugs; the Cartel, to kill him before he talks.

Finding El Presidente will be difficult because of his duplicates, but if either player can get the real one to his HQ, he wins.

title: Heavy Metal L-Gaim Expansion kit
types: Expansion for Base-game Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
An expansion that can be used with either Heavy Metal L-Gaim (Tsukuda, not Bandai's one) or L-Gaim Mark II. A sheet of counters and a rulebook with additional rules. 
Very tough to get in even Japan, was originally sold via mail order in an envelope (similar to some Avalon Hill expansions).

Expands

    L-Gaim Mark II
    Heavy Metal L-Gaim

title: Aura Battler Dunbine
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity rating 4 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

Based on the mecha science-fiction anime Aura Battler Dunbine. A 2-player hex-based ground mecha combat wargame.

Includes counters and 3 single-sided mounted maps. Rules included for a regular scenario and for a campaign game.

title: L-Gaim Mark II: Sveet
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity level 2 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

Based off the mecha anime Heavy Metal L-Gaim, this is a space-based 2 player hex  counter wargame.

Extremely tough to find in Japan, this is not an expansion to any of the other L-Gaim games, but an alternate, easier to learn (but of course still in Japanese) wargame.

title: Craters of Tharsis
description:
Craters of Tharsis is a two-player boardgame published in Buck Rogers magazine #3.  It is based, in part, on the novel Hammer of Mars (also published by TSR).  One player takes the role of the NEO freedom fighters, the other plays the omnipresent RAM.

The game includes a mapsheet of the area (where the battles for Mars take place), 6 pages of rules (covering basic initiative, movement, and attack phases), and one sheet of cut-out counters.

Victory points are given to each player for destroying (or stealing, for the NEO player) enemy units.  The game ends when all NEO troops are killed or all RAM Krait fighters have left the map.  The player with the most points wins.

title: The Gauntlet
description:
The Gauntlet is a two-player boardgame that was published in Buck Rogers magazine #1.

One player is Anatoly Karpov, the renegade Russian general who has stolen the Masterlink, a space based weapon satellite.  The other player is Col. Anthony 'Buck' Rogers, America's greatest pilot.

The game contains a map, 8 pages of rules, 106 cut-apart counters, and player ship displays.

The U.S. player wins if Masterlink is destroyed.  The Soviet player wins if Buck Rogers is killed and Kharkov survives, no matter how badly Masterlink is otherwise damaged.  Special tournament victory conditions are also provided based on varying levels of victory.

title: Zombie Rampage
description:
Zombie Rampage, the Battle for Smithville (Part III), is a two player tactical game that was published in R.I.P. magazine #3. One player takes control of the Zombies and one player takes control of the unsuspecting humans.

THe game includes a stylised map of Smithville, 3 pages of rules, and one sheet of cutout counters.

To win, the Zombie player must kill all the Humans so that the Zombies can continue to try to destroy America in the 'Zombie Nation' game (q.v.).  THe Human player must kill all the Zombies so that the events in 'Zombie Nation' do not occur.

title: Attack in the Asteroids
description:
Attack in the Asteroids, published in Buck Rogers magazine #5,  is a simplified version of the tactical ship-to-ship combat game from the XXVc Roleplaying game.  The game covers a battle between Black Barney, in the ship 'Free Enterprise' and three RAM battle cruisers.

The game contains a hex mapsheet, 3 pages of basic rules, ship charts, and a sheet of cut-out counters.

To win, either the Black Barney player or the RAM player must completely destroy the other player's ship(s).

title: Zombie Nation
description:
Zombie Nation, the Battle for More than Smithville (Part IV), is a game for two players that continues the battle started in Zombie Rampage (q.v.).  This game was published in R.I.P. magazine #4.

The game contains a map of the U.S., 3 pages of rules and one sheet of cutout counters.

The Zombie player has sent out mystical Graveyard Icons across the U.S. and the Army has been called in to put a stop to any further uprisings.  To win, the Zombie player must destroy all of the Army forces.  The Army player must destroy all of the Zombies and their icons.

title: Mafia
description:
2/4 Families players try to get the control of Sicily: they throw the die and move around a 8-shaped pattern, getting control of the cases. Some of them have also positive or negative effects.

Families are composed of a Boss and several young members. They can also fight each other and steal posses of cases of other families. Another player is the Italian State, using a Prefetto, three Carabinieri (military police) units and a secret services man. He must arrest all the Mafia men he can.

Mafia is a simple game with an unusual setting, that aroused some discussion in Italian newspapers when it came out.

title: Little Big Horn: Custer's Last Stand
description:
From the box:

The realistic battle game which recreates the historic confrontation between George Armstrong Custers 7th U.S. Cavalry regiment and the several thousand Sioux, Cheyenne and other Indian warriors led by Sitting Bull, Crazy Horse and various other chiefs.  It is once again June, 1876, and you are at the Battle of the Little Big Horn.

Contents: 280 counters, 7 7-hex Indian camps, 2 maps,  time record sheet

title: Zombies!!! 3:  Mall Walkers
types: Expansion for Base-game Fighting Horror Zombies
mechanisms: Modular BoardRoll / Spin and MoveTile Placement
description:
Zombies!!! 3 Mall Walkers adds a whole new level of excitement to shopping. Enter the front door, find what you need, and try to escape alive! Above all, Shop 'til you TRULY drop!

This expansion could be played stand-alone with shotgun guys (or other player markers) and tokens for bullets and hearts.

Part of the Zombies!!! series.

title: Goosebumps: Shrieks and Spiders Game
types: Action / Dexterity Card Game Children's Game Novel-based
description:
A simple variant of the game Spoons (as if Spoons weren't simple enough).  Plastic spiders are put in the center of the table (one less than the number of players).  Each player is given a scoreboard and four tokens to put in it.  Each player is then dealt a stack of cards face-down in front of them.

Each turn the players simultaneously turn over the top card from their stack.  If any of the turned-over cards shows a skeleton, the players yell Goosebumps and grab one of the spiders from the center of the table.  The player who didn't get a skeleton must turn in one of their tokens.  Play then continues.  The game ends when one player has discarded their last token, at which time the player with the most tokens remaining is the winner.

title: I Ching la voie du Ta Tchouan
description:
The way of the Ta tchouan (named I CHING in France) gather two players in the same goal : drawing a path through the board with identical square pawns (named Quarks) in order to reach the opposite edge with their color own, black or white, yin or yang... Each quark is composed by an equal part of the way for the two players.

Based on the Book of Changes like the Go does, this connection game provided a wide panel of strategy with only two simple rules : 
- INFLUENCE : you can't play around the last Quark played
- OPPOSITION : you can't break the paths, instead, you should build at least one of them by playing adjacent Quarks.

Initially build for a 6x6 pawn game, the cards provided in the Ta Tchouan box allow you to play on a 7x7, and it's not physically bound except by the time you need to play on an infinite x infinite board !!!

title: Cheat
description:
Cheat is a beer  pretzels bluffing game.

Players shake a container containing 2 dice behind a slider, then look at the numbers they rolled.  You must roll (or say you rolled) a higher score than the previous player. Points are lost by successful (or unsuccessful) challenges.

Similar to Mia.

title: High Stakes
description:
This is yet another Monopoly variant.

Instead of Atlantic City properties, players purchase Las Vegas casinos (circa 1974), and rather than paying rent when you land on a property, players must gamble an amount specified by the property owner.  Games include Craps, Blackjack, and Roulette. The game was endorsed by Jerry Lewis (box features his photo and signature).

Another version of the game, not endorsed by Jerry Lewis, comes in more conventionally sized box.

Although the game uses Las Vegas as a setting, the game uses the French Roulette wheel instead of the American wheel. The American wheel has an added space: the double zero. Someone noticed this when designing the box and placed a die strategically to cover up the zero in a photograph of the game!

title: Idro
description:
The battle among the Krosts, Tritons and Mermaids in the Moog sea for the creation o a new social rank which release slaves of the coral plantations.

Degree of difficulty: 4/6

Contents:

    170 counters in plasticized, matte finish cardboard, cut and printed on both sides, on them there are the various characters with their movement and combat factors.
    Cardboard tables to determinate the results of battles and of the morale.
    Calendar table.
    Table for hidden armies.
    Rule booklet in 4 languages with examples.
    Board in thick, rigid cardboard with a matte plastic finish, cut into 5 pieces, and printed in 5 colours. It represents the submarine Moog world.
    Plastic storage tray and dice.

title: Triple Traveler
description:
A collection of three abstract strategy games that all play on the same board.  The board and pieces are designed to stay put, so that the games can be played while traveling.  The three games are:

Tandu - Each player places their opponent's numbered tiles (1 - 14) face-down on the board.  They then take turns turning over one tile at a time.  If it is the correct tile in sequence (starting with 1), it is placed on the outside edge of the board.  The first player to place all 14 of their tiles wins.

Hannibal - Each player tries to capture their opponent's king by placing blocks around it.  The first to succeed wins the game.

Nile - Try to be the first player to place four of their pyramids in a row, while blocking the other player from doing so.

title: Kangaroo: The Jumping Game
description:
Players start with their pawns lined up on opposite side of the board.  Each takes turns moving one pawn.  Movement is made by jumping over a pawn in a straight line (vertically, horizontally, or diagonally).  If you jump over your own pawn, it is just movement.  If you jump over an opponent's pawn, it is captured.  Multiple consecutive jumps by one pawn can be made in a single turn.

The game ends when no more moves can be made or one player runs out of pawns.  Points are then tallied (1 point per captured pawn, 2 points for each of your pawns in your opponent's home row) and the high scorer is the winner.

title: Wheaties Sports Trivia Game
description:
A sports trivia game that celebrates 75 years of General Mills' Wheaties cereal.

From the box:

The object of the game is to score as many points as possible in Divisional, Conference, and Playoff rounds to get to the Winners Circle.  Once in the Winners Circle, players vie for the Championship Ring.  Points are scored by correctly answering trivia questions on tennis, golf, football, hockey, auto racing, baseball, the Olympics, basketball, and a special All Champions sports section that touches on nearly every champion and sport known to man.  Along the way you try to obtain strategic advantage by landing on Playbook spaces.  If you are lucky you get some draft picks, pick-up season-making free agents, figure out a team game plan, or make trades for the stretch run.

title: Crosswords
description:
From the box:

The object of the game is to be the first to complete one's personalized crossword grid.  Players move around the grid-shaped board by throwing the dice and correctly answering crossword-type clues.  Players can move around the board in any direction.  Along the outer [edge] of the board are 8 green squares.  It is by landing on these squares that the player has the opportunity to answer a clue and fill in his/her own personal grid.  

A handicapping system is presented to make the game more challenging depending on each player's level of expertise.

title: Cloister Games
mechanisms: Area EnclosureArea MovementPoint to Point Movement
description: Cloister Games is a nicely presented compilation of four medieval games, typical of those found etched onto monastery floors.  Fox and Geese is played on a board instantly recognizable to us as solitaire. The single Fox wins by jumping over the geese, landing on an empty point and thereby diminishing the flock until it is no longer viable. The geese win by hemming in the fox  so he cannot move. It's not easy to win as the geese. The fascinating game of Merels is better known as Nine Mans Morris and has an entry to itself elsewhere in this database. Albuquerque is perhaps the pick of the bunch, with a strategy resembling a cross between draughts and Merels and its influence is clearly to be seen in modern derivatives such as Kensington. Finally, Fierges is identical to draughts but without the compulsion (huffing) rule.  Each  game is eminently playable in its own right and, together, provide a fascinating insight into the development of modern draughts (checkers). The four boards are beautifully illuminated in medieval style and accompanied by wooden pieces.

title: Duel of Ages Set 2: Intensity
types: Adventure Civilization Expansion for Base-game Fantasy Fighting
description:
Ramp up the intensity in this exciting expansion to Duel of Ages.


    Enrich your experience with 3 new maps and 72 all-new characters and equipment.
    Confront 40 new labyrinth guardians.
    Unleash deadly creatures and machines upon the unsuspecting enemy - the powerful Bengal Tiger, vicious Hachetbeak, the Gemini automated defense system, monstrous Lancer, and others.
    Take the high ground on new terrain, the lofty Mesa.
    Defend your team base as you seek to destroy the enemy's.
    Capture and imprison enemy characters, then interrogate them.
    Make use of the valuable Lith Strategica.
    Challenge Lith Alliance, winning new friends through diplomatic efforts.


Expands

    Duel of Ages Set 1: Worldspanner

title: Duel of Ages Set 6: Field of Honor
types: Adventure Civilization Expansion for Base-game Fantasy Fighting Wargame
description:
Stand upon the Field of Honor...and challenge the watery-legged curs who dare to oppose you. At long last, you can make the despicable foes come to you, to answer for their myriad crimes and repulsive manners. Honorable characters may allow their opponent the first shot, while Dishonorable may act treacherously. It's raw colonial justice, as a small lead ball or sword point decides right and wrong...

Expands

    Duel of Ages Set 1: Worldspanner

title: Duel of Ages Set 3: Vast Horizons
types: Adventure Civilization Expansion for Base-game Fantasy Fighting Wargame
description:
This massive map expansion for Duel of Ages includes 21 all-new platters and 18 keys. Unless you plan to tile your
floors with the game, Vast Horizons should keep you happy for some time to come...

Expands

    Duel of Ages Set 1: Worldspanner

title: Duel of Ages Set 4: Royal Tournament
types: Adventure Expansion for Base-game Fantasy Fighting Science Fiction
mechanisms: Area Control / Area InfluenceDice RollingGrid MovementModular BoardPartnershipsPlayer Elimination
description:
The Royal Tournament challenges you to daring feats. Prepare to challenge at the jousts, in the skirmish fields and on the archery range. Feast everyone else under the table, or regale the court with epic tales. Great deeds will win new allies...

Expands

    Duel of Ages Set 1: Worldspanner

title: Duel of Ages Set 5: Mercenary Camp
types: Adventure Civilization Expansion for Base-game Fantasy Fighting Wargame
description:
War is hell......so pay someone else to fight it. At the Mercenary Camp, hire henchmen to take the field against your
enemies. But don't delay -- the mercs deal only to those with serious intent and ready cash...

Expands

    Duel of Ages Set 1: Worldspanner

title: Duel of Ages Set 7: Ruins of Cany XII
types: Adventure Civilization Expansion for Base-game Fantasy Fighting Wargame
description:
Ancient alien ruins for the taking......if one has the skill, courage and cunning. For the alien installation is not entirely dead and more than able to defend itself. Claw your way into the Outpost, Dead City, and to the ultimate find -- the Planetary Intellect.

Expands

    Duel of Ages Set 1: Worldspanner

title: S.F.3.D. Original
description:
(from the Box:)

The storm which is World War IV engulfs the continent of Australia. War sparks ingenuity. Ingenuity birth technology. Technology is escalation. The puppet regime which is called Shuttoral World Government is the enemy. The Australian-led resistance grows in strength with the advent of the HAFS Jerry, a tow-legged tank with a ground speed of 54 km/hr. War continues

January 11, 2885: New Canberra City falls to Australian forces. The Germans retreat south skirting the desert.
February 3, 2885: Shuttoral forces, isolated, make an abortive drive on the township of Gibson. A beachhead rescue saves most ot the force.
April 25, 2885: Shuttoral scientists make a secret presentation to Command of the prototype Krachen vogel, armed drone recon. This weapon will be particularly nasty to the Allies because of its similarity to the un-armed Neuspotter.
April 26, 2885: Plans begin for a new Shuttoral offensive towards New Canberra City. The directive is Take, or destroy.

SF3D is a Fast-Moving, Realistic 2-player Game of War, Inspired by the award-winning series of plastic model kits, by Nitto of Japan. This game has been thoroughly playtested in the U.S.
Limited, Numbered Edition of 2,040

480 Superb, die-cut doubled-sided oversized counters
4 folding, full-color, semi-geomorphic map boards
20-page Japanese rulebook, numbered
10 Scenario Cards, plus variants
1 Combat Chart Card, 2 Air Commitment Cards
2 six-sided dice


(BGG description:)

With all of the science fiction wargames that were published in Japan, almost all were based off anime shows, and none used original designs (even the US Battletech just used robots from JPN anime shows without permission to begin). This one does use its own story and designs.

The game includes 4 mounted maps, and many scenarios that are each given their own scenario cards (ala the US Squad Leader wargame). Includes slightly larger counters than are usually used in Japanese wargames.

There was an expansion/sequel to this produced.

title: Armored Trooper Votoms: Battling
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity level 5 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

Based off the science fiction mecha anime Armored Trooper Votoms.

Says The Role Playing game of Battle in the Votoms, but it's really more along the lines of Battletech than what most call a Role-Playing Game.

For a change of scenery from most of Tsukuda's 'outdoor' wargames, this takes place in an Arena.

title: Armored Trooper Votoms: Red Shoulder
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Complexity level 5 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

Based off the science fiction mecha anime Armored Trooper Votoms.

This is a 2 player hex-and-counter wargame. There are 6 scenarios. 2 maps are provided, and a set of data cards to keep track of the details of the robots that you control in the battle.

title: Armored Trooper Votoms: Civil War
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description:
This game is a game based on Votoms of the animated cartoon, Armored Trooper Votoms. The game reproduces the scene in the Kummen kingdom. The game is one in FS Series, and a comparatively easy difficulty -- Complexity level 2 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest). The appearing unit is AT, infantry, helicopter, vehicle, and ship.

2 player hex-and-counter wargame that takes place on Kummen. Includes 4 scenarios, over 2 maps; a jungle and a city.

title: The Amazing Spider-Man
description:
Hex-based board game for 2 players. One player plays the Amazing Spider-Man, and the other plays the bad guys. Spider-Man attempts to capture the enemies in rope or his web, and the bad guys try to enter a building with a armored car, break into it, and escape from Manhattan Island (or, if they prefer, to defeat Spider-Man).

Overall style is a hex-and-counter boardgame, with event cards and action cards to create variety from game to game. More light-hearted than most of Tsukuda's fare, this is part of their 'fun series' (as opposed to their 'not-any-fun series?). However, it is not overly simplistic, as the box does recommend Ages 12 and up

The rulebook is in Japanese, but the action and event cards are printed in both Japanese and English (on the same card, not two different sets). The map is in English (which, by the way, is 4 fold-out map sections that are combined to make one large map).

title: Stop it!
description:
Stop it! is a fast action dexterity card game where all players grab colored cards from five piles as quickly as they can. The deck is made up of 135 cards in 7 different colored suits. Each suit is made up of 17 color cards and 2 colored Stop cards. The remaining 2 cards are Superstop cards.

The basic flow of the game is that everyone grabs cards with one hand and puts it into their other hand until a stop card surfaces and someone yells Stop color for the color of the stop card. Any players in the process of picking up a card can add this card to their pile. Then, each player counts the number of cards of that color and the player with the fewest (or tied for the fewest) cards in that color receives a -1 card from the initial stock of 15 -1 cards. Additionally, if any player has cards out of order in their hand (not grouped by color), they receive an additional -1. The player who called the Stop then calls Go and the mayhem continues. Superstops cause the play to be stopped and the total number of cards to be compared, with the person with the fewest cards receiving a -1. The game ends immediately when the last -1 card is given out, and the winner is the player with the fewest -1 cards.

title: Crisis: 2000
description:
Crisis: 2000 is Joe Miranda's vision of a potential uprising within the borders of the United States of America.  This game, first published in GameFix magazine, is fast paced and unpredictable.

Contents:

    11X17 map
    100 diecut counters
    A sheet of charts and tables
    8 pages of rules (including designer's notes).




Each region of the U.S. is worth a number of points to either the Rebel or Government player.  At the end of 10 game turns the difference in points gained determines who wins (and by what level of victory).

Reimplemented by:

     Crisis 2020

title: Crusher Joe
types: Fighting Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction
description:
Complexity level 3 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

Based off the Crusher Joe science fiction action OVAs.

This is aimed at two players, one taking the Crusher side and going against the Murphy Pirates side. (As usual, Tsukuda says its 2-8 players, and simply says for everyone to get into 2 teams..)

Uses a square-graph instead of hexagonal map, but still uses counters like most of Tsukuda's games. The game itself is a fight/shoot-out inside a building.

title: 7 de Table
description:
It's hard to describe this kind of trick taking game, because the description of the game has a great chance of being longer than a single play. 7 de Table is made in Lyon (France) and has reached it's final version with engraved boxwood counters and a triangular leather bag to carry them.

There are 3 principles:

    The first player who reaches 7 points or more wins the game
    The points are easy to take by launching one of your Centaur pawns bumping into opposite pawns showing some points (one or two).
    There is no board, and at extreme limits... there are no rules either, the players have to define what is correct or not to block the enemy fire !




It seems to be a dexterity game like Carom's or Pool, but it can be played in 5 minutes and everywhere if there is a table or some kind of surface. In fact, it's a true politically incorrect game, that can be played according to its rules or... not ! The rules are a bit complex and explain the multiple combination between counters and action pawns, but this complexity is more valuable for the trickiness !!!

The game is short enough so that it can be re-played thus avoiding silly quarrels, so let's play !

title: Dragon Quest Dungeon
description:
This game is a fantasy based game with strong gameplay ties to Battleship.

Each player secretly sets up his own dungeon; there's a stand-up cut-out castle to use as a shield between the players. You place the square-shaped walls all over the place in your dungeon, along with stairwells to the smaller 2nd level of the dungeon. You also place your monsters and various treasures for the other player to discover, fake treasures (mimics) and your boss monster. You cannot place the weapons in such a way that they're impossible to get to (either cut off by walls or the boss monster). Your then tell the other player which space the entrance to the dungeon is.

Each player in turn calls out the space he wishes to move to. You must call out each space one at a time. If there is a wall there, the player's turn ends. If the space is clear, they may continue on. If there is a monster, it must be fought. If the player is victorious, he gains a reward card for defeating it and may continue on; otherwise his turn ends. If there is a treasure chest, the player may examine it. If it's a treasure, he may keep it and move on. If its a mimic (a monster that looks like a treasure chest), then he must fight it as if it was a monster.

Play alternates between players until one player gets all 3 necessary treasures and then fights and kills the boss monster; that player is the winner.

There is minimal text on the components; as long as one player knows the rules and what the cards do, it is easy to show the other player (the cards with JPN text on them have distinctive pictures to make it easy to remember once told what it does)..

title: Monster Maker: Dragon Treasure
description: One of the few Monster Maker games that does not use cards, this is a hex-and-counter boardgame. The object of the game is to get back the treasures the Dragon has stolen. The first player to get the 3 treasures and return to the castle is the winner.

title: Monster Maker: Dragon Attack!
description:
Come to think of it, the Dragon may be the one who was attacked. The humans showed off their own power stealing the Dragon's treasure, and taking it as their own. Finally the Dragon let out its anger, and began its revenge on the human kingdom of Silverado. The nearby villages burned from its breath, and every temple was destroyed. The Dragon proceeded towards the Royal Palace. Is there anyone who can stop the Dragon?

Dragon Attack is a simple fantasy boardgame. The player becomes an adventurer, and traverses Silverado, forming a party to stand against the Dragon. However, killing the Dragon is not the only objective. To revive the ruined Silverado will require a vast amount of money. In the end, when the Dragon is slain, the player with the most treasures becomes the true victor, and achieves glory for a long time.

(The above is my translation of the introduction to the game)

The game is a hex-and-counter style of game, where you move around the map, and turning over hidden counters to find enemies, allies, and treasure. However, anytime you roll a '1', the Dragon moves along a pre-determined path and destorys a village/temple. If noone can defeat the Dragon before it destroys the Royal Palace, everyone loses, making it a game where the players both compete against each other for treasure and against the game itself because of the Dragon-imposed time limit.

title: Monster Maker: Demon Slayer
description:
Based off the Monster Maker series of card games. In this game you move along an overland map, uncovering events/monsters in each area, and go on monster hunts to defeat monsters.

The game is still card-heavy in gameplay. You're attempting to strengthen yourself so that you can defeat the demon. Each card can be read normally and turned upside down (not flipped over). You read it one way when you are drawing it as a monster card, and the other way around when its a treasure/companion/event.

title: Monster Maker: Dungeon Wars 2
description:
Based off the Monster Maker card game, this is a all-out dungeon crawl. It has two completely different games. The first is a solitaire dungeon crawl. There are 3 decks of cards. The first basically details the rooms, with each card having lots of information on it to randomize what is in the rooms, how much treasure is found, what kind of monsters you meet, what kind of traps you set off, and so on. There are also a deck of monster cards and treasure cards.

It looks as if the game was intended as a solitaire game, as the multiplayer game is more of a dungeon maze race, without all the combat, traps, or such. To illustrate, the multiplayer game is called the 'basic game' and only takes up 3 pages of the rulebook. The RPG-type solo play' game takes up 11 pages of the rulebook.

title: Monster Maker: Dungeon Wars
description:
Fantasy board game based off the Monster Maker card games. This one is still card-heavy, as it uses cards for spells and some events. The board it made of of 4 boards that each show a corridor section with rooms and get put together to make a large map that varies each game.

The game includes 4 metal figures for the player characters.

title: Summonaria
description:
Summonaria is a game of tactical combat and resource management that pits players and their magical armies against each other as they try to seize control of five island strongholds.

On the island are five magic towers that have drawn the interest of the most powerful Master Summoners in the world.  They each want to fight for control of the towers and the power they contain. The object of the game is to move your armies in and seize control of a majority of the towers on the island.  Each player takes on the role of one of the five Master Summoners, who each have their own strengths and weaknesses and can summon different combat units to the island.  They do this by managing four magical resources that they have available to them.  As units are summoned onto the island, they are moved about where they have a number of options available to them:  visiting temples where they can be blessed, traveling through four different domains, attacking other players' units, and occupying the different towers to attempt to maintain control over them.

The first player to garrison a unit in the correct number of towers and hold them for a turn against his sieging enemies wins!

Summonaria has been re-released with a new fully illustrated battle board and variant rules to further customize gameplay and this new version is available now.

title: Phaestos Disk
description:
Phaestos Disk is a real game from ancient Crete. The time frame is unknown, but it was before Minoan civilization according to archaeologists.

The board is made up of the Phaestos Disk ancient boards - which are two different boards, one on each side of the disk. There are 2-6 players. Each player has seven pawns. Each pawn has the signs of Minos era. There are also three dice with the ancient Hellenic shape.

All pawns must enter the first board, complete it and then go to the second board, do the same and then return back to the beginning. The first player who manages to exit all his pawns from the two boards is the winner. Each square has its own sign, each sign has a command to do (f.e. go 10 spaces, back 5 spaces etc), there are some positions in which the pawns have some penalties and some other which give more rolls or movements.

Phaestos Disk has the following items:
1. Two Color Boards (Disk of Phaestos, item from the Museum).
2. Seven pawns different color and shape for each of the four player.
3. Three dices with different shapes.
Of course there is a 32-page leaflet with some informations for this game with many photos from the ancient Crete Greece, the island of Deus.

title: Labyrinth of Minotaur
mechanisms: Area MovementDice RollingMemoryRoll / Spin and Move
description:
Labyrinth of Minotaur [Minotauros] is an ancient board game.

This is a real ancient game from ancient Crete with boards found dating to  about 1.000 B.C.

There are many boards, with Labyrinths on them.

There are 2-4 players. Each player has seven pawns. Pawns must have the signs of Minos era.

Also there are three dice with ancient Greek shapes on them.

The player with the highest die roll plays first. All pawns must enter the board make a run and then return to the beginning. The players chose the board.
Boards can be on a big board on both sides. Player who manages to exit all his pawns is the winner. Each square has its own sign; each sign has a command to do (i.e. go 10 spaces, back 5 spaces etc).
So the board game has the following items:
1. Some Colored Boards with Labyrinths.
2. Seven pawns different in color and shape for each of the four players.
3. Three dice with different shapes each one.
4. Many other items.
Of course there is a 32-page leaflet with some information for this game with many photos from ancient Crete and from Greece. (The island of Deus)

title: Battle of the Ring
description:
Game included with The Wargamer Magazine Issue #1 and later republished as a stand-alone.

Grand Strategic, low complexity (2 page rules), game of the War of the Ring from the Tolkein book.  Apparently unlicensed publication was a hoot to play with the orc hordes rolling out in waves.  Needs more beer than pretzels to enjoy, but charming in a 1970's DTP kind of way.

title: Twilight Imperium: Distant Suns
types: Civilization Expansion for Base-game Negotiation Political Science Fiction Space Exploration
mechanisms: Dice RollingHex-and-CounterModular BoardTile PlacementVariable Phase OrderVariable Player Powers
description:
Twilight Imperium: Distant Suns is the second expansion for the game Twilight Imperium: 1st edition. It adds uncertainty and strategy to it with new optional rules (especially for Neutral Planets).  It also includes additional Ground Force and Dreadnought counters for each race, and other game aids.

Part of the Twilight Imperium Series.

Expands:

     Twilight Imperium




Sister Expansions:

     Twilight Imperium: Borderlands
     Twilight Imperium: Twilight Armada
     Twilight Imperium: The Outer Rim

title: Havic: The Bothering
description:
A direct parody/rip-off of Magic: The Gathering. Fairly rare to find a package that isn't opened.

From the Rules Card:

Welcome to Havic! You are a student battling others in a strange, mysterious world. You and your opponent each have 21 points of sanity. Once a player's sanity has been reduced to zero, he loses.

To reduce your opponent's sanity, you will need to recruit peons, create effects, and use articles in any way possible to destroy your opponent before he destroys you. Your deck is your weapon against your worthy foe. It must contain exactly sixty cards.

After thoroughly shuffling your deck, each player draws eight cards from the top of the deck. A die is rolled. The player who rolls the highest number goes first.

When it is your turn, a player first drops a property card. When whacked, or turned sideways, this card, if this card is a brewery yields one unit of alcohol: a convenience store yields one unit of cigarettes. You can now use this unit to recruit peons, create effects, and articles as you see fit.

Each Peon, article, and effect has a creation cost. It is denoted on the top right hand corner of the card. For each beer bottle, or cigarette shown on a card, one and of the same type must be whacked.

In the case of peons, the first number in the bottom right hand corner denotes the amount of damage this peon can do to your opponent, or other peons. The second number denotes the amount of damage that it will take to send this peon to the hospital.

When a peon first comes into play, he is hung over and can't attack, but he can block if he is not whacked. Your peons can attack only on your turn, and only if it is not hung over or whacked. To attack, you must first announce the attack phase, and then whack the peons that are attacking. The opponent then decides which of your peons his peons will block, or he can opt to take the damage himself, reducing his sanity (though only a peon with stealth can block another peon with stealth).

Unlike a peon, once an effect is cast, it goes directly to the hospital. An article also does not work during the turn it comes into play. and like a peon, it must be whacked to have it's effect. Once you are done attacking, it is your opponent's turn. At the beginning of your next turn, all whacked cards, unless otherwise specified, become unwhacked. Good luck!


    DO NOT HAVE EACH PLAYER: 


construct their own library of a predetermined number of game components by examining and selecting [the] game components from [a] reservoir of game components or you may infringe on U.S. Patent No. 5,662,332 to Garfield.

title: Castle Adventures
description:
The Lord of Darkness has plundered the Kingdom. Now the heroes must enter his castle and recover the treasures, fighting dragons along the way.

Each player (or duo) has a set of four heroes - king, princess, wizard and warrior. Each hero can retrieve gold and one type of treasure: works of art, jewels, magic potions and weapons, respectively. Treasure is kept in rooms, which the player places on his/her own track. Dragons appear in corridors, which are placed on an opponent's track, and must be fought with an attack card and the roll of a die.

Points are granted for retrieving treasures, killing dragons, capturing the Lord of Darkness and exiting the castle. The game ends when a player places an exit tile or when the deck of cards/tiles is finished.

This game is from Brazil and may not be available elsewhere.

title: Fury on Champlain
description: This game is set in the year 1814. A wargame with lots of shipping and troop movement. Based on a historic battle. (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_of_1812#Niagara_and_Plattsburgh_Campaigns.2C_1814 )

title: S-P-O-N-G-E: Fight the Evil
types: Adventure Card Game Horror Humor Print & Play
description:
S-P-O-N-G-E: Fight the Evil is a customizable card game based on the adventures of S-P-O-N-G-E (see http://s-p-o-n-g-e.com), an online role-playing organization devoted to H. P. Lovecraft's Cthulhu mythos (it took me quite a while to find out that SPONGE stands for Stopping Powerful Organisms from N Gulfing Everything).  It is nominally a two-player game but can handle more players quite readily.

In the game, each player is a SPONGE Historian, helping out on an investigation.  The Historian position at SPONGE is often a short-lived one, and the Inactive Files are full of past Historians that didnt make it.  The object of the game is to last longer than any of your fellow Historians.

Each player also represents the forces of Evil that threaten to thwart SPONGE at every turn.  This means that you will be playing cards on your opponents as often as you play them on yourself.

Every Historian has his or her own deck of cards, comprised of seven categories: Locations (where your investigation takes you), Characters (people you encounter), Items (stuff you find), Weapons (stuff you find that will kill Beasts), Beasts (an assortment of creatures bent on killing you), Tomes (knowledge man was not meant to know) and Events (things that just happen to happen).

Each turn you normally get two Action Points.  It costs an Action Point to draw a card, play a card or perform certain Special Abilities --discarding is free, however.  Some card abilities cost more than one Action Point (some cost more than two!).  Unused Action Points are passed on to the next player.

Icons appear on the cards and act to guide play --each card brings icons in play, and each card requires certain icons to be in play before it can be played.

There are numerous ways to lose the game.  Basically, any action that would put you into one of the Inactive Files (Known Dead, Presumed Dead, Asylum, Missing, Resigned, Inaccessible or Other) also puts you out of the game.  The only exception is the Reanimated file.  If you die and get reanimated, you can keep playing the game, but you will suffer certain restrictions, making winning more difficult.

title: Twilight Imperium: The Outer Rim
types: Civilization Expansion for Base-game Negotiation Political Science Fiction Space Exploration
mechanisms: Dice RollingHex-and-CounterModular BoardTile PlacementTradingVariable Phase Order
description:
Twilight Imperium: The Outer Rim is the fourth and last expansion for the game Twilight Imperium: 1st edition.  It adds two new races, 13 new hex tiles (to form a fifth galactic ring) and extra rules (and counters) for Leaders and Shock Troops.

Part of the Twilight Imperium Series.

Expands:

     Twilight Imperium




Sister Expansions:

     Twilight Imperium: Borderlands
     Twilight Imperium: Distant Suns
     Twilight Imperium: Twilight Armada

title: Twilight Imperium: Borderlands
types: Civilization Expansion for Base-game Negotiation Political Science Fiction Space Exploration
mechanisms: Dice RollingHex-and-CounterModular BoardTile PlacementVariable Phase OrderVariable Player Powers
description:
Twilight Imperium: Borderlands is the first expansion for the game Twilight Imperium: 1st edition.  It adds two new races, 16 Political cards, 16 Action cards, 238 new counters and extra rules for Assassins, Capital Ships and more.

Part of the Twilight Imperium Series.

Expands:

     Twilight Imperium




Sister Expansions:

     Twilight Imperium: Distant Suns
     Twilight Imperium: Twilight Armada
     Twilight Imperium: The Outer Rim

title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone: Through the Trapdoor
Diet: The Cheating Man's Game
description: A roll-and-move game that parodies dieting.  Players move around the six different diet circles (Low Cal Diet, High Protein Binge, Crash Diet, Drinking Man's Diet, Surgical Diet, and Sportsman's Diet) trying to lose all of their calories.  Players can play honestly, or cheat on their diet.  If they cheat and are caught, however, they gain even more calories than they had before.  Mealtime cards add random events to shake things up.  The first player to lose all of their calories wins.

title: Election Day
description: Players move around the map campaigning in the various states.  Each time they pass through a state, they increase their influence.  Once the campaigning round is over, dice are rolled for each state, the roll is modified by the player's influence, and the winner for that state is determined.  Whoever has the most electoral votes is the winner.  A deck of cards adds random events to keep things interesting.

title: Dragon Ball Z: Il Torneo
description:
Cardboard heroes fight each other in a Martial Art tournament set in the world of Dragonball. The arena is built on a flat surface and the fighters move by a series of rulers of different size.
The game can be used both on its own and as an advanced combat system both for Dragon Ball: Alla ricerca delle Sette Sfere and for the Dragonball + Dragonball Z - Il gioco di ruolo RPG.

Integrates with:

    Dragon Ball: Alla ricerca delle Sette Sfere

title: VCR College Bowl Game
mechanisms: Action Point Allowance SystemCard DraftingDice RollingRoll / Spin and Move
description:
Players roll dice to determine yardage and results are determined by Play Action Cards or Video Cassette

From the box:
See plays of your favorite teams. Enjoy hours of fast-paced college football action, the CFA College Bowl game includes hundreds of exciting plays of your favorite college teams nationwide on a VHS video cassette. Enjoy the thrill and rivalry inherent in college football. You interact utilizing 120 actual plays each game making crucial decisions such as whether to punt the ball or go for a field goal, and declining or accepting penalties. This is the most realistic football game ever. Pick your opponent and let's play VCR College Bowl Game.

title: Mystical Circle
mechanisms: Dice RollingRoll / Spin and MoveSet Collection
description: Players roll a die and move around a board to collect cards which when collected become a life reading

title: EPYX Play Action VCR Football
mechanisms: Action Point Allowance SystemDice RollingRoll / Spin and MoveSimultaneous Action Selection
description: Players roll a die and consult charts to determine results. Players choose offense and defense cards which give results or refer to VCR tape.

title: The Maze of Ishtar
types: Abstract Strategy Adventure Dice Exploration Fantasy Maze
mechanisms: Dice RollingHand ManagementLine DrawingModular BoardPattern BuildingPattern Recognition
description:
This obscure game is similar to the German Das verrueckte Labyrinth, but the maze is much more complicated. Up to 4 adventurers try to collect 4 items from the 4 corners of the maze and bring them to the center. Each of the complex tiles can be turned through magic during the game, an ingenious idea is that 2 tiles can be locked and prevented of being turned by having a pawn in-between them.
Each player commands himself and a smaller explorer pawn, which explores the tiles and collects spell cards.
Fantasy-themed, but essentially an abstract race/maze-game (which doesn't totally work, but is sort of interesting).

title: Metanon: The Biocode Adventure
mechanisms: Pattern BuildingPoint to Point MovementRoll / Spin and MoveSet Collection
description:
Metanon: The Biocode Adventure:  A Fun Way to Teach Kids about DNA!

Imagine that you're a space traveler whose ship has been forced to land on the planet Metanon. Your computer is damaged, and your ship is leaking fuel and oxygen. To complete your mission and return home, you will need to find three missing items and put them in your spaceship. Sound simple? Not so fast. You can get them only by entering three walled cities. To do that, you must collect Biocodes, and put them together in the right sequence and pattern combinations that unlock the cities' gates.

Biocodes and Brain Development:
(serious stuff for parents and teachers)

DNA keeps making headlines. Kids may not be ready to learn the difficult terminology, but Metanon:The Biocode Adventure prepares them to grasp the basic concepts of DNA. All players use the game's biocode pieces in different combinations. Why is this shape and color matching important? Just by playing the game, kids begin to understand how DNA works. This form of learning is one of the most effective ways of preparing young brains. The critical skills learned in Metanon:The Biocode Adventure help kids excel in school and ultimately in life.

At kSERO Corporation, Inc. we create games that help young children develop their cognitive and analytic skills. Our games are designed and tested by noted scientists and educators, using the latest discoveries in FUN and brain research.

title: Vici
description: Each player is designated a suit known only to him. The Relationship Cards spell out certain relationships among the suits. Your goal is to determine which other player is holding a suit and is your friend and which is your enemy, all the while collecting the cards that match only your suit. This is accomplished through the trading and drawing of cards. The first to collect all of his cards may then attempt to identify his friend (as designated by his relationship card). His friend then attempts to identify his own enemy.

title: Doorways to Horror
description:
From the back of the box:

Doorways to Horror (TM) will introduce you to a new era of VCR fun and excitement.  What weapons will you use to command the villainous vampire?  How much power will you risk to win over the werewolf and the ever-wicked witch?  How will you capture the rebellious zombie?  And what spell will control the legendary monster in his lair?

The object of the game is to win Gold by casting magic spells on some of the creepiest creatures that ever crept out of a crypt.  A roll of the dice lets you quickly COLORSCAN (TM) ahead on the videotape to your first Doorway to Horror.  There you may meet vampires, werewolves, witches, zombies and other menacing monsters -- all who come alive in classic film clips.

title: Pazaz
description:
Each round, players are dealt five cards that have a number on them.  They then take turns rolling the two dice.  If they roll a number that is on one of their cards, they turn that card over and collect the bets that are on it.  If they do not have the number rolled, the next person in clockwise order that does have that number gets to turn their card over and continue the turn.  When a 7 is rolled, the player antes another chip into the pot and hands the dice over to the next player.  The person with the most chips after three rounds of play is the winner.

Note: I do not know if all of them were made this way, but the board in my copy is covered with a fuzzy felt-like material.  It helps keep the cards in place when people are rolling the dice on the board.

title: Gambit
description:
Each player has 15 pieces, one king and 14 knights. Players alternate moving their pieces one orthogonal square. After a move, if an orthogonal line of one players pieces is next to an orthogonal line of another, the person with the longer line captures the other line. The King counts as two pieces for the purpose of capturing.

The object of the game is to capture the opponent's king, or the 14 knights.

title: War of Wizards
description:
Players are wizards battling in an arena. They begin at opposite sides of the arena, which is 20 spaces long. They alternate throwing spells at each other chosen from a vast array, 71 in all. Spells might be visible or invisible, and are represented by cardboard chits, face up or face down. Spells advance toward the opponent each turn, some fighting spells they encounter on the way, others not.

The rule book is 39 pages long, 20 of which are a list of spells and effects. There is a good deal of record keeping - since players must track information on all their spells and wizard.

title: Mind War
mechanisms: Action Point Allowance SystemDice RollingSecret Unit DeploymentSimultaneous Action Selection
description:
One of the Warriors of the Green Planet Trilogy of Games. The games are set on a future Earth that has suffered an axial flip of 72 degrees, resulting in various disasters and changes that result in this hypothetical post-apocalyptic game world.

In Mind War each player controls one, or perhaps a few mind warriors. Each player simultaneously plots where they are moving, where they are attacking, where they are defending, and how many mental points are to be allocated to each of these activities. Players then simultaneously move, and resolve their attacks. Iterate till one side is standing.

A set of expansion rules allowed Mind War to be played together with the companion games Warriors of the Green Planet and War of the Sky Galleons.

title: Afrikan tähti korttipeli
description:
Afrikan thti korttipeli is a card game using the theme and artwork of the popular Finnish board game Afrikan tähti (Star of Africa).

It is a simple trick-taking game for 2-5 players, using the numbering and suits of a standard deck plus some special cards.  There is also a Solitaire playing option.

title: Caper
description: Each player assumes the role of a jewel thief attempting to steal jewels from various secure locations and returning them to his respective hideout.  The game features some exceptional components, including a multi-level board and detailed miniature metal thief tools, some of which have moving parts.

title: Escalation
description:
From the box:  Escalation is a game of war.  Begin the game by positioning your forces consisting of battle pieces and mobile missile launchers within your Home Country.  Then maneuver them to areas throughout the world as permitted by the dice roll in order to attack an opponent.

During the game you can use airbases and ports to achieve a rapid and strategic deployment of forces.  Build and strengthen your forces by capturing countries, liberating POW camps, using the Draft and reaping the military benefits from Reinforcement cards and Mobile Missile Launcher cards.

Although the game appears to be self-published, the packaging and components are first rate, featuring a mounted board, coated cards, and plastic pieces.

title: Spiro T. Agnew American History Challenge
description:
Long before trivia games were in vogue, Vice President Spiro Agnew lent his name to a trivia game based on United States history.  The game features question cards in five categories: Age of Exploration, Colonies  Independence, Expansion Westward, Industrialization, and 20th Century America, as well as bonus cards such as Sing-Along Cards and Recitation Cards.

The question cards contain five questions in increasing difficulty.  Answers are not verified unless someone challenges the responder, in which case the correct answer is looked up in the back of the rule book.

title: Roll Bowl
description: Roll Bowl is an American football simulation game consisting of a board game football field, football players playing pieces, sideline marker playing pieces and 3 dice.

title: The Embattled Trek
types: Miniatures Movies / TV / Radio theme Science Fiction Wargame
description: A very early game of Star Trek Inspired starship combat.  Rules are intended for miniatures and tape measures, though conversions are included for BYOHM (bring your own hexgrid map).

title: Wood Wars: Fantasy Miniatures Game
description:
Wood Wars:  Fantasy Miniatures Game is an abstract miniature wargame. Armies are represented with small wooden pawns and wooden tokens. Armies are built on a point scale to ensure even battle conditions. It is a diceless game. Shooting and some spells are handled with marbles rolled through a cardboard tube, and hand to hand combat is based on a pawn's combat ratio.

The Ork Belly Games edition is from 2005 and includes races(dwarves, elves, goblins, and undead) not in the original version.

As of 2-14-07 the game can be found at: http://www.jimcorn.com

title: Cleopatra's Gambit
description: Cleopatra's Gambit is a game of strategy played across three separate boards. Players take turns placing a piece upon each board simultaneously, trying to form one of three special patterns. Each board is made up of 36 hexagonal spaces in a different configuration. Where you place your piece on one board dictates where you can legally place on the other two boards. The first player to form one of the three winning patterns on any of the boards wins.

title: Beware of the Wolf!
description:
CONTENTS:
Playing board. Showing a circular journey with 2 paths, inner and outer.
Spinning wolf and 12 trees on stands
Dice (with a wolf instead the no. 6)
2 x 4 playing pieces.

An exciting trip through the forest, as you try to avoid the prowling wolf and return to your house as quickly as you can.
Throw the dice and decide whether to take the long, safe route behind the trees or the shorter, daring path right in front of the wolf.
Catch up with an opponent and send him back to his house, to start all over again. But beware of the wolf! For if he spins round to face you, back you go.

title: Murder Mystery Party: Revenge of Konan Castle
description:
The Murder Mystery Party line of murder party games is the most extensive. They were originally published by University Games in California, but are now produced in England, though they still carry a note that the rights belong to University Games (who, when you call them, have no knowledge of the recent episodes).

These games play just like other main-stream murder party games like How to Host a Murder, Evening of Murder, Mysteries by Vincent, or Milton Bradley's Life of the Party. This episode:

Konan Castle was owned for centuries by the McDonald clan.  When the McDonalds killed two Campbells, a feud ensued and eventually the Campbells took the castle in the late 19th century.  The remaining McDonalds fled to the US and the castle went into disrepair.  For two generations (the year is 1955), the McDonalds waited to return to retreive their treasure (hidden within the castle).  So, a party of eight went to Scotland to search.  But the castle owner (Ian Campbell) was murdered.  Whodunnit?

title: GOOT! (Get Out Of That!)
description:
GOOT!(Get Out Of That!) is a game of tall tales, ripping yarns and outrageous excuses for 3 to 6 players or teams.  Over the course of the game you will find yourself in a series of sticky situations and as your fellow players try to thwart your efforts, you must endeavor to talk yourself out of them.
Contains 1 VHS video tape, 250 word cards, 150 last line cards, 18 'I got out of that' cards, 1 2-minute timer, 2 d6 and one write on/wipe off score card with pen.

title: Super Passa ou Repassa
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Party Game Trivia
description: Super Passa ou Repassa is a game based on a tv show. It's a quiz game for teens that permits you to do a trick if you don't know how to answer the questions. The timer in this game is a kind of slider.   A game for those Ages 8 and up.

title: Rex
description:
Rex was an independently published game made by Mag-Nif, 8820 East Ave. Mentor, Ohio, in 1982 (I wonder what's there now?). In many ways, the Gigamic games owe something to this one. In Rex, players stack colored balls onto nine pegs, one each per turn. The goals are to get three balls a) vertically on any one of the pegs b) horizontally on any level in any one row c) diagonally within any one row d) at the corners. It's not as confusing as it sounds once you read the instructions printed on the back of the box. Neat game. Probably didn't sell well. Ahead of its time I presume.

Similar to:

    Score Four

title: The Mall Game
mechanisms: Roll / Spin and MoveSet CollectionStock Holding
description: The Mall Game, Richmar Incorporated, 1977. I assume that this one was sold at shopping malls in the seventies. Somewhat Monopoly-like. You buy a lot and then lease stores. Although it looks pretty dull, this is a *fantastic* game as far as looking back at so many stores that no longer exist and the great seventies USA mega-mall boom in general. And who couldn't like a game where young players shop at the now-defunct Fredericks of Hollywood for a fancy nightie?

title: Quest for the Dungeonmaster
types: Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme
description: TSR #1016, 1984, Ages 6 and up Based on the cartoon show. Be the first to rescue the DM from Warduke. Choose the correct cards to play in order to move ahead. Or will you be sent back? Whoever reaches the end first wins.

title: Attica
types: Ancient Dice Educational Memory Mythology Number
description:
Attica is an ancient board game of Attica's Pessoi.
This is a real ancient game from the ancient Athens with boards and letters.
There are 2-6 players. Each player has ancient letters from Athens Attica Hellas.
Also there are tree dices with the ancient Greek shapes of Athens.
The player with the highest roll play first.

Attica contains the following items:
1. Some Color Boards.
2. Ancient Athens Attica letters with different color for each player.
3. Tree dice with different shapes.
4. Many other items.
And a 32-page leaflet with some information for this game with many photos from the ancient Athens Attica Greece, the land of the Goddess Athena.

title: Pegity
description: An oldie. Pegity is a game where players insert wooden pegs into a punch board. The object is to get five pegs of your color in a row. There are also little pieces of paper inside with designs on them, such as a house, doll boat, etc... which younger children could make with the game's contents instead of actually playing the game. Not a particularly rare or great game, but probably an early 20th century borrower from the game of Go-Moku, much earlier than say Othello for example.

title: Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot RED Booster
types: Card Game Expansion for Base-game Humor Negotiation
description:
This is the RED Booster expansion to the non-collectible, hysterical Killer Bunnies game.  This expansion includes 55 new cards and a red 12 sided die.

The addition of this expansion will add more Bunnies to the deck (Red Bunnies, to be exact, each with their own special power) and 4 more Carrots, making a total of sixteen to try to collect.  The expansion also adds a new market to the game - Rooney's Weapons Emporium, where you can buy back used weapons and get Defense Cards, adding a whole new level of strategy to the game!  Other new and hilarious spoof cards and loads of new evil weapons make this a worthwhile addition to the starter deck.

From the back of the box:
Can you defeat the Quite Irascible Diffractable Cheese Balls? Can you even say Quite Irascible Diffractable Cheese Balls? Send bunnies three rounds ahead in time with Bunny To The Future! The laughs continue as this wild and wacky Red Booster Deck delivers more intense strategy and even more Carrot grabbin' fun!

Expands:

    Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot

title: Chaos Chess
description: This is a set of 80 cards that change all the rules of chess. The cards range from permanent changes to instants to durational cards. It adds an element of luck to a game that never had any. However, most the cards are not over-powerful and your knowledge of chess will help you quite a bit. The game is still Chess at its core. Each card has its own art and flavor text, both of which are very well done. You will probably want some extra tokens beyond the initial 8 that are supplied. You will use tokens a lot in this game.

title: The Adventures of Harley
description:
Centered around the family dog, Harley, who likes to hide our Favorite Things, The Adventures of Harley is a co-operative children's game. The goal is to move Harley around the board and turn over cards from four stacks, revealing Dangerous Animals (Bear, Raccoon, Skunk, Porcupine), nasty Briar Patches, Dog Powers (Bark and Sniff), and Favorite Things (such as gloves, sneakers, socks, etc.). Dangerous Animals and Briar Patches block Harley's travels to the various locations as he tries to find the Favorite Things. As a co-operative game, everyone loses together or wins together!

Ages 5-9.

title: Signs Up
types: Children's Game Dice Educational Number Puzzle Word Game
mechanisms: Dice RollingPoint to Point MovementRoll / Spin and Move
description:
Equipment:
-Playing board, 4 playing pieces, 14 Sign cards, 32 Movements cards, Money

OBJECT
To be the player with the most money after all the signs are placed in the proper order.

Simple and attractive children game. Combine letters and numbers skills.
The different signs of the 7 shops (TO-YS, BA-NK, PE-TS, FI-RE, PO-ST, MI-LK, BO-OK) have been misplaced. Players will collect them and placed them on the right places. Movement is not by dice, but by CARDS (like in fast 111s). Each card reads a nice riddle/rhyme, like for example:

PUTTING UP SIGNS IS SOMETIMES A CHORE,
ADD 2 AND 2 AND  MOVE AHEAD  ----  
(this one will obviously move 4)

Other cards will send you directly to a particular shop, or entitle to steal a sign from another player, etc, etc Additionally, players can steal signs when meeting on the board, as long as they don't have more than 2 at anytime in the hand.

Every sign a player place on the right place is rewarded with 10 US !! The player with most money at the end is the winner.

So, LETTERS, NUMBERS, COLORFUL BOARD AND MONEY. A good mix for children!!!

title: Bohnaparte
types: Card Game Expansion for Base-game Farming Napoleonic Negotiation Territory Building
description:
Bohnaparte conquers the Bohnreich! The fourth Bohnanza expansion from Lookout Games (in a limited sales edition of 2500 pieces) puts you in the Bohnreich!  Plantations, villages, cities, fortresses -- and 3 to 5 generals, who want to bring these under their control.

The Bohnanza base game is needed. Using new cards in Bohnaparte, the Bohnreich is laid out; each player receives counters of his own color; and play then loosely follows that of normal Bohnanza, with a small difference: earned bean coins are not saved but are used to finance your conquests throughout the Bohnreich. At the end it matters only who has the largest part of the Bohnreich under control. Battling is accomplished using the numbers on the bean cards, which gives new significance to the formerly weaker bean types. Designer Hanno Girke describes the expansion set as Bohnanza meets Risk.

Includes 33 cards, 60 game markers, and rules. Graphics by Marcel-Andre Casasola Merkle.

The AMIGO-Edition of Bohnaparte includes 50 Cards, 72 game markers and rules.

title: WWII Skirmish
types: Abstract Strategy Fighting Negotiation Wargame World War II
mechanisms: Area MovementCo-operative PlayDice RollingHex-and-CounterPoint to Point MovementSimulation
description:
