Memory-type game which is different in that the orders are only read to the other players, but not shown.  Orders consists of 5 to 9 different cards, each with type and quantity.

title: Monopoly: Elvis Presley 25th Anniversary
description: Now Elvis fans can enjoy taking care of business a whole new way! A tender tribute to the King, this Monopoly is like no other. On this gameboard, youll travel from a humble beginning in Tupelo to the highlife in Graceland, passing Dont Be Cruel, GI Christmas, Blue Hawaii and other achievements on your amazing journey! Six collectible pewter tokens are a convertible, teddy bear, guitar, leather jacket, vintage record player and signature sunglasses.

title: Monopoly: Dale Earnhardt
description: Monopoly honors its first individual with a tribute to The Intimidator. In this edition, Earnhardt#039;s storied racecars are up for sale. As you roar around the game board, collect #30 Malibu #039;76, #3 Monte Carlo #039;95, #3 Japan Race #039;98 and more. Includes 8 custom Earnhardt-themed pewter tokens, custom dice, and autographed game board.

title: Monopoly: Ford 100th Anniversary
description: Celebrating Ford#039;s centennial, this is a Monopoly game for car lovers. The game board starts at the Model A and goes all the way around to the 2003 GT, with beauts like the 1955 Thunderbird and the 1934 Woody Wagon in between. Regular Monopoly money is replaced with custom Racing Dollars and custom cards replace Chance amp; Community Chest. Six collectible pewter tokens feature popular Ford models: 1914 Model T, 1932 Deuce Coupe, 1948 F-1 Pick-up, 1955 Thunderbird, 1964  Mustang and the 2003 GT.

title: Monopoly: Dog Artist
description: Using a technique known as strange ratio photography, Artlist International has captured the expressiveness and curiosity of mans best friend. Now Mr. Moneybags celebrates the popular line of canine photos with this special edition of Monopoly. Wheel and deal for the popular pooches including the lovable Labrador, the pugnacious Pug, the dutiful Golden and the faithful German Shepherd. Game includes game board, property trading cards, custom dog money and bankers tray, 32 food  water bowl cards, 32 dog houses  12 kennels (in place of houses and hotels), two dice, six custom pewter tokens and rules.

title: Monopoly: Harley-Davidson Motorcycles
description: In this edition of Monopoly you get to cruise the game board on a vintage 1903 Harley, or a Softail Deuce - there are 8 pewter game tokens customized just for Harley fans! On your ride, acquire all the Harley-related properties that you can. Once you've got 'em, buy garages to house them, or even whole dealerships where you'll show them off. When opponents stop in; charge them big bucks to look around; Includes custom Harley money, Chance and Community Chest cards, dice and a game board loaded with photos.

title: Badge of Honor
description: There's a cat stranded in a tree, a traffic jam at the intersection, a small fire in a neighbor's house!  There are so many things to do and learn in this board game designed especially for young players! Travel around the neighborhood in your car, helping out wherever you can. As you do, you collect the parts you need to complete your own Badge of Honor and win the game. Great job! Take the badges apart and you're ready to play again.

title: Who Said That?
description: Who Said That? is a game for everyone with 400 quotes taken from famous people, commercials, movies, cartoon characters and more! On your team's turn, you get two quotes, one at a time. When you guess Who Said It? correctly -- and in time! -- you move ahead two spaces on the game board.  Stuck? That's okay! Ask your opponents to read the hint that comes with the quote and if you're able to give the right answer now, you still get to move ahead on the board one space. Some quotes will be ones that come in a snap! Others are right at the tip of your tongue and just need that hint to help you through. Some will be tougher, but a good guess might be all you need to get your mover towards the finish. The first team (or player) to do that, wins!

title: Real Dumb Laws
description: Can you guess which dumb law is the real dumb law?  Based on the book 101 Real Dumb Laws, this board game will bring you laughs and amazement as you uncover real laws from all across the country! At the start of each round, players are read the beginning of a law and given four choices -- only one of which is correct.  Think you know the answer? If you're right, you get to move ahead on the game board. Get it wrong and any player can take a risk and try to answer correctly.  You'll be surprised, amazed and sometimes just bewildered at the dumb laws that really exist.

title: The Lewis & Clark Adventure Game
types: Adventure Children's Game Educational Racing Trivia
description: Join Lewis and Clark on their expedition from St. Louis to the Pacific Northwest! As you follow their route, you'll explore the wilderness by keel boat, canoe, horseback, and on foot. Along the way, you'll meet Native American tribes, see spectacular places, and encounter unfamiliar plants and animals. Your survival depends on knowledge, skill, and luck! Supplied with a provision of beads, you'll give gifts or trade for goods -- just like Lewis and Clark did! You'll also get a chance to spin a special compass, answer questions, and win four types of charms. If you're the first to complete the journey with all four charms, you win!

title: Reaganomics
description: Control money, missiles, go to war, win the Jelly Bean fund, avoid ABSCAM and the unemployment line, go to a CIA fund raiser.  Roll-and-advance game, first player to balance the budget wins. Parody game since during the Reagan administration the budget was never balanced and the debt increased each year.

title: Olympigs
types: Action / Dexterity Animals Card Game Children's Game Sports
description:
Contents:
A pack of cards
4 playing pieces (pigs)
3 sports action implements: High jump, long jump, and Pigput.

Following the instructions of the cards, players compete to be the first to successfully complete the 3 challenges.

title: Monopoly Junior: Toy Story
types: Children's Game Economic Movies / TV / Radio theme Negotiation
description: Simplified game play featuring lots of fun toys makes this game a great introduction to the family favorite. Travel around the game board as Woody, Buzz, Mr. Potato Head or Jessie. Youll be buying toys like Sarge, Bo Peep, Hamm and more, to find them a good home. When the first player runs out of money, everyone else counts their cash. The player with the most money wins! Comes with a game board, 24 Chance cards, 48 plastic houses, Monopoly Junior money, a die, four cardboard movers and plastic mover stands.

title: Ghost in a Box
description:
From the back of the box:
There is a Ghost in this box!

Release it into the mortal world and let the adventure begin. Who is the ghost? Where is it from? What does it want to tell you?

Delve into the secrets of the unknown. Every box contains a different Ghost ready to communicate with you. Every roll of the dice brings you one step closer to meeting the ghost.

Ghost-in-A-Box is a unique addition to family game night or any get together with friends. Everyone wins by helping to uncover the Ghost's identity...and it's secrets. Along with learning facts about the Ghost you will also learn interesting things about each other.

Each box contains:
The ghost
Ghost Master's Manual
Audio CD
Ghost identity scroll
Ghost portal
Ghost diary and pencil
The Choosing die
Ghost charm

title: Cohorts: Game of Roman Checkers
description: Cohorts is one of the oldest board games. Played on a larger board than Checkers, it allows more variations but simpler than Chess. This was TSR's 3rd in its Famous Authors Series with the rules prepared by L. Sprague de Camp. 2 players. Ages 10  up.

title: Circulation: An Incredible Journey
mechanisms: Pick-up and DeliverPoint to Point MovementRoll / Spin and Move
description:
An oddity in every sense of the word.  Players move 'plasma trays' through the arteries and veins to supply the arms, legs and head with 'food' and 'oxygen' while disposing of 'waste', warding off 'germ attacks' and controlling 'emergency situations'. Both an interesting game, an oddity, a rarity and an education. 2 to 4 players. Ages 10  up. Teaching Concepts from 1978.

INCLUDES: Gameboard, 130 die-cut counters (30 Food, 30 Gaseous Waste, 30 Renal Waste, 30 Oxygen  10 WBC), 18 Emergency cards, 15 Circulate cards, 4 'Plasma' trays (small cups), 4 score boards, spinner  instructions.

title: Sixth Sense
description:
Three dimensions for a classic strategy game.
The game is a platform on which players can put piles of square stones. The sensors on the platform will help the computer to take track of the moves.
Two different games are included in this early electronic device. In the first (like 3d tic-tac-toe), players have to put 4 stones in a row; the computer will keep track of the moves and tell the players if some of them won. In the second (the labyrinth), players have to find the hidden pattern generated by the computer by creating a tri-dimensional path.

title: Tribú
mechanisms: Point to Point MovementRoll / Spin and MoveTrick-taking
description:
Translated from the Italian box:
 In ancient times the wise Mother Earth gave birth to the Tribe of Tribes, whose destiny was to dominate the world. This lit the fierce anger of the Big Shadow, that made the world fall into the prison of the eternal alternation between light and darkness, and destroyed the Tribe. But the shaman escaped the vindicative rage and painted on a sacred and inviolable rock, with few primitive signs, the secret to win the dark power of the Big Shadow.
Many and many ages are passed since then. Six glorious Predestined tribes, heirs of the ancient Tribe, decide to face the challenge with the Big Shadow. Their names: Tralon, Orgos, Ab-Diar, Naum, Zark, Groden.
Now, you are the chiefs of those tribes. You have to reach the sacred rock, find the Ancient Sequence, transmit it to your Shaman and defeat the Big Shadow, with great honor. But the path for the sacred rock is long and dangerous. Right outside the village you'll wet yourselves in the Circle of the River of Life, where you can get the gifts of the Language, but you'll have to fight the Salamanders and the Rages, moved by the Big Shadow, to be able to get to the successive Circle, the Land of Chaos. Here you'll be lit with the ancestral frenzy, you'll fight with spears and hatchets the chiefs of the other tribes. Only if you were brave you'll be able to go to the Circle of the Initiation Sea, where you'll learn how to communicate with other tribes. With this you'll finally have completed your Table of the Language and you'll be able to enter the Final Circle: the Knowledge. Here, if you won't get burned by the fire of knowledge, you will be able to read the Ancient Sequence, go back to your village, say the remembered formula and, if it correct, win the game.
But warning: the Big Shadow will try every path to stop you or even win the challenge by covering the whole Circle of Knowledge with its dark presence.

As you have read the game is divided in several parts, each of which has a different objective, that, when reached, will allow players to go to the next part. One of the player is the Big Shadow, and plays against all the others.
Pretty nice but very long game with few standard mechanics and well made components.

title: Wort Genie
description:
In Wort Genie, two players (or two teams) compete to find the secret words of the opponent first. There are about 100 cards, each with 6 words on it, one placed vertically, the others horizontally (crossword-like). The players each take one card secretly. On their turn, they can ask the opponent for a letter. As answer they get all occurrences of this letter in a coordinate system, just like the one of Battleship. Then the next player can ask a letter. If they think, they know some words, they can guess them before asking for a letter. If correct, they can guess another word, until they are wrong or decide to ask for a letter. To help the players, all words on one card are related to the same theme. The first player to find all words on the opponent's card gets as many points, as the difference to the number of correct words the opponent has found out is, e.g. if the looser has found four words, the winner gets two points. Play proceeds until one player has ten points.

The English version of the game is called Battle Words. It was published by William Maclean's Games.

title: See you later ...
description:
See you later ... is a racing game for gamblers: Each player gets a pawn, puts it on the starting field of a race track, the first one in goal wins. In the middle of the board is a circle of 12 fields, where five different colored crocodiles are placed (belonging to no-one). There is also a deck of cards showing a number in the color of a crocodile. In their turn, a player reveals a card from this deck and sees if they can pull the corresponding crocodile the number of fields indicated by the card in clockwise order. This is possible, if the landing field is empty. After success, the player can decide to reveal another card and do the same. They can also decide to stop and move their pawn one field for every crocodile card which was revealed. But if it is not possible to move the crocodile, the player has to stop and give all cards already revealed to the next player. This player must reveal at least one card (if successful, they can move their pawn for all cards!). If a player in last place moves their pawn, they can double the value; a player in first place must move back, if they are not successful.

Some special action cards can also be used; they allow a player to stop only after an even number of cards revealed or force them to move back, etc.

The game is in German, but all components except the rules are language independent.

title: Buddel-Wuddel
types: Children's Game Dice Fantasy Humor Transportation
mechanisms: Dice RollingPick-up and DeliverRoll / Spin and Move
description:
(from the game box)
Rig-a-dig, dig!
The cheeky earth gnomes have stolen the treasures of the moles. Mole Max and his friends drive through the deep dark galleries to get back the treasures. But the way is dangerous as the gnomes drag them out of the trams. With a bit of luck the moles can step into the next tram or be freed by Goblin Gorgan. A digging dice game with tactics.

title: Polyglot
description:
The Game of International Languages

...a game which will enable you, your family and friends to develop a greater intimacy with foreign languages.

title: Ranger Commandos
description:
Rangers are United States Commandos especially trained for damaging raids on enemy bases and installations. These raids have as their objective the destruction of important docks, munitions plants, power stations, shipping etc.

Usually their mission is accomplished during the night and at dawn the Commandos return to their own bases. The game follows very closely the usual method of these raids.

title: The Amazing Dunninger Mind Reading Game
description:
This game isn't exactly played to win, but instead players get a score in percentage points which determines their levels of telepathic powers. The percent ranges are as follows: 100% to 82%, Exceptional Telepathic Powers; 81% to 70%, Good Telepathic Powers; over 52%, Some Telepathic Powers. Points are earned by mentally reading images on game cards that other players send to you telepathically.

Players move game pawns around the board along a path that goes through the Sky Temple, Earth Temple, Sun Temple, and Moon Temple. After circling the board players arrive at the Thought Plateau, which surrounds a picture of Mr. Dunninger, the game's creator and reputed Man with the Miracle Mind (according to the instruction sheet). Hints are included on the instruction sheet about how to concentrate and utilize your telepathic powers.

The game board is brightly colored and features Egyptian hieroglyphics throughout. Four sets of Cycle cards displaying letters, numbers, shapes, and colors, and four game pawns, as well as score sheets, the game board, and instructions sheet (one, double sided) complete the game.

The rules are a double sided 8.5 x 11 sheet of paper.  On the bottom of page 2, it states the game was created by Joseph Dunninger, 1967 Hassenfeld Bros., Inc., Pawtucket, RI USA.

The bgg data based listed Sid Sackson as the designer but this is not correct.  Sid does reference it twice in his journals on 10/29/67 and 11/7/67.  He writes that he thinks The Amazing Dunninger Mind Reading Game resembled I Spy.

title: Bushi: Sword vs. Sword
description:
A Samurai knew only loyal service: death was the reward for failure. The way of the Samurai was a harsh one, but it built men as strong as the semi-legendary weapons they carried until both the man and his creed were forged into a living dream, a dream that has survived the fall of empires and the dusts of history . . . This game is extremely fast. It is felt that it reflects the flow of sword vs. sword combat. The players will soon learn that there is more to the game than attack first. Much can be gained by waiting and counterattacking.

The game portrays a sword duel between two Samurai swordsmen during Japan's Feudal era. The object is to be the first to make a successful attack.

Both players secretly select simultaneous moves (there are 48 different moves including various blocks, cuts, stances, thrusts, etc., with optional rules allowing for feints.) The game is played on two large charts with a series of boxes representing each of the 48 moves a swordsman may make. Each box on the chart shows a player's current move and lists the permissible follow-up moves that may be selected in the next phase. These boxes also display the hit probability for the various attacks. This probability varies based upon the type of attack and the defender's move.

title: Khyber Rifles
description:
[A] tactical level game, simulating the constant struggle between the forces of the Raj and their various opponents, e.g. Afghan native irregulars and regulars and the fierce Pathan Tribesmen, of the Northwest Frontier. The period depicted here is the mid 1870's through the early 1880's. The scenarios are primarily hypothetical occurrences that are representative of the actions that took place in this area during that time period.

A magazine game published in The Wargamer Magazine #34. Features 10 minute turns, 50 yard hexes, and units comprised of about 10 men. Errata appeared in The Wargamer #35 at page 49.

title: Dark Stars
description: Stephen Newberg says: Dark Stars is played on both the Interstellar and the Interplanetary level so as to place the full range of space exploration and conflict possibilities in the hands of the players. At the time we did Dark Stars, I played a lot of board games, but almost none of them SF because  they were so bad. They routinely ignored pretty much everything having to do with astronomy, physics, and mathematics, and since my background is technical I found that hard to swallow. The main problem with just about every science fiction game I ran across was too much fiction and not enough science. We put a lot of hard science into the system's design, simplified as much as possible to be playable, to try to put some of the science back in, rather than having it just fiction.

title: IJN
description:
IJN, Tactical Naval and Naval-Air Combat in the Pacific, 1941-1945.

The first of a series of three completely mateable games that will cover all aspects of WWII naval combat on a low level tactical scale.  Using silhouette type counters representing individual vessels and aircraft, 100 yard hexes, 90 second turns, unique search systems, complete damage rules, and realistic combat interaction mechanics.  IJN accurately simulates the long periods of uncertainty broken by sharp, violent clashes that characterize war at sea.  Scenarios range from picket destroyer skirmishes to the Battle of Midway.

title: Torpedo!
description:
Torpedo!, Tactical Submarine and Anti-Submarine Warfare, 1939-1945. This is the submarine expansion for the tactical World War II air-naval series from SimCan. The other games in the series are IJN, Kriegsmarine, and Schnellboote.

SimCan says: Special rules cover the actions of submarines, convoys, ASW aircraft, mini subs, and even ASW blimps. The weapons of Japan, America, Netherlands, France, Canada, Russia, England, Italy, and Germany are included and scenarios range from one on one sub vs. destroyer actions to combined sub, surface,  air actions against the Murmansk runs.

title: Divine Wind
description:
'Divine Wind: Japan in the Pacific, 41-45.

A strategic scale game with one-month turns, 250nm hexes, and units representing naval divisions, infantry divisions, corps, armies, and fleets.

The simulation is on the grand strategic level and thus has the players, representing the heads of the combined Japanese and Allies commands, making decisions as to where and when to strike and with how much force, rather than detailing the individual combat actions of fields commanders or individual units ... Divine Wind may be played in one, two, or three years scenarios starting from the beginning of the war or as a campaign game covering the entire war.

title: Lebensraum
description:
Lebensraum, The Campaign in the East 1941 - 1945.

Lebensraum! is a grand strategic, moderate complexity game of the war between Nazi Germany and Soviet Russia, starting with the German invasion in late June of 1941 through to the final battles to Berlin in 1945. The game focuses on the Army Group level, with players controlling subordinate armies as the main combat formations. Leadership is a major component of the game, with each player having a pool of named and rated leaders available. Airpower, naval support partisans, production centers, and transportation networks are all covered. There are four scenarios, ranging from three to 13 turns, as well as a 16 turn campaign game covering the entire war. Turns are quarterly, with a map scale of 50 miles per hex.

This game can be combined with SimCan's West Front to cover the entire war in Europe.

title: Kriegsmarine
description:
Kriegsmarine, Tactical Naval and Naval-Air Combat in the Atlantic and Mediterranean, 1939-1945.

SimCan says: Three Spica class frigates slip silently through the Mediterranean night toward North Africa. In the light swells behind them follow half a dozen merchants carrying vital ammunition and petrol to the stalled Axis forces lying outside el Alamein. Without warning British warships appear off the port bow at only 1200 yards. The darkness is shattered by flash and gunfire. In six minutes it is over. Again the sea grows quiet, disturbed only by the occasional rattling hiss of a dying ship as the remnants of the Italian convoy limp on toward their destination.

title: Das Geheimnis der Abtei
description:
Each player gets four monks in one color. The player looks at the monks and places them on the starting field, so thta the other players can't see the monks. In play the players aren't allowed to look at the monks.
At the player's turn, he/she throws with both dice and chooses one monk. It's not allowed to devide the points of the dice along the monks. The player can choose to add or the deduct the numbers of the roll. Monks can move in any direction except for walls and bushes.

In order to find out, which of the strange monks is the intruder, the players have to question them. The questioning can take place only in the garden and only if a player with one of its figures comes exactly on the field of a fellow player figure. If this succeeds, then the active player picks up carefully the figure and looks at the figure secretly. Afterwards the monk is placed to its starting position.
If two monks are occuing a space, other monks cannot question them, until one of the monks leave. When both the dice display the same amount a questioning can be broken by another player.

The player who knows which monk is the intruder, can start the    persecution. The player has to throw the same amount with both dice.From this moment the player can only move with one monk, until he reached the intruder. The monk has to land on the same space has the persected monk and the player shows the monk. If the monk is the intruder, the intruding party is out of the game. Otherwise the persecuting party is out of the game.

The last order of monks standing win the game.

title: Assault on Tobruk
description:
Assault on Tobruk is a game type simulation of the successful assault by German and Italian forces in North Africa lead by Erwin Rommel on the Allied held fortress of Tobruk in the summer of 1942 ... [It] has an historic scenario and six alternate scenarios covering the actual and potential events at Tobruk. After choosing a scenario one player takes command of the Allied forces and the other player the Axis forces.

Each turn represents 2 hours, each hex is 650 meters, and counters represent company size units.

title: Java Man
description:
Java Man is a simulation game of tribal politics and survival in the pre-historic, pre-agricultural, pre-civilized era. Each player attempts to control a single tribe, to ensure the survival of his tribe, and to boost it along the road to civilization. Towards this end, players work to control the normally random movements of their tribes across a hexagon grid representing a typical area of the pre-historic world, so as to avoid or destroy hostile tribes, contact friendly tribes, and gather as much food as possible.

The success or failure of previous actions influences a tribe's willingness to obey a leader's orders. Tribes may be ordered, among other things, to go on the warpath against other tribes, to strip the immediate area bare of food, or to conduct mystic rituals, which may have dire results. A unique aspect of this simulation is that, theoretically, a player may win by ordering nothing at all. Of course, victory is more likely if the leader seizes control of the tribe and leads it boldly into the future... or perhaps into a tar pit.

The following comes from an advertisement for the game in The Dragon #42:

COULD YOU LIVE WITHOUT METAL, POTTERY, FARMING OR FIRE?

Well, Java Man could ... sometimes. Java Man is the colloquial term for Homo Erectus, the earliest of our ancestors to deserve the title 'man.' Remains of Java Man were first discovered in Java, where the species did not, survive, and later in Africa, where it did, although no one really knows why.

Now, Java Man is a challenging simulation game for one or more players. As leader of a tribe of Java Men, can you gather enough food to keep the tribe alive? Can you conjure up good medicine to make the tribe grow? Can you avoid natural disasters and the depredations of other hungry tribes? And, if the answer to all these questions is 'yes,' can you persuade the tribe to let you try? Find out now; play Java Man.

Java Man features die-cut counters, four-color map, rules booklet and player record sheets packaged in a rugged, 4-mil zip-lock bag. Send check or money order for $5.00 per copy, or ask your local retailer for Java Man.

title: Ortona
description:
Ortona: The Advance through Italy, Dec. 1943.

In December 1943 the Allied advance up Italy was stalling. To regain momentum on the Eastern flank the 1st Canadian Division was given the task of capturing the strategically important city of Ortona. Resistance was expected to be light. However torrential rain turned the countryside into a quagmire and the Allied artillery maps proved inaccurate. The Germans had dug in along the length of a gully outside Ortona and were reinforced by the elite 1st Parachute Division. The battle for the gully lasted 10 days with Germans fighting for every inch of ground and inflicting severe casualties before falling back to Ortona. Once again the Germans dug in.

Ortona is an operational game of the Allied drive on the city of Ortona in December 1943. The Allied player must attack two heavily fortified positions manned by excellent troops. The German player must conserve his small force, and time retreats and counterattacks with skill.

Turns are 1 day long, units are company sized, and each hex is 170 meters across.

title: Battle Stations
description:
Battle Stations: An Operational Game of Modern Seapower.

Battle Stations is a low complexity board game of naval conflict concentrating on the operational level. The game depicts the various areas of potential conflict on a series of maps scaled to about 24 miles to a hex. The interactions of surface, subsurface, and naval air forces are depicted by silhouette style counters. The data base of Seapower  the State, our strategic modern naval game, is used for the unit
values, thus providing a degree of mateability between the games. The operational nature of the game is emphasized by five-hour turns and a simple but effective combat system that
reflects the lethality of modern weapons systems. A number of scenarios are provided for likely conflict areas as well as a system to use Seapower  the State as a campaign game scenario generator.

title: Power Play
description:
The coup d'etat is generally a much less bloody way of seizing power than it's distant cousin, the popular revolution. Historically in the Third World, coups have changed more governments than elections since World War 2.

Power Play is a card and counter game for 2 players. The game models some aspects of the planning and execution of a coup. As such the game bears no relation to to any single historical event and many aspects of reality have been abstracted for game play.

title: Kamikaze
description:
The kamikaze attacks -- deliberate mass suicides that turned aircraft into devastatingly effective guided missiles -- were a unique phenomenon of World War II. In the closing months of the Pacific conflict, the desperate but indomitable Japanese command formulated a last-ditch equation: one plane could equal one ship. Kamikaze is a two-player game simulating a kamikaze raid on two to six U.S. ships.

Published as a magazine game in Fire and Movement issue 31.

title: West Front
description:
West Front: The Campaign in Europe 1943 - 1945.

West Front is our grand strategic game of the European campaign. It can be played in historical scenarios starting at either the Italian or Normandy landings or in an open landing zone campaign. The game focuses on the Army Group level, with players controlling subordinate armies as the main combat formations. Leadership is a major component of the game, with each player having a pool of named and rated leaders available. In addition, the game uses the same system as our Lebensraum game of the campaign in the East and the two games can be combined to produce an overall grand strategic game of the entire war in Europe from the start of the invasion of the U.S.S.R.

Turns are 3 months long, units are armies, and each hex is 50 miles across.

title: Schnellboote
description:
Schnellboote, Tactical Small Craft Warfare, 1939-1945.

SimCan says: Darkness cloaks the Slot. Off the bow two other boats of the squadron idle along silently at 4 knots, almost invisible. The radio crackles into muffled life. The Tokyo Express has just passed the other half of the squadron, too distant to attack, but they are coming in. And they will now be between the fires of all six boats. The giant motors crank over, phosphorescent wakes building along the hulls, as the PTs rush to the attack point at 40 knots. Not all will return, but the Express will derail tonight.

title: Gunslinger
description:
Take aim on this fast-paced card game of gunslingers and gamblers, bullets and bad blood, posses and Pinkertons . . . Loaded with 4 card decks, each of them offering you would-be gunfighters a chance for fame and fortune...or a very short career.

A beer and pretzels game of outlaw gangs in the Old West. The players control gangs of outlaws formed with cards drawn from the gunslinger deck. The object is to be the first gang to amass a specified dollar amount by pulling off successful bank robberies. Gunfights are resolved quickly by comparing the leather slapping ratings of the combatants.

title: Guerilla
description: Guerilla is based on the confrontation between Malaysia and Indonesia from 1963 to 1966. It simulates at section and platoon level typical operations of an infantry battalion in the First Division (Province) of Sarawak during the first half of the period of operations . . . Although an accurate simulation of the type of operations and tactics used, Guerilla does not claim to be a precise historical simulation of any particular period or aspect of the war . . . The Orders of Battle do not have any historical basis, but again are typical of the forces engaged on both sides. On the Security Force side . . . the composition of the game battalion is based on the Gurkha organization, slightly modified to suit the game.

title: Gladiator: Men vs. Animals
description:
The floor of the Colosseum (sic) had been divided into two almost equal halves, separated by a tall wooden wall. On each side of the wall wild animals stalked across the hot sands . . . bears, slinking lions and leopards and the solitary tigers who claimed the dubious honor of being the most dangerous of the beasts to hunt and kill . . . Two teams of men emerged onto the field. At the head of each team three spearmen . . . behind them a pair of swordsmen . . . the last man out of each gate carried a heavy lead mace.

The players control separate teams of six gladiators facing off in separate arenas against four animals.

title: Field of Honor
description: Envision the age of chivalry. The time when mounted cavalry reached its greatest heights. An important part of this period was the contest of knight against knight in the joust or Pas des Armes. This was the time of iron men who rode against each other, lance to lance, to prove their mettle. Field of Honor simulates the Pas des Armes, or informal joust, of the high middle ages.

title: Gladiator: Men vs. Men
description:
The Colosseum (sic) squatted like some primeval stone beast in the heart of Rome, its lofty upper arches casting shadows in the late afternoon sun over the sweltering pavement of this, the Emperor's proud capital . . . Dedicated to the Infernal gods, the Roman games proved to be one of the most awesome spectacles of regulated murder ever performed before human audiences . . . The gates of the plutonic kingdom were thronged with the ghosts of the defeated, yet Rome still glutted them in honor of uncaring gods who only reveled in the deaths of strong men . . . Rome has passed into the ages of antiquity, yet still the solemn bulk of the Colosseum presides over the ruins of an ancient city that once enjoyed the grotesque ballet of life and death under the uncaring sun.

The players fight four simultaneous battles between pairs of gladiators. There are four differently equipped gladiators on each team, two armored (Postulat with mace and Secutor with sword) and two unarmored (Dimacher with two daggers and Retarius with net and trident).

title: Eagle Day
description:
A game that appears to have been inspired by Zocchi's Battle of Britain (and to have borrowed a bit from the former game as well.) This game uses 10 minute turns, approximately 5 mile hexes, and units representing Gruppen (27 planes) and Squadrons (12 planes).

The game places you in command of the forces which took part in the original campaign . . . Eagle Day is two games-in-one. The Historical Game allows you to re-fight the original battle.   The September Game allows you to see what would have happened if the Germans had continued to bomb the RAF's airfields instead of switching the focus of their attacks to London . . . Eagle Day is played in 'full turns', each representing ten minutes of time. Each week has 20 full turns . . . When the third week is over, the game is ended.

title: Deluxe Fighter Pilot
types: Aviation / Flight Wargame World War II
description:
These rules are designed to give the players the feel of air-to-air combat in the early years of World War II. All the basic maneuvers used in fighter combat are included, and such variables as pilot experience and aircraft maneuverability and firepower are also taken into account . . . An ideal game would begin with 6 to 8 players.

Fighter Pilot was a set of World War II air combat rules for miniatures originally published by The Little Soldier in 1976. This Deluxe set converted the rules to a boardgame format and added some additional rules. Each hex is 100 feet across and each turn is approximately 1 second. Counters represent individual aircraft. The game includes 25 American, British, German, and Japanese fighters.

title: Dragoon vs. Hussar
description:
Become a cavalryman during the American Revolution, the French Revolution, or the Napoleonic Imperial Age. Try to maximize the   advantages of a Dragoon, Hussar, Cuirassier, Lancer, Horse Grenadier, Cossack, Light Dragoon or Mameluke . . . The system includes weapon differentiations, increases and decreases in experience leading to combat modifications, one-on-one and team play, and campaign operations. Movement and combat operations are done with written orders and simultaneous moves, with player options for when and where an attack is delivered.

A detailed tactical gaming system for man-to-man combat on horseback during the period of 1775 to 1830. There is no mapsheet, 54mm stand-up cardboard figures represent the horse and rider (or miniature figures may be used.)

title: Domination
description:
The two greatest challenges facing the military leader today are imparting professional knowledge to the solder and subsequent application of that knowledge in a training environment and/or on the field of battle . . . Training Technologies is committed to making that first great challenge much less difficult for you by enabling you to obtain a solid grip on the fundamentals of military knowledge; and we hope that by mastering 'Domination' you will become a much more knowledgeable and professional soldier/leader.

A trivia game in the style of Trivial Pursuit (fill your jeep with passengers by answering questions in various areas of military knowledge). Features 100 QA cards with questions in six different categories. The Domination questions come in six categories: Leadership, Soldier Skills, Weaponry, Military History, Tactics, Friends and Foes. Veterans and hardcore military buffs will appreciate questions such as When utilizing the leaf sights of the M203 grenade launcher, what is the maximum range you are able to select?

title: Clash of Eagles
types: Aviation / Flight Wargame World War II
description:
(BGG user description:)

Camelot is an Italian game company, hence the hiccups in their description of the game: [A] game that tries to reproduce the dogfights during the Second World War. Each player cover the role of one or more fighter or bomber pilots and must execute his mission; usually it consists of the classic dogfight when the only rule is engage enemy fighters trying to shoot down more planes than the enemy bringing back home your skin and your plane. The presence of some bomber within the `furball' can give you more interesting mission to complete.

Clash of Eagles is a tactical air combat game with each counter portraying a single aircraft. Each map hex is 80 meters across and a turn is 20 seconds long. The game uses mechanics similar to GDW's popular World War I air combat game Blue Max.

The aircraft included in the game reflect the early-war Battle of France/Britain period: Hurricane, Spitfire, Me-109, Me-110, He-111, Ju-87, Ju-88, Blenheim, Do-17, Gladiator, and C.R.42.

Expanded by:

    Malta, Clash of Eagles Expansion (includes an assortment of Italian aircraft along with some new rules)
    Sturmovik, Clash of Eagles Expansion (adds Russian aircraft)

title: H-Hour
description:
A game of man-to-man urban combat in World War II featuring German, Russian, and American forces. Each turn is fifteen seconds and each square is 10 feet across.

From the rulebook: The game is designed to recreate, as close as possible, the 'feel' and 'flavor' of infantry combat and the problems and decisions faced by the small unit leader . . . The combat units involved represent the average organizations of the U.S., Germany, and the U.S.S.R. The playing area represents typical European buildings and streets. All names on the maps are in German, but represent typical small town architecture and street plans left over from the Middle Ages . . . Proceed with caution: the town is unfriendly, the enemy is experienced and your men aren't expendable. You have your mission and your organization. As soon as you read the rules and set-up, it will be H-HOUR.

From designer's William A. Comito's comments in the rulebook: A game is one man's view of a particular subject, and is only as good as the author's research and experience. I designed this game from the viewpoint of a professional soldier who has spent 6+ years in the infantry, including two combat tours, and who has been an instructor in small unit tactics and map reading. My training has been in all aspects of infantry combat, and my research has included not only books but interviews with combat infantry veterans of WWII . . . The game is, honestly, an attempt to combine a miniatures game and a boardgame together. Most of the rules are written from a boardgame viewpoint, but can be readily applied to miniatures.

title: Hyper Battle
description:
2091 - On the fiftieth anniversary of the official establishment of the colony, New Terra declares itself independent of Earth's rule.  Earth, her own resources exhausted, has no choice but to go to war.  The Alpha Centaurian Revolution has begun... [A] fast-paced tactical game simulating ship to ship combat in hyperspace.  Included in the rules are 5 scenarios from the Alpha Centaurian Revolution, with alternates allowing you to choose your own forces.

Counters represent individual ships. The following ship types are included: police, destroyer, light cruiser, heavy cruiser, space fortress, battleship, dreadnought, and freighter. Each turn equals one minute and each hex is (ahem) 11 million miles (not a typo).

title: Concrete Jungle
description:
A game of counter-terrorist combat on a man-to-man level. Each player controls a team of commandos or terrorists, or each member of a team can be controlled by a separate player. These units may be pre-designed, or custom built by you, with different reaction time, skills, weapons, and body armor. The mechanics of play cover the specialized situations found in this type of combat and are condensed into an easy reference sheet for quick use.
The first game released by BTRC. A modern tactical game of small-unit military and police actions. Each counter represents 1 man or vehicle, each turn is 2 seconds, and each square on the map is 2 meters across.

title: Limit Up
mechanisms: Betting/WageringCommodity SpeculationRoll / Spin and MoveStock Holding
description:
(from the instruction booklet)
LIMIT UP is a board game which simulates commodity futures trading and which stresses good money and portfolio management. LIMIT UP players learn not only how the commodity markets work, but how to trade in them as well...
The object is to accumulate as much wealth as possible through the buying and selling of commodity contracts. Players trade in seven commodities: two grains (corn and wheat), two meats (cattle and hogs), one industrial metal (copper), one money instrument (T-Bills), and one precious metal (gold). These commodities differ in their volatility; the higher the volatility, the greater the opportunity for both profit and loss...
LIMIT UP makes you part of the commodity world. You can speculate on the expected price movement, protect your crop, balance your portfolio and limit your risk, or use high leverage. You compete with government policy, weather, and other market forces.
No commodity trade would be complete without an inside track; someone always seems to know more than others. In LIMIT UP, you know who is the insider, and you can watch that trader adjust his or her portfolio to profit from the news.

title: Push
description:
Contents:
small plastic board with relief
13 yellow + 13 black plastic balls

Players compete against each other by moving the balls a row at a time. Form a square of 3x3 balls of your color to win

Basically, it is like a 3x3 in-a-row game.
However, there is a twist that makes the game interesting and nice to play. A player can keep pushing rows as long as the ball that comes out belongs to that same player. Therefore, there is two things to worry about, the 3x3 square to be made, and to try to keep your turn for a few pushes. 
It comes with instructions for solo game.

title: X-Men Deck the Mutants Card Game
description:
A fast-paced and fun card game for fans of the X-Men superhero comic books. The players are all mutant heroes trying to capture Evil Mutants to score points and win the game.

Dice with special stickers are rolled each turn to determine what actions a player must take. These include drawing cards, swapping cards, and even a little bit of go fish.

Then the player captures one of the Evil Mutants in play with groups of cards from his hand.

In addition to the cards and dice, a scoring track is provided with plastic markers for the players to keep track.

This is one of a series of X-Men related games designed by Richard Borg for Pressman Toy Corp.

title: Quadriga
description: Each (slave in the stables of the Roman Colosseum) has 4 pieces (horses) in one color. Starting from a base line one attempts to bring all four pieces to a line in neighboring portions (form a Quadriga).

title: Armada
description:
Two proud fleets in full sail, Galleons (a medium or large sailing ship, built flush decked and without castles).
, Galleys (A lightly-built fighting ship, chiefly propelled by oars. Galleys were fast and could move independently of the wind, but they could not carry heavy armament, and were at risk in rough weather.) and Galleasses (A large oared warship, also propelled by sail, usually three-masted, with a gun deck over the rowers' benches). Which player will sink the opposing admirals vessels and gain the victory?

title: Missile Boat
description:
Missile Boat: Tactical Combat On, over, and Beneath the Sea,
1964-1984 . . . Recreates the conditions of present day naval warfare. The subject matter is that of tomorrow's headlines, not of history books. Using the capacities and weapons of the actual ships, players can explore the fascinating ramifications of modern naval fighting. Two players each take the role of a commander - American, Israeli, Egyptian, Chinese, or one of the dozens of nationalities . . . to re-fight the naval battles of tomorrow, today.

A tactical game of surface-to-surface, surface to air, air to surface, torpedo and ASW combat. Each counter represents an individual aircraft or vessel. Turns are 6 minutes; each hex is 1 nautical mile.

title: MiG Killers
types: Aviation / Flight Korean War Modern Warfare Vietnam War Wargame World War II
description:
MiG Killers: An Accurate Simulation of Jet Combat Thru the 1980's. Includes 40 historical scenarios. 4 solitaire scenarios with variants. Includes spotting, E.C.M., radar and infrared seeking missiles, fuel, ace status, plus optional and advanced rules. Spans jet combat from 1945 through the 1980's with more than 50 different battle-proven jet fighters accurately portrayed. 
In this tactical air combat game, each counter represents a single aircraft. Each turn is 5 seconds long and each hex is 245 meters across. Aircraft performance is reflected on individual data cards.

Expanded by:

    MiG Killers Expansion Kit

title: MiG Killers Expansion Kit
types: Aviation / Flight Expansion for Base-game Korean War Modern Warfare Vietnam War Wargame
description:
A bare bones set of expansion components plus two new special scenarios (Rodan and Firefox). Also includes a new set of aircraft data cards which are slightly larger than the cards in the original game.

Enclosed you will find 240 die-cut counters that have been mistakenly cut off-register and/or improperly bonded to the cardboard. Cut out the blue aircraft counters in units of 20 and use glue stick to bond them to the cardboard, centering them carefully, over the old markers. Be sure to remove any improperly bonded paper before gluing down the new markers. Then carefully use a razor-knife or Exacto-blade to cut the markers apart so that they may be removed without tearing.

Expands:

    MiG Killers

title: L.A. Lawless
description:
A game depicting the Los Angeles Riots of April 1992. The units represents groups of varying sizes (up to several thousand people) and each turn equals a half a day. Published in Moves magazine issue 75.

The purpose of the game is to give players a chance to use different game strategies to simulate the confrontation between police and rioters.  There are two players in the game: Authority (representing the city government, law enforcement agencies, and the general forces of law and order); and the Rioters (representing the people conducting the disturbances.)

title: National Liberation Front
description: National Liberation Front: A Game of Guerrilla Warfare in Today's World . . . [I]ntroduces new and unique design concepts that promote realistic military situations, including command problems that must deal with secret and simultaneous unit movements. Your strategy, consequently, must be based solely on the last known position of the enemy. A given enemy unit's strength is not known until contact has been established. Both, the government and the guerrillas, have different but equally difficult tasks ahead of them. Every aspect of the game has been carefully developed for easy playability but maintains a high level of combat simulation. Many original and innovative design concepts make this rare combination possible. When it is over, perhaps we, as players, will have reached a greater insight into the most prevalent type of warfare in the world today.

title: Mission Aloft
description:
A tactical game of air-to-ground and air-recon missions. Each counter represents an individual aircraft, turns are 30 seconds, and each hex is 2 miles across. The game uses the same map sheet for all 10 scenarios.

This game simulates some aspects of air warfare during the period 1960-1980. One player or team called the A-player must carry out one or more assigned air-to-ground attacks or a reconnaissance mission. The other player or team called the B-player employs interceptors and surface-to-air weapons to frustrate the A-player's mission. The game consists of many scenarios drawn from Arab-Israeli, India-Pakistan, and Southeast Asian conflicts as well as hypothetical situations.

title: NORAD
description:
Mishler's revised edition of a game originally published in 1973 by SDC's in Conflict Magazine #4. A solitaire variant is included.

NORAD is a representation of a hypothetical nuclear war between the United States and the Soviet Union in 1962 . . . In 1977 the Mishler Company purchased the rights for NORAD. Only minor changes were made on the game board and the unit counters. However, several changes were made in the rules, and the solitaire game was completely re-done and the 'Assigned Targets' optional rule was added. The historical simulation aspect was improved by giving the American player the capability to hide the exact location of his/her fighters. Also, the Russian bombers may no longer fly endlessly back and forth across the game board. In addition, several rules and the number of units was changed to balance the game.

title: Mobile Suit Z Gundam game: Take off MkII
types: Adventure Comic Book / Strip Miniatures Space Exploration
description:
This boardgame is designed based on the famous Japanese animation - The Z Gundam series. This is the first set of the Z Gundam boardgame by Bandai. Therefore the game does not contain any Z Gundam miniature.

The game comes with 12 Gundam miniatures (3 of each of the following: Gundam MkII, Rick Dias, Hi-Zaku, GM2), a game board showing the space around the Earth and Moon, a set of event cards and counters.

Players can choose to play as either Titans or AEUG. Each player has a fleet and 3 MS robots at the beginning. The player who has finished his secret mission, or gets rid of all his enemies wins the game.

title: Shadow Raven
description:
The Object of the Game is to beat your opponent(s) by doing one of two things: destroy his (their) home base(s) by depleting his (their) card library or by winning and claiming five different battle cards.

Interesting sci-fi card game, with seven types of cards: Character, Weapon, Vehicle, Familiar, Action, Battle and Energy. Shadow Raven CCG (combat card game) was designed, I believe, as a true CCG. However only 99 card 'starter' decks were produced. The game is likely to remain non-collectible. Each player needs a deck of his/her own.

title: Monstrosity
description:
In the not-too distant future, a group of underground mad surgeons assemble creatures from spare mutated body parts and make them fight. Join the insanity and send your own personal monstrosity into battle against your opponent's creation.

Monstrosity is played in two phases, with two distinct decks (50+ cards each). During the first round, players acquire spare body parts (arms, legs, torsos and heads) from the black market and construct creatures in their operating theaters. As each player collects mutated limbs and tries to assemble them, their opponent attempts to steal parts, sabotage the supplies, and generally dismantle the opposing creation. Round two pits the creatures against one another, as their owners play attack and defend cards to bolster their monstrosity's fighting abilities. It's a fast-paced, gruesome, and strategic battle game best suited for two players (although up to four can play).

title: The Slums
description:
In this nerve wracking game, collect stocks, build your companies and get ready to look for cheaper property because the rabble is moving in.

The Slums is a 2 to 6 player game (Ages 13 and up) guaranteed to keep you sweating and wondering, Who's going to move in next door?

In the Slums, you will build neighborhoods centered around massive Super Stores and collect Super Store stocks. You and your opponents will devaluate the neighborhoods by building slums and destroying property.  When your stock prices fall because of slums in previously trendy neighborhoods, you must decide whether it is time to sell stock or rebuild the neighborhood. You also have the option of just buying the cheap stock and letting someone else rebuild for you. One of the unique features of the game is that you will not know who is the winner until the very last piece is played. After all, a critically placed Slum can make the difference between thousands and millions of dollars.

Game play mainly falls into three parts. The first half hour is pretty much an all out war to build up as many companies as possible and collect stock. In the middle portion of the game, players hold onto their stock waiting for opportunities to build key buildings in order to tip the tide of the game in their favor. The last portion of the game is a fast paced, white knuckled race to either destroying the biggest company on the board or playing the last piece to end the game.

title: Twisted Tongue
types: Card Game Party Game Word Game
description: Using silly words and a little brain power, try to get your friends to make a mistake in this quick playing, and highly entertaining nonsensical word game.  There are multiple levels of play. Try using only the easy words and passing the cards, or use the full rule set for plenty of mind bending fun for the whole family.

title: Don: Continuing Criminal Enterprise
description:
DON: CCE is a new collectible card game that allows two players to assume the roles of the head of a Criminal Organization vying for control of a major city. The Player Don uses a wide variety of Associates and Family Members to attempt to bankrupt his opponent. In addition to henchmen, a Don may play actions directly from his hand to affect either his own Associates or his opponents. The Don who bankrupts his opponents funds is the winner.

DON: CCE is set in a timeless world of crime, containing elements from the Prohibition era through the rise of the modern mob. This fantasy world of the Mafia is simulated to allow players to battle each other in a spirit reflective of classic Gangster movies.

Player Dons use their tradable cards to generate funds, control vices and even whack their opponents Associates. Game rules are provided to play Sealed Deck, Double Sealed Deck and Constructed decks for use in tournament play, multiple player, and direct head to head competition. The Capo starter deck is available now.  The Capo booster packs, available in Summer 2003, will add a wealth of characters, actions, and possibilities to any game of DON: CCE. The complete card set at present contains over 200 separate cards representing everything from a lowly Babbo Crew to the powerful Made Men and the infamous Penitent Wife.  The artwork is highly stylized to represent the classic gangster photos of yesteryear with hints of contemporary crime.

Using a revolutionary new game system, Dons are able to control cards in ways that other card games have never imagined. Each players actions control how many cards he wishes to deploy as well as how many funds he chooses to spend.  In DON: CCE, each Don controls his fate through strategy, not luck.

Future expansions will add even more stylized elements of the genre, including more Law Enforcement, additional Associates, more Family members, and even more Vices for Dons to expand their businesses.

title: The Thing in the Darkness
description:
You are a journalist investigating the disappearance of a college co-ed. Each turn the player chooses from a list 
of places to investigate and then reads a paragraph to see what happens. These may involve dice checks and re-directions to yet other paragraphs. In addition there is a Time Chart -- the character must eat and sleep -- as this is also a race against time. Based on the H.P. Lovecraft's Cthulhu Mythos.

Most players will fail several times before managing to get to the key places at the right times and win.

Published in Fantasy Gamer #3, Dec/Jan 1984

title: Das Zauberschloss
types: Action / Dexterity Children's Game City Building Fantasy
description:
Game Idea: 
The little craftsmen in the enchanted wood are astonished: Their blocks disappear! Magician Grindlebur no doubt is involved in that. How on earth will they be able to finish the enchanted castle? The only hope now is nimble fingers and a bit of luck...

A game for 2-7 little master builders Ages 6 and up. With variant for younger players.

title: The Bigfoot Game
description:
Bigfoot, the legendary larger-than-life creature, is on the loose! You have three men in pursuit of Bigfoot who is standing on top of his mountain domain. You're curious to learn more about Bigfoot and hope to befriend him, but he feels threatened by your presence. Will you escape as he kicks the boulder in your path or will you be forced to escape to a safe zone! Only one player will succeed in getting three men on the mountain to become Bigfoot's friend for life.

For 2-4 players, Ages 7 and up

Description from the box

Bigfoot is on the loose!

You have three men in hot pursuit of this legendary larger than life creature who stands among the trees on top of his mountain home.

You're curious to learn more about this tall man-like creature - but the normally friendly bigfoot is worried about the twelve running men who are following his giant foot prints around the mountain.

Will you escape as Bigfoot kicks the boulder down the rugged mountain-side or will you be knocked over and be forced to return to one of the four safe areas?

Only one player will succeed in getting three men to the mountain top.  Will you win the race and become Bigfoot's friend for life?

title: Legless
types: Abstract Strategy Adventure Deduction Dice Economic Humor
mechanisms: Dice RollingPaper-and-PencilPoint to Point MovementTile Placement
description:
The virtual pub-crawl boardgame comes in a convenient, laminated A3 format * including rules of play and scorecards.

The object of the game is to visit all 7 pubs on the board without consuming more than 70 units of alcohol or spending more than 50 ( or the equivalent - pennies, monopoly money or even matchsticks will suffice )

Food outlets and feature squares enable players to reduce their units and add to their dwindling money reserves - there's even a betting shop for those who fancy their chances and a park for chilling out.

Although the luck of the dice is important, a fair bit of skill and judgment comes into the gameplay strategy.

The game takes about 20 - 30 minutes to complete and is readily understandable for ages 8 upwards. In theory any number of people can play but 2-6 players is ideal.


     The game can be customized to any town or area - send us details of your seven favorite pubs, take-aways etc. and we will make you a personalized version.

title: Number 2
description:
The time is late 20th century.  The kings of the royal family, including those of the Canary House, are very fond of melon.  But so are the queen, princess, and everyone else who works for the house such as chef, housemaid, vicar, and jester!  So a war over a piece of melon starts every day in the house, as well as among the royal houses.  Who on earth will be lucky enough to get a melon in the end?



Another Japanese import.  There are character cards, four event cards, and point cards.  The box says it's an homage to Alex Randolph.

title: Territory
description:
The Great Father-of-All was worried.  An argument occurred in the Heavens about which God should be given the newly created world.  So he decided to make the Four Pillars of God compete for sole power of the world.  it would be the God who could use the power from the secret Mighty Jar most suitably, and expand his territory most widely.  It is said the world was completed in seven days.

Imported from Japan, this abstract promises to be interesting.

title: Fürsten von Burgund
description: Abstract wargame. Be the ruler of the most of 22 territories. You have 5 knights and 9 pages for fighting and building castles and 1 trader for building trading posts. Each round youll get 10 action points for several actions At the end of the game (after 20 rounds) youll get 20 influence points for each castle and 10 influence points for each trading post and a unknown number of influence points which you accumulated during the 20 rounds. Only the player with the highest sum of IP controls that territory. Fighting is without dice and there are only 4 pages of rules.

title: 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea Game
types: Adventure Children's Game Movies / TV / Radio theme Nautical Novel-based
description:
(from the box)

Race Your Nautilus To Safety Past the Moving Gunboats!

Players race their Nautilus from START to HOME port---Land on a wheel and YOU control the gunboats---Rotate the gunboats to sink an opponent---Be the first player to sail the Nautilus to HOME PORT and win the game!

Every player is Captain Nemo in this exciting dimensional game.

title: Stick the IRS
description: Sticking the IRS does not require pins or needles or knowledge of the Internal Revenue Code. It requires tax players who are willing to take a chance with a Tax Shelter that may give financial security or may backfire. After four tours around the Board, the Tax player who has the most after-tax cash wins the game and has successfully been able to STICK THE IRS. The players move around the colorful board, landing on opportunities to earn income, spend money on non-deductible expenses and to purchase a variety of tax shelters. In addition, the players have a chance to receive annual reports that determine whether the tax shelter investment made them rich or, as in most real life shelters, turn out to be a bust. Finally, an exposure to the horrors and humor of audit lurks with every roll of the dice. Drilling for oil in Hawaii, establishing a baseball team in Alaska, reviving an old motion picture, and building ski condominiums in Texas are just a few of the fun and exciting tax shelter opportunities that the player is offered in STICK THE IRS. Although humorous and in good taste, the game also offers certain educational benefits in highlighting the good and the bad in the use of shelters to reduce taxes. The player who manages to best use his income, his CPA and his shelters, and therefore who manages to pay the least tax, is the winner, having successfully been able to STICK THE IRS.

title: Call My Bluff
types: Bluffing Card Game Deduction Educational Movies / TV / Radio theme Party Game
description:
This game is very similar to Balderdash but doesn't use a board.  Each player has six betting cards.  Three cards with values from 5 - 15 labeled True and four cards with values labeled from 5 - 20 Bluff.

A card is selected and four definitions are read out loud.  Three definitions are listed and the active player makes up the fourth.

Players then place a bet based on one of the definitions.  The players whom have correctly predicted the result get the points they have bet.  The incorrect bets are given to the active player.  The first player to score 250 pts wins.

This game has lots of cards.  672 bluff cards are included and each card has two words.

title: Interstate Highway
mechanisms: Point to Point MovementRoll / Spin and Move
description:
Object of the game is to travel the newly implemented Interstate Highway system based on a randomly drawn Trip Card (ex. Seattle to Miami) and be the player with the most money at the conclusion of the game. 
Along the way, players can be forced to pay fees to other players by stopping at the Motels, Filling Stations, Restaurants and Repair Shops. They can also be fined for speeding along their selected route. 
Conclusion of the game occurs when the first player reaches his destination (receiving a $50) Bonus. Monies are totaled and the player with the most money wins.

title: White Glove Girl: A Manpower Game
Conquistadores
description:
On an hypothetical American territory, the European colonizing nations of the XVII century send their expeditions searching for buried treasures. At the same time they try to hinder and eliminate the opponents, thanks to the feeling of hate separating the Indios and the white devils.

There are two ways to win the game: find half of the hidden treasures with your Conquistadors, or use the Indians to eliminate the Conquistadors of your opponents.

title: The Conquest of Space
description: The board displays thirty planets which are randomly connected by warps (the warps change each game). The game generally involves moving to planets with raw materials and transporting the raw materials to your home planet (or in some scenarios, to any home planet). Combat can occur between ships that arrive at the same planet, and some scenarios are conflict oriented. The game includes seven scenarios. The raw materials and ships are represented by translucent plastic chips of various colors.

title: Three Player Chess
description:
Chess for three players on a hexagonal board. Includes a standard chess board as well. Designer may be Robert Zubrin, as he is listed on the box and rules as the copyright holder.

Edit: I talked to Robert Zubrin at the 2011 Mars Society conference and he mentioned that he designed a chess variant for three people.  He should be listed at the designer.

title: Dream On
description: Dream On is an exciting new board game that answers the age old question 'What do my dreams really mean?' The game provides over 1000 dream interpretations derived from the works of the world's most prominent dream analysts.

title: Lost Worlds Adventure Set II: The Dwarf and Goblin Wars
description:
Mortal combat as Dwarves and Goblins meet in heroic battles in the deep caverns of the world!

The second boardgame based on the Lost Worlds series of fighting gamebooks. Players move miniatures around a 3-D plastic molded cavern, and maneuver on the board until they came into melee range, at which point they switched to the Lost Worlds books to resolve combat.

Rules were provided for movement, ranged combat and furniture. Components include Ral Partha metal miniatures, treasure cards, and ten scenarios. Also included are the Lost Worlds books for the Dwarf in chainmail with a two-handed axe, and the Giant Goblin with a mace and shield.

Part of the Lost Worlds series.

title: Trade Wars: The Game of Global Commerce
types: Economic Educational Negotiation Political Territory Building
description:
The Cold War is over! Now the Trade Wars begin. Trade Wars the board game is a microcosm of the real Trade Wars raging outside, driving global economic conflict home.
The Trade Wars board simulates the globe, and is divided into four geographic regions that a player may control. Players move through the regions of the board purchasing corporations, forming Trusts and Cartels, and collecting license fees from opponents. Players risk making unsound investments, paying license fees to other players, and encounter trade and tariff barriers. Players seek to create transnational corporate empires and either buy-out other players or run them out of existence. Each region has its own currency and players must deal with rising and falling currency exchange rates. Market Force cards randomly effect the game. Players may buy and sell corporations to other players or the bank.

This game has a player pre-determined length of play with variable playing options. Also of note, this game comes complete with player aids and a Teacher#039;s Guide for classroom play. Trade Wars is for ages 15+.

title: Nichts als Ärger!
types: Children's Game Expansion for Base-game Racing
description: Instructions and 52 cards to be used with any Parchisi-style game. Now a player may draw a card after a move or play a card instead of rolling the die. There is a hand limit of 5. The illustrated cards give special powers and effects.

title: Interpretation of Dreams
description:
Interpretation of Dreams lets everyone play amateur psychiatrist in an unbelievably funny game where with the aid of a specially compiled Dream Dictionary you will get to know yourself and your friends better.

Each player writes down an account of a dream. The moderator collects all the sheets and reads a dream aloud to the group without identifying the author. The group then identifies the symbol words in the dream and these are looked up in the Dream Dictionary. Each player writes an analysis of the dream, which are read aloud to the group. The players also write down a guess as to who they believe wrote the dream. The winner is the player who has the most correct identifications.

title: Touch
description:
Touch, Parker Brothers' game of palmistry.

Maxine Lucille Fiel has studied scientific hand reading and palmistry for 15 years . . . Maxine claims that the hand is like a graph that reflects the emotional and physical changes in the body.

Touch is intended as a group game for parties or other gatherings. It can, however, be played solitaire since it is basically a detailed guide to palm reading and analysis.

The game includes a set of oversized cards illustrating different categories of markings on the hand and a pad of Profile Sheets for recording which markings appear on a player's hand. The personality characteristic for each type of marking is listed in the game booklet.

The brief rules suggest that players break into groups and work on figuring out the what markings appear on their hands. Once these have been marked down on profile sheets, all of the sheets are gathered and the interpretations are read from the game booklet. The rules suggest that you read the analysis aloud and let your friends try to guess who is being described.

title: Bowlo
description:
The card bowling game is scored exactly as in the regular rules of bowling and playing technique is based on official bowling rules.

Typical bowling score sheets are included.

Ten frames are played. High score wins.

Players are dealt a hand of five Bowlo cards.

The deck consists of 52 cards:
17 Ball cards.
11 number 1 Pin cards.
12 number 2 Pin cards.
12 number 3 Pin cards.

Any number of these five cards may be discarded and new cards called for to retain a total of five cards, which every player must hold in order to score.

Should the original five cards held total 10 points a strike is called.

After a second hand or a draw, should a 10 be scored, a spare is credited.

An error is scored for any player who scores less than 10 Pins in two hands (or draws).

A bust (zero points) is scored when a player has a hand totaling more than 10 Pins.

title: Sail Away
description:
A game of yacht racing, and an interesting precursor to 3M's Regatta. Sail Away was possibly designed by Howard J. Mullin as he is listed as the copyright holder on the game board.

Sail Away is played on a board resembling a nautical chart overlaid by a square grid. The game includes six metal yachts numbered 1 through 6. The yachts lean to one side or the other according to their tack. The yachts are moved across the map using the intersections of the grid lines.

Movement is governed by a spinner which has an inner and outer circle of results - one circle for the upwind leg, and the other circle for the downwind and crosswind legs. In addition to the bit of luck injected by the spinner (reflecting the vagaries of the wind), there is also a slight chance for misfortune - two small spaces on the spinner allow for a player to lose a turn for having a man overboard and two turns for capsizing. The rules also cover blanketing effects by windward yachts toward leeward yachts, tacking, and jibing.

The course is somewhat fixed in that the wind direction is always the same (southeast) and there are three course markers designated on the map. However, there are four different courses that may be run: counterclockwise around the triangular course described by the three markers, clockwise around the triangular course, around course marker 2 and back, or around course marker 3 and back. In addition, players may choose to race one lap or multiple laps.

title: Airport
mechanisms: Point to Point MovementRoll / Spin and Move
description:
Consider yourself the Captain of an airliner on a flight from Miami, Florida to Seattle, Washington. The object of the game is to pilot your aircraft along the airways, crossing over the cities of your choice, in route to the destination airport and be the first to complete the flight.

This game is designed to be a realistic experience for the player, as many of the game rules are based on actual federal air regulations.

Pilot-players pit themselves against each other and other flying odds as they strive to stay in the lead. Each pilot must be careful of thunderstorms which can unexpectedly cross their paths, just as in a real flight. Each pilot might also hit strong headwinds, severe icing or even clear air turbulence, as they fly across the country.

title: Straightaway
description: A new look at the high-speed world of Grand Prix auto racing. Cars, drivers, the color and excitement of the race itself, with an important plus. Sponsorship of racing cars is big money business for the corporations and individuals who produce automotive parts and products. Now is your chance to be the heavy-spending sponsor of some of the world's fastest racing machinery. Through a new computer-type format you watch your drivers duel through lap after lap of flat out excitement, with your money riding on every down shift, power slide and switchback. An authentic and fascinating way of enjoying the thrills of official Grand Prix racing.

title: Hornswoggle
description:
Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to seek out your opponents and devastate them financially. You will assume the disguise of an attorney and the alias of your choice (Scooter Cohooter, Kid Fleece, L. Gotcha, or Sam Boozlebam). The rules and suggestions are only guidelines; you may operate on the principle that anything you can get away with is legal. In order to preserve the spirit of Hornswoggle, I recommend no mercy be extended to those players in dire financial straits.

Hornswoggle was designed to capture the essence and true spirit of the legal system. Certain modifications were necessary to make the game function logically (unlike the real thing).

Objective: To have the most money on deposit in the Swiss Bank after the game ends. You will accomplish this by suing your opponents. One third of your profits will be deposited in your Swiss Bank account.

title: Silver Cup Sailboat Racing Game
description: A simple sailboat racing game where the players race along a track around the board. Movement is governed by a spinner. Players may be confronted with trivia questions (regarding sailing) during the game - a correct answer moves a boat forward and an incorrect answer moves a boat backward. Additional cards are drawn during the game which provide further information regarding sailing.

title: Windshifts
description:
Dubbed A Tactical Sailing Game, Windshifts uses a novel game system combined with unusual components to recreate international yacht racing.

The board is randomly created as the race develops using 19 plastic map cards that lock together. The race is in three segments; a windward leg, a downwind leg, and then another windward leg to the finish line. As portions of the race are completed, the map cards from that segment are returned to the draw pile to be reused later in the game.

There are no spaces on the board. The direction and strength of the wind are indicated by lines on the plastic map cards. The distance a ship moves is determined by the wind strength and the ship's bearing in relation to the wind direction.

The ships have clear plastic bases with a numbered wheel mounted in the center. The ships' bases have lines molded into them that are aligned with the lines on the map cards to establish the bearing of a ship. As the ship is moved across the map, the wheel in the center turns, and each number on the wheel indicates one unit of movement.  On a map card with strong wind indicated a ship bearing on a beat, broad reach or downwind moves 4 units or one complete revolution of the wheel.  A beam reach bearing generates 6 units of movement.  On a map card with light wind indicated, the movements are half.

A plastic windshadow card is used to determine when an opposing boat is in disturbed air - this differs based on whether the boats are on the downwind or windward (upwind) leg.  The sail of a ship will cause the air downwind (behind) of it to move in weak chaotic swirl patterns, the sail effectively blocks the wind from supplying power to any other boat following downwind  within about 1 1/2 boat lengths.  In the game, the windshadow card is used to determine if one boat has blocked the wind from powering another boat.  If this is the case, the movement of the blocked boat is reduced.

title: AirLand Battle: Corps Operational Command in Europe
description:
