title: The HexGames
description:
One of the so-called Penny Games from tjgames, The HexGames are variations on both Reversi and Checkers, using a hexagonal board with hexagonal spaces, instead of a square board with square spaces.  The game is basically a board printed on heavy-stock paper, and a set of rules; you're supposed to supply the pieces for the games.

From the envelope: Take a checkers board, grab it by the two sides in the middle, and pull really hard until you stretch it into a hexagon.  Now you have the basic idea behind the HexBoard Games.  A cheap Hollywood remake of two classic 8x8 board games, Checkers and Reversi.  If you really did try stretching your checkers board and it ripped ... sorry about that.

Hexversi requires 91 penny-sized pieces that are differently colored on each side.  Hexchex requires 12 standard checkers for each player.

title: Lucky 13
description:
From the box: The entire family will enjoy this exciting, easy-to-learn game.  Using simple addition and subtraction, players get rid of their cards and score points by making the running total reach zero or 13.  Bonus points go to the player who uses one of the Lucky 13 cards to 'take the trick'.  With strategy, quick thinking, and a little luck, you can be the first player to score 500 points and win the game!

The deck is composed of positively- and negatively-numbered cards, and the point of the game is to go out first, like Rummy.  Lucky 13 is not quite a set collection game, and it's primarily geared for family gaming.

title: Cold War
types: Card Game Negotiation Political Print & Play
description:
At last, peace breaks out!  But, obviously, your previous allies will use the breathing space to re-arm, ally themselves with the enemy and invade us!  As the President, it is your sacred duty to beat the other countries to the punch.  The time for decisive action is now!

Each player has his own little country map, divided into conceptual areas: political, military, communications, production and population.  Each player also has a production card, 60 people tokens, 6 Action cards, 3 ships, 2 carriers and 1 airplane.  The players share 30 missile markers (power 5, 15 or 30) and 15 Goal cards.

The Goal cards represent your secret victory conditions (see below).  People will eventually spread not only over your own areas but the other players' --giving you a say in each player's destiny as will be seen below.

Play is in rounds, with each round beginning with a Player Order and Political phase, and then a varying number of player turns.

Player Order phase: The order of play is determined by each player's Communications area.  Each player counts his people in that area, and each other player with people in that area either adds, subtracts or stays neutral (his choice).  Largest score goes first during the round and so on.

Political phase: Place up to four of your six Action cards (keeping at least one), face down, in front of the other players, in any ratio.  This phase is resolved in sequence by all players.  Next come the individual player turns.

Production phase: Each player's production card is progressively filled up with people markers; the level reached indicates what can be produced.  Producing anything, even something way below the current fill line, empties the card (the people go back to the player's Production area).

Embarkation phase: People of your colour (up to 10) may be embarked on one of your ships.  Missiles (up to 30 total power) of a controlled colour may be embarked on a carrier or airplane of a controlled colour which happens to be off the missile's shores.

Action phase: The player must play one of his Action cards (the ones he kept earlier plus those played on him).  Political clout (people in your Political area) can be used to instead lay a card aside for a later round.

These player turns continue until all players pass.  The players then recover their Action cards from the discard pile.  Cards laid aside during the round are put back in the player's hand --so you may end up with a smaller or larger hand than usual.  A player without any people in his Population area, or with less than 5 total people markers on his country (diasporas don't count!) is eliminated.

Goal cards indicate either a player to eliminate (you win even if another player is responsible for your target's elimination) or two players to dominate politically or demographically.

The Action cards are:

Transfer - Transfer up to 5 people of your colour from one area to another, within your country.

Disembark - Up to 5 embarked people on one of your ships off another country's shores disembarks into any area.

Growth - For each 5 people of one colour in your Population area, add two more.  Enemies also grow if present.

Production - Move up to 5 people from your Production area into the production display.  They may be of another colour if their owner agrees.

Move - You can move one ship of your colour, or one carrier or airplane of a colour you control by one country.  Ships and carriers move clockwise or counter-clockwise, airplanes move anywhere.

Shoot - Fire a missile on board a carrier or airplane of a colour you control onto an area of the country where it currently is.  The missile kills as many people as its power.  The more powerful missiles can spill their effect over into other areas of the target country.  Casualties must be fairly spread between the colours present in the area (if it matters).

title: Walk in the Woods
description:
From the box:

Ah, a Walk in the Woods... to observe beautiful things such as Wild Flowers  Butterflies... to help each other gather Goodies such as Apples, Berries, Nuts  Herbs... to keep an eye out for nasty stuff such as Poison Ivy, Stinging Nettle, Biting Bugs, even Hot Sun... to share our Remedies to solve Problems we meet... and to plan together where to look next for Goodies  Remedies. Let's have a great day in the Woods and come Home with our Baskets full of Goodies, our Minds deeply quiet, and our Hearts nourished with natural things.

title: There's a Growly in the Garden!
description:
From the box:

Players help each other plant as big a Flower Garden as they can and also help the Growlies find what they need most, so they don't pick and trash the Flowers instead. With some sharing of ideas and talking over of strategies, we will help change Crabby, Messy, Greedy, Stinky  Snobby into happier creatures. Sometimes we will need Scarecrows as well as Special Items such as Fruit Soap, Cornstalk Brooms, Gold Coins, Smiley Buttons and, best of all, some delicious Humble Pie. Guess which Growly needs what item! On each turn, a player gets two cards to play somewhere in the Garden. When and where to plant a Flower? Or put a Scarecrow? Or leave a Pie? Decisions, decisions. Each game unfolds differently, so keep on your mental tiptoes. Lots of play value for as many as 6 players.

title: Africanus: SPQR Module
description:
Africanus recreates the two major battles fought in Spain by Rome's first great field commander, Publius Cornelius Scipio, later given the cognomen Africanus for his victory at Zama. Scipio is the first cog in the wheel that evolved the Roman army away from its highly linear velites-hastati-principes system to a more sectional and individual approach that would eventually become the cohort system of the age of Marius. His overseas victories and conquests also opened Rome's eyes to the possibilities of empire.

Battles:

    Baecula - 208 BC
    Ilipa - 206 BC




Expansion module for the Great Battles of History (GBoH) series game SPQR.

title: Dictator: Caesar Module
description:
Dictator introduces two key battles from the fading years of the Roman Republic, when Rome was faced with three major outside threats -- the Numidians under King Jugurtha; the Germanic invasion of the Cimbri, Teutons, and Ambrones; and the threat from the east of King Mithridates of Pontus -- and wracked with civil wars and the conflict for power between the two leading men at the turn of the century -- Gaius Marius and L. Cornelius Sulla -- all leading to the brutal dictatorship of Sulla. The outside threats led quickly to the establishment of the army as a political power base; the day of the military dictator was at hand, and the Republic was entering its death throes.

Expansion module for the Great Battles of History (GBoH) series game Caesar: The Civil Wars.

title: War Elephant: SPQR Module
description:
War Elephant provides players with counters and rules for recreating two of the major battles of the Seleucid Empire, a legacy of the late Diadochoi period in Mediterranean history.

The Diadochoi refined and reformed the Macedonian system of warfare perfected by Alexander the Great. There were, however, two major factors that made their tactical efforts somewhat less successful. None of them was anywhere near Alexander the Great in their ability either to understand or to utilize tactical systems. And, they loved elephants (to be honest, so did Alexander, but he never had the chance to use them). Thus, while this period is the heyday of the Macedonian art of war (if not exactly its apogee), we find the system becoming overly rigid and ill-served.

Two battles:

    Raphia - 217 BC
    Magnesia - 190 BC (also included in SPQR (Deluxe Edition))




Expansion module for the Great Battles of History (GBoH) series game SPQR.

title: Consul for Rome: SPQR Module
description:
Re-fights two of the more important battles of the Second Punic War: the Trebbia [218 BC], the first major battle of the conflict; and the Metaurus [207 BC], a battle that several writers consider one of the most important in world history.

Expansion module for the Great Battles of History (GBoH) series game SPQR.

title: Pyrrhic Victory: SPQR Module
description:
Pyrrhic Victory recreates the first two battles that the Epirote mercenary (and would-be Alexander of the West) Pyrrhus, King of Epirus, fought against the slowly but inexorably expanding Republic of Rome. It was the first time the Roman legions faced the Macedonian tactical system, although the phalanx as a military formation was quite familiar to them. It was also the first time the Romans encountered elephants. Although Pyrrhus appears to have won both encounters (there is some disagreement about the end results at Ausculum), the Epirote casualty rate was so high that it led to the formation of the term 'Pyrrhic victory.'

Battles:

    Heraclea - 279 BC
    Ausculum - 280 BC




Expansion module for the Great Battles of History (GBoH) series game SPQR.

title: Veni Vidi Vici: GBoH Caesar Module
description:
Expansion module for the GBoH (Great Battles of History) series game Caesar: The Civil Wars. Portrays the battles of Nicopolis, 48BC, and Zela, 47BC. Requires the parent game and the Dictator expansion module.

Expands:

    The Great Battles of Julius Caesar: The Civil Wars 48-45 B.C. and Dictator: Caesar Module (requires both)

title: Jugurtha: Caesar and SPQR Module
description:
Jugurtha allows players to simulate the two key battles of the Jugurthine War (112-105 BC), in which Rome expanded to take virtually all of North Africa, destroying, in the process, the once-proud kingdom of Numidia ... Jugurtha also gives gamers something they rarely see in ancient world battles: guerrilla warfare. Here's a rare chance to test your on-field maneuver capabilities. In addition, the Numidian forces are rather different from anything else we've seen: almost entirely light in nature, they rely on speed and mobility more than anything else.

Battles:

    The Muthul River - 109 BC
    Cirta - 106 BC




Expansion module for the Great Battles of History (GBoH) series game Caesar: The Civil Wars. SPQR is required to use historical units for The Muthul River scenario.

title: Diadochoi: Great Battles of Alexander Module
description:
Diadochoi covers the four major battles that took place during the early Diadochoi wars at the end of the 4th Century BC as Alexander the Great's marshals jostled and fought for position and control of his vast empire. Each of the diadochoi, the so-called 'successors', sought to expand upon and improve the Macedonian system of warfare so brilliantly used by Alexander. Ultimately, all they succeeded in doing was to rigidly formalize its elements, adding only hordes of elephants, the ultimate expression of which was the massive battle of Ipsus, the largest known elephant battle in history.

Expansion module for the Great Battles of Alexander, Deluxe Edition. Part of the Great Battles of History (GBoH) series.

title: Phalanx: Great Battles of Alexander Module
description:
Phalanx covers two of the major battles in the waning days of the Successor Wars, in which the Greek city-states and leagues and the descendants of the original Diadochoi were still fighting for Hellenic supremacy, and in which the phalanx -- the massive, heavy infantry formation brought to peak efficiency by Alexander -- was still in its heyday. The armies in these battles are very Macedonian in style, with a lot of mixing of unit types and capabilities, with the exception that, because of the terrain, reliance on cavalry is almost non-existent.

Expansion module for the Great Battles of Alexander, Deluxe Edition. Part of the Great Battles of History (GBoH) series.

Expands:

    The Great Battles of Alexander: Deluxe Edition

title: Operation Konrad
description: Operation Konrad is an operational level simulation of the SS drive to relieve the besieged German garrison in Budapest, in January, 1945. Each turn represents one day, each hexagon represents 3 kilometers across. Units range in size from companies to divisions. Moderate complexity with an average playing time of 2-3 hours.

title: Corsair!
description:
A game of piracy  plunder on the Spanish Main.

Avast and get your hooks on this exciting game of piracy and plunder. Here's a chance for all you buccaneers to tempt the hand of fate and roam the Spanish Main in search of treasure. Corsair allows you to command a fleet of pirate ships and set sail on an adventure you won't soon forget!

title: Mission: Grenada
description: Mission: Grenada is a tactical level simulation of the U.S. rescue mission on the small island nation of Grenada. A unique game system of action points allows for great flexibility. Moderate complexity with playing times ranging from 1-4 hours depending on the scenario played.

title: Christians and Lions
description:
Christians and Lions is a game for one, two or three players, and in fact requires the participation of the Divine Being Himself. (Are you on His good side?) It somewhat facetiously recreates the dire plight of those first Christians, facing certain death in the arena. We suggest that for maximum enjoyment and playability the participants forget for the time being that feeding otherwise innocent Christians to a pack of ravening wild beasts is a vile and reprehensible act. At least that's the rumor going around. In any case, it's all in fun.

From the Fantasy Gamer (Feb/Mar, 1984 issue #4) Review of CL, by Scott Haring:

Let's face it.  If you're seriously concerned that Nuclear War trivializes one of the most important issues of our time, and if you sometimes wonder if fantasy role-playing games are warping the youth of America, then Christians and Lions may not be the game for you.

Despite the warning on the cover (it says, The Irreverent Strategy Game, right there in big print), you may not be prepared for what's inside.  Therein lies CL's first hurdle - can anyone take seriously a game in which dozens of perfectly blameless innocents are ripped to shreds by marauding beasts?

~

...All this is very important in figuring the best strategy.
What? Strategy?  Yes, Virginia, this game is not only borderline tacky and a barrel of laughs, its also a fairly good strategy game.

title: Shuttlewars
description:
Published in Space Gamer (Issue 66 - Nov 1983)

A game of tactical, shuttle-to-satellite combat in orbit around the Earth. The Space Shuttle is armed with a 30 ton pulse laser weapon in its payload bay, and the three Killer Satellites are armed with either a similar pulse laser weapon or with proximity-detonated explosives.

Note that this is the second publication; the first was on the back of the Paranoia Press catalog.

title: Historiallinen Helsinki
description: Historiallinen Helsinki (Historical Helsinki) is an educational game that brings the history of the Finnish capital city alive. Unfortunately from a gamers' point of view the game is rather traditional and childish roll and move -game, where players try to collect a complete set of building cards from different eras. The cards are full of historical trivia about the buildings and thus the game is certainly interesting in historical sense.

title: ID: The Identity Game
description:
An adult conversation game for 3 or more players

Example of play:

Pick a Personality Card: You're Julius Caesar. (Don't tell anyone).

Announce your category: You're a Political, Military or World Leader.

Then get players to guess who you are by giving clever answers to Question Cards.

Q: If you were a type of clothing, which would you be?

You might answer: A toga.

Q: If you were a type of food, which would you be?

You might answer: A salad.

Contents:

324 Personality cards
216 Question cards
150 Plastic chips

title: PerPlexus
description:
From the instructions:

PerPlexus is a game requiring both quick thinking and a constantly changing strategy.  The play board is a network comprised of 6 sliding play pieces or shuttles that can be moved right or left, offensively or defensively, by either player.  The game objective is to place 5 stones in a row -- horizontally, vertically, or diagonally -- while blocking the opponent's attempts to line up 6 stones in a row.  Each shuttle has spaces for 7 stones.  PerPlexus requires that a player plan moves several turns in advance whether playing stones or moving shuttles.

title: Pop of the Form
types: Movies / TV / Radio theme Music Trivia
description:
Radio 1's Pop Music Quiz Game
Roll the dice to determine which question to answer. Answer the question correctly to score a point next to that number and another turn. Some questions have bonus points available. Answer six questions in a row for a 2 point bonus.
The game ends when a player scores at least one point against all numbers from 1 to 6. That player gets a two point bonus. The player with the most points wins.

title: Words, Words, Words
description: Each player has to simultaneously make up words from the same set of letter cards which are dealt randomly. On each turn, all players are given one minute to select their best word, the longest of which wins the round and is written onto the playing board in a vertical or horizontal fashion. All subsequent words placed must connect, in crossword fashion, to those words already on the board. Points are scored for each letter written on the board to make up a word (as indicated on the letter card) plus bonus points whenever a bonus square is covered.

title: Icebreaker
description: Icebreaker is an interaction board game designed for four or more players. The aim of the game is to score 2000 points. To gain points, players must perform forfeits. If players refuse to perform or co-operate with a forfeit, points are deducted from their score.

title: Wallace & Gromit Going Crackers
description:
Join the world of Wallace and Gromit and their friends in a fun-filled game that'll have you doing rather odd things.
If you're Wallace, you have to pull your mouth into a grin every time you sing, say or name something. Gromit, on the other hand, can only draw.
Do the task before the time runs out... and you collect points. The player with the most points wins. Special gameboard spaces keep the surprises coming. You may get to switch characters, collect extra points or lose a turn as you take a tea break. Each game is different and varied and the tables can turn at any time in this game of ups and downs and batty stunts.

title: Space Crusade: Mission Dreadnought
types: Expansion for Base-game Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Expansion for Space Crusade.  Adds ultra-heavy weapons and more powerful Chaos Dreadnoughts.

Inspired by the factory siege during the Stalingrad battle of 1943.

Expands:

    Space Crusade

title: Zzzinity
mechanisms: Auction/BiddingCommodity SpeculationRoll / Spin and MoveStock HoldingTrading
description:
From the box...
It's a reckless roller-coaster ride through the high-pressure world of big business booms and busts. That's Zzzinity, the game of chance and skill where anyone and everyone can play the financial market like a real entrepreneur. In this tense and exciting game for all ages, Zzzinity stands for the pinnacle of business achievement - and it's within your reach. With a little imagination, lots of intuition, zeal and creativity, you too can climb to the summit of success.

title: Up For Grabs
description:
Players choose 6 pegs of a particular color and load them randomly - color up.

First player winds the timer, then pushes it and begins the game.

As they pop up, players turn as many of their own colored pegs over as they can before time runs out. The first to turn over all pegs of their own color wins.

title: Drag-Ominos
description: A difficult to find version of Pressman's many Omino games.  This one features 3-part colored dragons.  The object is to be the first player to use up all his Drag-Ominos.

title: Space Crusade: Eldar Attack
types: Expansion for Base-game Science Fiction Wargame
description:
Expansion for Space Crusade which adds the Eldar, their leaders, and weaponry.

Expands:

    Space Crusade

title: Duell der Schamanen
description:
Two Shamans battle each other to win the title The greatest Shaman.

Each player has a set of numbered tokens (1-9) and some shell tokens. The numbered tokens are placed onto the 33 playing area, one of each player in each of the playing areas.

After all tokens are placed the battle starts, by choosing the place the battle occurs. One player secretly chooses the row while the other chooses the line of the battle. Then the two tokens in the battle square are compared - loser pays the difference to the winner in shell tokens.

Then one player may switch the position of two tokens. After this the next battle starts.

The winner is the Shaman who manages to collect all shell tokens.

Quite nice little W. Kramer game which was published together with Knizia's Nuba.

The first edition, in 1978, was named Check-Point.

title: Ogre Reinforcement Pack
types: Expansion for Base-game Science Fiction Wargame
description:
The G.E.V. and Shockwave supplement you've been waiting for: battle-ready replacements for scuffed-up counters and crumpled maps, along with four multi-map scenarios! New rules include towing options, random Ogre damage, and the variant Ogres previously only available in The Ogre Book. Fight to recover crippled Ogres on The Day After, deliver a crippling punch to a Combine industrial complex in Body Blow, or Fake Out the Paneuropeans by concealing your true objective until it's too late!

A supplement for Ogre and G.E.V. which includes a full set of counters from each game and a set of the Shockwave supplement counters. Also includes the maps from G.E.V. and Shockwave which are used in the multi-map scenarios.  Expansion of the Ogre/GEV Family.

Scenarios:

    The Day After (section 7.02)
    Body Blow (section 7.03)
    Fake Out (section 7.04)




Expands:

    Ogre
    G.E.V.
    Shockwave

title: Demontowers
description:
In Demontowers the players are warlords in a fantasy land whose identities are secret. They try to conquer some of the so called demontowers to win the game, and at the same time try to guess which lords the other players are to gain certain advantages over them. You can also reveal your lord to start a revolution in which a certain race defects to your side, so that winning is easier, but you have all the other players against you at this time.

The original Game version is only suited for 2-4 players. A 5- or 6-player-game is possible with an expansion, which comes with additional character-cards and all the other necessary stuff except for the missing dice-sets for the additional players.

title: Cabal
description:
Cabal is a two player asymmetric game.  One player is the Escaper and the other is the Trapper.  There is a main board which consists of a 9x9 grid of holes, and then each player has a board shaped to fit in the hand that represents the 8 spaces around the position of the Escaper's pawn on the main board.  The Escaper simply plots where they want to move.  The trapper has 3 colored pegs to put into his personal board.  If the Escaper moves to the position of the green peg, the move occurs but the green peg is placed on the board (anywhere except next to the Escaper); to the yellow peg, there is no move and the yellow peg is put down where it was pegged; and to the red peg. the move is blocked and the red and yellow peg are put on the board where they were pegged.

The game has 3 molded plastic boards and about 60 pegs in 4 colors. 3 sets of rules with slightly different forms of play are included.

title: Timelag
description: Timelag is a strategic science fiction game of combat across the reaches of outer space where Einsteinian time dilation directly effects the flow of play in the game. As the years wear on, the warring civilizations reach higher technological levels. Subsequently, they produce ships which are better than the ships sent out previously. Of course, we are speaking of time relative to each player's home base. The ships themselves will have hardly aged at all relative to their Home Base. The concept presents interesting situations since one never knows for certain the 'age' of his opponent's ships.

title: Battlegame Book 3: Galactic War
mechanisms: Dice RollingPick-up and DeliverSecret Unit Deployment
description:
A book that includes four realistic space wargames. Each game has a double A4 sized board and a page of black and white counters that need to be cutout and in some cases assembled to be stand-up starships. This game book is number 3 in the Battlegame Book series.

The four games are:
Space Pirates. 2-4 players. Players control 3 ships and are racing to pick up cargoes from asteroids and return them to earth. Each ship has a speed from 0 to 5 must change speed by one unit each turn. The moon orbits the earth, and is a constant hazard. Attacks are permitted and send the loser out of control. Landing is a fine art of judging speed.

Deadly Planet. 2-4 players. Each player has a team of astronauts stranded on a hostile planet and they have to reach specific pick-up point. Dangerous beasts roam the planet, some of which can be ridden; others exist only to attack astronauts.

Invasion Earth. 2 players. The Ganoids are invading Earth's seas. The earth player using orbital missile satellites, submarine and surface fleets must track down and destroy the Ganoids spawning craft. It is a game of careful placement as the Ganoid player tries to over-extend the Earth player's resources.

Galactic War. 2 players. The Krul vs the Stellar Federation. Players expand across the map capturing planets to increase their technology rating and dodging the randomly moving anti-matter cloud. Combat and conquest depends on the number of ships in the fleet. As only one ship can occupy each space, long snaking fleets stretch across the board. Some of the ships are annihilators - suicide bombers that destroy all neighboring ships. Ship types are kept secret from your opponent.

title: O Alquimista
description:
Translated from the box: A young shepherd dreamed of a treasure hidden in the Pyramids of Egypt. He decided to follow the dream and, in the quest for his Personal Legend, faced great mysteries. The lessons of that journey are in this exciting game.

Based on the book by Paulo Coelho.

title: Plug-A-Jug
types: Action / Dexterity Children's Game Dice Real-time Word Game
description: The object of the game is to be the first player to spell plug a jug.  Players take turns rolling a six-sided die.  The sides of the die show either a blank, a jug, or a cork.  Players take turns rolling the die.  When one player rolls a jug symbol they open the jug and shake out the small plastic letters and try to spell plug a jug.  While they are doing this the other players takes turns rolling the die, until one of them rolls the cork symbol.  Once a cork symbol is rolled, the jug is plugged, and any additional letters are returned to the jug and the play continues until one player spells plug a jug.  If, while shaking letters out of the jug, the black marble falls out, that player must return all of their letters from this and previous turns to the jug.  The jug is then plugged and play continues.  The game contains enough plastic letters (32) for four players to be able to spell plug a jug, the six-sided die, and the dreaded black marble.

title: Bewilder
types: Abstract Strategy Card Game Deduction Memory
description:
The board for the game consists of a plastic tray with nine compartments arranged in a 3x3 grid for holding the playing cards.

The cards have either a blue circle or a green circle on them. To start the game, the cards are dealt into the tray, alternating blue and green on each row (i.e. Row 1: B,G,B; Row 2: G,B,G; Row 3: B,G,B).

The first player has to attempt to change the color pattern of the cards to 9 Blue Cards in exactly 9 moves. S/He may pick any card from any compartment and place it into any other compartment. this counts as one move. S/He may not take two cards from the same compartment consecutively OR place two cards into the same compartment consecutively. After s/he completes nine movers his/her turn is over.

For each card s/he has changed to blue, s/he scores one point. If all nine cards are the correct color, an additional nine points are scored.

The next player then attempts to do the same thing with the color opposite of the one used by the preceding player.

The first player to 100 points is the winner.

title: Cover Up
description:
From the box:

Cover-Up is a game for the entire family. The idea is for each player to cover up as many squares and gain as many points as possible using the tiles provided for each player. However each tile played must touch another tile and cannot cover a black square. Each player must be careful not to give the easy plays to other players or not to leave themselves an unplayable position.

The game features a square board with 256 squares (16x16) on it. Some of the squares are blacked in, others have a number, while the majority are white and blank.

Each player receives a set of translucent tiles in one color (yellow, blue, green, or red). The tiles vary in size from one space to 2x2 spaces in size.

Players take turns placing tiles on the board in an attempt to cover numbers which increase scoring. Black spaces may not be covered.

title: Dominator
description:
A chess-like science fiction themed game. The game board represents the planet Elkos and is broken up into a series of hexes with four different types of terrain: Flatlands, Rough, High plateaus, and bunkers.

There are four different types of pieces corresponding to the four Elkosian races of the planet. The Etons move in a straight line and are blocked by anything but flat terrain. The Artilla Squads also move in a straight line, but may traverse flatlands and rocky terrain. The winged Ariel Bombers may traverse any terrain, but fly short distances - they also carry bombs to bombard the opponents. Finally, the Dominator Lord (one per side) moves up to three hexes but may not ascend plateaus. Its special ability however is to convert any opposing piece to its side by moving next to it.

An interesting twist to the game is that the game board may be altered through the use of bombs. When a bomb is dropped, the owning player may use one of 14 tri-hexes to alter the landscape, thereby making previously impassable terrain passable.

The game ends when either the opposing Dominator Lord is killed, one side no longer has pieces other than the Dominator Lord to move, or a stalemate is reached.

Game components are mostly card stock, three color printing on the board.

title: How to Host a Murder: All My Children
description:
From back of box:
Eight of Pine Valley's most colorful characters await the arrival of their host at a dinner party held at the elegant Chateau Restaurant.  But high spirits soon turn to astonishment as Detective Trevor Dillon announces that their host has been murdered!  Which All My Children suspect is guilty of committing the crime?  You and your dinner guests will enjoy hours of suspense and intrigue recreating eight of daytime television's most tantalizing roles and figuring who among you is the murderer!  All you need is a sense of humor and a willingness to take a lighthearted attitude toward blackmail, sex, larceny, deceit and murder.  Just add eight suspects and the food.  This All My Children special edition episode of How to Host a Murder supplies the rest!

title: Snoopy Come Home
types: Children's Game Comic Book / Strip Movies / TV / Radio theme
description:
Based on the movie of the same name, with a blue cover depicting Snoopy and Woodstock. Standard track game in which players attempt to find Snoopy, and bring him home.

Players need to first bust Snoopy out of Lila's apartment where he has gone after visiting Lila (his original owner) in the hospital.  Then it's a free-for-all as everyone tries to take control of Snoopy and return him to the dog house.  Players can use telephone booths as shortcuts, use cards to cause the player with Snoopy to lose a turn or send a player to other locations on the board, or place a 'No Dogs Allowed' sign to block Snoopy's path.

title: Nibelungenlied
description:
Published in Abstract Games #14, and at the About.com boardgames website.

Components


     A triangular grid board with 5 vertices on each edge, with the three vertices in each corner marked off as castles.  The base of the board has the West corner at the left and the East corner at the right. The peak of the triangle is called North.  The castles are Xanten in the West (the Netherlands), Worms in the East (Burgundy), and Isen in the North (Iceland).
     A set of chess pieces.
     Two screens.


Set-up Table




    
        Character

         Board Piece  

         Player Pieces 

        Sequence

         Start

    
    
        Gunther   

         white king   

         white rook    

           1    

         N Worms

    
    
        Kriemhild 

         white queen  

         white bishop  

           2    

         E Worms

    
    
        Hagen     

         white knight 

         white pawn    

           3    

         W Worms

    
    
        Siegfried 

         black king   

         black rook    

           4    

         N Xanten

    
    
        Brunhild  

         black queen  

         black bishop  

           5    

         W Isen

    


Concept

The forces of Tragic Destiny (Tod) and Natural Order (NO) are in opposition.

NO wins if Siegfried marries Brunhild or Kriemhild, which occurs if Siegfried is alone with either queen in a castle (both pieces occupy vertices of the same castle and the third vertex is vacant).

Tod wins if Gunther marries Brunhild, which occurs if Gunther and Siegfried are both in a castle with Brunhild; or if Gunther and Hagen kill Siegfried by the three of them occupying the neighbouring vertices on a triangle, with no vertex being part of a castle.

The victory conditions can be filled at any point in a turn, and the game ends immediately.

Set-up

Put each board piece on the grid point position listed in the Set-up Table under Start.  Each player takes one of each player piece, and puts them behind the screen in front of him.  One player is Tod, the other NO.  Tod chooses 2 of his 5 player pieces and puts them on the table in front of his screen.

Play

Each player secretly chooses 2 of his player pieces, excluding those placed in front of the screen (i.e. on turn 1 Tod has a choice of 3 pieces, NO a choice of 5).  The player with 5 pieces may not choose the exact pair in front of the screen of the other player (either one may be chosen, but not both pieces).  The chosen pieces are simultaneously revealed, and put in front of the player screens.

Resolving Movement


     No pieces match.  Each board piece that corresponds to a selected player piece may move one space.  (Four board pieces move)
     One piece is matched. Each board piece that corresponds to a non-matched, selected player piece may move up to two spaces.  (Two board pieces move).
     Both pieces match.  No board piece is moved.


Board pieces are moved in the sequence given in the Set-up Table, by the player who selected the corresponding player piece.  Each board piece moves from point to point on the grid.  No piece may pass through another piece or share a grid point.

The player with 4 player pieces in front of his screen now puts all his pieces behind his screen.

The turn sequence is now repeated with players choosing two of their remaining player pieces, simultaneously revealing them and doing any allowed moves they choose.
Play continues in this way until one or other player wins the game.

The Story of the Nibelungenlied

The Nibelungenlied is an epic poem written in Germany about 1200AD, though its sources are far older.  It tells how the peerless prince Siegfried from Xanten in the Netherlands, comes to Worms to court the beautiful Kriemhild.  However, King Gunther and his two brothers jealously guard their sister Kriemhild.  Gunther wishes to win the hand of Brunhild of Iceland, but she will only marry the man who can win three contests against her mighty strength.  Gunther and Siegfried strike a pact, whereby Siegfried will help Gunther win Brunhild's hand and in return he may marry Kriemhild.  Using his magic cloak, Siegfried secretly assists Gunther to defeat Brunhild, both on the field and in the bedchamber.  Unfortunately, Siegfried keeps Brunhild's ring and girdle, and ultimately bestows them upon his wife Kriemhild.  A small grievance leads the queens to fight, the ring and girdle are produced, and Brunhild is humiliated.   She enlists Hagen, the chief vassal of Gunther, to help her get vengeance, and Gunther and Hagen murder Siegfried while out hunting.  Kriemhild swears to exact revenge, marries the recently widowed King Etzel (Attila the Hun) and finally invites Hagen and her brothers to Attila's court, where in a crescendo of battle and blood, everyone dies and honour is redeemed.

Siegfried and Brunhild are clearly destined for each other, and in older versions of the story he is betrothed to her, but is bewitched away by Kriemhild.  The Natural Order would be that Brunhild is won fairly and that Siegfried may marry any woman that he chooses.  The forces of Tragic Destiny twist the natural order so that Brunhild is tricked by Gunther and Siegfried, or that Hagen and Gunther murder Siegfried to obtain his magic cloak.

title: Battlegame Book 1: The Wild West
types: American Indian Wars Fighting Trains Wargame
description:
This is Battlegame Book 1.
The second half of the book contains 4 games, each with an A3 colour board, and monocolour pieces to cut out and assemble (most are folded like a triangle to make a stand-up piece with 2 faces.

The four games are:

Buffalo Hunters: for 2 to 4 players.  Players control a chief and a brave, and have the object of capturing horses and buffalo.  The animal pieces flee when an indian moves adjacent to them, so the trick is to drive them onto your other piece sitting in a stationary ambush or to drive them against an obstacle.  A horse doubles an indian's movement and is required to transport a dead buffalo back to camp.  Combat and theft of animals is permitted.

Red Cloud's War: for 2 players.  The US Govt player has to keep supply wagons rolling up the trail to Fort Keogh, the Red Cloud player needs to stop the wagons and starve Fort Keogh to surrender.

Iron Horse: for 2 to 4 players.  Use your surveyors and construction gangs to build your railroad to Central City before the other players.  This would be simple were it not for the Indian tribe which means you have to hire gunmen for protection.  Gunmen can also be used to terrorise other player's workers, or to have a shoot out with another gunman.  Some gunmen are better than others, and all will work for the player offering them the most money!

Lincoln County War: for 2 players.  Major Murphy and Sherriff Peppin take on Alexander McSween and Billy the Kid.  A real wild west shoot out, with the Kid's gang trying to break through to the Chisum spread before the rifles, pistols and Col. Dudley's Gatling gun mow down McSween or the Kid.

title: Space: 1999
types: Abstract Strategy Dice Movies / TV / Radio theme Racing Science Fiction
mechanisms: Dice RollingPoint to Point MovementRoll / Spin and Move
description:
It's essentially Chinese Checkers with a rotating board.  The goal of the game is be the first player to move your 4 spaceships home.  During your turn, you can move 1 piece by either:
1. moving 1 space
2. 'jumping' over any ship or ships, checkers-style

After you move, you then roll a die and the board spins from 1 to 3 spaces left or right!  The end-game usually consists of everyone moving their last ship back and forth until a lucky die roll is made.

title: Home Golf
mechanisms: Point to Point MovementRoll / Spin and MoveSimulation
description: Vintage HOME GOLF Pebble Beach 1961 GAME Includes Driver, Fairway Wood, No. 3 Iron, No. 5 Iron, No. 6 Iron, No. 7 Iron, No. 9 Iron, Wedge and Chipper PLUS Instruction Booklet.  Greens (made of Styrofoam). It's played in the comfort of your living room. The course is an accurate and detailed replica of the world famous Pebble Beach golf course in Monterey, CALF. Object of the game is to complete the course in the fewest possible strokes. The game consists of a set of 18 Fairways, a Putting Green, a Putter.    When a player's marker finally lands on a green, he actually putts across the felt-lined green (which takes up most of the box) into the little hole marked by the 8 flag with his little plastic putter.

title: Mad Chatter
description: This game is somewhat reminiscent of $25,000 Pyramid. A circular card with a visible category and 10 hidden items is placed into a viewer. A chart that is placed into the lower part of the viewer indicates which 2 players will play this round, and which will be giving the clues as opposed to guessing. The clue-giver presses a button to reveal each of the 10 items in turn and gives clues to the other player until the word is either guessed, or the clue-giver decides to pass. Passed words may not be revisited later. Once all 10 words have been gone through, or time runs out, each of those two players receive a point for each word that was guessed correctly. The next pair of players are then designated, a new category card is placed into the viewer, and the process is repeated until all of the pairings on the player chart have been completed. This tends to be a balancing factor, since all players get a round where they are paired with the better players, as well as the not-so-good players.

title: Piracy on the High Seas
description:
Each player must obtain a ship, captain and crew and attempt to take the loot from the treasure ship (or each other), bury it on Treasure Island and return with the map to Pirate#039;s Cove.

Contents:

Gameboard
2 Six-sided Dice
4 Metal Ship Tokens
1 Gold Treasure Ship Token
1 Treasure Card
1 Treasure Map Card
4 Pirate Captain Cards
4 Pirate Crew Cards

title: Poker Bingo
description:
From the box:

Poker Bingo consists of an exciting variety of five games using Bingo boards, chips and a deck of special size playing cards, which are all included. Each game combines the play of Bingo with a poker style.

Each player takes a Poker Bingo board and chips for markers. The dealer shuffles the cards and places them face down in front of him. He turns the top card and calls it out. The players that have the called card space on their board, cover that space with a chip. Play continues in this manner.

title: The War of the Worlds
description:
From the rules:

THE WAR OF THE WORLDS is a two Player game. One Player controls the Martian forces and attempts to attack and destroy the city of London. The other player controls the Human forces and attempts to destroy the Martians and protect London.

title: Proteus
description:
From the Kadon website:

Michael's concept was to create a meta-game that allowed for rule-changing but had a fixed slate of  rules, unlike the fluid game of Nomic. The rules on 9 wood tiles determine how the players may move their pieces, trade the tiles, or even win. A rule is activated when a player's piece enters a correspondingly shaped tile, and the previously active rule is turned off. A placement phase precedes the movement stage. Experienced players can sometimes win even before movement begins. The strategy is intense because long-range moves are not calculable. For two players, Ages 12 and up.

On Omni's list of best new games, 1983.


Online Play

     Boardspace.net (real time, AI option)

title: Fluster
description:
Fluster: Parker Brothers Cross-up Word Game

Each player is given a pad of game sheets, each sheet containing two 5x5 grids. Each square of each of the grids contains a number from 1-25, randomly distributed. Each player, in turn, calls out a letter and a number. All of the players then write that letter in a square with the given number, in either the left or right grid, attempting to create words in the grids. after the grids have been filled, the scores are tallied, with each valid word being worth 1 point per letter.

title: Amphorae
description:
Amphorae or Das Zehn Vasen Spiel is tile pickup game. A 7x7 grid is filled with 40 tiles (10 amphora pictures made up of 4 tiles each), with the 9 tic tac toe spaces containing hostage tiles to complete the grid. You can move 2 or 3 spaces containing one right hand turn, and you can pick up the last tile you move off.

The object of the game is to pick up complete sets of amphoras.

A player can only keep two tiles in his/her hand Any tile placed in front of you that is less than a set of 3 in an amphora can be picked up by anyone who lands on a hostage tile.

So the trick is to get three tiles all in one amphora in successive turns, and lay them down immediately. These are now worth 1 point and are safe from being stolen.

A completed amphora of 4 tiles is worth 4 points.

title: Scrabble Scoring Anagrams
description: Draw letters and place into a central area.  All players then try to make words from those letters.  Players may capture words made by other players by adding new letters from the pool to existing words. The game comes with 180 wooden letter tiles in red ink.

title: Mamoonia
description: Mamoonia is a 2 to 3 hourlength adventure fantasy game for 16 players, where every player plays the role of one of the King Josephs sons. They should try to put together the amulet powers again, seeking and discovering which ones, among the 12 fragments, are the 4 real ones. In order to reach such a goal, players must make their own characters progress by increasing their physical strength and mental powers, and by gaining enough experience points to be admitted in the different Orders. The High Priests will help them to face such a difficult task: their heroes start as Apprentices, then they grow into Mystic Warriors, Knights Wizards, Sorcerer Sword-Masters and conclude their evolution becoming capable and powerful Masters of War and Magic.

title: Wickie
description:
Wickie is a German board game for children; it is designed to promote recognition of colors and numbers.  Thematically, it is uses elements from a television series of the same name.  Players assume the roles of Wickie and his friends as they race each other to board a Viking ship.

Each player selects a character and takes four tokens.  They play their turns by first rolling the dice.  There are four lanes to reach the ship.  The squares (of which some are colored) on the lanes are printed with the faces of a die.  A player can move his or her token to the next square if one of the rolled dice matches the square's.  If the token moves onto a colored square, it can jump once to the next square of the same color.  Each character can take a short at certain points along the path.  As each square cannot accommodate more than one token, blocking is possible.  However, a token can jump across blocking pieces if the player has a die that matches the square at the opposite side of a block.

The game ends when one player gets all four of his or her tokens aboard the viking ship at the end, making him or her the winner.

title: Algoritmo
description:
Algoritmo won the first edition of the contest for unpublished games, Premio Archimede, in 1994. Quality Game published it the year after.
Each player has a little plastic computer that runs on the board to get rid of all the output cards he got at the beginning. Each player has a little cardboard console with three boxes called A, B and C. The player draws three numbers from a special deck. He arrange them on the boxes as he see fit. To move on the board, dice are not used: the little computer can advance of A + B spaces, A - B spaces or, from certain spots, of B x C spaces. Numbers can be changed in certain spaces. When the computer stops on a space with a certain letter, the player can discard the matching output card if he has one. When a player lands exactly on the End space, the one with less output cards wins.

title: Pinko Pallino
types: Abstract Strategy Maze Racing Territory Building
description:
A dark wooded is divided into 11 x 11 squares separated by grooved lines. Each player has a steel pawn and 21 steel fences.

The pawns are placed on the middle square at opposite ends of the board. Each player has to move his own pawn across the board to reach any square on the opposite side. Each turn a player can either move his pawn one square, or put a fence to close two square sides. When a player runs out of his own fences, he can only move the pawn.

Placed fences can not be removed. The only limit to placing them is that you can never totally close the enemy pawn: you have to leave a way, no matter how long, to reach its goal.

The game was been licensed to Gigamic for an international edition under the title of Quoridor. Differences are a smaller board, 4 wooden pawns (for 2/4 players), 20 wooden fences total (10 each in a 2-player game, or 5 each in a 4-player game) and the abolition of diagonal movement.

Re-implements:

    Blockade




Re-implemented by:

    Quoridor

title: Auto Market
description:
Each player is a car builder. He can get contracts for car components (engines, electrical systems, chassis...) from all over the world, at different prices and in different currencies: dollars, ECUs and yens. Three sets of money banknotes are included in the box. 
Once the player has assembled the cars, he can sell them in Europe, America or Asia getting the price in ECUs, dollars or yens respectively. The price of the cars in each market depends on the global offer by the players. The exchange rate among the three currencies depends on their use by the players.

title: Hill(y) Billy
description:
Hill Billy Times is an auto racing game with a twist. The object of the game is not necessarily to win, but to finish the race with the most money. It also has a set of scrap metal race cars which the game designer notes, should be completely clean, but we cannot guarantee that they are sterile.

Components include the game board and rules (German), 30 game cards, five cars, and game money (approximately 160 chips in four colors, worth varying numbers of points).

Players bid for starting position, then draw cards to dictate movement. Each card has various hazards listed. The active player shows their card to everyone, then secretly picks a set of results and writes it down. The opponents pay insurance based on what hazards they think will be on the active player's selected option. The active player then reveals their choice and moves based on the option chosen. If the opponents did not insure themselves against the hazards that appear, the active player collects money from them.

The race ends when the racers clear one of the two rows containing stacks of bonus money out.

title: Solitaire ASL
types: Expansion for Base-game Wargame World War II
description:
Solitaire ASL: WWII Tactical Warfare Solitaire Module for the Advanced Squad Leader system. Game boards not included.

Must have Advanced Squad Leader, Beyond Valor: ASL Module 1 and Yanks: ASL Module 3 to play.

Ownership of non-desert mapboards of the ASL System is recommended to make full use of this system.

260 counters
14 solitaire missions
4 Generation Cards
1 ASL Chapter S
1 ASL Chapter S divider

Complexity: Very high

Second edition adds 8 more Generation Cards and 7 more missions, and 260 more counters.

Expands:

    Advanced Squad Leader, Beyond Valor: ASL Module 1, and Yanks: ASL Module 3 (all are required)




Scenarios:

Mission 01: Cautious Advance 
Mission 02: Pockets 
Mission 03: Recon 
Mission 04: Bunker Busting 
Mission 05: Take the Highway 
Mission 06: The Fortress 
Mission 07: Block Party 
Mission 08: Patrol 
Mission 09: Enemy Offensive 
Mission 10: Hold the Line 
Mission 11: Tank Attack! 
Mission 12: Besieged 
Mission 13: The Bridge 
Mission 14: Human Wave 
Mission 15: Pursuit 
Mission 16: Airlanding 
Mission 17: River Assault! 
Mission 18: Bridgehead 
Mission 19: Escape! 
Mission 20: Amphibious Assault 
Mission 21: Beach Defense

title: Principles of War: Napoleonics
description:
A set of Napoleonic miniatures rules. Units have a base strength which is modified by a die roll. This strength is used as the basis for firing, melee and morale tests, but not determined until the player needs to know it.

Movement is based on initiative points, based on a  die roll. Better officers get a better roll.

The game consists of the rules and includes army lists for all major participants in the period 1793-1815.

title: Triangle
mechanisms: Pattern BuildingPattern RecognitionPoint to Point MovementTile Placement
description: (From the box) Triangle is unlike any other board game you've ever played. Yet it has one thing in common with all the classic games - it doesn't yield its secrets all at once. Played at basic level, Triangle is as enjoyable and as satisfying as draughts. It's almost as easy to play too. Except that the moves with which you capture your opponent's pieces are far more varied and interesting.

title: Sportac
description: A simple representation of an athletics meeting. Lots of different events are portrayed. Players compete mainly by rolling dice.

title: The Book of Greek Myths Pop-up Board Games
description: Four separate pop-up board games and a small booklet on the myths that inspired them. The games are The Trojan Horse, Odysseus, Theseus and the Minotaur, and Daedalus and Icarus. The book includes a spinner, different stand-up pieces for each game, and a small storage pocket.

title: Net.opoly
description:
The board game that challenges you to become King of the CyberSurfers, with a CyberEmpire of Web Sites and CyberBucks.

Surf the Internet, buying, selling and trading Chat Rooms, News Desks, Computer Stores, Shopping Carts, Game Rooms, Sports Dens and more. Buy Web Sites, then upgrade them with Megabyte Chips and Gigabyte Chips to collect CyberBucks as other players hit those sites.

Increase your revenues by landing on You've Got Mail spots.  But watch out for those Virus! spots!  They can cost you CyberBucks or a feared scamming penalty or that nasty Connection Interrupted:  Go Offline!

Similar to Monopoly but selling websites instead of real estate.

title: CLAC
description:
A high quality trivia board game for young and adults (15 years and older), made of wood. It is innovative in both the dynamics and the questions. To obtain the correct answers the players must figure them out rather than just search in their brains. Thus, the questions are sorted by the abilities required to answer them instead of their corresponding area of knowledge.
The game is played by teams and it is conceived to minimize the frustration: most the questions can be answered by all the players, granting them the pleasure of the intellectual activity carried out successfully.

title: Kupido
mechanisms: Co-operative PlayHex-and-CounterPartnershipsRole PlayingRoll / Spin and Move
description:
Kupido is a humorous game about love affairs. 
Each player distributes his points among six characteristics: Physical appearance, Culture, Charm, Money, Feelings, Eroticism. The first four of those scores are public the last two are secret. 
Each player also fixes the minimum scores for each characteristic of his/her ideal partner. 
The board depicts a city, divided into hexes. Players wander on it, looking for their ideal mate: a character of the opposite sex whose 4 open scores fits their secret goals. In the meantime, their own scores change: in the Gym the physical appearance increases (if there are no accidents...) while in the Fast food it can suddenly drop down!
When two characters suit each other with their 4 open characteristics, they can make a couplet. They then move together with a 4-sided die (instead that alone with a 6-sided one) until they reach a private house or a hotel. At this point they can show each other the two secret characteristics: if they don't fit they split apart. But if they fit, they win as soon as they reach the Cathedral or the City Hall.
Each hex of the map and each playing card has a humorous comment about each game effect.
To play, you do not need to have the same amount of male and female characters: you only need at least two males and two females. A rare quality of this game is that player can enter the game later or go away before the end with no problems.

title: JZ
description:
If you are an Avalon Hill collector, this game is certainly one of the Holy Grails, and may well be the proverbial IT. The big one. Certainly one of the harder titles to track down. This is JZ, a.k.a. WJZ, the game created by WJZ-TV channel 13 in Baltimore, copyrighted by the Robert Goodman agency.

According to AH's Silver Jubilee guide, WJZ was never in the Avalon Hill line; having been the only game Avalon Hill ever published as a private-label job. [p.25] Aside from copies retained by Avalon Hill personnel, this game was distributed solely as a promotional item by WJZ-TV in Baltimore, MD (USA).

JZ bills itself as, The TV ad man's game. Two to six players compete for high score in the form of advertising accounts and advisory fees. Players can make their accounts more valuable with fortunate advertising time purchases.

Contents for the game are as follows:


     Instruction sheet
     Game board
     2 dice
     6 pawns
     6 strips for marking each accounts' class 
     24 pink Buy Time cards
     12 green Regional account cards
     12 blue Local accounts
     8 brown National account cards 
     2 small cardboard storage inserts


JZ comes in the standard flat box form typical of AH games made in the late 1950s and early 1960s.

The Buy Time cards, of course, are an exercise in shameless self-promotion by WJZ's advertising department -- both for the station and its parent company, Westinghouse. Some of the cards are now a bit dated, with references to buying time on the Buddy Deane Show and the Steve Allen Show.

Luck plays a far greater role than skill, as JZ is a simple roll-and-move game. Each player hopes to land on favorable spaces or draw cards that will allow them to land on and upgrade advertising accounts, going along the board until they bail out at Retirement or reach THE BITTER END. The person with the most valuable advertising portfolio at the end of the game is the winner.

title: Spider-Man Swing into Action
types: Action / Dexterity Children's Game Comic Book / Strip
description:
A 3 dimensional board game where Spiderman swings from a web suspended between 4 towers above a rotatable disc simulating a manhole cover.

Bad guy discs are located on points adjacent to points on the manhole discs.

Movement is controlled by a single deck of cards. players take turns to draw a card and follow instructions. after use the card is discarded, when all the cards have been used the game is over.

Cards instruct to move yourself, a bad guy disc swing spidey or rotate the central disc. the object is to collect as many bad guys as possible before the card deck runs out.

the winner is the player with the most bad guys.

Spiderman swings around and seemingly at random chooses a bad guy to be collected.

title: SpyQuest
types: Adventure Deduction Memory Movies / TV / Radio theme Spies/Secret Agents
description:
From game box:

Your quest is about to begin. Think you'd make a good secret agent?

Put your spy tactics to the test. In SpyQuest(TM), you'll watch one of three action-packed espionage adventure movies on your own VCR. Each of these half-hour long Hollywood-quality motion pictures was produced exclusively for SpyQuest(TM) and bridges the gap between live-action adventure and you, the player. Next, you'll be traveling the world uncovering clues to a secret location. Sound easy? Not so fast. You'll have to decipher the configuration of a key, tooth by tooth. You'll be interrogated about your knowledge of the film as you compete against other agents on the same mission. They'll use road blocks, naval mines, spy scopes, and sabotage kits against you to reach the location first. Of course, you can use the same tactics on them, so anything goes! Be the first agent to uncover the secret location, travel there, and survive a triple interrogation and you're proven secret agent material. With five sets of interrogation questions and 64 different secret location possibilities, you'll have a new and different adventure every time you play. Good luck and may the best spy win!

title: Endangered
types: Adventure Animals Children's Game Educational Environmental
description:
With the increasing public concern over the growing number of endangered species and the inhumane 
treatment of animals, FAMILY GAMES has developed a line of board games, card games and puzzles 
in order to enlighten children of all ages to the animals predicament.

ENDANGERED is a realistic and fast paced game which makes participants aware of the plight of 
endangered species as they travel the world searching for reasons and remedies to aid their 
chosen animal.

title: BrickQuest
description:
BrickQuest is a game of small-scale fantasy combat similar to HeroQuest, Warhammer Quest, or MageKnight Dungeons. It requires at least two players to play and can be played easily by four to six players.

One player takes on the role of the BrickMaster. His job is to create, using construction blocks, a variety of dungeon rooms in which the game will take place, and creatures to inhabit them. Ideally these rooms will be modular so they can be added to the table one at a time as players enter them or get sight of them.

The remaining players will play heroic characters who enter the dungeon in pursuit of gold and glory.

Since BrickQuest is a boardgame, it uses a higher level of abstraction than roleplaying games. Rather than trying to capture all the nuances of fantasy combat, it uses simplified rules for quick and balanced play.

title: Final Fantasy IX Tetra Master Card game
Nuts!
description: You are a squirrel! Yes, you are and you need to collect nuts. But the other squirrels want them too. The tiles with the nuts have a different value. How to get them? You have cards for your movement. Each player has the same cards. The player with the most points of nuts wins. You have to bluff and manage with your cards. This is a fun and bluff game.

title: Zippidy Zoo
description:
Be an animal at the zoo!

4 Baby-elephants, -tigers, -bears and baby parrots are lost in the huge zoo and far from home. If you are the first to bring these babies home, then you will win the game! Wind your way through the zoo maze. Take short cuts on boats, bridges, and trolleys-whenever you can!

The game board consists of separate pieces that can be put together differently every time. And so every game is different because the game board constantly changes. Also
contains animal playing pieces, animal baby tokens and a spinner. For 2-6 players.

title: Caesar
description:
From the rules summary:

Each turn represents one year in the life of a Roman estate. Until the War deck is exhausted, players are jockeying for position trying to get the most votes. Whoever has the most votes at the end becomes Caesar and wins.

Each player is a senator starting with a modest estate, influence in the senate, and two legions to command.

Players will build their wealth to acquire votes by by shrewdly managing their fields, bidding for public works and the favor of the gods, or on the battlefields against the barbarians.

[GS9204]

title: Winter Pause
description:
This is a free indoor soccer board game for two players. The game may be downloaded from www.krimsu.de
The game components consist of a player board ( two identical jpeg files ) English rules ( or German )and a sheet of counters.
You play a coach in charge of directing five players and a keeper on a board consisting of  9x14 (126) squares. Each turn you roll three dice and may use them to dribble, pass, or run. Generally you may only use one die per soccer player and move in one direction as is the case in dribbling. If you are running a player without the ball, or if you are passing or shooting, you may use the pips on another die to change directions ( curve )  and move in that new direction. Movement points are flexible, in that you do not have to use the maximum amount shown on the die if you don't want to, but direction of travel is usually linear unless you use the second die as mentioned above. The components ( especially the field which you have to print twice ) are beautiful.

title: Children of the World
description:
Children of the World - the exciting journey around the world - a dice game for 2-6 players aged 5-8 years.

A hefty wooden board with a world map and 6 very nice little wooden dolls (each unique) representing children from the different continents.

Each player starts with 5 postcards from his or her continent and attempts to be the first to give them all away to other children (players) encountered in travels around the world.

title: Check Mate
description: Chess variant on a small board. 4x4 spaces. Each one owns a set of thirteen cards. He gets five of them on his initial hand. Play a card with Chess symbol on the board or make a normal chess move with the cards you played already. Aim of the game is to get more points than your opponent. Eg. the Queen is worth 10 Points . A pawn 3 points. 4 Special cards are also included.

title: Clash
description: You have 7 pieces with digits from 1 to 7. Try to win the opponents 7. You do this by clashing (4 playing pieces meet at a corner). The higher sum of digits there wins. The winner can move one of the digits from the opponent to another place on the board. Some obstacles on the board make it difficult to move your pieces.

title: Zebulon
description: You have 5 nobles and 14 peasants. Try to connect your camps on the board with a chain of peasants. If you want an already occupied space, one of your nobles fights for you in this mix of Chess and Twixt.

title: Evil Stevie's Pirate Game
mechanisms: Area MovementCampaign / Battle Card DrivenDice RollingRole Playing
description:
This is a game, involving elements of both roleplaying and tactical combat, in which grown men and women sit on the floor and push toy pirate ships around, going Arrrr!  The rules are primarily geared towards LEGO ships and sets, but any sort of toys can be used.

In this game, one person will be the GameMaster, while all of the other players will be commanding their own pirate ships.  During a turn, a player, will plot their course, move their ship, fire on other ships or islands, board other ships, and/or search for buried treasure.

title: Ciphagrams
description: From the game box: Just unscramble the words and add up your points as you move around the board; take a chance with your options if there's time! The gameboard is strategically designed for scoring purposes, player interaction, and is color coded for category specification. With this is mind, even the brainiest players can lose!!!. It contains 1,984 Ciphagrams waiting to be solved under four select categories: World Cities, Food and Drink, Animals, and Health.

title: Nøff, Kvekk, Mjau
description:
Nff, Kvekk, Mjau is a Norwegian Children's Game.

There are two large children's dice, one with geometric shapes and one with primary color single large dots. There are five heavy cardboard animal cards similar to bingo cards with animals on them. Each turn, a player tosses the dice, and the fastest player to mimic the matching animal's sound gets a point. The first player to six points win the game.

title: Spit it Out!
description:
This is a game based on verbal gymnastics based on tongue twisters. You have a 15 second timer that you perform one of three different types of tongue twisting events...

Good luck!

title: The Near East
types: Expansion for Base-game Wargame World War II
description:
The Near East, Europa IX, is a module of maps and counters covering the countries of the Near East.

Three maps cover Asiatic Turkey, Syria, Iraq, and Western Iran, at the standard Europa scale of 16 miles per hex. They display the diversity of terrain in the region, from sandy desert to high mountain peaks, from the marshy lowlands of the Persian Gulf to the rugged, wooded coast of the Caspian Sea, from the wadis of Syria to the karst of Turkey.

Counters cover the armed forces of Turkey, Iraq, Iran, and Egypt, at standard Europa scales of divisions, brigades, and regiments. Air units represent groupings of 40 to 60 aircraft, organized by type (such as fighters or bombers) and model (from Gladiator biplanes to 4-engined B-24 bombers). Naval units represent individual large warships or flotillas of smaller vessels. The counters also include British and Indian forces which do not appear elsewhere in Europa.

The charts give the orders of battle for the countries of the Near East, and a set of guidelines for combining The Near East with Western Desert (Europa Game VI) is included.

Game Components:

    three 21 x 27 maps (Europa Maps 20, 21, 22)
    240 die cut counters (Counter Sheet #35)
    chart set

title: Spain and Portugal
types: Expansion for Base-game Wargame World War II
description:
Spain and Portugal is an Europa module covering Spain and Portugal during World War II: it consists of a map, counters, and chart set.

The 21 x 27 map covers the Iberian Peninsula from Portugal to Spain's Ebro Valley, linking with westernmost Spain on The Fall of France (Europa VIII) map. The map, at the standard Europa scale of 16 miles per hex, displays the wide variety of terrain types of Spain, from the many mountainous regions to the occasional lowland swamp.

The 240 counters cover the armed forces of Spain and Portugal at Europa scales. Ground units are divisions, brigades, regiments, and battalions. Air units represent groups of 40 to 60 aircraft, organized by model and type, such as HE 111B bombers, Spitfire V fighters, and JU 52 transports. Naval units represent individual large warships and flotillas of smaller vessels. The counters also include the British garrison at Gibralter and other British forces for use in the Battle for Spain scenario.

The charts include the Europa mobilization schedules for Spain and Portugal, and the Battle for Spain scenario.

Game Components:

    One 21 x 27 Map (Europa Map 23)
    240 Die-cut Counters (Counter Sheet #43)
    One Chart Set
    One Europa Scenario

title: Junior Executive
description:
A children's game on a sophistication level equivalent to Monopoly. Players run businesses (toys, candy, soda, ice cream), trying to become the most successful. Business elements, and a little decision making, but mostly luck.

When a player rolls double ones, the season marker moves ahead one season. The game ends when it lands on the season where the game started.

title: Cherry Ames' Nursing Game
description:
Object of the game 
Two to six players travel around the game board, which represents various phases of nurses' training, obtain six rings of six different colors, and strive be the first to graduate successfully from nursing school.

Game equipment 
Playing board, six playing pieces, thirty-six colored rings, a spinner, and twenty Cherry Ames cards.

title: Winning: The Bicycle Race Game
mechanisms: Point to Point MovementRoll / Spin and MoveSimulation
description: Winning: The Bicycle Racing Game challenges up to six players to compete against one another to finish a three-stage race in the least total time.  At the start, all cyclist have the same chances of winning the race.  Victory will be decided by how well a player plans and performs his or her own race strategy, using energy and stamina carefully to overcome both the other cyclist and the rigors of the race course itself - just as though you were competing in an actual bicycle race.

title: Credibility Gap
description:
In 1967, Amherst Game Company prefaced this game with the phrase: The CREDIBILITY GAP game is intended purely for the entertainment of its players.  It is not intended to have any special reference to the present Administration in Washington whose concern for the truth is well known. Ideally the players should regard the game as set in some distant future time.

With this Tranquilizing Myth, 2-4 players are invited to partake in Credibility Gap, a political satire game published during the time when the term credibility gap was in greatest vogue. It remains equally timely today.

Players ferret out the Truths of the Administration from the Big Wheel, recognizing Brittle Analogies, Solemn Platitudes, and other variants while avoiding the dreaded Snow Job. They are aided by cards which, in proper combination, will permit them to give opponents Good or Bad advice, make Demands, gain access by phone or mail to the Big Wheel, or seek for the Big Wheel's Truth Vault itself to attain the elusive Truths. The first player to accumulate 20 Truth markers is the winner.

Components include:

     4 wooden Liberty Bell movers,
     80+ wooden Truth markers,
     a four piece puzzle board,
     36 Administrative Pack cards, and
     58 Citizens' Deck cards.

title: Castle of Magic: The Castle Cursed
types: Adventure Deduction Expansion for Base-game Fantasy
description:
The Castle Cursed expands Cloud Kingdom's original Castle of Magic game by adding Wild Magic cards to the game. It also offers a replacement set of wizards suited to using the Wild Magic.

A limited edition reprint (30 copies) of The Castle Cursed, containing only 15 wizard cards, was made available in 1998.

Expands:

    Castle of Magic

title: Championship Baseball
description:
This 1966 Tod Lansing creation bears no relation to the more widely known Championship Baseball marketed by Milton Bradley. It featuring two sets of 25 chips (thin counters) each of which represents a player on a 25 man roster for each team, plus offense and defense strategy cards. A cross-index of offense and defense cards determines play selection, and die rolls determine the exact results for each situation. Several different levels of play are offered.

Both teams sets of player chips are identical; i.e., each player has the same 25 players to build their respective lineups from.

title: Eurocracy
description:
This seems to be an educational game about European politics. It has a clear relationship to Monopoly.

From the manual:

Eurocracy is the game about democracy in Europe.
In the game the twelve member states of the European Community are fully integrated. There is just one state with one government and one parliament. According to their size, the member states are represented on the game board with one to four cities and/or regions. The flags symbolize the states to which cities and regions belong.
Players are political parties competing for power. Each party is supported by two social groups. The players go with their playing piece as party leader on a continuous through Europe. By winning elections in cities they obtain Members of the European Parliament. Cities may be exchanged on a voluntary basis. Players in control of all cities of a member state are entitled to European Ministers each time they pass Brussels. The first player to form his or her government of 12 Ministers wins the game and is proclaimed European Prime Minister, provided that he enjoys sufficient support in the European Parliament.

title: Columbus Was Wrong
description:
In Columbus Was Wrong, players compete by trying to sail from Spain to India and back. However, there is a twist: they must do so without sailing off the edge of the world.

The major components include an antique globe with two movable disks suspended around the equator, twelve small plastic ships (3 per player), and the dice that determine movement. Each player has only one ship on the board at a time; the remainder are a reserve to be drawn upon if needed.

Players uses their turn to advance his ship and rotate the board based on his die roll. Certain spaces will allow a ship to move closer to the globe; others force the player further out. If a ship is force to sail off the edge of the board, the player tries again with a fresh ship in Spain. A player who runs out of ships is out of the game.

title: Challenge the Yankees
description:
Challenge the Yankees is a simple two player baseball simulation that was published twice. The first set, printed in 1964, uses 1963 stats; the second, printed in 1965, uses stats for 1964. One player takes the Yankees, and the other takes a collection of Major League All Star players. Die rolls indexed on each batter determine the result of a pitch; special card draws add further random behavior to fly balls, ground balls, and base hits of varying types.

In the 1964 edition, blank player cards are provided for the owner to make up cards for his home team or for his own group of All-Star favorites.

Baseball card collectors have made this game difficult to find in its original complete state. The player cards each contain a photo of the person represented along with their stats for the season. With players such as Mickey Mantle and Hank Aaron in the mix, many sets have been at least partially stripped over the years.

title: Bean Bag Buccaneers
description:
Bean Bag Buccaneers is a two player children's game, the object of which is to pick up your treasure chest on the central island and sail back safely.

Each player has a giant sailing ship as their main game piece. Each ship has a removable sail, two trigger-action side panels, and a huge spring-driven cannon. Players take turns moving forward along a prescribed track and shooting bean bags at their opponent's ship. A hit on one of the side panels will force it to pop off and give the player a free shot at the other side; a hit forcing the sail off becalms the ship for a turn.
